reviews.message: Okay for the adults and a pure delight for the kids.

reviews.name: John Wilmes
reviews.message: Among the many errors of The Super Mario Bros. Movie, screenwriter Matthew Fogel plops him and his brother Luigi into a milquetoast Brooklyn family that doubts them and disrespects their small-business dreams.

reviews.name: Andre Meadows
reviews.message: I've been wanting a Super Mario Brothers movie like this for a long time... I was smiling the entire time I was watching this movie.

reviews.name: Mat Brunet
reviews.message: Is this the greatest movie that is worth all those years of hype and anticipation? Honestly, no. Is it still a fun adventure to see the beloved games adapted to the big screen? Oh, absolutely!

reviews.name: Sheraz Farooqi
reviews.message: Crisp animation, mostly strong voice acting and fun for the entire family. No doubt Mario is a juggernaut franchise for Illumination and Universal. But overall, The Super Mario Bros. Movie is nothing groundbreaking and can be very generic thematically.

reviews.name: Megan Williams
reviews.message: The Super Mario Bros. Movie is a very enjoyable and fun film.

reviews.name: Omar Holmon
reviews.message: This is a movie for adults, children, teens, and anyone that ever rocked with them Mario Bros.

reviews.name: Morgan Shaunette
reviews.message: Older moviegoers will likely be turned off by the simplicity of it all, but for fans who are young or young at heart, it’s an entertaining trip down the warp pipe.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: The Super Mario Bros. Movie is the Illumination style done at its absolute worst.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: While Mario has never been about its story, that doesn’t translate well to film. It misses the opportunity to expand upon its lore and characters in new ways. If it doesn’t take a Super Mushroom for next time, this franchise won’t stay fun for long.

reviews.name: Michelle Kisner
reviews.message: Captures the fun and whimsy that Nintendo is known for.

title: Book Club: The Next Chapter
description: The highly anticipated sequel follows our four best friends as they take their book club to Italy for the fun girls trip they never had. When things go off the rails and secrets are revealed, their relaxing vacation turns into a once-in-a-lifetime cross-country adventure.

characteristics.Producer:: Erin Simms, Bill Holderman

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Book Club’s next chapter is a pleasant Hollywood fairy tale where likeable people in nice outfits go somewhere pretty. The audience that made the first movie a hit won’t mind that one bit.

reviews.name: Mark Meszoros
reviews.message: A second serving of broad, frequently sexually charged humor and low-stakes drama. Most important the aforementioned formula is the deep female friendship that keeps the group together and on the move — it’s tons of hugs and a bit of tough love.

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: This quartet of talented travelers deserve better than this flighty, frenetic, briefly anecdotal fluff, filled with cliched PF-13 double entendres.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...the picture eventually (and perhaps inevitably) segues into a hit-and-miss, entirely episodic midsection that slowly-but-surely wears out its welcome...

reviews.name: Tara McNamara
reviews.message: In other words, Book Club: The Next Chapter doesn't offer any new discoveries -- rather, it delivers the idea of Italy that many non-Italians likely already have in their head.

reviews.name: Rex Reed
reviews.message: It’s the kind of film that exists for the sole purpose of entertainment, which it provides consistently.

reviews.name: Sarah Knight Adamson
reviews.message: The movie is fun-loving, feel-good, and nostalgic, although the script sadly lacked creativity and substance--all is forgiven as seeing these Hollywood stars in the beautiful sun-soaked setting of Italy is fantastic.

reviews.name: Sara Michelle Fetters
reviews.message: Much like the first film, Book Club: The Next Chapter is another easygoing lark that does zero that’s unexpected yet still generates just enough genuine laughter to make its sitcom-level simplicity bearable.

reviews.name: Stephen Romei
reviews.message: What do you get when you put three Academy Award winners in a movie that has almost no plot and just a skerrick of a script?

reviews.name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
reviews.message: What should be an empowering big screen moment for a female ensemble cast whose average age is 77 is sadly let down by the lazy, by-the-book script.

reviews.name: Marah Eakin
reviews.message: This one’s more of a mindless beach read than a Pulitzer Prize–winning page-turner.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Frankly, the 2018 comedy left us with extremely low expectations, but this sequel is much more strongly written, including sparky humour, warm character-based drama and, yes, goofy silliness that prevents taking it remotely seriously.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: A hokey sequel...a page not to turn.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: If you are in the mood for a light comedy with some dynamic actresses who feel like genuine friends than Book Club: The Next Chapter is a great choice

reviews.name: Kathia Woods
reviews.message: Book Club: The Next Chapter features a likable cast and a gorgeous setting, as well as story elements that keep the plot moving

reviews.name: Clarisse Loughrey
reviews.message: Their film is so stuffed with incident -- all of it preposterous, and occasionally insulting to the intelligence of its central quartet -- that it sours what could (and should) have been a joyful celebration of desire and indulgence at any age.

reviews.name: Katie Walsh
reviews.message: It may be treacly and unrealistic, but “Book Club: The Next Chapter” has heart and soul, and it’s as sweet and quaffable as an Aperol spritz on a hot day.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: This is a tired exercise is appealing to older audiences, and they should be insulted at the cynical pandering being tossed their way.

reviews.name: Candice McMillan
reviews.message: Like the rest of the film, the ending is predictably saccharine ... [but] as far as light, conflict-free movies go, The Next Chapter ruffles no pages, bends no corners and primes itself as the naughty, movie beach read of the year.

reviews.name: Lynn Venhaus
reviews.message: In fact, this is the type of movie that one shouldn’t overthink, for then the contrivances and artificial sweetener-quality of the script will reveal themselves. Just enjoy the witty remarks about aging and accept the premise.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: Book Club: The Next Chapter should be the last.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: If anything, the writing in this chocolate-box travelogue of a sequel is even lazier than that of the first film, with much cackling innuendo and sparkly narcissism...

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: This sequel is dragged down by the same thing as the original, just on a more picturesque scale. The script is flat, and the writing is inane.

reviews.name: John Urbancich
reviews.message: As in the first "Club," Bergen's tart-tongued jurist steals the show in the laughs department by, among other things, forming a mutual admonition society with a police chief marvelously portrayed by Giancarlo Giannini.

reviews.name: Anne Brodie
reviews.message: Underwhelming, trite platitudes and pap, it gets sappy fast, it’s slight but harmless with enough blue jokes to keep you awake. A better, more complex, witty script would have gone a long way for these deserving stars.

reviews.name: Carla Renata
reviews.message: The sequel is a vibe...period and proving that it really does get greater later especially when Jane Fonda, Diane Keaton, Mary Steenburgen and Candice Bergen are involved.  Not to mention they flipping validating the men and not vice versa

reviews.name: Johnny Oleksinski
reviews.message: It’s a “Dumb and Glummer” of a sequel that confuses the worst punchlines ever for Prosecco fizz, when the groaner jokes go down like lukewarm vodka.

reviews.name: Kevin Carr
reviews.message: A whimsical and entertaining – if not a bit corny – comedy about women still looking for friendship and adventure.

reviews.name: Donald Clarke
reviews.message: Would we rather see the stars have dumb fun than struggle with fading capacities in a half-cooked slice of grey Oscar bait? Maybe. Maybe this will do. One of the more enjoyable dreadful films of the season.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: Watching Book Club: The Next Chapter is like watching someone else’s home movies – great fun for them, boring for you.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: Look, I liked the idea of this being a riff on The Hangover or Bridesmaids, but the action is all so ploddingly predictable and, as Carol’s husband Bruce suggests, “if you have to explain the joke, it’s not funny”.

reviews.name: Denise Pieniazek
reviews.message: The story is less effective and funny than its predecessor... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: In every conversation between the four women, each of them chips in with a quip or a platitude, almost as if their agents are standing by with a stopwatch to make sure their client gets the same number of lines as the others.

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: The movie doesn't start poorly... but approximately half an hour into it, we don't want any more of it. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Thelma Adams
reviews.message: It’s all in good fun, though, and short on snark, as the old friends celebrate ushering their soul sister to the altar amid the twists and turns of woman’s romance fiction. This chapter’s a boisterous bachelorette party -- hold the hangover.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: The four veteran stars deserved sharper dialogue and a better plot. But this is a rare sequel that doesn’t disappoint.

reviews.name: M.V. Moorhead
reviews.message: It's hard to completely dismiss any movie that features Hugh Quarshie singing "Gloria," in Italian, accompanied by Mary Steenburgen on the accordion.

reviews.name: Kevin Fallon
reviews.message: After witnessing the soul-healing powers that emanate from Book Club: The Next Chapter and taking in its valuable lessons about connection, love, and living life to its fullest, I don’t think I even need that therapist anymore.

reviews.name: Patrick McDonald
reviews.message: Formulaic & inoffensive, with decent laughs, but elder ladies spouting sex jokes needs retiring. I’ve alway dug the Murphy Brown acid delivery of Candice Bergen, which mitigates the basic upper middle class privilege. Look it up in your Funk & Wagnalls!

reviews.name: Mae Abdulbaki
reviews.message: Book Club: The Next Chapter is fluff & it will occasionally pull on the heartstrings, while also serving as a beautiful travel commercial for Italy.

title: The Randall Scandal: Love, Loathing, and Vanderpump
description: This Hulu documentary from ABC News Studios and LA Times Studios charts the unbelievable tale of B-movie mogul Randall Emmett who rose to fame on the heels of his engagement to Bravo megastar Lala Kent. When their relationship publicly collapses and a bitter custody dispute ensues, Randall is caught up in a swarm of bombshell allegations and lawsuits that rock Hollywood and the Bravo-verse.

title: John Wick: Chapter 4
description: John Wick (Keanu Reeves) uncovers a path to defeating The High Table. But before he can earn his freedom, Wick must face off against a new enemy with powerful alliances across the globe and forces that turn old friends into foes.

characteristics.Producer:: Basil Iwanyk, Erica Lee, Chad Stahelski

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: It’s hard to surpass the sheer visual exhilaration of previous Wicks, so Chapter 4 amplifies the comedy by tossing Wick down a couple hundred steps or battering a villain who looks cribbed from a Dick Tracy comic strip.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: The John Wick series comes to an anti-climactic and thoroughly interminable close with this absolutely endless entry...

reviews.name: Q.V. Hough
reviews.message: An exhilarating action film that takes itself and its bizarre world seriously.

reviews.name: Alejandro Turdo
reviews.message: Not sure exactly how badly we needed a fourth John Wick installment, but it is always a fun ride.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: This pulp one was more entertaining than the others in the series.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: While Tom Cruise is jumping bikes off a ramp in Norway, Reeves is whipping reverse 180s on a famous circle drive in Paris while shooting bad guys. That’s him doing just about every ounce of stunt work and fight choreography. He’s in a league of his own.

reviews.name: Agustín Acevedo Kanopa
reviews.message: The whole arc, with its excesses and ridiculousness, ends up closing –but above all, it seems to condense– not only the leit motifs of the saga, but almost everything that has been choreographically action cinema of the last 20 years.

reviews.name: Víctor López G.
reviews.message: Translation: We can consider ourselves fortunate, because this self-aware delight, committed to the cause of relentless entertainment, has transformed cinematic action into a true work of art.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: The fight scenes are so kinetic, so recklessly energetic and just so much fun that the three hours fly by like so many bullets whizzing past Wick’s head.

reviews.name: Kent Garrison
reviews.message: Please don't stop making John Wick movies anytime soon.

reviews.name: Frantz Jerome
reviews.message: John Wick: Chapter 4 benefits by knowing what it is and holding fast to what works. Clean visuals, blistering action, streamlined plot progression, and cutting-edge stuntwork.

reviews.name: Sheraz Farooqi
reviews.message:
John Wick 4 is a masterclass in action movies. Chad Stahelski brings his absolute best game to this film, with action sequences that leave you in awe. 

With incredible stunts, sets and cinematography, it’s one of the best films of the year thus far.

reviews.name: Marie Asner
reviews.message: Sit back, relax, mind the language, and see fight scenes to dazzle the eye.

reviews.name: Travis Johnson
reviews.message:
John Wick: Chapter 4 is not just the magnum opus of the series, it actually corrects a problem that the series has had for a while, a question we haven’t had an answer for over the last couple of films.

What does John Wick want?

reviews.name: Rosa Parra
reviews.message: “John Wick: Chapter 4” is by far the strongest film of the franchise with some of the best action in film history. The rewatchability factor will demand multiple viewings, and after seeing this movie, your eyes and mind will never be the same.

reviews.name: Josie Melendez
reviews.message: It's up to par with all the other films in the franchise. There were moments when you could laugh. Moments where you could cry. Highly enjoyable!

reviews.name: Stephen A. Russell
reviews.message: Its less like a [three-hour] fight sequence and more like an incredibly bonkers ballet

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: The best film in the series, featuring four or five action set pieces that are breathtaking.

reviews.name: Michael Calleri
reviews.message: There isn’t much dialogue because there never is in a movie involving hitman Wick. Once again, Keanu Reeves plays him with as much taciturn moodiness as possible. He’s sullen, silent, and strong through 169 relentlessly supercharged minutes.

reviews.name: Shawn Edwards
reviews.message: "John Wick 4" hits the mark. This grand ballet of mayhem and ultra-violence goes on a bit too long but is never dull. The story threads aren’t the most complex, but Keanu and friends commit to the action and it’s stellar.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: Clocking in at a hefty 169 minutes, the fourth Wick movie spreads its wings and goes full-blown epic. Every single shot is a dazzler, it has a surefooted pace, and the simple story is elevated to mythical status.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: ... Overkill in more ways than one. All that said, there are some extraordinary fight sequences, leavened with cherishable wit.

reviews.name: Brian Gill
reviews.message: I wasn't sure the Wickiverse could ever top "knife museum" but then they handed our man John a pair of nunchucks and...well...

reviews.name: Richard Bardon
reviews.message: I wasn't sure the Wickiverse could ever top "knife museum" but then they gave our man John a pair of nunchucks and...well...

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: No matter how a John Wick movie finishes, it ends with viewers wanting more — and this is no exception, including more of Yen as Caine alongside Keanu.

reviews.name: CJ Sheu
reviews.message: Who knew the Wickiverse was a (murderous) utopia?

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: A nearly three-hour orgy of mayhem that’s flashy, raucous, brainless and as nutritious as a Twinkie.  But fans will eat it up and, like Oliver Twist, ask for more.  Others might feel not just glutted by the excess but somewhat nauseated by it.

reviews.name: J. Don Birnam
reviews.message: If there were an Oscar for "best headshot effects" this movie would win it.  And its over the top, senseless and overly long plot would lost it every other accolade possible.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Emphasizing spectacle over substance at every slow-motion turn while trying to constantly outdo itself, this ambitious sequel feels like a director’s cut that could have benefited from some judicious trimming.

reviews.name: Nestor Bentancor
reviews.message: The strongest chapter in the Wick saga and of the best Hollywood action films of all time! The magnetic characters -especially Donnie Yen- anchor the brutal and beautiful torrent of mayhem. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: One last fever dream of violence and mayhem, giving viewers a final chance to watch John Wick seek the kind of revenge on the wealthy and all-powerful that we all dream about.

reviews.name: Caffeinated Clint
reviews.message: The Godfather II of action movies. Blisteringly entertaining, and packed with some of the best action and fight sequences ever put on film

reviews.name: Peter Gray
reviews.message: Somehow retains the sense of basicness that led the original to such prominence, whilst layering itself with the operatic expansion of its near-video game-like ultimation.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: It's a fantastic finale (maybe) for a favorite franchise.

reviews.name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
reviews.message: John Wick: Chapter 4 is still entertaining. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: The fourth film in the very entertaining John Wick series delivers lots more action and even some affecting consequences.

reviews.name: Kevin Harley
reviews.message: Energised by a swaggering electro-rock score, this is pulp cinema at its most giddy and gleeful.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: Bring on the stunt people- John Wick is back in town.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: An absolutely excellent, masterful final lap for the series with Reeves dedicating himself to the action movie art form.

reviews.name: Jana Monji
reviews.message: This installment of the series offers nearly three hours of action, humor (a 4DX bonus), and sweeping landscapes. All come with high kill and diversity scores. There's also an Easter egg for East Asians.

title: Love Again
description: What if a random text message led to the love of your life? In this romantic comedy, dealing with the loss of her fiancé, Mira Ray sends a series of romantic texts to his old cell phone number... not realizing the number was reassigned to Rob Burns' new work phone. A journalist, Rob is captivated by the honesty in the beautifully confessional texts. When he's assigned to write a profile of megastar Celine Dion (playing herself in her first film role), he enlists her help in figuring out how to meet Mira in person... and win her heart.

characteristics.Producer:: Basil Iwanyk, Erica Lee, Esther Hornstein

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Love Again starts out with an uncomfortable premise, and things get worse from there. Even those who ironically enjoy Hallmark TV romances might have difficulty with a movie that can’t seem to hit the right notes.

reviews.name: Harris Dang
reviews.message: Fluffy, cheesy and nary a sense of ingenuity, Love Again can be seen as a throwback to the plentiful rom-coms of yore. Or as a laughable pastiche with sugar levels so high, it will make your teeth rot. Let the power ballad of the Queen guide you.

reviews.name: Neil Soans
reviews.message: Even the lead pair’s chemistry is up for debate. Love Again’s rehashed plot can’t help falling prey to all the rom-com tropes by being sappy and entirely predictable with not enough comedy.

reviews.name: Marah Eakin
reviews.message: It’s got a Hallmark-level plot, and in other hands, perhaps the movie could be a little charming.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: If you want to see something familiar and comfortable and entertaining, "Love Again" is a decent option; just don't go to see it expecting something new or different. There would be no use. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: It still overall charmed me and I thought everything with Celine Dion was cute. I love the idea of people falling in love over their words.

reviews.name: Sukanya Verma
reviews.message: Give me Priyanka Chopra Jonas clobbering away in a cheeseball action series over moping around in a silly, schmaltzy, romance that's long past its shelf life.

reviews.name: Miles Klee
reviews.message: It is of course Dion’s overwhelming voice and music that flood your heart, not this flimsy and occasionally morbid story.

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: ... A romantic comedy where everything you think it's gonna happen, happens. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: Sadly, I’m not sure her [Celine Dion's] five new ballads power over this rom-com’s sizable plot holes.

reviews.name: Steven Warner
reviews.message: Love Again sounds like a title where novelty goes to die, and the resulting film certainly does nothing to deviate from such lowered expectations.

reviews.name: Peter Gray
reviews.message: Despite the wacky commitment of Dion, Love Again is not a product you’re likely to fall for; you’re not even likely to settle either, as it’s all too sadly bland that you’d be better off adopting a mantra of the singer herself and stay “All By Myself”.

reviews.name: Fausto Fernandez
reviews.message: ... A journey towards the light not only from the darkness (the death of the loved one) but in its company to try to understand and overcome it. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Natalia Trzenko
reviews.message: Playing herself, the singer [Celine Dion] lends freshness and novelty to a plot that's loaded with all the Rom-Com toolbox clichés, yet still manages to come out from it better than other movies of its sort. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: However unintentionally, some romantic comedies can prove to be quite divisive, pleasing some with their twee, featherweight tales of love while making others wish for global thermonuclear destruction. Love Again is such a film.

reviews.name: Tara McNamara
reviews.message: But in a world in which movies like Mamma Mia!, Yesterday, and Blinded by the Light have already explored ways of making a movie inspired by a single artist/group's music, a romance that co-stars Dion as a sort of guardian angel makes its own sense.

reviews.name: Andy Klein
reviews.message: This putative romantic comedy is so bland that it’s already dribbling away from my memory.

reviews.name: Rex Reed
reviews.message: It’s not much to examine at length, much less remember, but if you’re in the mood for a Hallmark card to revive your faith in gooey rom-coms, Love Again is not the one.

reviews.name: Dan Bayer
reviews.message: While the film doesn’t offer the non-stop campfest some people might feel they have been promised, it does have enough self-consciously ridiculous moments to stay entertaining even when it looks somewhat cheap and slapdash.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: The presence of Celine Dion, who provides the soundtrack with new songs besides her presence, helps to make this too syrupy flick at least a reason to watch.

reviews.name: Richard Roeper
reviews.message: You can probably guess the next series of developments, and let’s just say those guesses wouldn’t be far off. Love Again plays out like some ungainly melding of You’ve Got Mail and the Gwyneth Paltrow-Ben Affleck plane crash movie Bounce...

reviews.name: David Ehrlich
reviews.message: Most of the laugh lines in Love Again are stale enough that even just hearing them kind of hurts your teeth, but for all of its blatant ridiculousness, this movie seldom tries to be funny.

reviews.name: A.A. Dowd
reviews.message: Your heart will go on, and your eyes will look away in embarrassment.

reviews.name: Fletcher Peters
reviews.message: It’s not that Love Again has a script so marvelous that ChatGPT could never replicate it. In fact, we’re looking at the exact opposite situation... Love Again is a rom-com so uncharming that the film’s dreadfulness can only be attributed to human error.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Perhaps a rare instance where an entire movie has been crafted around an extended cameo, Dion's presence at least enhances the soundtrack, if not the woefully predictable plot.

reviews.name: Adrian Horton
reviews.message: Unfortunately, only Dion can deliver this combination of cheese, camp, unabashed earnestness and exaggerated sentimentality. On everyone else, it feels effortful and a little cringe...

reviews.name: Jesse Hassenger
reviews.message: A series of awkward gestures meant to comprise a movie.

reviews.name: Mark Hanson
reviews.message: The film is nothing but a chintzy promotional tool for Celine Dion.

reviews.name: Alonso Duralde
reviews.message: I’ve seen Hallmark movies where the romantic leads have better chemistry, where the screenwriters have crafted better banter (and more skillfully summoned the ghost of The Shop Around the Corner), and where the fake snow looks more realistic.

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: A lazy, misguided, and uninspired romance, Love Again proves that streaming services and Hallmark haven’t entirely cornered the market on poorly made, low aiming lovey-dovey content just yet.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: This is a shockingly oblivious and embarrassing movie.

reviews.name: Peter Debruge
reviews.message: There’s not much chemistry between Chopra Jonas and Heughan — and how could there be, since they’re stuck in a one-way conversation for half the movie? Plus, Mira’s texts are just so sad.

reviews.name: Travis Hopson
reviews.message: Strouse goes to wildly contrived lengths to deliver this power ballad of a love story, and it’s one that maybe only Celine Dion fans will be able to hear.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: Heartwarming, tender and witty. If you enjoy 90's romcoms like You've Got Mail and While You Were Sleeping, you'll probably enjoy Love Again, too.

reviews.name: Russ Simmons
reviews.message: There’s not a believable moment in “Love Again,” so it’s for hardcore rom-com fans only.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: Carries initial care for profound situations of pain, finding ways to address the reality of the mourning process without completely losing itself to cliché.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: The painfully unfunny, boring, and very outdated Love Again is a fake-looking romantic comedy/drama that also wants to be a Céline Dion commercial. The romance looks forced and unnatural. Everything is an embarrassment for everyone who made this junk.

title: Dark Nature
description: While recovering from an abusive relationship, Joy joins her friend's therapy group on an isolated mountainous retreat. Led by a doctor with experimental methods, the group is soon forced to confront a monstrous entity.

characteristics.Producer:: Berkley Brady, Michael Peterson

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a completely misguided endeavor that might’ve fared better as a short film (but even that seems unlikely).

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: I was too bored by its shallow search for answers to care what happens.

reviews.name: Marie Saadeh
reviews.message: Though the film shows some promise for Brady's future work, Dark Nature's attempts to make an affecting exploration of trauma — or at the very least give us a good scare — leave much to be desired.

reviews.name: Daniel Gorman
reviews.message: It’s an agreeable enough thriller that has unwisely cribbed from a beloved modern genre staple and simply can’t measure up to its predecessor.

reviews.name: C.H. Newell
reviews.message: Dark Nature is an authentic, fascinating exploration of trauma and the post-traumatic stress disorder that typically comes along with it, and it’s important that Berkley Brady, a Métis artist, is the director-writer behind it.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: The Métis director’s first horror feature is gripping from beginning to end and is anchored by a skilled female cast who captures trauma and PTSD in all its damaging, even deadly effects.

reviews.name: Rob Hunter
reviews.message: Dark Nature is ultimately a fairly straightforward tale of survival as Joy and the others fight against past wounds and present monsters, and while it doesn’t rewrite the subgenre it delivers where it counts with horrifying chills and survival thrills.

reviews.name: Sarah Musnicky
reviews.message: DARK NATURE is an uncomfortable watch. But it reminds us that if we want to heal from what haunts us, we must embrace the darkness.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Brady knows the landscape well and makes effective use of it.

reviews.name: Christopher Cross
reviews.message: A creepy atmospheric psychological horror film that uses trauma like a bag of tricks but fails to reconcile its supernatural elements with the emotional struggles of its characters.

reviews.name: Kate Sánchez
reviews.message: If there is a movie this year that has made me want to crawl out of my skin, it’s [Dark Nature].

reviews.name: Joe Lipsett
reviews.message: Dark Nature skips over its most unique and intriguing elements...in order to get to the somewhat satisfying violent bits. [T]he film laid the groundwork for a deeper exploration of healing via female friendships and therapy that it fails to pay off.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Paranoia, trauma and the survival instinct are all explored in Dark Nature, a robust and anxiety-inducing debut from new voice Berkley Brady.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: ... by placing the creature up front, but, by doing so, it undercuts a far more interesting story regarding Joy, her trauma, and the consequences of not facing it sooner.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: And with a bit of a twist waiting in the wings, Joy's arc solidifies in a satisfactory way. So much so that it ensures the journey was worth our time despite also emphasizing how her companions might disagree.

reviews.name: Nikki Baughan
reviews.message: Its mix of spiritualism, survivalism and genuine scares make for solid entertainment.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Berkley Brady’s feature debut merges the natural, the supernatural and the psychological on an all-female trip into the wild

title: Victim/Suspect
description: On her first solo investigation, journalist Rae de Leon travels nationwide to uncover a shocking pattern: Young women tell the police they've been sexually assaulted, but instead of finding justice, they're charged with the crime of making a false report, arrested, and even imprisoned by the system they believed would protect them.

characteristics.Producer:: Christopher Clements, Rachel De Leon, Julie Goldman, Alice Henty, Amanda Pike, Nancy Schwartzman
characteristics.Production Co:: Center for Investigative Reporting Studios, Motto Pictures

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: A document of superb journalism but is unfortunately told in a sludgy, distracting fashion.

reviews.name: Jordan Lyon
reviews.message: To call Victim/Suspect hard-hitting and infuriating is a massive understatement. This documentary will leave you angry beyond words, but you should watch it nonetheless.

reviews.name: Natalia Winkelman
reviews.message: The film, which examines cases in which sexual assault survivors are charged with false reporting, is the rare entry whose revelations feel cogent, earned and memorable.

reviews.name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
reviews.message: Watch, learn, take action. Reform won’t happen unless we demand it.

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
reviews.message: The information is harrowing and disgusting, but it’s also inspiring to see how one journalist’s dogged investigation shed light on a troubling pattern in law enforcement leading to actionable changes for the better.

reviews.name: Romey Norton
reviews.message: Unfortunately, this documentary is another example of how the systems put in place to protect us can fail us miserably.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: A film about a police culture that doesn’t seem to take rape charges seriously—or, at the very least, doesn’t think that thoroughly examining accusations is worth the hassle when intimidation and humiliation will facilitate their jobs.

reviews.name: Brianna Zigler
reviews.message: Victim/Suspect manages to be at once fascinating, improperly focused and somewhat redundant.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: An artless documentary that feels overwritten and orchestrated to a fault. The topic is important and infuriating, but it’s not a particularly well-made film.

reviews.name: Kent Turner
reviews.message: [A] powerful, hard-hitting investigative documentary.

reviews.name: Sheri Flanders
reviews.message: This documentary doesn’t offer much in terms of craft, but one could perhaps make the argument that the subject matter necessitates no-frills storytelling that soberly focuses on facts and video evidence.

reviews.name: Juan Carlos Ugarelli
reviews.message: A revealing study on two sides of journalism: the tabloid press that accuses without evidence and sows disinformation, further stigmatizing these women; and investigative journalism that digs into minefields... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Dwight Brown
reviews.message: It’s easy to feel overwhelmed with sadness and empathy for the victims. Easy to feel proud that a young reporter and documentarian turned wrong into right. That takes courage.

reviews.name: Brian Tallerico
reviews.message: [Victim/Suspect] suffers from the Netflix brand of overproduction, looking just a little too flashy and sinking everything with voiceover and interview sound bites that have been scripted to death.

reviews.name: Barbara Goslawski
reviews.message: Yes, the film generates a sense of the anger at the system that has perpetrated this injustice but not enough to warrant much further thought or even action.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: A very solid, depressing piece of accessible documentary journalism about a very troubling trend.

reviews.name: Katie Smith-Wong
reviews.message: A heartbreaking but eye-opening piece of filmmaking.

reviews.name: Sheri Linden
reviews.message: Measured and sometimes muddled, but unquestionably important.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: A strong, powerful documentary that, despite feeling a tad neat and cold at times, benefits from De Leon's presence. And most importantly: it is a film that will remain engraved in your memories for a long time. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Sarah Bea Milner
reviews.message: An upsetting documentary.

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: Victim/Suspect ends up being a vital and eye opening examination of widespread injustice that still leaves a lot on the table thanks to its strangely narrow focus.

reviews.name: Lena Wilson
reviews.message: You may need to take a month-long depression nap after you finish watching it, but this documentary will stick with you.

reviews.name: Kate Erbland
reviews.message: It’s all so very sober, so deeply sobering, that when actual emotion pops, that’s what jars. It shouldn’t be the case -- all of this should rattle us and move us into action.

reviews.name: Fran Hoepfner
reviews.message: That these stories are worth being told is inarguable, but is this the proper lens to go about it?

title: Bama Rush
description: In August 2021, the long-held tradition of sorority recruitment at the University of Alabama, also known as rush, went viral on TikTok.  Becoming a viral sensation and cultural phenomenon using the hash tag “Bama Rush,” to date more than 2 billion people have watched.  In the upcoming feature documentary BAMA RUSH, Fleit follows four young women as they prepare to rush at the university in 2022.  In this documentary, Fleit explores the emotional complexities and stakes of belonging in this crucial window into womanhood.

characteristics.Producer:: Andrew Freston, Danny Gabai, Zachary Luke Kislevitz

reviews.name: Johnny Loftus
reviews.message: ... The documentary offers the young women it profiles respect, as well as the space to speak freely about their experiences, which ultimately allows it to find a different way into the motivations behind rushing in the land of Roll Tide.

reviews.name: Audra Heinrichs
reviews.message: A compelling, if not thoroughly heart-wrenching, watch.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: What it reveals is an exclusionary environment that views beauty, wealth, privilege, and conformity as the highest of ideals—and which seems, in some cases, to exacerbate the very problems these young women believe it will solve.

title: The Fire that Took Her
description: An exploration of the murder trial for Judy Malinowski.

characteristics.Producer:: Patricia Gillespie, Julie Goldman, Christopher Clements, Carolyn Hepburn, Kristi Jacobson, Tracy Elizabeth Jarrett

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: The Fire That Took Her is a tough but necessary viewing experience that is meant to both enrage and inspire those watching, and it does both with unblinking courage on both sides of the camera.

reviews.name: Natalia Winkelman
reviews.message: This true story’s themes of domestic violence, traumatic injury and addiction are unpacked in the straightforward documentary “The Fire That Took Her.”

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: While it would be easy to dismiss the package in which these interviews and recordings arrive as conventional, the subject matter can't help but elevate the material beyond our objectivity too.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: The Fire That Took Her is, quite simply, an absolutely devastating documentary.

title: Exorcism in Utero
description: Herma Frigg, a pregnant woman running from a bad relationship, becomes possessed when she puts on a magical ring she discovers in the basement of the house where she is house sitting. Haunted by stranger dreams, she sleepwalks next door to visit Peter O'Neill, the pre-teen horror movie buff living next door in her sleep. As Herma's body transforms and her mind deteriorates and Peter deals with family drama, these visits lead to an unusual bond between the two. But can Peter find a way to help Herma find a way out of her predicament and save her unborn baby?

characteristics.Producer:: Chad Buffett, Susan Helfrich, Brad Littlefield, Rich Wolff

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: Still, if Skybak isn’t quite as gun-shy about digging deeper into his themes moving forward, I’ll be genuinely curious what he’s got lined up next.

title: Fangs Out
description: A Group of college students head to Mexico for some cheap plastic surgery. There they meet Dr. Pavor, a creepy surgeon who is actually a vampire, harvesting victims for his blood cartel. Aided by his blood thirsty nurses he systematically carries out his evil plan. When a detective looking for his missing daughter arrives -- all hell breaks loose in a bloody combustible conclusion.

characteristics.Producer:: David S Sterling

title: Wanda Sykes: I'm An Entertainer
description: The comedy icon sounds off on parenting with her French wife, the perils of public bathrooms and why she's tired of going high when others go low.

reviews.name: Anne Brodie
reviews.message: Gentler than some of the sharp material she’s covered - an hilarious impersonation of Mitch McConnell, using her mic cords, why Black people disapproved of the Jan 6 insurrection and COVID happy place. The woman’s a keen observer and translator.

title: Bullets for the Bad
description: A down-on-his-luck bounty hunter rides into a beleaguered town in the midst of a power struggle between a gang of desperados and the local cattle baron. When the baron's daughter is abducted on her wedding day by the gang, he hires the bounty hunter to rescue his daughter by any means necessary.

title: Unmarked
description: Diverse individuals set out to preserve and protect Black burial grounds that have fallen into disrepair due to social inequities in the South.

title: Roadkill
description: Like a modern-day Highwayman, Connor Shelby spends his days on the isolated highways of rural Australia stealing from unsuspecting victims. He justifies his actions by saving his earnings in the hope of taking the love of his life, Lucy Miller, out of the harsh and unforgiving Australian outback. Across the country, in his 'quest from God', a serial killer moves from town-to-town executing those he believes to be 'sinful'. Hot on his trail are Detectives Albert and Ernest, driven and logical, the pair follow the trail of bodies in an attempt to find and stop the brutal killer. Their hunt brings them to the South Australian town of Renmark, Connor's current refuge. After two young men report being mugged on the highway, the detectives investigate and discover the two cases may be closer to one another than he first realized. After having his identity exposed, Connor's hunt for redemption, justice and most importantly, revenge, begins.

characteristics.Producer:: James Whitrow, Alexander Whitrow

title: Papaw Land
description: Set in Arkansas in the late 1990's, a troubled 17-year-old named Matthew is slipping into a cycle of alcohol and drugs that looks all too familiar to his single mother, Christy. Desperate to break the cycle, she sends him away for a summer of sobriety and honest work at his grandfather's place in the Ozark Mountains. Against the hum of cicadas, Matthew comes to know the generational abuse that has happened there--secrets that change how he looks at those closest to him, and at himself.

characteristics.Producer:: Justin Blake Crum, Michael Turner, Cameron Vaughan, Brandon Vedder, Jessica Crum, Travis Sellers

title: Afghan Dreamers
description: Members of an all-girl robotics team from Afghanistan struggle to succeed in international competitions while combating their male-dominated culture and the threat of Taliban rule.

characteristics.Producer:: David Cowan, Beth Murphy

reviews.name: Sarah Boslaugh
reviews.message: [The Dreamers] offer this message for the girls and women still in Afghanistan: “We know things are difficult. Don’t lose hope. We’ll raise our voices on your behalf and fight for your freedom.”

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: [A] stirring, if somewhat by-numbers, documentary...

title: Cocaine Shark
description: A new, highly addictive stimulant is on the streets called HT25, derived from sharks, which causes monstrous side effects; after a leak at the lab, mutated sharks and other creatures are set loose, as a small band of people tries to stop the carnage.

characteristics.Producer:: Rob Hauschild

title: Hard Feelings
description: Two best friends try to make it through high school while dealing with embarrassing new urges -- and their very inconvenient feelings for each other.

reviews.name: Romey Norton
reviews.message: It’s got an incredible pace, filled with many comedic scenarios and jokes. If you’re into your teenage rom-coms, this film is for you.

title: Mother's Day
description: When the son she's never known gets kidnapped, former special agent Nina dusts off her deadly skills to bring him home — no matter who gets in her way.

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
reviews.message: While Mother’s Day is way better in terms of action than that other Mother-themed movie on Netflix, the story suffers from a lack of connection with the players due to skimpy character development.

title: 100 Years of Warner Bros.: The Stuff That Dreams Are Made Of
description: Four brothers set out to build a movie studio from the ground up--while making a giant leap from silent films to "talkies." As the Warners stand up to WWII Nazism, personal ambitions lead to family betrayal.

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: Beautifully narrated by Morgan Freeman, 100 Years of Warner Bros. is a must-watch four-part documentary that takes audiences behind the scenes of the studio's history.

title: 100 Years of Warner Bros.: Clint, Kubrick and Kryptonite
description: After a historic sale, Warner Bros. navigates the upheavals of the '60s and '70s. Under a new strategist CEO, the company enters an era of unmatched storytelling with groundbreaking ­projects.

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: Beautifully narrated by Morgan Freeman, 100 Years of Warner Bros. is a must-watch four-part documentary that takes audiences behind the scenes of the studio's history.

title: The Hole in the Fence
description: At a secluded exclusive summer camp in the Mexican countryside, under the watchful eyes of their adult guardians, boys from a prestigious private school receive physical, moral and religious training to turn them into tomorrow's elite. The discovery of a hole in the fence sets in motion a chain of disturbing events as the boys devolve into a Lord of the Flies-like mob mentality that creates and spreads hysteria in this profoundly disturbing coming-of-age drama that unravels like a horror movie while drawing on actual events.

characteristics.Producer:: Fernanda De la Peza

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Director del Paso was making a statement about Mexico’s heirarchy, the Catholic faith that rewards the rich by keeping the poor meek. But this story could be set in many places at this point in time.

reviews.name: Hugo Lara
reviews.message: [Del Paso] maximizes his main location, a place in the middle of the forest, filmed with an atmosphere that suddenly recharges with psychological terror... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Javier Perez
reviews.message: Lacks a dramatic anchor to bond with the audience despite some unsettling dramatic flashes and tensions. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alejandro Alemán
reviews.message: Del Paso reinforces his ability to portray chaos, and through its montage, have fear and indignation invade us. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Carlos Bonfil
reviews.message: An intelligent thriller, with agile rhythm, stupendous artistry in photography and sound, and a polarizing theme that is open to discourse. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: The Hole in the Fence is a story that captures [the essence of] what you read about in the papers. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Fernanda Solórzano
reviews.message: The Hole in the Fence manages to build a sinister universe that, on the one hand, is close to us and, on the other, is inserted into a vein of horror mythology. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: It is hard to argue against The Hole in the Fence being anything but one of the best films of the year.

reviews.name: Vassilis Kroustallis
reviews.message: A skillful attempt to bring a reality usually (and understandably) hidden from view; it will mobilize its various actors in an orchestrated way.

reviews.name: Amber Wilkinson
reviews.message: Despite being rather on the nose in terms of his plot beats, del Paso has an eye for a strong image and a psychological feel for the insidious viewpoint of the adults, washing over the children like a bad benediction.

reviews.name: Israel Acosta Aroche
reviews.message: Joaquín del Paso brings us a provocative and shocking film that manages to mix elements of psychological terror and political criticism. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Wild Life
description: WILD LIFE follows conservationist Kris Tompkins on an epic, decades-spanning love story as wild as the landscapes she dedicated her life to protecting. After falling in love in mid-life, Kris and the outdoorsman and entrepreneur Doug Tompkins left behind the world of the massively successful outdoor brands they'd helped pioneer -- Patagonia, The North Face, and Esprit -- and turned their attention to a visionary effort to create National Parks throughout Chile and Argentina. WILD LIFE chronicles the highs and lows of their journey to effect the largest private land donation in history.

characteristics.Producer:: Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi, Jimmy Chin, Bob Eisenhardt, Anna Barnes
characteristics.Production Co:: National Geographic, National Geographic Documentary Films, Little Monster Films

reviews.name: Oscar Goff
reviews.message: As corny as it sounds, it is as if the Tompkins were trying to save the world so they could continue to live in it together.

reviews.name: Christy Lemire
reviews.message: It's so well made, and puts you in the middle of some really breathtaking scenery.

reviews.name: Lael Loewenstein
reviews.message: It's beautifully told. A little shapeless, but still affecting.

reviews.name: Robin Clifford
reviews.message: One fascinating aspect of “Wild Life” is the sense of entitlement the Tompkins and Yvon Chouinard, the founder of Patagonia, have for themselves and their lofty plans to save the earth through capitalism.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: An inspiring true story about conservationism that proves not all billionaires suck. A bit too sanitized, likely due to the filmmakers relationship with their subject, but informative nonetheless. Outdoor photography is unsurprisingly excellent.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: Watching the movie may prompt some adventurous eco-tourists to visit Chile and Argentina, to see if it’s as beautiful and wild as it looks on the screen.

reviews.name: Laura Clifford
reviews.message: This is not only an incredible story of environmental activism, but one of scrappy, rugged individuals not only scaling physical heights but succeeding against all odds in the business world.  And it’s a love story.

reviews.name: Josh Kupecki
reviews.message: It’s a biographical portrait of the Tompkins, yes, but its focus is geared more toward their conservation and rewilding efforts and, more poignantly, toward Kristine.

reviews.name: Michael Rechtshaffen
reviews.message: Wild Life is committed in equal measure to the formidable challenges of land preservation and self-preservation.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: Wild Life is very well-made, but I’d have preferred it made perhaps by more disinterested parties than these directors, who seem to move in largely the same deep-pocketed, globe-trotting, brand-affiliated circles as the couple who are their subjects here.

reviews.name: Randy Myers
reviews.message: Another breathtaking journey from Chin and Vasarhelyi, one that fits snugly in their canon about indomitable rule breakers who achieved greatness and broke their barriers by persistence and unwavering dedication.

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: A warming, epic story that exemplifies how it’s not too late to make big changes.

reviews.name: Luke Gorham
reviews.message: There’s no denying that Wild Life is a flawed film, and less formally ambitious than most of what Chin and Vasarhelyi have before attempted... But despite these considerable question marks, Chin and Vasarhelyi remain deeply empathetic filmmakers.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: This is a different type of high-wire act for the filmmakers, but one that is no less harrowing.

reviews.name: Esther Zuckerman
reviews.message: A documentary that comes off mostly as a PR stunt.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Although the various elements don’t always come together, the film — like the Tompkins — has its ecological heart in the right place.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A winsome nature documentary.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: My biggest takeaway from the whole is optics. This is a feelgood story with some effectively heartfelt and honorable machinations, but it's also a mostly superficial puff piece that can't quite shake its public relations air of artifice.

reviews.name: Amy Nicholson
reviews.message: A rickety helicopter tour of a fascinating marriage; nearly every scene makes you want to stop and explore in more detail.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: Wild Life becomes a call to action ... as well as a touching act of preserving the mission and memory of a conservationist, friend, and husband.

reviews.name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
reviews.message: Whatever the admirable intentions behind the Tompkins’ actions, how they went about it reeks of high-handedness. And the blind eye of the directors, mired in paeans to high-mindedness, only makes it worse.

reviews.name: Lauren LaMagna
reviews.message: Doug and Kris Tompkins saved an immense amount of land, and it is beautifully showcased through cinematographers Chin and Clair Popkin’s lens (the use of aerial and wide shots are meant to be looked at for ages).

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: Captivating, emotionally engrossing and well-edited.

reviews.name: Thomas Floyd
reviews.message: Wild Life lacks the pulse-pounding suspense of Free Solo and The Rescue, but its depiction of selfless philanthropy is galvanizing all the same.

reviews.name: Guy Lodge
reviews.message: [A] handsome, emotionally stirring documentary...

reviews.name: Matt Donahue
reviews.message: Wild Life is an inspirational journey of one person’s trials and tribulations and how she found herself in the end.

reviews.name: Rodrigo Perez
reviews.message: Part love story, part tribute to their benevolent worldview and philanthropic efforts, and part inspiring changemakers doc.

reviews.name: Abe Friedtanzer
reviews.message: Vasarhelyi and Chin guide another exhilarating and emphatic look at the world around us and the way in which one set of individuals is choosing to make a difference.

reviews.name: Dan Fienberg
reviews.message: It’s still beautiful to look at, but I most enjoyed Wild Life as a complicated procedural about land use (don’t expect to see that blurbed on a poster any time soon).

title: Influencer
description: INFLUENCER tells the story of Madison (Emily Tennant, "Riverdale"), a popular social media influencer who is having a lonely and uneventful trip in Thailand despite what she tells her followers on Instagram. While reflecting on her boyfriend canceling the trip, she meets CW (Cassandra Naud, "See"), a fearless and enigmatic traveler who offers to take her to some of the most Instagram-worthy locations. Together they share authentic meals and drinks with locals, discussing the differences between Madison's online presence and CW's lack of one. After showing Madison all of the amazing sights, things take a different turn when CW brings her to a surprise location -- a deserted island that is completely off the grid.

characteristics.Producer:: Kurtis David Harder, Tesh Guttikonda, Brandon Christensen, Jack Campbell, Micah Henry
characteristics.Writer:: Kurtis David Harder, Tesh Guttikonda, Kurtis David Harder, Tesh Guttikonda

reviews.name: Randy Myers
reviews.message: Influencer confounded me countless times and it sticks landing oh so well. It also has something potent to say about social media.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: Offers a chilling look at our natural insecurities, arrogance, and conceit when it comes to our online presence, but it also is a really fun horror-thriller that’s exceptionally satisfying.

reviews.name: Josh Davis
reviews.message: "Influencer" is a tight, tense, contemporary thriller that doesn't reinvent the wheel, but still delivers a solid entry into the genre.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: A suspenseful, and absolutely stellar dark thriller...

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: Naud does a fantastic job with the material she is provided and is the best part of Influencer. From her sinister stares to her subtly manipulative manner, she controls the scene every time she is on screen.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: It slightly wobbles in the second act and some of the characters feel a tad shallow, but the finale is more than satisfying.

reviews.name: Oti
reviews.message: Probes the disparity between online facades and authentic living while masterfully unravelling exciting twists through brilliant performances that enrich the narrative.

reviews.name: KT Mahe
reviews.message: Influencer is able to cut through competition by delivering compelling visuals, tantalising arcs and villainous commentary. A thrilling ride in what makes us human, perfect and unhinged.

reviews.name: Joey Keogh
reviews.message: This is a brutal and incisive look at social media addiction but the scariest thing about Influencer might just be how it reflects our own online obsession back at us.

reviews.name: Sharai Bohannon
reviews.message: Influencer feels like there was a good idea somewhere that got rushed along the way. I don’t know what the original idea was but this movie is as shallow as it paints its characters to be.

reviews.name: DarkSkyLady
reviews.message: Cassandra Naud gives a hypnotic performance and, combined with the rest of the cast and unexpected turns, makes Influencer an entertaining cautionary tale.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: A zippy sun-soaked thriller that rewards the viewer with its spellbinding blend of glitz, glamour, and mystery.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: Influencer becomes this canny and morally slippery exploration of what objectification means and how it functions in our culture.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Kurtis David Harder’s taut Thailand-set thriller follows the anxiety, emptiness and increasing isolation of online celebrity

title: Blood & Gold
description: At the bitter end of World War II, a German deserter and a young woman are drawn into bloody battle with a group of Nazis hunting for hidden gold.

characteristics.Producer:: Christian Becker, Amara Palacios

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: Blood & Gold is a very good film and may be the best of its kind since Inglourious Basterds.

reviews.name: Leslie Felperin
reviews.message: It’s predictable but tightly staged and well paced, and if you’re scrolling through the streaming platform looking for something fresh, it’s not a bad choice for switch-your-brain-off entertainment.

title: Tin & Tina
description: After a traumatic miscarriage, a young couple adopts two peculiar twins from a convent whose obsession with religion soon disturbs the family.

characteristics.Producer:: Olmo Figueredo González-Quevedo

reviews.name: Jorge Loser
reviews.message: Tin & Tina sins by making us believe that it's a daring film at its core awaiting to explode in a crescendo but ends up falling into a collection of conventions that are more or less perturbing... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo Vázquez
reviews.message: The film, playful and disturbing in equal parts, only loses some steam in a long denouement that dips into the anticlimactic a couple of times... [Full review in Spanish]

title: Being Mary Tyler Moore
description: Chronicling the vanguard career of Mary Tyler Moore, weaving her personal narrative with the beats of her professional accomplishments, highlighting her groundbreaking roles and the indelible impact she had on generations of women who came after her.

characteristics.Producer:: James Adolphus, Debra Martin Chase, Andrew Coles, Laura Gardner, Rishi Rajani, Ben Selkow, Lena Waithe
characteristics.Production Co:: HBO Documentary Films, Fifth Season, Hillman Grad

reviews.name: David Bianculli
reviews.message: Being Mary Tyler Moore helps you appreciate the show, and the actor, even more.

reviews.name: Richard Whittaker
reviews.message: It's most interesting when it truly lets Moore be complicated,

reviews.name: Dan Fienberg
reviews.message: To watch Laura Petrie and Mary Richards (and Beth from Ordinary People) in action is to invariably come away with boundless respect. Adolphus and his documentary understand that.

title: MobKing
description: After returning home from a lengthy prison sentence, a loyal crime family confidant quickly realizes that he and his family are the targets of the organization that he remained devoted to all of his life. In order to save his family, he must choose whether to run or fight back.

characteristics.Producer:: Antoni Corone, Jokes Yanes, Cristy Trabadass
characteristics.Writer:: Jokes Yanes, J. Bishop, Cristy Trabadass, Ciro Dapagio
characteristics.Production Co:: Button Man Films, Mainman Productions, Ciro Dapagio Films

title: Cracked
description: Ruja (actress/model Chayanit Chansangavej) returns to Thailand from New York with her young daughter Rachel to settle her late father's estate. Included in her inheritance are two mysterious portraits of a bewitching woman that she is told are worth a fortune, if only they weren't damaged. Desperate to sell the paintings, Ruja hires Tim (K-pop star Nichkhun), an art restorer, to prepare the canvases for sale. But the cracks in the paint have begun to reveal long-hidden secrets, and as strange phenomena begin to emerge around them, Ruja and Rachel quickly realize their lives are in grave danger.

characteristics.Writer:: Surapong Ploensang, Pun Homchuen, Eakasit Thairaat, Ornusa Donsawai

reviews.name: Bobby LePire
reviews.message: Ploensang’s debut hits the sweet spot.

reviews.name: Josh Bell
reviews.message: Director and co-writer Surapong Ploensang packs in vaguely scary elements that don't fully come together.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Does well enough by most of the genre conventions...but "Cracked” hits a wall in its repeated moments of “Little Rachel is in PERIL” and seems to have maxxed out its possibilities before all the (over) “explaining” starts.

title: Country of Hotels
description: Country of Hotels tells the stories of the desperate souls who pass through the doors of 508, a room in an anonymous, decaying hotel. In 508, a heating unit whispers with increasing menace, while a television set randomly flips channels, revealing a guest's secret paranoid fantasies, and a stray look into the bathroom mirror becomes the quickest way to disprove your existence.

characteristics.Producer:: Saba Kia

reviews.name: Evan Dossey
reviews.message: Country of Hotels isn’t a hidden gem by any means, but two-thirds of it embody an interesting and generally well-crafted attempt. It’s just a shame it doesn’t find its way home.

reviews.name: Federico Furzan
reviews.message: There’s enough knowledge to understand there’s a storytelling potential that was sadly not well used this time and Country of Hotels ends up being a complex miss that you will probably forget about quickly

title: Days of Daisy
description: Daisy Bea spends her days as a high school librarian, stuck in a rut with both her personal and professional life. As her 40th birthday approaches, she starts to feel pressured to settle down and start a family. When the art teacher at Daisy's school abruptly quits mid-term, Daisy takes it upon herself to give West High School students the art program that they deserve. Through her adopted profession, she begins to question the true meaning of parenthood and how she fits within those boundaries. Daisy, however, doesn't fancy herself much of an artist. When she meets the local photographer Jack Palmer at an exhibition, she ropes him into her plan and begins to see a new future for herself.

characteristics.Producer:: Jency Griffin Hogan, Aaron Hogan, Emily Morrow
characteristics.Writer:: Alexander Jeffery, Paul T.O. Petersen, Paul Petersen, Jency Griffin Hogan

reviews.name: Joel Fisher
reviews.message: Between the addition of the quirky best friend, the love triangle and the attempts at conflict, it feels like the audience is being pulled in too many directions.

reviews.name: Kenneth R. Morefield
reviews.message: If a film’s story is engaging, production elements are rarely a detriment to one’s enjoyment or appreciation of it

title: Trust Nobody 2: Still No Trust
description: Bricks is back for revenge after the love of his life attempted to kill him and take his bag of money, which had a million dollars of his hard earnings. Bricks is about to bring havoc to any and everybody involved.

characteristics.Producer:: Ramon Sloan

title: Unclenching the Fists
description: Ada is stuck. Living in a dead-end industrial town in North Ossetia, she is caught in the tight grip of the men in her life. But when her older brother returns home and her domineering father suddenly falls ill, Ada finally sees a possible path to freedom.

characteristics.Producer:: Alexander Rodnyansky, Sergey Melkumov
characteristics.Writer:: Kira Kovalenko, Anton Yarush, Lyubov Mulmenko

reviews.name: Phil Hoad
reviews.message: There’s an uncanny claustrophobic charge to Kira Kovalenko’s family drama, though it finally exhales an equally powerful sigh of self-redemption.

reviews.name: Grace Han
reviews.message: Claustrophobia suffocates the big screen in Kira Kovalenkos latest feature... its atmospheric pull is undeniable. Kovalenkos delicate handiwork and direction breathes life into her work of fiction."

reviews.name: Maria Garcia
reviews.message: The underlying weakness of the film lies in the screenplay, although Kovalenko's direction and her preoccupations in this film mark the emergence of a new voice.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: A poignant coming-of-age drama, elevated by its naturalistic style, its powerful message and its authentic performances. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ela Bittencourt
reviews.message: Such pivots, from emotional roughness to flash tenderness, define Unclenching the Fists, perhaps most notably in Ada and Akim's thorny relationship with their father.

reviews.name: David Walsh
reviews.message: In fact, the drama becomes somewhat overwrought and murky, but the bleak social and psychological conditions are unforgettable.

reviews.name: Gary M. Kramer
reviews.message: Kovalenko's urgent, unsentimental approach is what makes Unclenching the Fists so potent.

reviews.name: Piers Marchant
reviews.message: It's a portrait of familial love, on one level, as the siblings try to cope with their father by banding together against him, and of tremendous loss, as the brutal disruption in their lives plays out between them.

reviews.name: Carlos Losilla
reviews.message: Unfortunately, Kira Kovalenko's feature debut oscillates between an attractive fragmentary structure and a more conventional dramaturgy, never quite finding a tone that makes sense of either. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Frank J. Avella
reviews.message: Russian director Kira Kovalenko has crafted a truly gripping, hypnotic, and astonishing tale...

reviews.name: Soham Gadre
reviews.message: Kovalenko has a sympathetic, humanistic relationship with the characters she's depicting.

reviews.name: Robert Daniels
reviews.message: A daring and complex leap by Kovalenko.

reviews.name: Diego Semerene
reviews.message: Unclenching the Fists is a tale of how the desolation of a nation inhabits and engraves a woman's body.

reviews.name: Guy Lodge
reviews.message: A frenzied vocal tone and wild, untethered physicality connects all the performances, with every character seemingly eager to burst out of their own body, and by extension, the life in which it's stranded.

reviews.name: Alistair Ryder
reviews.message: Kovalenko's film is unsparing in its bleakness - it makes perfect sense that Kantemir Balagov, the director of Beanpole (and co-screenwriter of her debut, 2016's Sofichka) has described it as the best film of the decade.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: All four principals are making their film debuts, and while all are impressive, Aguzarova is the winning presence, aided by Soslan Khugaev as Akim, lost souls whose connection, while likely feeding into comorbidity, remains poignant.

reviews.name: Steve Pond
reviews.message: Cast mostly with amateur actors, the film is a dark slice of neorealism with a palpable sense of claustrophobia that Ada feels in her life and in her family.

reviews.name: Demetrios Matheou
reviews.message: Far less affecting than it ought to be. In fact, it is much like its characters: earnest, intense and often suffocating.

reviews.name: Morris Yang
reviews.message: Unclenching the Fists assuredly portrays the subjectivity of personal experience without resorting to the easy satisfaction of unraveling it.

title: Sarah Silverman: Someone You Love
description: Filmed at The Wilbur Theater in Boston, Sarah Silverman: Someone You Love features the New England native showcasing her fearless chutzpah.

title: Sisu
description: During the last desperate days of WWII, a solitary prospector (Jorma Tommila) crosses paths with Nazis on a scorched-earth retreat in northern Finland. When the Nazis steal his gold, they quickly discover that they have just tangled with no ordinary miner. While there is no direct translation for the Finnish word "sisu", this legendary ex-commando will embody what sisu means: a white-knuckled form of courage and unimaginable determination in the face of overwhelming odds. And no matter what the Nazis throw at him, the one-man death squad will go to outrageous lengths to get his gold back -- even if it means killing every last Nazi in his path.

characteristics.Producer:: Petri Jokiranta

reviews.name: Alastair McKay
reviews.message: Although the film feels a little desperate to court comparisons with the John Wick franchise and Tarantino’s Inglourious Basterds, when it’s focused purely on delivering brain-off, Friday night action-movie entertainment it’s hard to resist.

reviews.name: Daniel Rester
reviews.message: An absurd but fun piece of pulp, Sisu plays like a mix of a spaghetti Western, a World War II thriller, and John Wick.

reviews.name: Jonathan Anderson
reviews.message: Some parts are ridiculous to the point of being implausible, but suspension of disbelief is paramount to enjoying this kind of flick.

reviews.name: Robin Clifford
reviews.message: As I watched the loner’s skills kick into high gear, I was thrilled by the imagination that went into the depicted mayhem. It is stylish, extremely violent and deadly and, for a fan of war movies and action thrillers, amusing as hell in its invention.

reviews.name: Alex Godfrey
reviews.message: Serving up stone-cold multiplex mayhem, Sisu makes no bones about it — this is a film about one mad bastard killing a gazillion Nazis. It’s almost impossible not to love it.

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: Imagine all the satisfyingly gory Nazi killing sequences from Inglourious Basterds neatly packed into a 91-minute grind-house-style B movie.

reviews.name: Cath Clarke
reviews.message: It’s super fun entertainment, which mostly disguises the fact it’s not going to stick in the mind for long.

reviews.name: Brian Lloyd
reviews.message: 'Sisu' is grisly, entertaining, and with a distinct flavour and personality in a landscape of movies that is increasingly homogenised and flatten to meet broad, accepted tastes. It's sharp, strong, and leaves you thirsty for more.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Prepare for minefields, Nazis, dogs, explosions, water crossing, gun toting prisoners of war and so much more in this juggernaut of violence, determination and survival.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: Sisu knows what it is and doesn't try to pretend to be anything else: an adrenaline-packed, violent action film served up with plenty of self-aware campiness. Jorma Tommila's portrayal of Aatami Korpi, the hero who fights Nazis, is a crowd-pleasing blitz.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: Sisu's the ultimate metal movie; a Tarantino-knock-off with hyper-violent action seen through a blackly comedic lens.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: It’s an absurd, epic action film from a country that rarely produces them. Sisu provides non-stop thrills – and who doesn’t love to see a bunch of Nazis die in the most glorious fashion?

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: The heightened quality of everything onscreen hopes to evoke gleeful and shocked laughter over the nonstop procession of stabbings, explosions, and dismemberments. And it mostly works.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: Sisu delivers a no-nonsense bloodbath crafted with love and understanding of age-old action movie tenets.

reviews.name: Laura Clifford
reviews.message: From the delightfully warped mind of “Rare Exports” writer/director Jalmari Helander comes a comically violent genre mashup about a legendary Finnish ex-commando known as The Immortal because of his absolute refusal to die.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: The question is, are you in the mood to see exhilarating bursts of rough justice? Given the state of the world now, I can’t imagine why you wouldn’t be.

reviews.name: Andrew Crump
reviews.message: “Sisu” communicates the basics without glossing over the record, and best of all without taking up time better spent liquifying bad guys.

reviews.name: Tony Baker
reviews.message: If you like gritty action go check it out.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: It doesn't have much to say, but it says it at full volume with maximum fervour and an intense disinterest in ambiguity.

reviews.name: Chris Sawin
reviews.message: Sisu is a 90-minute slaughter fest loaded with despicable characters that you will actually enjoy seeing being ripped to pieces. It endorses its simplicity a bit too heavily, but is an otherwise immensely entertaining piece of popcorn entertainment.

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: Sisu has a pure white-knuckle ferociousness that can be felt viscerally.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A skillfully crafted action film with an absorbing dramatic arc that quietly builds into a deafening crescendo of bloody, gory, Nazi killing.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: The action is absorbing and easily readable; the kills are, almost without exception, fierce and gory. The carnage isn’t unpleasant, because it’s mostly visited upon Nazis.

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: Fanciers of grindhouse cinema could do a lot worse than Jalmari Helander’s off-the-wall one-man-against-the-odds blood-fest [which] wins no points for credibility, but earns quite a few for its willingness to go completely over-the-top.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: A riveting, violent fantasy of an action movie.

reviews.name: Crockett Houghton
reviews.message: Sisu is the thrill ride that we were all promised. It doesn’t pull any punches. It’s bloody and gory but it still manages to keep us interested and wanting to know more about the characters.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: A balls-to-the-wall Nazi-killing affair that more than lives up to the hype.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: The film will likely make the day of those fond of violence, but should be superfluous for audiences expecting cleverer plots.

reviews.name: Bilge Ebiri
reviews.message: I kept imagining it as what might have happened had Sergio Leone been alive to direct Crank: High Voltage.

reviews.name: Brittany Witherspoon
reviews.message: Helander’s historical action film is full of surprises & grit. Sisu is a beautiful story about pure determination, containing epic action sequences.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: Not all viewers will want to subject themselves to Sisu's unrelenting brutality. But those who have a taste of this kind of cinema will find an intense one-hour and 31-minute plunge into a starkly diminished world.

reviews.name: David Fear
reviews.message: Should you want to spend 90 minutes watching Nazis get shot, stabbed, gutted, blown up, run over, and beaten with a variety of inanimate objects, in the most violent and gory manner possible, this war movie is the answer to your pulp-cinema prayers.

reviews.name: Kurt Halfyard
reviews.message: A straight-as-an-arrow romp, which is really an excuse to shoot, slice, and dice Nazis in a colourfully outrageous fashion ... a bit of a simple, mostly harmless, nuke-the-fridge kind of fun. I mean, who is against killing Nazis?

reviews.name: Alton Williams
reviews.message: Sisu is one of the best action movies of the year.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: Sisu is a rhapsody of action cinema. In many ways, it feels like a predecessor to John Wick, but this dark, gloriously brutal Finnish WWII film is its own beast. A white-knuckle thrill ride with a high Nazi death count.

reviews.name: Emiliano Basile
reviews.message: From its opening credits Sisu references '70s and '80s films, recalling them with passion and enthusiasm and focusing on the purest, unpretentious entertainment to deliver a primal and instinctual film. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Abhishek Srivastava
reviews.message: This action-packed drama outshines even the John Wick series in terms of thrilling, high-octane action.

reviews.name: Adam Graham
reviews.message: A lean, mean Nazi-killing machine, Sisu is a brutal, bloody fantasy built for maximum fanboy thrills.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: This movie may be in very “bad taste,” but it is very funny, sometimes breathtakingly well-crafted, and in its way more emotionally satisfying than many a deeper meditation on man’s inhumanity to man will be this year.

reviews.name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
reviews.message: Without a doubt, an impressive experience.  [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Super Mario Bros. Movie
description: With help from Princess Peach, Mario gets ready to square off against the all-powerful Bowser to stop his plans from conquering the world.

characteristics.Producer:: Christopher Meledandri, Shigeru Miyamoto

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: Sometimes I get the feeling that the adventure of Mario and Luigi never goes beyond the routine level. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Suchin Mehrotra
reviews.message: A harmless, generic blur of kid’s 'content'.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Harmless; it amounts to a Burger King kid’s meal and night of Nintendo 64. I’m not sure Illumination will ever take one single risk, but I do think their cheery, color-splosion style for 7-year-olds works for a movie about Super Mario Bros.
