description: A merry mash-up of sisterly affection, parental disappointment and bold action, POLITE SOCIETY follows martial artist-in-training Ria Khan who believes she must save her older sister Lena from her impending marriage. After enlisting the help of her friends, Ria attempts to pull off the most ambitious of all wedding heists in the name of independence and sisterhood.

characteristics.Producer:: Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Olivier Kaempfer, John Pocock

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
reviews.message: The unconventional mannerisms of Ria [Priya Kansara] transform this story from a rote comedy into one that’s elevated in humor, stuntwork, and choreography.

reviews.name: Matthew Simpson
reviews.message: With great central performances, downright contagious energy, and a great story about what it means to be family, Polite Society is one not to miss.

reviews.name: Dann Gire
reviews.message: A boldly deranged, multi-pop-cultural movie...

reviews.name: Sonal Pandya
reviews.message: Priya Kansara shines in this fun yet uneven comedy.

reviews.name: Rubén Rosario
reviews.message: This tasty snack is no black belt, but it gives your comfort-food movie cravings a decent workout. It'll do.

reviews.name: Wade Major
reviews.message: I love British comedies, I love Bollywood, and I love kung fu movies, but pack them all into one and it's like jack of all trades, master of none.

reviews.name: Claudia Puig
reviews.message: A fusion of British wit, Kung Fu action movies, and Bollywood... And a very sweet celebration of sisterhood.

reviews.name: Stephen Romei
reviews.message: This 104-minute movie is a promising big screen debut from Manzoor, who is 33. It will be interesting to see what she does next.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: It’s a crowd pleaser, certainly, and Manzoor and Kansara are talents to watch.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: Add the authentic love shared by Kansara and Arya and it's tough not to come aboard for a madcap adventure that cements Manzoor's talent as someone worth following.

reviews.name: Julian Lytle
reviews.message: Polite Society is a fun and playful homage to 70s martial arts film that also mixes in Jane Austin-style romance and early 2000s teen comedies. The core sister relationship of Ria and Lena ties this fun remix of styles together to make a great experience.

reviews.name: Fletcher Powell
reviews.message: Everyone’s clearly having a whole lot of fun.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: Polite Society may not go heavy on social impact but it offers an opportunity to watch a teenager give oppressive tradition a karate-chopping, high-spirited kick in the pants.

reviews.name: Kelly Vance
reviews.message: At 103 minutes, Polite Society is about 20 minutes too long.

reviews.name: MontiLee Stormer
reviews.message: Well-choreographed fights in gowns and bangles feel like next-level Final Girl. The comedy feels genuine, the drama is organic, and while the ultimate reveal may seem preposterous, is that what you’re going to quibble over? No, you’re not.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: In all actuality, sometimes you want to beat up outdated standards rather than talk a hole through them. This is what 'Polite Society' does – it takes an axe through all the criteria of what women are supposed to go towards.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: It’s impossible to not be won over by the fearless inspiration in Polite Society. This is one movie that packs a powerful punch.

reviews.name: Ruth Maramis
reviews.message: A fun, boisterous genre-bending celebration of sisterhood boosted by Priya Kansara's spunky performance. It went off the rails a bit in the third act but overall it's a kick-ass triumph!

reviews.name: Archika Khurana
reviews.message: Polite Society is a lively, daring punch you won’t mind taking.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: It’s Kill Bill meets Sense and Sensibility.

reviews.name: Elaine Cho
reviews.message: Polite Society draws from the personal frustrations and challenges of writer-director Nida Manzoor, who grew up in a Pakistani Muslim family.

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: This slice of suburban family comedy is also a martial arts extravaganza, a bizarre coming-of-age story, and a black horror fantasy with a wedding theme.

reviews.name: Edwin Arnaudin
reviews.message: A quirky delight — until it enters cuckoopants territory.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: The pinballing plot is constantly surprising, and both Kansara and Arya sparkle in this kickass celebration of sisterly bonds.

reviews.name: Esmé Holden
reviews.message: Polite Society... isn’t really committed to any of the genres it mashes together, let alone its style. It’s directed with rote competence but pronounced flatness — a true television sensibility.

reviews.name: Patrick McDonald
reviews.message: After you, Madame, kick ass! The assertion of women as equal in battle as any action stars is as natural as the day is long – with Priya Kansara & Nimra Bucha in the lead! Plus it's one of the funniest films this year, it will (Clint Voice) MAKE YOUR DAY!

reviews.name: Peter Gray
reviews.message: A film for the dreamers and appreciators of cultural cinema, Polite Society ironically says to hell with the rules – but respectfully so, of course.

reviews.name: Alison Willmore
reviews.message: Finally, all the angst of diasporic existence... can be confronted with a straightforward punch to the face. It’s a device that Polite Society can’t entirely pull off, though it’s still a good time.

reviews.name: Dana Han-Klein
reviews.message: A thrilling authentic ride that captures the bottled up rage of a teenage girl perfectly. Refreshing action sequences, three dimensional characters, and a plot you won't see coming elevate this from polite to delight.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: Polite Society has fun with its absurdist take on action films. It makes clever commentary about modern feminism and how aspirational culture affects people. Nida Manzoor has sharp writing and directing in this well-cast movie with great comedic timing.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: Manzoor attempts, with only sporadic success, to mix slapstick violence and Muslim-family comedy with an outlandish genetics sub-plot that might have been lifted from a 1950s B-movie.

reviews.name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
reviews.message: It's to Manzoor’s immense credit that she builds the intrigue with both great intricacy and humor, overcoming the initial flaws in her design.

reviews.name: Paul Whitington
reviews.message: While the tone may be playful, a subplot involving genetic cloning pokes fun at arranged marriages. All in all, an enjoyable romp.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: With style and attitude to spare, this subversive genre mashup playfully tweaks stereotypes with an empowered heart beneath its romantic-comedy silliness.

reviews.name: Robert Abele
reviews.message: Manzoor...always finds an honest vibe to win you over, whether it’s sisterly camaraderie, youthful awkwardness or you’re-going-down spunk, which allows the abundant personality in her wonderful cast to hit all the necessary top notes.

reviews.name: Monica Castillo
reviews.message: Nida Manzoor’s riotously funny and action-packed film “Polite Society” is a bold feature debut that defies categorization.

reviews.name: Andrea Thompson
reviews.message: It’s a delightfully kick-ass ode to sisterhood, whether familial or found.

reviews.name: Tom Santilli
reviews.message: ...the most surprisingly enjoyable film of 2023.

reviews.name: Tim Stevens
reviews.message: [T]he real selling point of Polite Society is its impeccable mix of action and humor.

reviews.name: Edward Douglas
reviews.message: It’s a shame that Nida Manzoor’s debut just doesn’t deliver in the way one hopes from the premise.

title: Leave No Trace
description: A father and daughter live a perfect but mysterious existence in Forest Park, a beautiful nature reserve near Portland, Ore., rarely making contact with the world. But when a small mistake tips them off to authorities, they are sent on an increasingly erratic journey in search of a place to call their own.

characteristics.Producer:: Anne Harrison, Linda Reisman, Anne Rosellini

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: The writing and direction by Debra Granik is sharp and sure. This has the lean, spare look of a low-budget independent film, but it is emotionally rich and powerful.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: “Leave No Trace” struck a chord with me early, and I could feel its emotional tug all the way till the end. It’s not a movie deeply concerned with plot. Instead it is all about character.

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: Ben Foster gives the performance of his career – it’s a knockout. Leave No Trace doesn’t have a false note in it.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: Granik brilliantly delivers the viewer into the characters' spatially and socially secluded world, making otherwise normal, crowded living environments seem oppressive and even dangerous by comparison.

reviews.name: Raquel Stecher
reviews.message: a truly superb drama that offers no answers and just takes viewers along for the ride.

reviews.name: MaryAnn Johanson
reviews.message: Writer-director Debra Granik's take on PTSD in military veterans is of course compassionate but perhaps slightly less tolerant of the isolation that her male protagonist...

reviews.name: Jennifer Merin
reviews.message: Debra Granik's Leave No Trace is a gripping drama...

reviews.name: Sandie Angulo Chen
reviews.message: Despite the heartbreaking stories she tells, she gives them (particularly the young women in her films) a flicker of hope in the darkness.

reviews.name: Nikki Baughan
reviews.message: [It] concerns itself with individuals attempting to exist outside societal norms and, in doing so, proves to be a moving study of love, loss and what it means to truly belong.

reviews.name: Cate Marquis
reviews.message: Debra Granik's Leave No Trace is a gem of a film.

reviews.name: Betsy Bozdech
reviews.message: Where their story goes from here isn't always easy to watch, but thanks to McKenzie and Foster's fully committed performances and Granik's nuanced direction, it's powerful and compelling.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Leave No Trace is a slow burn, and carefully constructed; the performances are measured and calm. There's no need to overplay the drama - the circumstances presented here are serious enough as they are.

reviews.name: Taylor Baker
reviews.message: ...Foster's most subtle performance and an exciting debut from both Debra and McKenzie who I can't wait to see more out of.

reviews.name: Robin Holabird
reviews.message: I loved Director Debra Granick's feature Leave No Trace, which captures a pulled-from-life sense of surviving off the grid in Pacific Northwest forests.

reviews.name: Jim Rohner
reviews.message: While the film alludes to larger societal problems such as America's treatment of veterans, and inflexible, societal views about what it means to be a caregiver, the primary narrative focus is on an intimate relationship between two people...

reviews.name: Fletcher Powell
reviews.message: This is director Debra Granik's first fiction feature since ... Winter's Bone, and it's been worth the wait.

reviews.name: Candice McMillan
reviews.message: Leave No Trace is wonder to behold, a hard watch made even harder by the fact that it really happened. It is a truly American story of love, survival and acceptance in our country's often forgotten frontier.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: Leave No Trace should start a healthy conversation while providing a heartfelt story that doesn't ring false even once during its 110 minutes.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: One of the very best films of the year.

reviews.name: Zehra Phelan
reviews.message: Taps into the gut-wrenching possibilities of the kindness of humanity; it is delicately compelling and intricately detailed.

reviews.name: PJ Nabarro
reviews.message: Another tour de force from Granik - a filmmaker who instinctively knows how to alchemise the dramatic, cinematographic and anthropological elements of her stories so acutely.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: It is not an easy thing to place us into the lives of people we've never had real-life contact with, but this is the stuff that fuels Granik's creativity, and Leave No Trace is a fresh reminder of her talent.

reviews.name: Matt Cipolla
reviews.message: [Granik] strikes a keen balance of examining the characters like an anthropologist would study another culture, but she never becomes too detached.

reviews.name: Scott Phillips
reviews.message: Leave No Trace is a brilliant examination of family, sacrifice and the price a parent is willing to pay so his child can lead a better life.

reviews.name: Prahlad Srihari
reviews.message: Leave No Trace is a deeply affecting but ultimately universal tale of children leaving home to embark on an independent life. Letting go may be painful, but it's a necessary process.

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: Delivers something so full of strength and sadness that anyone who calls it slow should have to take a 100-level course in humanity.

reviews.name: John Lui
reviews.message: Granik has drawn yet another deeply affecting portrait of families who live on the margins - sometimes by choice, often because of circumstance. Her images of poverty are warmly generous, yet free of condescension or romanticisation.

reviews.name: Jim Ross
reviews.message: Script, direction, and acting all work together to deliver a story that clearly communicates what is at stake for its characters and what they represent with a rare subtle intelligence.

reviews.name: Kristy Strouse
reviews.message: Leave No Trace will undoubtedly leave many impressions, as it is a beautiful and expertly made film that shouldn't be overlooked.

reviews.name: Susan Wloszczyna
reviews.message: What I most appreciate about Granik's approach is how she eschews exposition and trusts her leads -- in this case, a terrific Ben Foster in a rare contemplative role, and knock-out New Zealand newcomer Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie.

reviews.name: Claudia Puig
reviews.message: [Director Debra Granik] focuses on the humanity of the characters without ever judging them.

reviews.name: Catherine Capellaro
reviews.message: The simple story touches on themes of trauma and loss, belonging and technology. But it does so effortlessly by focusing on a relationship between a father and daughter.

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: A father and daughter story of haunting beauty.

reviews.name: Joey Keogh
reviews.message: Leave No Trace finds its tension in the growing gap between father and daughter as Tom's worldview widens while Will's closes in.

reviews.name: Gillie Collins
reviews.message: Setting Leave No Trace in the wilderness allows Granik to portray an extremely enmeshed - yet, under the circumstances, healthy - father-daughter relationship.

reviews.name: Rita Cannon
reviews.message: McKenzie and Foster serve as compelling guides on Granik's emotional journey.

reviews.name: Andiee Paviour
reviews.message: To hide out in a national park takes the grace, stealth and skill of a wild animal. Will and his 13-year-old daughter have been doing just that in Portland, Oregon, living peacefully off the grid, when the long arms of the law close in.

reviews.name: Brent Hankins
reviews.message: Quiet and somber, with long stretches of little to no dialogue, Leave No Trace isn't likely to appeal to everyone, especially with its purposefully vague approach to storytelling and deliberate obfuscation of details.

reviews.name: Wendy Shreve
reviews.message: In essence, Leave No Trace, reinforces why independent filmmaking continues to capture what mainstream films often cannot--human nature exposed to the elements.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: If Leave No Trace isn't quite as formidable as Debra Granik's Winter's Bone, it's still a potent drama marked by a superlative turn from teenage actress Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie.

title: To Catch a Killer
description: A modern-day Clarice Starling, Eleanor (Shailene Woodley) is a young police investigator wrestling with the demons of her past when she is recruited by the FBI's chief investigator (Ben Mendelsohn) to help profile and track the work of a disturbed individual. As the police and FBI launch a nationwide manhunt, they are thwarted at every turn by the individual’s unprecedented behavior. Given her tortured psyche, Eleanor may be the only person who can understand the mind of their assailant and bring him to justice.

characteristics.Producer:: Aaron Ryder, Stuart Manashil, Damián David Szifron, Shailene Woodley

reviews.name: Amelia Harvey
reviews.message: To Catch a Killer works as a police procedural with just enough intrigue to stop it from feeling like a paint-by-numbers crime drama. It wants to make a bold statement about the cultural atmosphere that breeds killers but fails to commit to the cause.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: The mystery is engaging, and the acting is all top-notch, but eventually, the plot fails to deliver the result you expected.

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: A dark, draggy police procedural that... proves to be considerably less profound and powerful than the makers imagine.

reviews.name: Nestor Bentancor
reviews.message: Focused on investigating its characters, this contained, broody procedural, shares some DNA with productions like Silence of The Lambs and Mayor of Easttown. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: To Catch a Killer starts with the far-fetched concept that an experienced FBI agent would rely heavily on an inexperienced city police officer to help capture a mass murderer. The plot goes downhill from there.

reviews.name: Alejandro Turdo
reviews.message: There is an undeniable 90s vibe To Catch a Killer and it is for sure a solid Thriller. But at the same time it manages to dig deep into some of the most pressing issues in present day American Society. Great display of Szifron's talent at the helm.

reviews.name: Gregory Wakeman
reviews.message: Unfortunately, To Catch A Killer doesn’t have the script -- and tries to include way too much thematic substance -- to match Szifron and Julia’s impressive visuals.

reviews.name: Marcelo Stiletano
reviews.message: With the pulse of an exemplary storyteller and skilful creator of tension-filled atmospheres, Szifron creates a world where easy, superficial, and malleable solutions can only push us to make irreparable mistakes. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: Szifron demonstrate his masstery of dialogue constructions, in introducing characters, and in filming action sequences with intriuge or brio. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Tony Medley
reviews.message: It's a tenuous proposition and it leads to a denouement that challenges reason, given the sociopathy of the killer. Worse, it treats the vicious cold-blooded killer with surprising and blatantly unjustified sympathy and understanding.

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: ... At times To Catch a Killer recalls The Wire in its exploration of bureaucracy and manipulations inside security and intelligence agencies. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Adrián Monserrat
reviews.message: Audacious, intimate, and elegant, To Catch a Killer deserves to be watched in the theaters. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: Although it is a proficient crime thriller, its formulaic story doesn't set it apart from other productions of the same genre. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a decent-enough thriller that feels like a throwback to the similarly-themed fare of the 1990s.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: It’s been a minute since I’ve gotten a quality detective thriller in the vein of Silence of the Lambs. To Catch a Killer is not hitting hard enough to measure up to that modern classic, but it’s certainly more worthwhile than junk like The Snowman.

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: While it's always a pleasure to see Woodley in anything, I fear she's been  let down by a fairly pedestrian screenplay here.

reviews.name: Jenn Adams
reviews.message: Though the narrative sometimes lags under the weight of its message, the film is an edge-of-your-seat thriller that doesn’t shy away from the more problematic elements of the sub genre.

reviews.name: Ray Gill Jr.
reviews.message: With so much focus on the chase, Szifron never taps into the emotional wreckage experienced by the victims, but Woodley and Mendelsohn successfully reveal the human beings behind the badges.

reviews.name: Whang Yee Ling
reviews.message: A rising director and a reliable star are hampered by a limp script -- their serial killer drama shoots blanks.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: Many may be surprised that the straight-to-VOD-looking To Catch A Killer is not only very gripping but also doesn’t paint the police in a flattering light. It touches on corruption, racism and questions the system. Still, it’s too surface-level.

reviews.name: Tara McNamara
reviews.message: And although Szifron's approach doesn't glamorize gun violence, it still feels like it could encourage a potential shooter who might be thinking about doing something similar.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Filmmaker Damian Szifron takes an inventive visual approach, even if the ambitious script turns out to be rather pedestrian.

reviews.name: Christian Toto
reviews.message: Ben Mendelsohn shines, again, but thriller falls prey to lackluster finale.

reviews.name: Rex Reed
reviews.message: To Catch a Killer is a thriller that thrills more than other similar films do, and Shailene Woodley adds another laurel to her already impressive resume.

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: To Catch a Killer is not worth watching at the theatre or video on demand pricing. The film squanders a compelling and thoroughly enjoyable turn by Mendelsohn.

reviews.name: Don Shanahan
reviews.message: Tension that had been accumulating all movie from a frightening unknown menace should be snapping hearts and necks, but it unravels.

reviews.name: Stephanie Archer
reviews.message: While the ending might not land for all, the overall delivery of the film is intense, engaging, and unforgettable.

reviews.name: Andrew Dignan
reviews.message: You can feel the film fumbling around for some sort of an explanation for this decidedly American phenomenon, but it loses its nerve somewhere along the way, abandoning any kind of stinging indictment for a wan variation on “hurt people hurt people.”

reviews.name: Michael Frank
reviews.message: Szifron’s unable to put personality, verve, or distinction into To Catch a Killer.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: For the first half-hour, To Catch a Killer is outstanding. Then it gradually, consistently goes downhill.

reviews.name: James Verniere
reviews.message: Yes, it's flawed. But these actors are watchable, and I'd like to see Woodley in a follow-up.

reviews.name: Peter Martin
reviews.message: Without descending into shrill sloganeering, the implicit anti-gun messages are weaved into the fabric of the narrative, elevating the material from the typical, limited, familiar range of police procedurals.

reviews.name: Marya E. Gates
reviews.message: Its ambitions overwhelm its abilities.

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: Clunky dialogue, unrealistic leaps of logic, and an unnecessarily stuffy tone ultimately sink To Catch a Killer...

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: More suspenseful than its generic title suggests, this mildly taut thriller nevertheless stumbles through formulaic procedural trappings and a ridiculous ending.

reviews.name: Dustin Chase
reviews.message: As good as any limited series crime thriller, it begins with a bang pulling the viewer to the edge of their seat and keeping them there the entire time.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: The juxtaposition [of the filmmakers' ideas with police procedural plotting] isn't perfect, but their ability to let their characters be flawed and complex does allow our normal preconceptions born from Hollywood copaganda to get pushed aside.

reviews.name: Casey Chong
reviews.message: Shailene Woodley and Ben Mendelsohn elevate this otherwise familiar and uneven psychological thriller.

reviews.name: Travis Hopson
reviews.message: To Catch a Killer will leave you reaching for the latest true crime podcast for the suspense that is sadly missing.

reviews.name: Allen Almachar
reviews.message: There’s nothing here that we haven’t seen executed with more creativity and style in other productions. What we get is a cover performance that knows the lyrics but lacks the soul.

title: F9 The Fast Saga
description: Vin Diesel's Dom Toretto is leading a quiet life off the grid with Letty and his son, little Brian, but they know that danger always lurks just over their peaceful horizon. This time, that threat will force Dom to confront the sins of his past if he's going to save those he loves most. His crew joins together to stop a world-shattering plot led by the most skilled assassin and high-performance driver they've ever encountered: a man who also happens to be Dom's forsaken brother, Jakob (John Cena, the upcoming The Suicide Squad).

characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz, Vin Diesel, Justin Lin, Jeff Kirschenbaum, Joe Roth, Clayton Townsend, Samantha Vincent
characteristics.Production Co:: Perfect Storm Entertainment, Universal Pictures, One Race Films, Original Film, Roth/Kirschenbaum Films

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a predictably broad premise that’s employed to periodically watchable yet mostly underwhelming effect...

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: I can’t help but wonder why Fast and Furious 9 would not have sufficed as the title here. At least 2 Fast 2 Furious has a goofy pizzazz to it. Naming conventions aside, the most recent entry does nothing to take the series in a new direction...

reviews.name: Benjamin Wiebe
reviews.message: As a theatre-going experience, I can’t recommend F9: The Fast Saga enough.

reviews.name: Adrian Ruiz
reviews.message: F9 is one or two too many explosions and one or two too many quips away from achieving its goal of as an action flick with an intriguing plotline and stalls out as an overly self-aware stunt fest with a storyline you wish you had more time with.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: To be fair things like logic, reality, even physics simply don’t apply to these movies. You have to turn off a portion of your brain and let some obvious questions and concerns drift off into the ether.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: If you hate the logic smashing exploits of muscle-bound gearheads, theres nothing here to convince you otherwise. However, for the many people who made this one of the biggest franchises in the world, it delivers the outrageous nonsense you paid to see.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: At heart, this still carries everything this franchise is known and loved for and continues to show that there are more miles left in this already impressively long franchise.

reviews.name: Christopher Cross
reviews.message: The most daring entry in the franchise that is almost impossible not to walk away from with a massive smile on your face.

reviews.name: Oliver Jones
reviews.message: At its very best, there's something positively life-affirming about F9, the fifth Fast & Furious movie directed by Justin Lin.

reviews.name: Dorothy Woodend
reviews.message: Maybe it matters not, but the impulse to pump hype, hot air, bum warmers and a full rack of ribs into something - whether a movie theatre or Vin Diesel, so that it is barely recognizable from its former, more modest self - is everywhere...

reviews.name: Casey Chong
reviews.message: Overall, Fast & Furious 9 is a bloated disappointment that tries too hard to be serious and silly and I hate to say this - this ninth film is the worst entry I've ever seen since 2009's Fast & Furious 4.

reviews.name: Witney Seibold
reviews.message: Physics? Bah! Who needs it? 'F9' is gloriously brash and stupid, like eighteen different Saturday morning cartoons mashed into an amorphous ball of idiocy. This is a compliment.

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: The explanation for Han's survival is as nonsensical as the caper that sends Roman and Tej where no F&F cast member has gone before, if you catch my (Tokyo) drift.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: The important thing is to have as many ingredients as possible, no matter how well they combine with each other. More is more; caution is for cowards. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rohan Naahar
reviews.message: Years from now, F9 will settle into its position as the Fast & Furious franchise's forgotten entry - Rock-less, ridiculous, and ultimately irredeemable.

reviews.name: Akhil Arora
reviews.message: Jakob is a self-serious villain and the film treats him seriously too, unlike F9's self-aware and fun-laden approach elsewhere. It's just not the right move. Look to The Suicide Squad and how James Gunn makes better use of [John] Cena.

reviews.name: Kip Mooney
reviews.message: Definitely delivers on the expectations of its fanbase, but once again it could have been something more.

reviews.name: Luke Goodsell
reviews.message: Its charm overrides its implausibility, retaining that spark of DIY ingenuity that has practically made this series the people's franchise.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: Its dizzying exercise of magnetized cars and international espionage seems to me as predictable and repetitive as the rims of a tire on the road. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Víctor López G.
reviews.message: An exemplary blockbuster to enjoy leaving every last gram of grey matter at the doors of the theatre.

reviews.name: Bill Watters
reviews.message: It's one thing to create a film that is mindless fun, but it's another to have your lead actor emoting like it's an earthy drama while the dumbest action sequences to be seen since Travolta landed a helicopter on a plane's wing in Face/Off.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: It's Old Home Week in this installment.

reviews.name: Luke Parker
reviews.message: F9 is a stupendously stupid movie. Total nonsense. Bombastic and, forgive the pun, ludicrous. But I'd be lying if I didn't say I had a lot of fun watching it. I now support multi-million-dollar goofball productions.

reviews.name: Bruce R. Miller
reviews.message: There's fun here. It just never lasts longer than a pit stop. Lin oils this vehicle for maximum performance and tosses in the undercoating, even though it's unnecessary.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: I applaud Universal for not giving Diesel the money to de-age himself. I applaud the tiny, sporadic surprises this film offers. I applaud that I never have to watch it again.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: Pointless cameos, cheesy dialogue and low-stakes CGI-enhanced mayhem. A fun franchise has got lost in space.

reviews.name: Matt Atchity
reviews.message: Rest assured, that if you came for the spectacle, you won't be disappointed, and it's amazing that the filmmakers are still coming up with new things to do with vehicles.

reviews.name: Kelechi Ehenulo
reviews.message: The Fast Saga may be racing one quarter at a mile, but with two movies left, all roads now lead to Wrestlemania.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: The usual adrenaline rush of excitement, action, and humor [causing you to] at least crack a smile. That's why we keep watching these dumb movies anyway.

reviews.name: Sergio López Aguirre
reviews.message: Every dollar spent is seen and heard on screen, but none of that works when your characters are removed from all reality and worst of all is that they take themselves too seriously and not in an ironic way. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alejandro G. Calvo
reviews.message: Movies must be valued based on their goals and aspirations, and Fast & Furious aspires to be very summer entertainment. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Peter Canavese
reviews.message: These movies have become wacky...campy, corny, hammering away at this theme of 'family' with a good car chase in Edinburgh, there's still a frantic energy in these movies, but the word for them is 'stupid."

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: The absence of screenwriter Chris Morgan is noticeable, as the structure and storytelling is sloppier, to the overall detriment of the film

reviews.name: Richard Trenholm
reviews.message: Fast! Furious! Family! Vroooommm!

reviews.name: Ed Whitfield
reviews.message: The lack of human interest stalls the engine and flips the vehicle.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: The fast, furious, full-throttle outlandishness needed to keep an audience's ever-dwindling attention span has long since reached the limit.

reviews.name: Elaine Cho
reviews.message: After Michelle Rodriguez called out F8 for its dated machismo, F9: The Fast Saga regains lost traction.

reviews.name: Damian Levy
reviews.message: The film flexes the kind of self awareness to push the series into full blown parody, while still showing some mileage left.

reviews.name: Robert Ham
reviews.message: The action isn't so clever or coherent as the merry mayhem Lin unleashed on Tokyo and Rio in previous Fast & Furious films, but the sweet camaraderie between Dom and his loyal cronies endures.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: It's more popcorn fun with a science-fiction theme.

title: Peter Pan & Wendy
description: Based on J. M. Barrie's novel "Peter and Wendy" and inspired by the 1953 animated classic, "Peter Pan & Wendy" is the timeless tale of a young girl who, defying her parents' wishes to attend boarding school, travels with her two younger brothers to the magical Neverland. There, she meets a boy who refuses to grow up, a tiny fairy and an evil pirate captain, and they soon find themselves on a thrilling and dangerous adventure far, far away from their family and the comforts of home.

characteristics.Producer:: James Whitaker

reviews.name: Kent Garrison
reviews.message: It's a shame this one didn't get a theatrical release. Lowery's sweeping scenery deserves to be highlighted.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: I would argue this is one of the better efforts compared to the likes of the much more expensive Beauty and the Beast and The Lion King, which is also what I’d expect from director David Lowery.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: Even a respected auteur like director David Lowery can’t save Peter Pan & Wendy, yet another bland live-action adaptation of a Disney classic...

reviews.name: Colleen Morrissey
reviews.message: Peter Pan & Wendy is a puzzlingly bland take on one of the liveliest children’s stories of all time.

reviews.name: Dirk Libbey
reviews.message: While Peter Pan and Wendy misses some opportunities to possibly elevate its material, the end result is still pretty entertaining.

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: Poignant and fanciful.

reviews.name: Wade Major
reviews.message: There's too much corporate constraints on this film... I think it's time to just cut this franchise loose.

reviews.name: Brian Gill
reviews.message: It's not a totally worthless endeavor but in a world in which dozens of Pan adaptations exist, there's not enough here to separate the movie from its predecessors. If you're going to hire David Lowery, let him cook!

reviews.name: Lynn Venhaus
reviews.message: Another disappointment among Disney’s increasingly lackluster live action reboots of their classic animated films, “Peter Pan and Wendy” lacks imagination in its re-imagining.

reviews.name: Gregory Wakeman
reviews.message: Peter Pan & Wendy might be overly saccharine from time to time, but Lowery’s swash-buckling approach to direction makes sure that it’s always light-hearted and fun to watch unfold.

reviews.name: Mike Scott
reviews.message: Even with pirates, a fairy, a Native American princess and a man-eating crocodile, it arrives as oddly unimaginative stuff.

reviews.name: Candice McMillan
reviews.message: All talk, no crocodile bite ... The parts just don't add up to a completely engaging trip to Neverland.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: There’s not much here besides something to keep the kids out of your hair for a couple of hours.

reviews.name: Margot Harrison
reviews.message: It's great that kids now have a Peter Pan that doesn't lean into antiquated gender roles. As an adventure, though, this version never quite takes flight.

reviews.name: Rosa Parra
reviews.message: “Peter Pan & Wendy” is a refreshingly and welcomed adaptation of this story with strong performances all around and fantastic camera work.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: At times, watching this film is like sitting in on a therapy session as a deeply disturbed pirate confronts his repressed memories. All of which will fly over the heads of its intended young audience as surely as Peter does over the rooftops...

reviews.name: Mat Brunet
reviews.message: I’m not calling this Peter Pan Gone Wrong, but it’s not as good as that show either.

reviews.name: Mark Meszoros
reviews.message: While no classic, “Peter Pan & Wendy” is a pretty charming affair, one that should be most appealing to relatively young children.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: Another expensive so-so remake...Blessed with a huge budget and some wonderful visual effects, the film looks splendid yet doesn’t come close to capturing the vibrancy and magic of the timeless 1953 film, opting rather for a darker take.

reviews.name: Julian Lytle
reviews.message: Peter Pan and Wendy is purposefully crafted with care and thoughtfulness, and while it succeeds in expanding the ideas of Wendy, Hook, and Tiger Lily, it’s at the cost of the character of Peter Pan.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: Peter Pan and Wendy never masks the redundancy of Disney’s remake formula.

reviews.name: Fletcher Powell
reviews.message: There’s an alternate universe where David Lowery made a Peter Pan movie with ultimate freedom, and imagining that makes watching Peter Pan & Wendy a little bittersweet.

reviews.name: Deborah Ross
reviews.message: There is swashbuckling and the ticking crocodile and Smee, but the narrative always feels perfunctory and inert possibly because there’s just no spark between any of the characters, least of all Wendy and Peter, who is portrayed as a sulky kind of chap.

reviews.name: Nicole Ackman
reviews.message: Peter Pan & Wendy shows the usefulness of the concept of the Disney live-action remake; it updates the racial and gender politics of the original 1953 animated film while also drawing further from the story upon which that story was based.

reviews.name: Tyler Smith
reviews.message: In the end, Peter Pan & Wendy is a fantasy film that undercuts its own sense of wonder.

reviews.name: Jennifer Green
reviews.message: The Disney brand will bring broad audiences to Peter Pan & Wendy, but they might be surprised by the broody aesthetic and contemplative messages of Lowery's adaptation, not to mention its alternate ending.

reviews.name: Joey Rambles
reviews.message: Both visually and narratively uninteresting, Peter Pan & Wendy is another forgettable live-action remake from Disney, and further proof that live-action versions of animated movies are just not on par.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: Grinds all of the fantastical elements out as much as can possibly be done for a story about using magical dust to fly

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: Peter Pan & Wendy is visually spectacular and tells the story we all know about the boy who could fly. It’s one of the better of these Disney retreads and that is ultimately enough.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: Of course there’s swashbuckling derring-do and a giant crocodile too, but Law gets to infuse the panto appeal of Hook with genuine pathos.

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: [Peter Pan & Wendy] is impressive at times but there is also the feeling that, once again, the corporate machine "domesticated" and distilled everything original and daring... Not everything that dazzles is great cinema. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: While it looks great, sounds great, and at times plays great, it doesn’t have much of a lasting effect.

reviews.name: Linda and Al Lerner
reviews.message: The themes of childhood wonder, imagination and friendship all play out in a predictably mundane storyline. While Peter Pan and Wendy is worth streaming, this new re-telling of the well-worn fable may not make you want to crow.

reviews.name: Sarah Knight Adamson
reviews.message: “Peter Pan and Wendy” is the perfect title as Wendy shares the spotlight with Peter and at times outshines him due to her broad screen time and her determined performance.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: While I appreciated certain aspects of David Lowery’s production, “Peter Pan & Wendy” was a chore.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: Children too might object to the film’s seriousness — although it comes with a sense of wonder and plenty of swashbuckling action scenes.

reviews.name: Noel Murray
reviews.message: The movie is entertaining and has a professional polish; but it’s also very safe.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: It’s an expertly made movie, but one in which the lifeblood has been mostly drained.

reviews.name: Brianna Zigler
reviews.message: It’s bogged down by a slog of unimagination that spends too much time sucking the life and magic out of a story set in a magical world. Maybe that’s part of the point, but shouldn’t we also want to go to Neverland, even if only for a moment?

reviews.name: Ryan McQuade
reviews.message: Lowery has been talking about mortality, growing up and legacy, so he fits perfectly here. The only aspect of the film that I didn’t love is that the scale feels so small.

title: Robots
description: Charles is a womanizer while Elaine is a gold-digger. The duo learn humanity when forced to team up and pursue robot doubles of themselves.

characteristics.Producer:: Cassian Elwes, Julien Favre, Stephen Hamel, Lars Sylvest

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: As the contrivances go up, the laughs go down in this romantic comedy with a science-fiction twist, and a potentially amusing premise is squandered along the way.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: Christensen and Hines don’t have a vision for cinematic silliness, creating a terrible episode of television instead.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: [T]he movie is mostly defined by its lack of insight, foresight, and any ability to see how poorly imagined and executed the attempted humor here is.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: Robots with artificial intelligence could have come up with a better movie than the filmmakers responsible for the drab and unfunny comedy Robots, an embarrassing dud that fails to blend sci-fi and romance into an interesting story.

title: Missing
description: When her mother (Nia Long) disappears while on vacation in Colombia with her new boyfriend, June's (Storm Reid) search for answers is hindered by international red tape. Stuck thousands of miles away in Los Angeles, June creatively uses all the latest technology at her fingertips to try and find her before it's too late. But as she digs deeper, her digital sleuthing raises more questions than answers... and when June unravels secrets about her mom, she discovers that she never really knew her at all.

characteristics.Producer:: Natalie Qasabian, Sev Ohanian, Aneesh Chaganty
characteristics.Production Co:: Bazelevs Production, Sony Pictures, Search Party

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: The format means there’s no room to hide, and Reid is talented enough to excel in a role that requires her face to be on screen for the best part of 90 minutes; to hold your own against veterans like Long and Almeida is no mean feat.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: The imagery is fiendishly clever, sending a terrific cast spiralling through a series of mind-boggling twists and turns. But as involving as the movie is, the plot completely disintegrates if you take a moment to think about it.

reviews.name: Jack Bottomley
reviews.message: Missing does unleash some mighty big twists and turns, at points stretching the very credulity it successfully builds overall, and maybe having one reveal too many, but – despite threatening to – it never comes off the rails...

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: The inventive approach and the frantic energy of the storytelling elevate the picture above its slightly gimmicky formal device, though this film lacks the novelty value that made Searching such a talking point.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: As a nosey parker riff on the dating history of your parents, the film has a clickbaity kind of appeal...

reviews.name: Brian Lloyd
reviews.message: 'Missing' misses the point.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: Writer-directors Will Merrick and Nick Johnson push a little at the boundaries of credibility, but it’s ingeniously done.

reviews.name: Chris Wasser
reviews.message: Good fun for an hour, but the novelty wears thin, and that final third is positively bananas, in all the worst ways. Approach with caution.

reviews.name: Alison Rumfitt
reviews.message: The final act was one reveal too many, unfortunately, and a glib use of a serious subject matter doesn’t help.

reviews.name: John Nugent
reviews.message: A gripping, well-told, incredibly watchable thriller for a new generation of TikTok sleuths — and a compelling argument to up your average screen-time.

reviews.name: Allison Rose
reviews.message: Reid has been honing her acting skills for a number of years and she just seems to be getting better as time goes on.

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: Missing ups the stakes not only with its use of digital technology but in giving the film an international flavor.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: It’s more of the same, only not nearly as cleverly constructed as Searching. Still, it’s catchy enough to make it a reasonably diverting techno-thriller.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: Truly unpredictable with multiple gasp-worthy twists, this masterfully edited story told entirely through technology screens is an anxiety-inducing thriller that despite going off the rails a bit at the end is exciting and engaging form start to finish.

reviews.name: Kristen Maldonado
reviews.message: Missing has to be the craziest movie I’ve seen this year! With twist after twist, Missing will have you screaming at your screen as you try to figure out whodunnit.

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: Missing is a taut techno-thriller that keeps you riveted with its twisty proceedings.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: An offshoot of found footage, the setup feels less spontaneous and more manufactured by comparison, leaving the viewer to feel pushed and pulled through the ensuing suspense by the editing, sometimes in clumsy ways.

reviews.name: Eric Webb
reviews.message: When it’s not registering on the Gasp-o-Meter, Missing finds just enough nuance between its browser tabs.

reviews.name: Ronak Kotecha
reviews.message: When it comes to new-age digital thrillers Missing is clearly a cut above the rest.

reviews.name: Whang Yee Ling
reviews.message: This 21st-century techno thriller is cleverly constructed, if increasingly far-fetched. It is best at capturing the digital dexterity of the younger generation and June proves a smart and likeable heroine.

reviews.name: Blai Morell
reviews.message: ... this entertainment is instantly forgettable, but man, it's so enjoyable to watch in the recliner of a movie theatre. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Harris Dang
reviews.message: Missing is another stellar effort at a Screenlife thriller that shows that ingenuity in storytelling can make well-worn narratives feel shiny and new again. Recommended.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: The riveting Missing is right on target at grounding its nerves and thrills alike in all that can be uncovered, endured and experienced with your fingers on a keyboard and your eyes staring at your chosen rectangle.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: [Missing] constantly shifts audience sympathies, delivers more than one jaw-dropping twist and makes full use of its tricksy conceit.

reviews.name: Mikel Zorrilla
reviews.message: A thriller that engages and flies by. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jake Wilson
reviews.message: If you were teaching a course on cyberstalking -- or, to put it more neutrally, online detective work -- you could do worse than show Missing in the first class.

reviews.name: Peter Gray
reviews.message: A welcome twist on the found-footage genre subsect that practically ran itself into the ground through overexposure, Missing makes a classic narrative feel inviting and fresh.

reviews.name: Javier Ocaña
reviews.message: Missing continues with another contemporary text-book whodunnit. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Liam McEneaney
reviews.message: Buoyed by an appealing cast, a strong star turn from Storm Reid, and a tightly written and directed story, 'Missing' is far better than it deserves to be.
reviews.full_review: Buoyed by an appealing cast, a strong star turn from Storm Reid, and a tightly written and directed story, 'Missing' is far better than it deserves to be.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: There’s lots of ingenuity at play here...An amusing irony with the film [is that] we usually escape a long day of staring into computer screens and reading by going to the cinema, yet the experience of watching Missing requires that you do exactly that.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: The important thing is that while you're in the cinema, surrounded by people just as invested in the story as you are, “Missing” works really well. It turns out that there is still a lot to do with this format. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Kimber Myers
reviews.message: Though Missing has more serious subjects on its mind than just advocating for unique passwords and better digital hygiene, this is a highly engaging, slightly silly movie mystery made more for Gen Z than its predecessor was.

reviews.name: Nadine Whitney
reviews.message: … a decent techno driven thriller that moves at a breakneck pace …

reviews.name: Erik Childress
reviews.message: Another clever entry in the you-too-can-be-a-detective-on-the-internet mystery that may cheat itself into a corner but knows just when to drop its reveals and keep us engaged especially with a nice turn from Joaquim de Almeida

reviews.name: Casey Chong
reviews.message: [Nick] Johnson and [Will] Merrick bring out the best in [their cast] including Storm Reid's engaging lead performance as June

reviews.name: Benjamin Franz
reviews.message: A tight, taut mystery with incredible acting, this terrific film explores how our children use social networks.

reviews.name: Lael Loewenstein
reviews.message: A really interesting experiment in style. The way that it's done is constantly gripping and holds your attention.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: Find a terrific thriller in 'Missing.'

reviews.name: Eric Eisenberg
reviews.message: It gets a bit silly, but never too much to undermine the tension, and it stays grounded thanks to a solid lead turn by Storm Reid.

reviews.name: Laura Sirikul
reviews.message: Missing is a worthy successor of Searching with its unexpected twists and shocking conclusion. It doesn’t present anything new but it is fun to see the crazy storytelling elements and interesting use of social media mediums.

title: Faithfully Yours
description: Using each other as alibis, two friends sneak off to indulge in secret affairs, but their elaborate web of lies unravels when one of them goes missing.

characteristics.Producer:: Rachel Van Bommel
characteristics.Writer:: Elisabeth Lodeizen, Paul Jan Nelissen, André van Duren

reviews.name: Barbara Shulgasser
reviews.message: The consequences of lying are emphasized but the pursuit of pleasure and control are far more fundamental and disturbing themes.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: Van Duren makes a halfway decent attempt to build some paranoid suspense as Bodil sniffs out others’ secrets as she tries to conceal her own, but the endeavor is frustratingly generic, and increasingly absurd...

reviews.name: Jason Flatt
reviews.message: Really there is little redeeming or worthwhile about Faithfully Yours. Just don’t watch it. Even by the time it gets to the end and two reasonable twists take place, it’s already far too late for them to redeem what is just entirely dull from the onset.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: A subtly-acted slow-starter, with a fine, flashy finish, a “solid” genre piece that never quite crosses over into riveting.

title: Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie
description: The film, which will incorporate documentary, archival and scripted elements, will recount Fox's extraordinary story in his own words -- the improbable tale of an undersized kid from a Canadian army base who rose to the heights of stardom in 1980s Hollywood. The account of Fox's public life, full of nostalgic thrills and cinematic gloss, will unspool alongside his never-before-seen private journey, including the years that followed his diagnosis, at 29, with Parkinson's disease. Intimate and honest, and produced with unprecedented access to Fox and his family, the film will chronicle Fox's personal and professional triumphs and travails, and will explore what happens when an incurable optimist confronts an incurable disease. With a mix of adventure and romance, comedy and drama, watching the film will feel like... well, like a Michael J. Fox movie.

characteristics.Producer:: Davis Guggenheim, Annetta Marion, Jonathan King

reviews.name: Mel Campbell
reviews.message: Fox’s quick wit illuminates this remarkable documentary … The effect is uncannily vivid and playful, like being in the passenger seat of the time-travelling DeLorean.

reviews.name: Jennifer Green
reviews.message: The film also uses scenes from Fox's own films and TV shows to illustrate points Fox makes about his life. It might inject unintended meaning into some of the footage, but it makes for compelling visual storytelling.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: It’s a cozy profile that invites empathy more than sympathy.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Still isn’t about fame, or illness, but instead the strength of character it takes to navigate both. “I’m a tough son of a bitch” Fox declares early on, and Guggenheim’s triumphant film only cements that claim.

reviews.name: Alejandro Alemán
reviews.message: Still is a documentary that not only situates itself in nostalgia, but it is also a film that shows us what living with Parkinson's is like [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Mark Meszoros
reviews.message: You can’t help but empathize with Fox as you watch Still, but this is no pity party — it’s a celebration of a life well lived, even if that living hasn’t always been something out of the movies or TV.

reviews.name: Carla Renata
reviews.message: Michael J. Fox is a survivor and  an inspiration despite the world swirling around him.  The same person who worked days shooting Family Ties and evenings at Back to the Future - doesn't know what giving up is and thank goodness for us he never will.

reviews.name: Emiliano Basile
reviews.message: ... This documentary does not resort to cheap shots or sentimentality, instead, it uses the troublesome experience in an artistic way. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: Still doesn’t sugarcoat what Fox is facing these days, but it nevertheless strikes a tone of positivity.

reviews.name: Stephen Romei
reviews.message: Asked why he wants to continue to tell his story, he says, “I love my mind and I love the places it takes me and I just don’t want that to get cut short.” Anyone who watches this uplifting film will share that feeling.

reviews.name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
reviews.message: Still [is] like watching Fox’s life back through a new filter...

reviews.name: Sarah Knight Adamson
reviews.message: Of the 30 films I screened at Sundance Film Festival, this was my number 1 choice--an excellent biography with themes of love, persistence, addiction, optimism and hope are a true testament to overcoming adversity.

reviews.name: Richard Roeper
reviews.message: While gimmicky at times, the film offers some poignant glimpses of the star’s Parkinson’s symptoms and his 1.21-gigawatt personality.

reviews.name: Andy Klein
reviews.message: This is a wonderful movie.

reviews.name: Wade Major
reviews.message: Absolutely terrific. It is both heartbreaking and inspiring at the same time, and I think that's by design.

reviews.name: Tom Meek
reviews.message: It’s hard not to like Fox, and the film only deepens that by detailing what he’s overcome, his acceptance of his current challenges and commitment to family.

reviews.name: Jeremy Jahns
reviews.message: This is an interesting look into the life of an inspiring person.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: Outstanding...Thankfully, Fox adopts a distinct pity-me-not attitude.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Assembled warmly and unflinchingly, this documentary is a powerfully moving portrait of the actor who charmed the world in the 1980s and 1990s and has lived with Parkinson's for three decades.

reviews.name: Jorge Loser
reviews.message: Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie is more than a classic story of overcoming adversity; it transmits an inspiring message about appreciating life as an experience filled with lights and shadows... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Tarek Fayoumi
reviews.message: The unforgettable documentary demonstrates realism and emotion, while never going too far down the rabbit hole of sadness, finding the light in Fox’s life as well.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: For me, the title suggests something else, he's still here -- living as fully as he can and offering a story that's sure to inspire others.

reviews.name: Bob Grimm
reviews.message: A reminder of Fox's greatness as an entertainer and a human being. Love this guy.

reviews.name: Matthew Jackson
reviews.message: “Still” focuses deftly not just on how Fox’s world evolved in the wake of his Parkinson’s diagnosis in the 1990s, but on how Fox now sees his entire existence when filtered through what he’s survived, what he’s celebrated, and what he’s won and lost.

reviews.name: Tara Bennett
reviews.message: STILL is an impressive, inspiring and sometimes heartbreaking look at Fox’s ongoing journey, made all the more powerful for being told in his voice.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: Guggenheim flexes both muscles in telling a profile on someone and using his directorial skills. It’s one of the best documentaries of 2023.

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: While the material itself is straightforwardly biographical, the presentation is imaginative, making “Still” engaging for its style as well as its content.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: Beneath its fizzy clips and Eighties pop soundtrack, Guggenheim’s film sometimes has the soft contours of a standard showbusiness autobiography, with Oedipal tussles, twinkling ironies and lucky breaks...

reviews.name: Korey Coleman
reviews.message: The filmmakers don't try to dwell on the sadness. It's one of those documentaries that puts life into perspective.

reviews.name: Sarah Ksiazek
reviews.message: Still is an entertaining and unique documentary that reveals the early life of the star Michael J. Fox, how he became famous, and, in a sort of way, reintroduces him to those who grew up with him.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: Inspiring and with superb film editing, Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie is a must-see documentary for anyone who wants to get a personal look at how Michael J. Fox refused to make his Parkinson's disease into a tragedy but instead turned it into a triumph.

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
reviews.message: The documentary is both heartbreaking and uplifting, told in a captivating narrative to showcase how despite a debilitating disease, Michael J Fox is thriving and triumphant.

reviews.name: Lynn Venhaus
reviews.message: Neither a pity party nor a puff piece, the film is a thoughtful chronicle of the life and career of one-time “Boy Prince” of Hollywood as told through his performances and candid conversations with the film’s director Davis Guggenheim.

reviews.name: Mark Kermode
reviews.message: A dazzling collage of interviews, dramatisations, snappily chosen film and TV clips, family footage and narrated biography...

reviews.name: Ray Pride
reviews.message: Tmphatically captures that vivid, peculiar energy that has always been present in the 1980s-bred star’s performances: restlessness coupled with a bracing agitation... Funny, heartfelt, sometimes harrowing, and whiz-bang entertaining.

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie is a documentary in constant motion, and just like the older Fox, it knows when to stop, pause and take it all in.

reviews.name: Liam Lacey
reviews.message: Guggenheim’s documentary employs clever editing, using Michael Fox’s onscreen fictional characters to illustrate his biography and his transition from '80s’ hot-shot star to a still funny but thoughtful advocate for Parkinson’s disease.

reviews.name: Patrick McDonald
reviews.message: What was particular effective is when director Guggenheim, with his editor Michael Harte, intercut the clip history to create the MJF man in motion. This creative approach gives Fox the story and recognition that he deserves. With director interview.

reviews.name: John Urbancich
reviews.message: The falls and significant breaks/bruises that come with it are all part of a great personal story based on Fox's four books and filled with more hope and humor than sadness and suffering. Blessings and good thoughts all around.

reviews.name: Tynan Yanaga
reviews.message: If Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie shows us anything, it’s the extinguishable spirit and lust for life that has kept this man going for decades. He’s unstoppable on so many fronts and remains a stunning encouragement and role model for many.

title: The Pope's Exorcist
description: Inspired by the actual files of Father Gabriele Amorth, Chief Exorcist of the Vatican (Academy Award®-winner Russell Crowe), The Pope's Exorcist follows Amorth as he investigates a young boy's terrifying possession and ends up uncovering a centuries-old conspiracy the Vatican has desperately tried to keep hidden.

characteristics.Producer:: Doug Belgrad, Michael Patrick Kaczmarek, Jeff Katz
characteristics.Writer:: Michael Petroni, Evan Spiliotopoulos, R. Dean McCreary, Chester Hastings
characteristics.Production Co:: Jesus & Mary, Ad hoc studios, Screen Gems, Loyola Productions, 2.0 Entertainment, Intimacy on Set

reviews.name: EJ Moreno
reviews.message: Russell Crowe understands the assignment and brings what should be a redundant supernatural film to "I might need more of these" levels.

reviews.name: Nestor Bentancor
reviews.message: Without possessing memorable qualities, it's a dynamic horror product that lives in the limbo of mediocrity. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Kevin A. Ranson
reviews.message: What works is Crowe's attachment to the attitude and belief of Father Amorth while enduring the standardized Hollywood fare... (including) plot similarities to The Nun, as if someone thought, 'Oh, we can do better than that,' and damn well proved it.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a paint-by-numbers thriller that’s been suffused with some of the exorcism genre’s hoariest conventions and clichés...

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: It brings up tonal and thematic questions this frequently dumb movie doesn’t have the wherewithal to answer.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: Few horror films have so benefitted from the presence of such a genuine, effortless star.

reviews.name: Juanma Fernández París
reviews.message: ... A film that doesn't do anything new with genre conventions and doesn't generate the dramatic depth it thinks it has. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Víctor López G.
reviews.message: A tremendously fun exercise in demonic horror that manages to stand out among its peers by using its huge wit, its charming campy spirit, and a Russell Crowe in his element having a great time among crucifixes, holy water sprinklers, and bibles.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: The type of routine religious horror film that should be forgettable but isn’t, thanks to an engaging performance from Russell Crowe and a strong story that over delivers on what it promises.

reviews.name: Korey Coleman
reviews.message: Russell Crowe provides a very charismatic performance, and there are intentionally funny moments throughout. The third act is when the movie goes overboard.

reviews.name: Crockett Houghton
reviews.message: If you’re a fan of horror or Russell Crowe, or better still a fan of both, this movie is a must-see.

reviews.name: Cody Leach
reviews.message: The self-aware tone and Crowe's performance helps a fairly formulaic exorcism movie to stand out a bit. It still suffers greatly from the cliche's and redundancy that has plagued this subgenera for decades.

reviews.name: Steven Warner
reviews.message: But lest you think the movie sounds more serious or profound than it actually is, Avery is not the least bit interested in anything resembling depth or authenticity, and thank God for that.

reviews.name: Mel Valentin
reviews.message: ... the overall result manages to rise above its campy, pulp-horror plotting and well-worn, overused ideas.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: The central mother-daughter tension is well sold by its compelling duo and it offers perhaps a more realistic view of the situation than your typical, simplistic, Hollywood resolution.

reviews.name: Austen Goslin
reviews.message: The Pope’s Exorcist doesn’t match the bone-deep terror or filmmaking heights of the original Exorcist, but sets itself apart by building the whole movie on an understanding that its whole premise is a little silly.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: Within this film is an assortment of flavors; some will stand out more on your palette than others. One has to wonder how many messages have to get cut in a body for Pope’s Exorcist to realize it already had new elements to spell things out with.

reviews.name: Nicolás Delgadillo
reviews.message: Far too reminiscent of the tired and cliched genre it’s playing in to stand out in an exciting enough way.

reviews.name: Cody Dericks
reviews.message: Viewers may hope that, half a century after “The Exorcist,” this new film must make new discoveries and attempt some original ideas for the exorcism subgenre of horror. But unfortunately, all they’ll find is a film as stale as expired communion wafers.

reviews.name: Chris Vognar
reviews.message: The Pope’s Exorcist will certainly never go down as a classic of the genre, but it’s better than it has any reason to be. Sometimes, the devil you know gets the job done just fine.

reviews.name: Oliver Jones
reviews.message: An absurdly plotted, blood-drenched haunted house movie...with all the vitality and vivaciousness of a 15th-century corpse.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: The Pope's Exorsict doesn't break new ground, but it's a solid enough entry in its horror subgenre.

reviews.name: Clint Worthington
reviews.message: It’s hard to overstate just how much Crowe elevates this thing; he sails through each scene with a dancer’s grace, elevating the material without ever stooping to mock it.

reviews.name: Alistair Ryder
reviews.message: Director Julius Avery's film makes up in eccentric entertainment what it lacks in genuine scares.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: Crowe is not enough to make The Pope’s Exorcist a good movie overall, but it gets the kick it needs with his presence.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: It isn't fun. It's so against fun, whenever it approaches fun it bounces off it like a negatively-polarized magnet.

reviews.name: Damien Straker
reviews.message: Russell Crowe’s likeable performance is the only commendable aspect of this forgettable horror rehash.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: The demon possession elements all feel quite familiar, but this film gets a pass for Crowe's committed, not-too-serious performance. His Amorth is cool and in charge, but also sometimes charmingly goofy.

reviews.name: Stephen Romei
reviews.message: It is a powerful historical drama and Crowe is outstanding as a real life Vatican exorcist-in-chief.

reviews.name: Austin Burke
reviews.message: It is a combination of familiar ideas and tropes that may keep viewers entertained because of a fun performance from Russell Crowe. Avery injects enough style and darkness, but the script never allows it to stand out. It falls short of being fun enough.

reviews.name: Kevin Carr
reviews.message: A noisy, murky, nonsensical, derivative horror movie wannabe.

reviews.name: Luke Y. Thompson
reviews.message: A tighter edit focused purely on the crazy bits could be a big cult hit; as is, it might be timed just right for a 4/20 viewing with plenty of smoke breaks.

reviews.name: Robert Kojder
reviews.message: Russell Crowe understands the assignment, appropriately hamming it up, but the filmmakers here are caught between having fun with this absurdity and treating certain themes and clichés too seriously

reviews.name: Matt Zoller Seitz
reviews.message: A watchable but far-from-special rehash of exorcism movie cliches.

reviews.name: Bilge Ebiri
reviews.message: The Pope’s Exorcist may not be a comedy, but it does sometimes feel like a joke. On us.

reviews.name: Pete Hammond
reviews.message: Crowe, giving us a sharp characterization of the unpredictable Amorth, is a godsend (sorry) for this movie, becoming the one genuine beacon of credibility in what is mostly a very Hollywoodized look at the subject matter.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: What it may lack in innovation, The Pope’s Exorcist readily compensates for in its spirited take on a tried and true concept.

reviews.name: Seth Freilich
reviews.message: Congrats to Mr. Crowe, who joins the pantheon of bad accent movies which runs the gamut from Kevin Costner’s Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves all the way right back to Russell Crowe and his own Robin Hood.

reviews.name: Nate Adams
reviews.message: “The Pope’s Exorcist” edges very closely into so-bad-it’s-good territory.

reviews.name: Elisabeth Vincentelli
reviews.message: Avery drives the film at a pace as caffeinated as Amorth himself, and manages to incorporate legitimate scares into a plot halfway between Indiana Jones and a Dan Brown potboiler, with camp touches worthy of Ken Russell.

title: 365 Days
description: In order to save her relationship from falling apart, a woman goes to Sicily, where she meets a dangerous man named Massimo.

characteristics.Producer:: Maciej Kawulski

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: Come for the simulated bumping and grinding, stay for the ridiculous drama, stilted acting, hilarious soundtrack, and laughably offensive ideas about male and female desire.

reviews.name: Daniel Barnes
reviews.message: This repugnant Fifty Shades knockoff plays like an erotic rewrite of The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.

reviews.name: Alejandro Turdo
reviews.message: The Room meets Beauty and the Beast, 50 Shades of Grey and the stockholm syndrome in this cheesy erotic thriller with not a single positive aspect about it. Why such a product is Netflix's top movie of 2020 baffles almost everyone.

reviews.name: María Alba
reviews.message: If you find yourself watching this make zero expectations. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Dustin Rowles
reviews.message: It's the kind of movie you fast forward to get to all the good parts, only to realize that there are no good parts.

reviews.name: Jonathon Wilson
reviews.message: It's only on the strength of its looking-good-naked leads and their palpable hot people chemistry that the film remains perversely watchable, though at two hours it's more an exercise in cinematic self-flagellation than high-trash entertainment.

reviews.name: Tracy Clark-Flory
reviews.message: Like a big-budget porn film with dramatically thinned out narrative and character development, a bunch of unambiguously abusive "foreplay" added in, and all of the hardcore elements taken out.

reviews.name: Barbara Shulgasser
reviews.message: Sex domination fantasy is graphic and violent.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: There haven't been line readings this poor since the third act of The Room...

reviews.name: Shikhar Verma
reviews.message: The problem lies in the fact that the makers of 365 Days counter every morally incorrect step with a self-aware one.

reviews.name: Peter Canavese
reviews.message: Strictly for those wondering, "what would a straight-up ripoff of 'Fifty Shades of Grey' look like if it were made in Poland?"

reviews.name: Alejandro Alemán
reviews.message: A porn movie is more honest than this trash. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Taylor Andrews
reviews.message: 365 DNI romanticizes an extremely toxic relationship, which is never okay.

reviews.name: Jessica Kiang
reviews.message: Thoroughly terrible, politically objectionable, occasionally hilarious...

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: The movie pretty much cops every move made by 50 Shades, as if it were a bible of antisexy awfulness.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: A "Fifty Shades of Grey" kidnapping porn mafia picture - softcore, of course

title: Renfield
description: In this modern monster tale of Dracula's loyal servant, Nicholas Hoult (Mad Max: Fury Road, X-Men franchise) stars as Renfield, the tortured aide to history's most narcissistic boss, Dracula (Oscar® winner Nicolas Cage). Renfield is forced to procure his master's prey and do his every bidding, no matter how debased. But now, after centuries of servitude, Renfield is ready to see if there's a life outside the shadow of The Prince of Darkness. If only he can figure out how to end his codependency.

characteristics.Rating:: R (Language Throughout|Bloody Violence|Some Drug Use|Some Gore)
characteristics.Producer:: Robert Kirkman, David Alpert, Bryan Furst, Sean Furst, Chris McKay

reviews.name: Anthony O'Connor
reviews.message: … often fun but profoundly uneven …

reviews.name: Kip Mooney
reviews.message: A gory comedy that doesn’t overstay its welcome.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: Please, for the love of God, it's a 90-minute movie--75 minutes of which are spent wondering when it's going to get back to the point.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: Ultimately undone by its self-satisfied snark and the bombastic CGI overkill decreed by the modern movie marketplace.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: The core idea of the fractured relationship between a narcissistic monster and his abused assistant is ripe for a neo-psychobabble satire with an earnest streak, but it’s frustratingly underdeveloped.

reviews.name: José Roberto Landaverde
reviews.message: Renfield strives to be innovative, and that's appreciated, though its reluctance to indulge in the macabre and absurd is noteworthy. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Renfield leaves the coffin door open for a sequel, which might be pushing the concept too far. However, there’s plenty of bite in this comedy to make it a low brow crowd pleaser.

reviews.name: tt stern-enzi
reviews.message: Nicholas Hoult brings a lot of energy and fun... he's always ready to spill into campy every once in a while too. It's a great pairing... You know Nicolas Cage is living in that world.

reviews.name: Benjamín Harguindey
reviews.message: ... Disposable entertainment that's only sellable by the presence of a star and the false promise of a novel approach to the material. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: ... A whirlwind of situations that do not take the time to justify themselves so as to not flood the path of what is already a dull-bladed blender of everything that contemporary vampire stories suggest. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: Ultra-violent, frightful thriller/horror/comedy - with wild-eyed Nicolas Cage delivering an over-the-top, campy performance.

reviews.name: Víctor López G.
reviews.message: A rollicking party you attend to see Nicolas Cage unleashed, for its explicit violence and over-the-top humor, and in which you stay for some endearing characters whom you unexpectedly end up adoring.

reviews.name: Paul Salfen
reviews.message: Cage seems to be having the time of his life hamming it up and gleefully creating a bloodbath everywhere he goes. While the comedy aspect isn't quite as sharp as the horror side, it's still a decent mix that many other films get wrong.

reviews.name: Marcelo Stiletano
reviews.message: Once again, Cage shows us that he perfectly understands what charisma means in cinema. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Hayden Mears
reviews.message: The villains, the Lobo gang, are deliciously, cartoonishly evil, and the depth of their motivations starts and stops at superficial interpretations of “control.”

reviews.name: Tim Cogshell
reviews.message: Go to the movie and have some fun. It's a gorefest, folks -- heads really roll.

reviews.name: Andy Klein
reviews.message: I think it's minor work, but it's perfectly entertaining.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: Not as funny as it could’ve been, the action scenes are horrendous, and not nearly as visually compelling as what’s implied by a New Orleans-set vampire movie starring Nicolas Cage.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: So much potential here but the comedic/dramatic delivery was much less than expected.

reviews.name: Trace Thurman
reviews.message: It's a fun enough time. Nothing more, nothing less.

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: The film is entertaining and will rejoice lovers of gore. What Renfield lacks, though, is mystery. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Matt Hudson
reviews.message: Cage really sinks his teeth into this role and the chemistry between he and Hoult sells the premise. The action is beautifully bonkers and OTT, but, with all of the assembled comedic talent, it's a shame Renfield isn't...funnier.

reviews.name: Kristen Maldonado
