reviews.message: Reinfield is a bloody good time! [...] It’s very gory, stylized, over the top, and campy [...] Nicholas Hoult is a great lead in this, I liked Awkwafina playing a role we haven’t really seen her in, and Nicolas Cage was perfectly cast.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: Cage, who can chew scenery like no human on earth, finally gets to deliver the biting (pun intended) performance he’s dreamed of since “Vampire’s Kiss” in 1988. It’s a pity, really, that Cage’s chance came in a movie that’s so … bloodless.

reviews.name: Adam Olinger
reviews.message: Renfield is so close to working and occasionally it does. Overall though, the script focuses on the wrong aspects that end up dragging the whole thing down.

reviews.name: Mark McPherson
reviews.message: Renfield manages to find fun parts of its vampire premise and sink its fangs deep enough to appreciate a Nic Cage Dracula picture.

reviews.name: Cody Leach
reviews.message: Renfield is a fun, zany, and ultra-gory good time! Nicolas Cage as a Legosi-era Dracula is something I never knew I needed in my life.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: In Renfield, Nicholas Hoult is a delight as Dracula’s much-abused personal assistant. But even Nicolas Cage as the Count himself can’t keep the movie on track.

reviews.name: Alison Gillmor
reviews.message: As the newly self-actualized Renfield would say, it is enough, and it has enough, at least for horror comedy fans looking for some light laughs and even lighter scares.

reviews.name: Ryan McQuade
reviews.message: Renfield gets too broad for its britches, and that’s unfortunate, but that being said, Cage is still really great here.

reviews.name: Rachel Ho
reviews.message: There's a lot to sink your teeth into.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...an irresistible, fun premise that’s squandered to exceedingly (and distressingly) palpable effect by McKay...

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: None of these fragments cohere into the bloody rewarding romp that may have been intended. Oh well, it’s possible to enjoy Renfield in small bites, but Bela Lugosi can rest easy.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: It’s loud, cluttered, diverting, sporadically funny, and depthless—a hectic mishmosh, but still better than most such enterprises. In other words, not exactly good, but reasonably cheering in its not-bad-ness.

reviews.name: Rachel West
reviews.message: All in all, Renfield doesn’t quite suck, but it’s not the campy vampire comedy we — or Nicolas Cage — deserve.

reviews.name: Asher Luberto
reviews.message: McKay's goal with this movie is to give the source material a new look, but he doesn't have the tools to carry out a proper makeover. This is a re(vamp)ing that could have used a little more coherence.

reviews.name: Ross Anthony
reviews.message: Despite all the blood and silliness, there's actually a warm-hearted encouraging message here. Probably won't win any oscars, but I had a great time watching it!

reviews.name: Marianna Neal
reviews.message: [Renfield] actually could have been a great, campy horror comedy, but in the end it's just a bland movie elevated by some great scenes and a great performance.

reviews.name: Chris Wasser
reviews.message: We’re constantly interrupted by some clumsy crime yarn about a cop and a gangster and their complicated family lives. That’s not what we came for... we don’t deserve Nicolas Cage -- and he deserves better than whatever this is.

reviews.name: Nick Johnston
reviews.message: Renfield suffers from a disease somewhat endemic to modern comedy, which is that, in its desperation to try and outrace the limits of its high-concept premise, it overcomplicates everything.

title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
description: It's the height of the Cold War, and famous archaeologist Indiana Jones (Harrison Ford), returning from his latest adventure, finds out his job at Marshall College is in jeopardy. He meets Mutt (Shia La Beouf), a young man who wants Indy to help him find the legendary Crystal Skull of Akator, and the pair set out for Peru. However, deadly agent Irina Spalko (Cate Blanchett) is searching for the powerful artifact, too, because the Soviets believe it can help them conquer the world.

characteristics.Producer:: Frank Marshall

reviews.name: Joe Williams
reviews.message: There are so many levels of nostalgia piled onto Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull that it’s hard to unearth a nugget of new inspiration; but the golden oldies that are doled out should dazzle those who cheer for the familiar.

reviews.name: Jack Garner
reviews.message: It's near-perfect summer fun, on par with two of its three predecessors and an ideal accompaniment for a bag of popcorn

reviews.name: Aaron Mesh
reviews.message: Crystal Skull is packed with this kind of Thrilling Wonder Stories boys' pulp, true to the series' zany serial roots and the gee-whiz mood of the '50s... A pity, then, that the third reel is such a washout.

reviews.name: Gary Wolcott
reviews.message: The fourth film in the series is everything you expected -- and more.

reviews.name: Michael Smith
reviews.message: Welcome back, Indiana Jones and Harrison Ford, the two of you have both aged well.

reviews.name: Stuart Klawans
reviews.message: As transparent as its title artifact, and just as obviously made from plastic, Crystal Skull conforms to type by offering a new version of old trash pleasures, only without the novelty.

reviews.name: Steve Persall
reviews.message: What really matters is action, and Spielberg can still shove the pedal to the metal.

reviews.name: Paul Byrnes
reviews.message: It is like seeing a dear old friend. Indiana once made us all feel we could be stronger and braver, if we tried. And he wasn't a silly modern superhero, just a guy who combined a thirst for knowledge with great courage and ingenuity.

reviews.name: Bruce R. Miller
reviews.message: Spielberg doesn't scrimp on any of the action. He sends his stars over waterfalls, into sand pits and on the run from a particularly scary army of giant ants. Sometimes, it seems like filler but with Indiana Jones, is there ever such a thing as too much?

reviews.name: Margot Harrison
reviews.message: What makes it work, besides the sheer giddiness of those Saturday-afternoon-serial-inspired stunts, is the people.

reviews.name: Chris Knight
reviews.message: [Ford] does a convincing job as an ageing adventurer not quite ready to join the museum-worthy objects he collects.

reviews.name: Craig D. Lindsey
reviews.message: Spielberg makes up for the story’s lack of cohesion (and coherence) by keeping the pacing swift and the action sequences busy.

reviews.name: Sukhdev Sandhu
reviews.message: Ford himself is absolutely fine.

reviews.name: Anthony Quinn
reviews.message: Just occasionally, you remember why you liked this stuff in the first place. The rest of the time, it just looks like Indy's battered brown fedora: old hat.

reviews.name: Eden Munro
reviews.message: While there's nothing wrong with a lightweight, thrill-a-minute Indiana Jones adventure... there’s just no excuse for taking 20 years to get around to a film that disappoints increasingly as the reels roll on.

reviews.name: Barbara Vancheri
reviews.message: Most of the two-hour adventure is pure fun, and hearing the iconic John Williams theme triggers muscle memory. Indiana Jones may not deliver the thrill of a new franchise, as Iron Man does, but it’s like catching up with an old friend.

reviews.name: Jay Stone
reviews.message: Indy's back, but I'm not sure why.

reviews.name: Katherine Monk
reviews.message: It's been close to 20 years, but the core of the Indiana Jones franchise remains well-preserved in a sticky cocoon of candy floss and coloured sugar thanks to the talents of proven cinematic confectioners Steven Spielberg and George Lucas.

reviews.name: Nicholas Barber
reviews.message: It might seem to be an odd criticism of a character we last saw chatting to the immortal guardian of the Holy Grail, but sometimes, frankly, Indy is just silly.

reviews.name: Jim Ridley
reviews.message: Indiana Jones is rescued, though, by its leading man’s uncharacteristic amusement and by its director’s palpable high spirits.

reviews.name: John Griffin
reviews.message: As hoped, the surest kicks come from daring swordfight scenes, awesome waterfalls and armies of stinging, crawling things present since the dawn of the movies.

reviews.name: Charlotte O'Sullivan
reviews.message: This is a fun watch: an antiques roadshow that, when it can be bothered, makes time fly.

reviews.name: Donald Clarke
reviews.message: Skull never quite regains the standard of its opening act, but there is cheap fun to be had throughout.

reviews.name: Rick Bentley
reviews.message: In the end, Ford shows his critics that Indiana Jones has just gotten better with age. It is a shame the franchise has not aged as well, and may be a hard sell, especially to those who grew up in the post-Indy world.

reviews.name: Christopher Kelly
reviews.message: Instead of reinventing Indiana Jones for a new era, Spielberg just makes it seem like every other summer movie cluttering the multiplex.

reviews.name: Karl French
reviews.message: Ultimately, while far from dull, this lacks the energy and wit of the first and third films, and sadly has more in common with the uninspired Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.

reviews.name: Clint O'Connor
reviews.message: Ford's charm helps make Crystal Skull greater than the sum of its parts.

reviews.name: Jeff Simon
reviews.message: A triumph -- and almost as much of a summertime gift to audiences as was intended.

reviews.name: Peter Keough
reviews.message: After the relatively exuberant opening sequences, I felt I was being beaten with pipes.

reviews.name: David Lamble
reviews.message: It's manically staged, good clean fun until the whole enterprise dissolves into a repetitive-motion syndrome, continuous loop of a story that just stops trying to make any sense at all.

reviews.name: John DeFore
reviews.message: Though the filmmakers can't resist some 21st-century indulgences that don't really belong in the series' universe, [Skull] often lives up to the thrills moviegoers have come to expect, Pavlov-style, when they hear John Williams's virile theme.

reviews.name: Eleanor O'Sullivan
reviews.message: Spielberg and Lucas have made a movie that encapsulates benchmarks of their lives and their careers, rolled all that stuff into 124 minutes of witty, headlong action and told a pretty good yarn, too.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: So many moments in this film make me want to holler out, “You still got it!” to everyone involved, especially Harrison Ford, who, 19 years later, still encapsulates what it means to be an adventure hero.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: I will never understand the hatred for the refrigerator scene. You want a low point? How about Shia LaBeouf's brash greaser Mutt Williams swinging through the trees alongside a bunch of CGI monkeys?

reviews.name: Niall Browne
reviews.message: When it was first announced, Steven Spielberg and George Lucas stated that they'd be doing this "the old fashioned way" with minimal CGI, and Janusz Kaminski would be kept on a tight leash, and wouldn't be using his "white-out" style cinematography.

reviews.name: Tony Black
reviews.message: A film long, to my mind unfairly, lambasted by critics and indeed fans, perhaps because in part it moved away from the template laid down in previous instalments.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: They've taken a character of extreme popularity and a trilogy of great admiration and added an additional chapter of unnecessary absurdity.

reviews.name: Jason Best
reviews.message: The kind of action that was funny and exciting in Raiders of the Lost Ark now looks incredibly dated.

reviews.name: Alex Maidy
reviews.message: I contend that it is a worthy addition to the Indy mythology and is actually better than another movie in the original trilogy. But yes, for Indiana Jones Crystal Skull is an interesting case study.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: I simply must give kudos to what is easily the year's most stellar cinematography from Oscar winner Janusz Kaminski.

title: The Son
description: A cautionary tale that follows a family as it struggles to reunite after falling apart. THE SON centers on Peter (Hugh Jackman), whose hectic life with his infant and new partner Beth (Vanessa Kirby) is upended when his ex-wife Kate (Laura Dern) appears at his door to discuss their son Nicholas (Zen McGrath), who is now a teenager. The young man has been missing school for months and is deeply troubled. Peter strives to take care of Nicholas as he would have wanted his own father (Anthony Hopkins) to have taken care of him while juggling his and Beth's new son, and at work an offer of a dream position in Washington. However, by reaching for the past to correct its mistakes, he loses sight of how to hold onto Nicholas in the present.

characteristics.Producer:: Iain Canning, Joanna Laurie, Karl Hartman, Emile Sherman, Christophe Spadone, Florian Zeller
characteristics.Production Co:: Neddy Dean Productions, Film4, See-Saw Films, Embankment Films, Orange Studio, Ciné@, Ingenious Media

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: The characters played by Hugh Jackman and Laura Dern are basically the upper-class equivalents of Dumb and Dumber’s Harry and Lloyd.

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: ... A film about insecurities, and in which the weight of the performances are committed and emotionally mature. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ezequiel Boetti
reviews.message: ... A cold, soulless film that watches a family fall apart without caring much about it. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: If The Father (2020) was a powerful drama that left me disarmed with astonishment, then The Son made me eye-rolling several times.

reviews.name: Guillermo Courau
reviews.message: The Son is an uncomfortable sketch about familial relationships in the 21st Century with better intentions than results. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: As much as it is full of good intentions and great performances, the film falls short, thanks to its frustrating characters, scenes of emotional manipulation, and little interest in delving into the character of Nicholas. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Benjamín Harguindey
reviews.message: The Son comes across as a melodramatic parody of the play. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: Zeller's too smart to make a truly "bad" movie, and there are some interesting ideas here... But the messaging is so blunt, and the narrative descent so predictable, it leaves little room for actual emotional engagement.

reviews.name: Mireia Mullor
reviews.message: Zeller explores family fractures that lead to denial and misunderstanding, but along the way prefers to tread commonplaces and employ emotional artifices. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Randy Meeks
reviews.message: Two interminable hours that, in the end, only work as a reminder to always take contraceptive measures. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: By the end of this soaringly mediocre film, there is not a character you wouldn’t say that to, happily.

reviews.name: Luis Martínez
reviews.message: A painful, relevant, and essentially tough film sustained by that kind of serious, solemn, quiet acting that wins so many awards.

reviews.name: Javier Ocaña
reviews.message: Devastating study on youth depression with a great Hugh Jackman. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Cameron Meier
reviews.message: The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree, the saying goes – unless you’re "The Son," which has little in common with "The Father."

reviews.name: J. Don Birnam
reviews.message: It's very simple: Do not watch this film, not even with its noteworthy cast. This is pointless, unadulterated suffering, unmoored from any sense of self or reality.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: If only The Son also spent more time showing rather than telling — indeed, with its talk-heavy screenplay always betraying the story's stage origins, it devotes almost all of its efforts to telling.

reviews.name: Brian Lloyd
reviews.message: 'The Son' disappoints because it does nothing to speak to the reality of the subject matter. Its mawkishness, its insincerity, and the stageyness - deliberate or otherwise - just underline how much of a failure it truly is.

reviews.name: Hilary A White
reviews.message: While sleekly filmed and featuring a strong cast trio in Jackman, Dern and Kirby, this unrelenting two-hour melodrama is hard work by the time it wraps up.

reviews.name: Rosalynn Try-Hane
reviews.message: The ending is predictable but the journey towards it interesting.

reviews.name: Saskia Baron
reviews.message: The film plays out as a waiting game made no less predictable by the overtly emotion-signalling Hans Zimmer score. Zen McGrath isn’t given much to work with as Nicholas and gives a fairly one-dimensional portrait of a troubled youth.

reviews.name: Rory Doherty
reviews.message: None of The Son’s ideas indicate deep empathy, none of its drama feels grounded or nuanced, and none of its characters feel like real people.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Tremendous performances are let down by The Son’s reluctance to go deeper. Mental Health is a complex and pertinent subject, and a braver approach combined with the capable cast might have made something very special.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: Hugh Jackman, Vanessa Kirby, and Laura Dern try to give their all into a story that doesn’t seem to understand the center point of its narrative or how to bring all its elements together in a coherent matter that flows together.

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: A badly misjudged melodrama, this domestic tale is bogged down in heavy handed histrionics and sentimental notes that makes you want to run away.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: Zeller explores how sadness repels; how people involuntarily recoil from depression, perpetuating the isolation of the sufferer.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: The movie has some faults but overall the story and the actors impressed me.

reviews.name: Clarisse Loughrey
reviews.message: There are no ill intentions behind The Son, but sometimes stories are so badly judged and naive in their execution that they turn ugly.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: It is simply unimaginable that in real life such well-heeled New Yorkers, for whom therapy is as much a staple of existence as the skinny soya decaf latte, would be so blindsided and befuddled by a depressive teen.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: There are some heartbreaking moments but the tone is relentlessly grim, the performances are stilted and the outcome is predictable.

reviews.name: Charlotte O'Sullivan
reviews.message: Nicholas’s pain should overwhelm us. It doesn’t, because it’s not allowed to.

reviews.name: Grant Rollings
reviews.message: Hugh Jackman takes an impressive tilt at the standards set by Hopkins, but is undone by a faulty script.

reviews.name: Emma Simmonds
reviews.message: An impossible dilemma brings the film's concerns into sharp focus, but much of what unfolds feels stiff and sanitized.

reviews.name: Danny Leigh
reviews.message: Jackman resumes conveying psychic trauma with the air of someone thinking he might have lost his car keys. But it’s the film that has the character flaw no actor could redeem.

reviews.name: Cris Kennedy
reviews.message: ... certainly a difficult watch.

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …while Jackman makes more than a decent fist of his character here, the earnest drama of The Son feels both too much and not enough…

reviews.name: Olly Richards
reviews.message: Everything is a little too self-conscious, but the longer the film goes on — and it does rather go on — the more it seems this artifice might be a deliberate choice, to make the entire world as dishonest and uncomfortable as Nicholas sees it.

reviews.name: David Sexton
reviews.message: It’s plain torture, cruelly manipulative yet also hopelessly underwritten, once taken out of the theatre, into the light.

reviews.name: Emily Breen
reviews.message: Despite the fine work from its cast (spotlighting Zen McGrath), Zeller's wayward focus detracts and dilutes the power this film always seems to be on the edge of unleashing.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: As cautionary tales go about what not to keep lying round the house when a suicidal teen is present, Zeller clearly should have paid more attention to the plausibility of such an important detail. The flub simply undercuts the rest of the film. A pity.

reviews.name: Sandra Hall
reviews.message: The actors penetrate the murk to make something very touching out of their response to the tragedy which is threatening to derail all their lives.

description: After a catastrophic crash on an unknown planet, pilot Mills (Adam Driver) quickly discovers he’s actually stranded on Earth... 65 million years ago. Now, with only one chance at rescue, Mills and the only other survivor, Koa (Ariana Greenblatt), must make their way across an unknown terrain riddled with dangerous prehistoric creatures in an epic fight to survive.

characteristics.Producer:: Sam Raimi, Deborah Liebling, Zainab Azizi, Scott Beck, Bryan Woods
characteristics.Production Co:: Raimi Productions, Beck Woods, Columbia Pictures, BRON Creative, Sony Pictures Entertainment (SPE)

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: Driver makes it all stick. It’s his first lead role in the action hero genre, and he adds depth and nuance to a thinly written role. We don’t know much about Mills, but the actor keeps us plugged in due to his ability to elevate material.

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: Confusingly bland and riddled with plot holes, 65 doesn’t give its talented lead much to work with.

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: Dreary, under-developed wannabe sci-fi action adventure that strives for suspense but plays like the kind of grade B-creature feature that used to be drive-in theater fare.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: With excellent, double-strength VFX and whole-hearted embrace of B-movie aesthetics, 65 is terrific entertainment with outstanding action cinematography giving the film a visual polish that sits several grades above what we typically see in Marvel films.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: ... It’s Just Fine in a way that renders it an acceptable 93 minutes of escapism without making you upset that you wasted your time watching it.

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: The premise doesn't hold up to close scrutiny and the narrative can be jarringly slow-paced.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: "After Earth" with little that would pass for humor and no swagger. The limited thrills and Driver's bland by-the-book approach make this play like the extremely-padded-with-filler "Twilight Zone" episode it was begging to be.

reviews.name: Tony Baker
reviews.message: It wasn't terrible... I really feel like Adam Driver and Ariana really brought some heart to the movie, that I cared about the characters.

reviews.name: Marie Asner
reviews.message: The unexpected is always just around the corner.

reviews.name: Santiago Alverú
reviews.message: An adventure that should be more like a roller coaster and less like an intimate story. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Edwin Arnaudin
reviews.message: What is this January dumping ground movie doing on screens in March?

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: Just an average sci-fi story with no chemistry between the two leads.

reviews.name: Ricardo Rosado
reviews.message: ... A fantastic premise that fails to take full advantage of its own approach and, although it wants to amuse us to the fullest, it remains an irresistible video store cover. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jorge Loser
reviews.message: 65 isn't creative at maximizing its possibilities, but... it sustains its idea with the efficiency of a sci-fi paperback. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Sean Chandler
reviews.message: "65" is from the writers of "A Quiet Place," but it lacks any of the creativity or emotion of that film. The film wastes all the potential world building in the setup, and instead delivers a bare bones "get from point A to point B" movie.

reviews.name: Jeff Ewing
reviews.message: The Adam Driver-starring thriller is a lean, mean exercise in sci-fi suspense set far in our planetary past (if only by sheer misadventure).

reviews.name: Rex Reed
reviews.message: 65 is a gruesome thing to watch, even for dinosaur lovers—and not much fun, either.

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: Driver gives a Driver-level performance and it’s a tight 90 minutes. And those two aspects alone are enough for a passable dino actioner.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: '65 operates at a pace that both manages to slog down and speed past how interesting something like this could be.

reviews.name: Dylan Roth
reviews.message: 65 is essentially a big-budget version of a simple, made-for-streaming creature feature, nothing more and nothing less.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: I amused myself by thinking of 65 reasons to walk out...

reviews.name: Armond White
reviews.message: 65 might be the first film ever based on a movie poster. Its unoriginality and witlessness follow the blatancy of most contemporary content.

reviews.name: MaryAnn Johanson
reviews.message: Adam Driver’s intensely focused, utterly unironic performance is the only saving grace of this movie of few ideas and little suspense, mystery, or excitement. There aren’t even that many dinosaurs.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: I like its simplicity and straightforwardness. I like its indifference to being something revolutionary or groundbreaking. And I like its taut 93-minute frame, which turns out to be all a movie like this needs.

reviews.name: Manuel Betancourt
reviews.message: The revelation that accompanies the title card for Scott Beck and Bryan Woods’ 65 all but demands a hearty guffaw, except this is a film that knows little of humor.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: While 65 starring Adam Driver isn’t a good movie, it does paint a dystopian portrait of terrible health insurance across the universe that is, unfortunately for us Americans, all too believable.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: It's like defending a tree sloth: unnecessary.

reviews.name: Benjamín Harguindey
reviews.message: [An] elementary sci-fi adventure of survival. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Hernán Ferreirós
reviews.message: ... The film feels like 65 million years long. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Kevin Harley
reviews.message: The action sequences are equally half-baked, leaving the dinos stripped of majesty, while a climax that echoes countless 90s disaster films is further proof that 65 has precious few ideas of its own.

reviews.name: Dex Wesley Parra
reviews.message: While there’s not enough outer space to call it an intergalactic odyssey and barely enough dino havoc, 65 has just the right amount of vigor to survive its relatively short runtime.

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: Scott Beck and Bryan Wood have written a short script. Maybe because they were in a rush, the internet ran out or they ran out of ideas and decided to milk them. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Korey Coleman
reviews.message: 65 is too repetitive and its premise is too simple. You'll be good catching it at home.

reviews.name: Ruth Maramis
reviews.message: A terribly underwhelming, suspense-free sci-fi, but still watchable thanks to Adam Driver’s commanding presence.

reviews.name: Dwight Brown
reviews.message: It wasn’t enough! Whatever they paid Adam Driver for holding this feeble movie together, it wasn’t enough.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: 65 plays like a studio film that’s had a lot of post-production meddling, not least in the way it repeatedly feels the need to explain its easy-to-grasp premise.

reviews.name: Nick Johnston
reviews.message: 65 might not be the kind of high-concept meme movie worth screeching loudly about to your friends... but it is a decently solid time at the movies,

reviews.name: Jeremy Jahns
reviews.message: A boring slog of an action… drama, sci-fi film.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A disappointing sci-fi film.

reviews.name: Matt Neal
reviews.message: 65 is as disappointing and oddly misfiring as its title. Yeah, the dinosaurs are cool, but that's about it.

title: Dark City
description: John Murdoch (Rufus Sewell) awakens alone in a strange hotel to find that he is wanted for a series of brutal murders. The problem is that he can't remember whether he committed the murders or not. For one brief moment, he is convinced that he has gone completely mad. Murdoch seeks to unravel the twisted riddle of his identity. As he edges closer to solving the mystery, he stumbles upon a fiendish underworld controlled by a group of ominous beings collectively known as the Strangers.

characteristics.Producer:: Andrew Mason, Alex Proyas
characteristics.Writer:: Alex Proyas, Alex Proyas, Lem Dobbs, David S. Goyer
characteristics.Production Co:: New Line Cinema, Mystery Clock Cinema
characteristics.Sound Mix:: Dolby A, Dolby Stereo, SDDS, Surround, Dolby SR, Dolby Digital

reviews.name: Dan DiNicola
reviews.message: The movie's design is its only redeeming feature. This is one movie which seems to have been made almost exclusively for members of a Dungeons & Dragons fan club.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: The other major item of note in the film is its visual effects. From a giant clock to a city changing before our eyes, Dark City is one of the most spectacular visual effects feats to come out in recent memory.

reviews.name: Kristy Strouse
reviews.message: Dark City is nearly a nightmare-fueled neo-noir masterpiece. It’s surreal, it’s odd, but it’s also remarkably creative and deserves to be seen.

reviews.name: Bill Boisvert
reviews.message: Real humanists may have misgivings.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: Trying for a modernized film noir mixed with gothic science-fiction, the film is a striking blend of genres and motifs.

reviews.name: Drew Dietsch
reviews.message: Dark City is unabashed in its eccentricities and relishes the hypnotic, mystifying world it creates.

reviews.name: Kathi Maio
reviews.message: If, for some reason, you have yet to see Dark City, do not hesitate to rent, tune in, or purchase it. It is one of the finest science fiction films of recent memory.

reviews.name: Sergio Benítez
reviews.message: 'Dark City' is one of those productions that, the more you see it, the more extra details and better feelings it prints. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Mike Clark
reviews.message: Dark City is fascinating, visionary filmmaking that captures the sensation of dreaming and being unable to wake up.

reviews.name: Michael Dequina
reviews.message: A visionary slice of visceral experience.

reviews.name: Jon Popick
reviews.message: Writer/Director Alex Proyas needs to stop it with the writing and concentrate on making the pretty. He needs to find a good script and just direct it.

reviews.name: Rob Vaux
reviews.message: The experience of Dark City is one that no film lover should miss... seen now as it was intended after 10 long years of wandering in the shadows.

reviews.name: Peter Canavese
reviews.message: Proyas assembles his inspirations into a unique amalgam with the power of myth to tap the fears and desires of our collective unconscious. [Blu-Ray]

reviews.name: Jesse Hassenger
reviews.message: mixes visual marvels with B-movie archetypes

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: Was "The Matrix" before "The Matrix" was ever in the pop culture lexicon...

reviews.name: Jules Brenner
reviews.message: In the annals of noir Sci-Fi, by any measure, this is a Classic of cinematic invention.

reviews.name: John J. Puccio
reviews.message: ...the movie is mostly style, but it's a style so engrossing, it more than makes up for any lack of substance.

reviews.name: Lisa Alspector
reviews.message: A mishmash of iconography lifted from better movies.

reviews.name: Todd McCarthy
reviews.message: Dark City trades in such weighty themes as memory, thought control, human will and the altering of reality, but is engaging mostly in the degree to which it creates and sustains a visually startling alternate universe.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: City ultimately plays like one of those art-deco dystopian CD-ROM adventures of recent years.

reviews.name: Rita Kempley
reviews.message: [A] stylish hybrid of futuristic thriller and film noir.

reviews.name: Andrea C. Basora
reviews.message: Proyas floods the screen with cinematic and literary references ranging from Murnau and Lang to Kafka and Orwell, creating a unique yet utterly convincing world.

reviews.name: Stephen Hunter
reviews.message: If you don't fall in love with it, you've probably never fallen in love with a movie, and never will.

reviews.name: Paul Tatara
reviews.message: This is one of those movies that's more concerned with set design motivation than anything that's going on inside the characters' heads.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: One of the most ludicrous movies in years.

reviews.name: Gary Brown
reviews.message: Dark City is a truly scary flick.

reviews.name: Pablo Villaça
reviews.message: Um verdadeiro clssico contemporneo da fico cientfica, nos presenteia com um roteiro brilhante, uma fotografia impecvel, uma direo de arte belssima e,  claro, com questionamentos filossicos incrivelmente instigantes.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: The sound and visuals of this movie are not to be missed on the big screen if at all possible.

reviews.name: Tom Charity
reviews.message: Murdoch's quandary proves surprisingly engrossing, the art direction is always striking, and unlike most contemporary sci-fi, the movie does risk a cerebral approach, tapping a vein of postmodern paranoia.

reviews.name: Anthony Miele
reviews.message: Complex, yet extremely compelling.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: An unsettling depiction of reality as elusive and ephemeral.

reviews.name: Laura Clifford
reviews.message: e of the most breathtakingly spectacular looking films to come down the pike in some time..

reviews.name: Jeffrey Overstreet
reviews.message: It's a bit overbearing the first time you experience it, but the film holds up under repeat viewings, revealing more and more complexity and coherence.

reviews.name: Eugene Novikov
reviews.message: It is a film noir that is either for teenage boys, sci-fi fanatics or movie geeks. It won't appeal to many. But if you fit into one of the above categories you will fall in love with Dark City.

reviews.name: John R. McEwen
reviews.message: The effects are breathtaking.

reviews.name: Nick Davis
reviews.message: Even if Dark City is a little off-putting in its basic approach, there is a bounty of good things to be said about it.

reviews.name: Liam Lacey
reviews.message: An almost really good movie lies somewhere in the stylish junkyard of Alex Proyas's Dark City.

reviews.name: Peter Keough
reviews.message: Proyas has, perhaps unconsciously, created an allegory of his own industry, a manufacturer of banal dreams, emotional clichs, hackneyed artifacts, and high-tech hoo-hah designed to conceal the vacancy within and without.

title: Big George Foreman: The Miraculous Story of the Once and Future Heavyweight Champion of the World
description: Big George Foreman: The Miraculous Story of the Once and Future Heavyweight Champion of the World is based on the remarkable true story of one of the greatest comebacks of all time and the transformational power of second chances. Fueled by an impoverished childhood, Foreman channeled his anger into becoming an Olympic Gold medalist and World Heavyweight Champion, followed by a near-death experience that took him from the boxing ring to the pulpit. But when he sees his community struggling spiritually and financially, Foreman returns to the ring and makes history by reclaiming his title, becoming the oldest and most improbable World Heavyweight Boxing Champion ever.

characteristics.Producer:: David Zelon
characteristics.Writer:: Frank Baldwin, George Tillman Jr., Dan Gordon
characteristics.Production Co:: Mandalay Pictures, State Street Pictures, Affirm Films

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: There’s something about it that just feels minor, like it’s not as ambitious as it probably should have been

reviews.name: Prabhjot Bains
reviews.message: Big George Foreman is not only a bad faith-based film, but it doubles as a terrible boxing movie that does a grave disservice to divinity, the sport and audiences who are duped into seeing it.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: The film is just as clunky as its ungainly title would suggest, striking a generic one-two punch that will leave viewers knocked out from sheer boredom.

reviews.name: Wade Major
reviews.message: It's a little saccharine at times... But it's really a beautiful story, and you're with it every step of the way.

reviews.name: Hosea Rupprecht
reviews.message: The films presents a sweeping view of the of life of the oldest boxer to win a heavyweight title. Unfortunately, it tries to do too much and ends up bouncing through Foreman's life with too little depth.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: I loved this movie! Khris Davis was amazing as Foreman and the whole movie played to my admiration emotions from beginning to end.

reviews.name: Collin Garbarino
reviews.message: With respectable production values and an iconic hero, it’s the kind of faith-based film that could find favor with a wider audience.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: 'Big George Foreman' is an inspiring story of a Black man rising out of poverty to make his dreams come true – and it should. However, it takes the most “don’t rock the boat” way and aligns with many films of its ilk before it.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Indeed, Foreman's story is definitely worth telling, and at least this film recounts it in an accessible, entertaining way. But it leaves us wondering about the deeper truth that's left off-screen.

reviews.name: Tom O'Brien
reviews.message: Even after the film careens from one event to another for over two hours, as the credits rolled, audience members have merely visited George Foreman but have never really gotten to know him.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: ... The script gives us the dullest kind of life-story movie: a simplified, unvarying trudge through a checklist of events.

reviews.name: Tim Cogshell
reviews.message: An excellent movie about a beloved figure who indeed seems ageless and whose story includes the kind of comebacks usually reserved for fiction.

reviews.name: Alci Rengifo
reviews.message: Tillman and Davis’s approach should be commended for putting aside other boxing movie clichés, even when the movie veers on getting a bit too corny.

reviews.name: Sandie Angulo Chen
reviews.message: This traditional biographical and faith-based drama benefits from Davis and Sullivan Jones' stand-out performances as Foreman and Ali.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: It’s solidly and safely directed by George Tillman Jr, but will likely appeal more to the Christian cinema crowd than to the sports movie audience.

reviews.name: Hope Madden
reviews.message: George’s rise to gold medals, heavyweight belts and best-selling grills has indeed been extraordinary. It deserves better than the ordinary treatment that comes from Big George Foreman.

reviews.name: Richard Brody
reviews.message: “Big George Foreman” is strong in depicting the outer life of the boxer, but when his conflicts are internal, the movie can’t meet sterner artistic demands.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Davis gives what can only be described as a breakout performance.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Like the fighter himself, it's big and bloated and  ungainly on its feet, but with a gentle charm that made this boxing legend, owner of the greatest overage comeback in sports history, a folk hero.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: If you do know something of his story [George Foreman] then you’ll see it for what it is: disappointingly humdrum and shallow.

reviews.name: Chase Hutchinson
reviews.message: The story of Foreman returning to compete in the ring after retiring is a remarkable one, but it is told here via painfully unremarkable filmmaking which crosses over into being downright manipulative with such shamelessness that it almost defies belief.

reviews.name: Robert Kojder
reviews.message: Somewhat passable during its first half, functioning as a rise to fame and wealth from nothing generic sports story that, unfortunately, becomes frequently hilariously bad once it pivots into faith-based mode

reviews.name: Paul Whitington
reviews.message: The boxing scenes are well done, only a stone would be unmoved by George’s childhood, and the relationship between George and his trainer Doc Broadus is perhaps the most interesting one in the film.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: George Foreman’s life has the making of absorbing and entertaining biopic -- this isn’t it.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: This faith-based biopic provides only Wikipedia-level insight into the fascinating life of the legendary heavyweight champion, and never feels as dynamic as its subject.

reviews.name: Julian Roman
reviews.message: Big George Foreman overcame every obstacle with incredible resolve. A star-making lead performance from Khris Davis shows how a misunderstood man continually picked himself up from the bottom.

reviews.name: John Nugent
reviews.message: An all-too conventional look at an unconventional man, Big George Foreman is, alas, a swing and a miss.

reviews.name: Edward Douglas
reviews.message: Foreman’s story is incredible to watch unfold due to the fantastic job done by Tillman and Davis in telling that story.

reviews.name: Ross McIndoe
reviews.message: The film stumbles sluggishly from one chapter in Foreman’s life to the next.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: This is a movie that doesn't quite know what it wants to do, except to give us the basics of a story that probably deserves more.

reviews.name: Sean Collier
reviews.message: Davis and his co-stars ... put in solid work, but the script is uninspired and the in-ring action is dull.

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: Davis is impressive as Foreman, but just as in real life, it is Sullivan Jones as the charming and hubris-fuelled Ali who steals every scene from under him.

reviews.name: Richard Crouse
reviews.message: Big George Foreman is a by-the-book biopic, by the way of the good book. It’s a standard, faith-based cradle to grill biography that hits the highs and some of the lows—like hiding under an open sewer pipe to avoid police—in service of its messaging.

reviews.name: Grant Rollings
reviews.message: Even Davis and Forest Whitaker, playing George's mentor Doc Broadus, can't lift an often flat-footed drama. This story... has plenty of meat. But it's never tender or raw.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: Raging Bull it is not.

reviews.name: Harry Guerin
reviews.message: An old-school, solid-rather-than-spectacular movie. Whatever shape you're in, you'll feel like more of a contender after watching it.

reviews.name: Todd McCarthy
reviews.message: Eventually, if you like boxing and are willing to accept this as a sanitized and truncated version of the full story, it’s not hard to sit back and enjoy the eventful aspects of the big man’s life and his engaging personality.

reviews.name: Radheyan Simonpillai
reviews.message: A strong filmmaking team could have made a meal of this story. Unfortunately, Tillman Jr. settles for a lousy boxing movie in service of a sermon.

reviews.name: Frank Scheck
reviews.message: It sounds like the title of a biography for young readers, and that’s pretty much how the by-the-numbers film plays.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: Mildly engaging, but often shallow, unfocused and saccharine.

title: Fast & Furious
description: When a crime brings them back to the mean streets of Los Angeles, fugitive ex-convict Dom Toretto (Vin Diesel) and agent Brian O'Conner (Paul Walker) reignite their high-octane feud. However, when a common enemy rears his head, Dom and Brian must learn how to work together and trust one another in order to defeat him.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Intense Sequences of Action|Drug References|Intense Sequences of Violence|Language|Some Sexual Content)
characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz, Vin Diesel, Michael Fottrell

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: It is undeniably nice to see the friendship built up again, as that relationship has always been a strength of the franchise. Granted, the film does take itself way too seriously...

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: A thin, oddly miserable draft of the formula that Fast Five would ultimately refine, Fast and Furious squanders its obvious potential with a dour tone and visually sloppy car chases.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: Lives up to its name during the opening moments - even before the title flashes onscreen.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: After getting off to a flying start - a prologue depicting the hijacking of a petrol tanker on a mountain pass is top-notch stuff - the film loses serious momentum due to a sluggish story.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: Provided a cinematic equivalent of NOS to the franchise with a tone shift that helped make it one of the most popular and profitable action series in the last decade.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...a combination of kinetic filmmaking and hulking charisma that can only be called bro bliss.

reviews.name: Adam Ross
reviews.message: The tagline for this film is: 'New Model, Original Parts'. It should be: 'Are you dumb enough to pay for the same film twice?'

reviews.name: Laremy Legel
reviews.message: Though I admit the title of the film is slightly dumb, I can't really fault much else going on here.

reviews.name: Dave White
reviews.message: Bummer.

reviews.name: Joshua Starnes
reviews.message: As hard as it is to believe, having the old gang back really does make a big difference, just not big enough. Lin isn't the director to offer anything new enough to make Fast & Furious worth your time unless you're a hardcore fan of the series.

reviews.name: Sam Bathe
reviews.message: Here's hoping this is the last, but after the huge amount of money it has taken already in the States, don't be surprised to see a 5th.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: Isn't worth even the most forgiving action fan's time...

reviews.name: Nick Rogers
reviews.message: One of the film's biggest laughs is showing title credits. Clearly, after a prologue in which thieves play chicken with a burning, tumbling oil tanker, the possibility exists this is a Steven Soderbergh experimental gamble. Dumb, fun & entertaining.

reviews.name: Michael Dequina
reviews.message: Lin makes the few set pieces sandwiched between the many flat, talky scenes count as much as they can.

reviews.name: Matt Soergel
reviews.message: 'Fast & Furious?' The stars of this sequel are more like Sluggish & Vaguely Grumpy, though it's nothing a little bit of fiber in their diets couldn't cure.

reviews.name: Sonny Bunch
reviews.message: 'Neat to watch' summarizes the film quite nicely. The revenge subplot that drives Fast and Furious is uninteresting since we haven't seen these characters in eight years.

reviews.name: Jordan Hoffman
reviews.message: Fast & Furious is a piece of junk, but at least it is an entertaining and endearing piece of junk. For a franchise I actively dislike, this is the best of the bunch.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Chen
reviews.message: General unoriginality contributes to 'The Fast and the Furious' series' own issue as a 'seen one, seen 'em all' series.

reviews.name: Anders Wotzke
reviews.message: If it's not fast and furious automotive action you're after, hoping instead for a cohesive character driven plot, then you're more likely to just get furious pretty damn fast.

reviews.name: Bill Gibron
reviews.message: Fast & Furious could be called Grand Theft Autopilot. Lin knows that his demographic doesn't care about truth. They want to see stuff smash up - and in as outlandish and outrageous a way possible.

reviews.name: Paul Chambers
reviews.message: A completely disposable action movie.

reviews.name: Clay Cane
reviews.message: The dialogue resembled bad '80s porn with extreme overacting and cheesy one-liners. Ironically, Fast & Furious is like porn, you want them to shut up and get to the action!

reviews.name: Sean McBride
reviews.message: works as a mindless collection of racing sequences and cool cars, made all the better because of Diesel's extremely likable bad-boy persona and a director who knows how to keep his foot on the gas, action-wise

reviews.name: Bruce Bennett
reviews.message: It definitely could have used more humor and, according to the alpha males in my viewing party, more sex appeal...and we're not talking about injectors and camshafts.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: With his sleepy-eyed gaze and biceps that no shirt can contain, Diesel quietly commands the movie.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: What's amazing about this loud, lazy film (they couldn't even be bothered to give it a title) is that it's still entertaining

reviews.name: Lori Hoffman
reviews.message: With Diesel anchoring the storyline, and director Lin dazzling us with his car crashing extravaganzas, Fast & Furious will likely unleash another series of sequels.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: What is this, the fourth 'Fast and Furious' movie?

reviews.name: Peter Canavese
reviews.message: Furious entertainment for a moment of "populist rage." But it's hard to escape the feeling that Fast & Furious is more than a little...mechanical.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: The ending leaves just enough of a cliffhanger that a fifth installment is all but guaranteed. If it's anything like this one, I'm down for the ride.

reviews.name: Julie Rigg
reviews.message: The latest film is extremely noisy, features some fine stunt driving, particularly in its opening sequence, but it's dramatically a bit of a dribbler. I'm still trying to figure out the relationship between the opening of the film and the ending.

reviews.name: Julian Shaw
reviews.message: Diesel's bassoon-voiced, low-watt charisma seems best placed in this franchise, and there is an undeniable spark with his foil Walker, who's all white teeth and Californian tan.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: Early, pre-credit scenes are so meticulously choreographed and expertly edited that you just cannot wait for the real film to begin. However, minutes later, you can't help wishing the thing would just hurry up and finish.

reviews.name: Paul Byrnes
reviews.message: There are only a couple of things to be said about this movie: the cars are fast, the racing is faster and none of it makes the slightest bit of sense.

reviews.name: Margaret Pomeranz
reviews.message: The soundtrack pounds away as the cars compete in the most unbelievable races with so many quick cuts and CGI that you hardly know who's where in relation to anyone else. But it doesn't matter.

reviews.name: Christopher Tookey
reviews.message: The film appears to have been not so much directed as welded together out of other bad movies that have crashed and burned.

reviews.name: David Edwards
reviews.message: As far as car chase movies go, it's right on the money with great action scenes, terrible dialogue and some seriously sub-par acting.

reviews.name: Anthony Quinn
reviews.message: "Ride or die, remember?" Er, not really, no. More like "Yawn and forget", as Nabokov once recommended. Only 13-year-old boys and Jeremy Clarkson could possibly enjoy this.

title: Soft & Quiet
description: Playing out in real time, SOFT & QUIET is a runaway train that follows a single afternoon in the life of an elementary school teacher, Emily, who organizes an inaugural club meeting of like-minded women. When they all decide to move the meeting to Emily's house to keep the wine flowing, they stop at the local store to pick up refreshments. At the store, an altercation breaks out between a woman from Emily's past and the group, leading to a volatile chain of events.

characteristics.Producer:: Joshua Beirne-Golden, Josh Peters, Saba Zerehi, Beth de Araújo

reviews.name: Elissa Suh
reviews.message: The committed depiction of the characters’ moral malevolence forces you into submission. You’re made to feel complicit and the curtain-drop ending falls flat.

reviews.name: Brian Costello
reviews.message: It's not a movie one will easily forget. It's a drama-horror that reminds us that the people who seem like the most ordinary of citizens can be as horrific as hockey mask-wearing axe murderers, if not more so.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Disquieting, discomfitting and disturbing almost on a molecular level

reviews.name: Javier Ocaña
reviews.message: A Ku Klux Klan made up of affable smiles, wounded spirits, and perverse aggression. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: C.H. Newell
reviews.message: All at once, Soft & Quiet tackles racism, as well as the role many white women play in upholding white supremacy, and how white women use toxic masculinity to help patriarchy operate to its fullest, best extent.

reviews.name: Kristian M. Lin
reviews.message: This thriller made to look like it was shot in one take will give you unpleasant flashbacks, because it’s so good at capturing that particular brand of resentment and entitlement...

reviews.name: Peg Aloi
reviews.message: Beth de Araújo is a brave and bold new filmmaker and this feature debut is nothing short of stunning.

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
reviews.message: Unfortunately, this devolves into watching trauma for trauma's sake without the redemptive arc of a comeuppance for the villains.

reviews.name: Mary Beth McAndrews
reviews.message: From incredible performances to the tense long take that builds to an explosive finale, Soft & Quiet is a contender for the scariest movie of not just 2022, but of the 21st century.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Writer/director Beth de Araújo’s feature debut is an incendiary single take on racism’s shift from clubby theory to ugly praxis

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: writer/director Beth de Araújo builds the momentum so well and the performances are so insidiously effective that it works despite its obviousness

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: This what-if miniature may strike some as a bit hyperbolic, but it cannily illustrates how people who think of themselves as upstanding citizens can whip themselves into a reactionary frenzy ...

reviews.name: Joel Harley
reviews.message: As a home invasion movie, it’s more Hate Crime than The Purge – loud, upsetting and genuinely difficult to watch. This is easily the most horrifying film of the year.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Go in blind, but be warned and keep your guard up. This is how you do social horror.

reviews.name: Harvey S. Karten
reviews.message: The message is that once you hate, there is no telling what you may do. Mission accomplished.

reviews.name: Joe Friar
reviews.message: Beth de Araújo introduces us to the new face of horror and terrifyingly she’s probably someone you know. It could be the most unnerving film to carry the Blumhouse signature.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Brazen hate speech remains scary because it still only represents a small portion of the discourse behind closed doors. Director Beth de Araújo takes this issue head-on with her stunning debut thriller.

reviews.name: Matthew St. Clair
reviews.message: Soft and quiet, this movie definitely isn't.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: At 90 minutes, it is a long time to spend in a movie full of misery and unseemly actions. It gets its job done, but I’m unsure if this is the harrowing journey I needed.

reviews.name: Jon Mendelsohn
reviews.message: Soft & Quiet has all the reasons to exist but should be watched at the viewer's own risk because it is not afraid to go as far as possible to effectively make its point.

reviews.name: David Fear
reviews.message: The formal conceit forces you, in fact, to pay attention to how easily combustible incidents like the ones you see in Soft & Quiet are, and acknowledge how embedded into our modern firmament this prettified poison is now.

reviews.name: Igor Fishman
reviews.message: [Soft & Quiet is] a misguided film that traps its audience inside of a hate crime, uncertain how to tie up the difficult array of themes it broaches, as it barrels on its repulsive trajectory; a caustic sadism on autopilot.

reviews.name: Katie Rife
reviews.message: Soft & Quiet is extremely effective as a piece of educational agitprop.

reviews.name: Natalia Keogan
reviews.message: Soft & Quiet succeeds precisely because it adopts risky narrative elements, intensifying the disquieting anxiety inherent to witnessing an atrocity as it plays out before one’s very eyes.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: It starts out as an intense and ultimately necessary confrontation of modern America. Unfortunately, the stylistic gimmick of a long, unbroken take ends up limiting the film’s perspective and, in its final half hour, hastening its downfall.

reviews.name: Carlos Aguilar
reviews.message: Within 90 minutes, their monstrous worldview turns them into murderous home invaders, and though the timeframe is arguably an exaggeration, it gets the point across succinctly.

reviews.name: Beatrice Loayza
reviews.message: The film is a palpable joyride steered by the kinds of women who, de Araújo seems to think, could easily get away with it.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: This is a purposefully disturbing thriller that sounds a loud-and-clear call to pay attention. It leaves you shook.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: [T]he ... vital element is in how Soft & Quiet depicts the inescapable escalation of thoughts, to words, and, finally, to actions.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: For genuine, stomach-churning horror, Michael Myers, Pennywise the Clown, and the whole pantheon of the Cthulhu Mythos have nothing on the women of Soft & Quiet.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: The easy flow of de Araújo’s film and the intensity of its characters makes it easy to miss just what an impressive achievement it is at a technical level.

reviews.name: Jason Adams
reviews.message: The innocence of the American Dream is befouled, and this brave movie looks the filth of it straight in the face. It's the truest sort of horror -- the one too horrible to be anything but true.

reviews.name: Rob Aldam
reviews.message: Soft & Quiet goes to places other films fear to tread.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: The first act lives up to its tile, drawing people in even though there is definitely something wrong. . As Soft & Quiet ups the stakes, things become more visceral, disgusting, and sad. You won't be able to turn away even though you want to.

reviews.name: J Hurtado
reviews.message: Once the veneer of civility fades in the first twenty minutes of Soft & Quiet, it truly becomes something to behold.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: So repulsive that any intelligent societal critiques that were to be made are overshadowed by the vile dialogue and subject matter.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A purposefully unpleasant cautionary tale about white supremacy.

reviews.name: R. Colin Tait
reviews.message: "Soft and Quiet"  begins as subtly as its title implies. It sneaks up on you. By the time you realize what its actually about, its too late and you are swept into a narrative (and a world) that you do not want to be a part of.

reviews.name: Kathia Woods
reviews.message: This movie had a chance to say something responsibly instead it went for trauma porn. It's extremely irresponsible to glamourize racism especially when Asian Americans are still actively being attacked.

reviews.name: John Fink
reviews.message: To say Soft & Quiet is designed to get your blood boiling is an understatement.

title: Furious 7
description: After defeating international terrorist Owen Shaw, Dominic Toretto (Vin Diesel), Brian O'Conner (Paul Walker) and the rest of the crew have separated to return to more normal lives. However, Deckard Shaw (Jason Statham), Owen's older brother, is thirsty for revenge. A slick government agent offers to help Dom and company take care of Shaw in exchange for their help in rescuing a kidnapped computer hacker who has developed a powerful surveillance program.

characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz, Vin Diesel, Michael Fottrell

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: The film features some wild stunts and really drives home the family theme that has come to dominate the series.

reviews.name: Olly Richards
reviews.message: A heartfelt send-off, giving this entry more emotional weight than would be usual. Its primary focus, however, is still on being absurdly entertaining.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: But let’s be honest and true, nobody goes to a “Fast and Furious” movie for the performances. It’s all about the cars and the action. We get a lot of both.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: Your brain cells will be pummeled into submission over the course of an overlong two-hours-and-seventeen-minutes; your tolerance for subpar acting will be tested, and then some; but those in the mood for such diversions will be delighted.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Nearly a decade later, Furious 7, the sixth  sixth  sequel in the fascinating Fast and the Furious franchise, takes seemingly-impossible stunts to a whole new level  rather, a whole new solar system.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: The zenith of the series' inspired ridiculousness before it began feeling overegged, Furious 7 offers a strong tribute to Paul Walker and would've frankly been a mighty ending for the entire enterprise.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: Furious 7 is something to see, strictly for the pure adrenaline and entertainment.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: The true shame is that, despite zero constraints on the magnitude of potential action sequences, few of the extravagant set pieces actually contain anything conceptually new.

reviews.name: Tony Asankomah
reviews.message: Fast & Furious 7 certainly is the Ultimate tribute to Paul Walker; some of the scenes just make you want to cry...

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: After losing one of the stars in 2013, Furious 7 brings emotion as they always have.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Essentially an action-packed and thrilling adventure with a thread of humanity.

reviews.name: Kelechi Ehenulo
reviews.message: Despite the faults, Fast and Furious 7 is every bit as entertaining as its predecessors with an emotional weight that holds the film together for all the right reasons.

reviews.name: Allen Almachar
reviews.message: There's a sincerity here that packs a surprisingly emotional counterpoint to the action.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: Watching Furious 7, you get the distinct impression that, when faced with a creative choice, the filmmakers paused to ask themselves, "What's the most insane, over the top thing we can do here?" Then they went ahead and did that.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: [Delivers] entertaining stunt action and [combines] it with a fun plot that not only keeps its sense of humor, but also contains a good deal of heart and emotion.

reviews.name: Brandon Davis
reviews.message: If you leave logic at the door, buy the biggest popcorn bucket the theater has to offer, and want to have fun- Furious 7 is the film that will take you on the ride you're looking for.

reviews.name: Kirsten Acuna
reviews.message: "Furious 7" is probably one of the most ridiculous non-stop action rides you'll see this year. It's also probably one of the few action films which will also reduce you to tears by its end.

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: Convoluted as the story is, the way they say goodbye to Paul was well done and really very poignant.

reviews.name: Ryan Syrek
reviews.message: "Do we really need another Fast and Furious movie?" No. No we do not. We also didn't need to land on the moon. Nor did we need to create the 1967 Ford Mustang. We did it because it was awesome and we could, dammit.

reviews.name: Dominic Griffin
reviews.message: We want these films to go on forever, and perhaps they will; but, for now, this is a fine film to ride off into the sunset to.

reviews.name: Phil W. Bayles
reviews.message: If this is the end of an era, it's ended on a high note.

reviews.name: Richard Lawson
reviews.message: Furious 7 is respectful, even solemn, when it needs to be, but is still, thank God, plenty of crazy fun.

reviews.name: Josh Dickey
reviews.message: We deserve better than this.

reviews.name: David Crow
reviews.message: There is a genuine emotional resonance to Furious 7 that is painfully real.

reviews.name: Perri Nemiroff
reviews.message: Furious 7 is certainly a popcorn movie geared towards delivering big thrills, but it's also oozing with heart and passion.

reviews.name: Russ Fischer
reviews.message: Why are you even reading a Furious 7 review?

reviews.name: Tara Brady
reviews.message: Director James Wan (Saw, The Conjuring) may be a dab hand at things that go bump in the night, but action is not his strong point.

reviews.name: Armond White
reviews.message: Furious 7 works on the simplest level: Bad guys die, good guys win. Success.

reviews.name: TK Burton
reviews.message: You'll walk about with a half-smile, feeling vaguely like you got hit in the back of the head, but in a way that's strangely satisfying.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: With Furious 7 they were trying to make an over the top action film and they do a great job with it.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: It never takes itself too seriously. It's that playful ability to realize its own absurdity that has helped elevate the franchise as it continues to grow -- both in film numbers and cast members.

reviews.name: Amanda Greever
reviews.message: But perhaps, what"Furious 7 does best is the simple, eloquent tribute to Walker at the end of the film.

reviews.name: Marisa Carpico
reviews.message: While the movie succeeds spectacularly where Walker and his character Brian are concerned, it's far from the franchise's best installment.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: The action is huge and outrageous and plentiful and inventive, all good attributes here.

reviews.name: James Clay
reviews.message: FURIOUS 7 has found the proper transmission to provide what viewers will expect: little brains and a ton of brawn (and for the first time in a long time, that's perfectly fine).

reviews.name: Zaki Hasan
reviews.message: No matter how you feel about these films, the seventh one isn't going to suddenly change your opinion.

reviews.name: Jennifer Heaton
reviews.message: It's an entertaining and carefree party of a movie from start to finish, screaming nonsense at the top of its voice and paying no attention to the obvious illogic in its thinking.

reviews.name: Aaron Peterson
reviews.message: Fast cars, gorgeous characters, adrenaline pumping action, and an ending that warms the heart. This franchise isn't for everyone, but it's definitely for me.

reviews.name: Molly Templeton
reviews.message: Furious 7 is full of absurd, intricate stunt sequences that are quite gleeful in their lack of bearing on reality.

reviews.name: Pamela Powell
reviews.message: This constant bombardment just becomes boring.

title: The Artifice Girl
description: A team of special agents discovers a revolutionary new computer program to bait and trap online predators. After teaming up with the program's troubled developer, they soon find that the AI is rapidly advancing beyond its original purpose.

characteristics.Producer:: Aaron B. Koontz, Ashleigh Snead
characteristics.Production Co:: Paper Street Pictures, Last Resort Ideas, Blood Oath

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: Balancing difficult conversations about where technology is leading the human race with rapid fire dialogue and performance driven drama, The Artifice Girl is both a rarity and one of the biggest surprises of the year thus far.

reviews.name: Shikhar Verma
reviews.message: In a world that is full of movies that twist the idea of AI into a villainous narrative, the talky and philosophical ‘The Artifice Girl’ takes a tender approach to conscience and what it means to understand right from wrong.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: It’s a surprisingly tender drama of ideas that at times reminded me of a variation on the 2001 Spielberg/Kubrick film “A.I. Artificial Intelligence.”

reviews.name: Romey Norton
reviews.message: Probing ethical implications around the use of A.I. is current and, indeed, something we will see more of in our storylines. (Maybe they’ll even be written by an A.I.).

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Franklin Ritch’s sci-fi sees a team hunting sexual predators while tackling the ethics of technological singularity

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: Franklin Ritch has fashioned a brilliantly creepy and thoughtful piece of speculative fiction that smartly uses the confined space of its budget-saving interrogation room setting to amplify the intrusive nature of AI in our daily lives.

reviews.name: Noel Murray
reviews.message: The action is in the dialogue, which presents a series of invigorating arguments about where the ethical lines are when it comes to creating and then exploiting an intelligent computer program.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: It’s an assured, adventurous film of ideas, albeit one I found easier to admire than be emotionally engaged by.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl is top-notch science-fiction and dramatic storytelling, with an unexpected intimacy that makes me eager to see what Ritch brings us next.

reviews.name: Robert Kojder
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl succeeds as a stagey moral drama

reviews.name: Sheila O'Malley
reviews.message: A thought-provoking film that examines the ethics of A.I., moving into even the existential aspects of the concept of artificial intelligence.

reviews.name: Daniel M. Kimmel
reviews.message: “The Artifice Girl” is the sort of small, intelligent science fiction film that proves the genre is capable of much more than the special effects extravaganzas churned out by Hollywood.

reviews.name: James Perkins
reviews.message: Ritch’s expert writing and raw acting as this troubled yet determined genius manages to give audiences plenty to ponder on whilst also addressing very real issues in a sensitive fashion...

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: Despite the strong opening of The Artifice Girl, most of it never finds a way to make this not-so-great debate compelling as drama.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Tells in a flat way about the ethics of AI used online to trap pedophiles.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: Very human story about advancing technology is filled with strong performances while boasting an engaging story. As much a character study as science fiction.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: Provocative and timely, but concurrently exhausting and monotonous.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: One of the most tedious, monotonous movies I’ve ever seen.

reviews.name: Mae Abdulbaki
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl is engaging & compelling, bolstered by stellar performances from its cast & exceeds where other AI-focused stories might falter.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Ritch has made a no-budget indie they should screen and use as instruction and inspiration in film schools.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: Ritch maintains enough tension via filmmaking craft, and his cast via intensity of psychological dynamics, that this very talky, nearly action-free drama never grows ponderous.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A sophisticated and provocative sci-fi story about artificial intelligence, ethics, science, and humanity, the film is a cerebral work that is very demanding of its audience.

reviews.name: Meagan Navarro
reviews.message: It’s in the measured layering of complicated character work and ethical conundrums that Ritch’s feature eventually finds its magic.

reviews.name: Jonathan DeHaan
reviews.message: What starts as a dark crime thriller slowly reveals itself to be a really well thought out, dialogue driven low-fi science fiction tale of humanity.

reviews.name: Stephanie Malone
reviews.message: A stellar sci-fi drama as compelling as it is provocative, "The Artifice Girl" explores the intersection of AI and human ethics — treading into profound philosophical considerations regarding the value of existence and what it means to be happy.

reviews.name: Molly Henery
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl is a thought-provoking sci-fi thriller shedding a compassionate and emotional light on ethical issues.

reviews.name: Keri O'Shea
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl asks, ‘What are we doing?’, stops off at the rhetorical, ‘Oh god, what have we done?’ and then heads over to, ‘Well, what should we do?’

reviews.name: Daniel Gorman
reviews.message: If a computer program can learn to affect human emotions by imitating them, at what point does the line blur and the emotions become real? Ritch seems to have his mind made up, although some viewers might not be so convinced.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl stands to grow more relevant every day, and the questions it asks are evergreen. It’s quite an accomplishment and should be treated as such.

reviews.name: Richard Whittaker
reviews.message: It's a complex and captivating sci fi fable... but told with touching intimacy.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: A stroke of science-fiction genius, Franklin Ritch’s The Artifice Girl is a commanding analysis of the murky waters that AI development presents.

reviews.name: Andrew Murray
reviews.message: Exploring the murky and morally grey areas surrounding artificial intelligence with philosophical depth and keen observation, Ritch’s sharply written handling of the topics raised is a timely meditation on our possible future with technology.

reviews.name: Caitlyn Downs
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl is weighty, engrossing work, showcasing exactly what sci-fi has to offer in terms of thinking about the world around us.

reviews.name: Jacob Oller
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl shows promise from writer/director/star Ritch in his ability to take a sharp sci-fi idea to the finish line, but it needs far more imagination to pull off its artifice.

reviews.name: Allan Hunter
reviews.message: [A] smart, dialogue-heavy sci-fi thriller which explores qualms about the use of increasingly sophisticated digital technologies to attract and potentially trap online child predators.

reviews.name: Andrew Todd
reviews.message: If you thought the ethics of what’s being done at Boston Dynamics and ILM were unsettling before, wait until The Artifice Girl creeps into your brain.

reviews.name: C.H. Newell
reviews.message: Like any profound work of sci-fi, The Artifice Girl makes us question ourselves and our sense of morality by using sci-fi to push the horizons of our mind beyond the limits of society’s general conscience/consciousness.

reviews.name: J Hurtado
reviews.message: [S]ets a new template for speculative fiction on screen... the fact that this is Ritch's debut feature is absolutely astonishing

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Smarter than most films of its ilk and refreshingly free of misplaced sentiment.

reviews.name: Jon Mendelsohn
reviews.message: The Artifice Girl showcases intriguing ideology and a stellar performance from its young star but suffers by showing and not telling.

title: A New Old Play
description: One evening in the 1980s, Qiu Fu, a leading clown in 20th-century Sichuan opera, departs this world and must reluctantly set off for the Ghost City under the escort of two underworld officials. Along the way, he meets old friends. As they recall the past, earthly scenes creep into the mists of the Netherworld. Qiu Fu's life in opera unfolds against the backdrop of a secular upheaval. The "New-New" Troupe in which he grows up and learns his trade is affiliated with the military. As power shifts, the troupe is cast loose to wander rootlessly through a broken world. Despite this unsettled destiny, shaped by war, famine and political turmoil, Qiu Fu becomes one of the finest clown-role performers in Sichuan opera. And yet, one day he finds himself clapped in a pigsty as a political revolution rages outside. Outside the Ghost City, sitting among familiar faces, Qiu Fu drinks the mandatory bowl of Forgetfulness Soup to erase his memory. A lifetime of hardship, pain and sorrow, all vanish as if they had never been.

characteristics.Producer:: Ding Ding, Yang Jin

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: An amazingly tense film for fans of Chinese opera and Chinese politics.

reviews.name: Calan Panchoo
reviews.message: It is as multilayered as the traditions of old and as daring as the convictions of new.

reviews.name: Kathy Fennessy
reviews.message: At 179 minutes, A New Old Play might seem like a daunting watch, except it's a lively, lovely film, even in the saddest moments.

reviews.name: Sean Gilman
reviews.message: Occupying something of a middle ground between Hou's The Puppetmaster and Chen's Farewell My Concubine as a history of 20th century China as seen through the eyes of a theatrical performer, A New Old Play is an unusual kind of epic.

reviews.name: David Bax
reviews.message: A New Old Play is as entertaining to watch as it is deeply moving.

reviews.name: Diane Carson
reviews.message: At three hours running time, director Qiu Jiongjiong’s A New Old Play demands and rewards patience with a chronicle of Chinese history from the 1920s through the 1980s.

reviews.name: Richard Brody
reviews.message: Qiu Jiongjiong tells this story with affecting intimacy and candid observation—and with archly ironic methods.

reviews.name: Ryan Swen
reviews.message: [Qiu] implicitly puts himself in the lineage of these performers and artists who have contributed to a rich Chinese folk tradition. On the strength of A New Old Play, such a gesture is more than earned.

reviews.name: Austin Considine
