reviews.name: Alton Williams
reviews.message: Scream VI is a great slasher movie for a new generation that is sure to please fans of the original movies.

reviews.name: Paul Salfen
reviews.message: Another sequel in the super self-aware franchise that finds itself rebooting again with just enough familiarity and predictable retreads mixed with fresh jolts of horror in what is an often seen-it-all-before genre.

reviews.name: J. Don Birnam
reviews.message: The franchise manages to stay entertaining with freshly inventive horror sequences, but its failure to adhere to its own self-professed "rules" for who should die in a sequel spells trouble and could spell further problems.

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: These movies are now effectively nothing more than parodies of themselves, and parodies of parodies are eventually a dead end in more ways than one.

reviews.name: Alex Bentley
reviews.message: Unless filmmakers are able to inject some new ideas into the mix, it might be best to let the series die, once and for all.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: I’ve always appreciated the humor in these films, but by the time things go wholly over the top for the finale this time, the joking has run its course.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: The Big Apple has just enough bite to make Scream VI worthwhile... (but) In an era when elevated horror is winning Oscars, this rule-breaker from the past can’t seem to be anything other than a retro diversion.

reviews.name: Bob Chipman
reviews.message: I'm still not a 'fan' of this franchise, but I can't say it isn't doing its job at this point.

reviews.name: Derek Sante
reviews.message: Honestly, it felt like more of a comedy with lots of blood, than a horror movie that was supposed to frighten.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: Hits all the right notes a "Scream" thriller requires.

reviews.name: Kristen Maldonado
reviews.message: There are some gruesome and high stakes sequences. They tap into franchise rules with big budget, big cast, but also subverted expectations and do the opposite of what you’d expect. The Scream franchise gets more bolder and more creative as it goes along.

reviews.name: Tony Baker
reviews.message: It was solid. It was entertaining. It was exciting.

reviews.name: Sean Chandler
reviews.message: Another solid entry in the consistent franchise. By moving the action to New York City it adds just enough newness to keep things fresh in the long running franchise.  This time around the kills are also a lot more brutal.

reviews.name: Christian Toto
reviews.message: Slasher franchise brings meta rants, gore and surprising amount of fun.

reviews.name: Andy Klein
reviews.message: The first one that is really a step down... Having said that, it's still a fun ride.

reviews.name: Trace Thurman
reviews.message: Pull Quote: With higher stakes and some truly suspenseful (and fun!) set pieces, Scream VI might be the best Scream sequel since Scream 2.

reviews.name: JD Duran
reviews.message: SCREAM VI is painting with a broader brush in regards to franchises while also channeling what was so great about SCREAM 2.

reviews.name: Kimber Myers
reviews.message: With Scream VI, Scream (2022) filmmakers Matt Bettinelli-Olpin and Tyler Gillett are so interested in reinventing Wes Craven’s saga and keeping audiences guessing and grossed out that they’ve made a film that makes no impact at all.

reviews.name: Justin Brown
reviews.message: I really enjoyed this and appreciated that the new setting gave the series new blood. There's a lot of things that didn't add up but it's so much fun that I can ignore it for the most part.

reviews.name: Brandon Collins
reviews.message: For the sixth entry in the series, this was a great adjustment from the past two entries in giving us a new setting and an incredible opening sequence. My main gripe is that the writers have to do better with the "murder mystery" element...

reviews.name: Tatiana Albandos
reviews.message: The New Yorker in me just couldn't get over some of the logistical details of the characters and their surroundings. However this was very entertaining and a nice update on a series that has had long legs.

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: Don’t be shocked if there are more laughs and whoops in the cinema than there are shrieks and gasps – but Scream has never tried to take itself too seriously which has always been part of the charm.

reviews.name: Ed Whitfield
reviews.message: One’s left with the sense that the series has some untapped potential.

reviews.name: Stephanie Archer
reviews.message: Scream VI is a love letter to horror, to a franchise, and to its fans, proving that not all stories are dead.

reviews.name: Isaac Feldberg
reviews.message: Too cliche-riddled and irony-poisoned to avoid collapsing into exactly the sort of artificial franchise extension Craven would have slashed to ribbons.

reviews.name: MontiLee Stormer
reviews.message: The opening sequence points out modern sensibilities mingled with basic human fallibility, and every kill sequence is an original that doesn’t rely on recycled ideas. The action is fast-paced, the dialogue is kept conversational, and it’s clever.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: More brutal than ever, this new entry manages to keep the legacy of the popular franchise alive, while delivering an ingenious mix of thrills, humor, and nostalgia. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Joe Lipsett
reviews.message: An enjoyable continuation of the franchise from Radio Silence, carried by the relationship between the Core Four and featuring stand-out city set pieces involving ladders and subways. Killer reveal and motivation is fine, but not on par with Scream 2

reviews.name: Joey Keogh
reviews.message: Bettinelli-Olpin and Gillett are more confident this time around, taking more risks and putting their own spin on a franchise that they were maybe too fond of as fans to truly experiment with during the previous film.

reviews.name: Stacey Yvonne
reviews.message: The point, it turns out, is perseverance, pluck, and accepting all parts of yourself, even the villainous.

reviews.name: Alex Barr
reviews.message: Speeding through a switchback road of finger pointing, red herrings and deception, the film will surprise and confuse even the most ardent Wes Craven fans until the final seconds.

reviews.name: Chris Wasser
reviews.message: The dreaded Ghostface has, indeed, relocated to Manhattan for another round of gruesome slasher carnage. Does it enhance the story at all? Don’t be daft.

title: The Menu
description: A couple (Anya Taylor-Joy and Nicholas Hoult) travels to a coastal island to eat at an exclusive restaurant where the chef (Ralph Fiennes) has prepared a lavish menu, with some shocking surprises.

characteristics.Rating:: R (Some Sexual References|Language Throughout|Strong Violent Content)
characteristics.Producer:: Adam McKay, Betsy Koch, Will Ferrell

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: stylish and engrossing and sadistically enjoyable

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: The art of the meal and the consumer’s craving for more more s’more are just two of the topics explored in a far tastier “eat the rich” offering than the overcooked Triangle of Sadness.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: Never the thought and vision of a cheeseburger made such an impression on me. And by this time your appetite should be big for both the food and the movie.

reviews.name: Audra Schroeder
reviews.message: The story, penned by Will Tracy and Seth Reiss, is expertly paced, punctuated by gorgeous title cards announcing the dishes.

reviews.name: Bob Chipman
reviews.message: Bad pretentious art that thinks it's critiquing bad pretentious art, told exclusively through the medium of food metaphors? ...yay.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: It’s a slow-building revelation that will result in a gasp, and then it just builds on the “out there” abilities of a thriller/horror hybrid. Come for Ralph Fiennes, but stay for the outrageously bizarre finale.

reviews.name: Eleanor Ringel Cater
reviews.message: As horror-satire goes, The Menu isn’t especially sophisticated. And true foodies can probably poke holes in every course. But in its own insistently odd way, the film is a good deal of palate-cleansing fun.

reviews.name: Brian Gill
reviews.message: Finally, we have the definitive proof that American cheese on a burger is good.

reviews.name: Patrick Hicks
reviews.message: Mark Mylod brings a healthy balance of entertainment and satire to his audience, accented by delicious performances from a cast of characters that make us question what a fine dining experience should look like.

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: Dark, wry, scathing, and utterly riveting, The Menu serves a deliciously twisted treat.

reviews.name: Alexandra MacAaron
reviews.message: Both 'Glass Onion' and 'The Menu' owe some of their success and much of our enjoyment to the late, great Lady Mallowan. We are deep into Agatha Christie territory here.

reviews.name: Ryan McQuade
reviews.message: It's a movie that I was enjoying with each bite as it was going along, because it's not just about culinary obsession...but it's a damning criticism of how we consume art.

reviews.name: Pablo Villaça
reviews.message: Its critical view of the economic elite is one that Cinema, as a politically dynamic Art, reflects with increasing frequency in a reality in which social inequalities become greater and greater. [Full review in Portuguese]

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: .... "The Menu" is a delicious treat from appetizer to dessert, balancing the sweet and savory to offer a unique experience that ultimately reminds audiences not to f*** with the people who serve you.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: The Menu starts off intriguing, but eventually gets too bogged down becoming the very thing it’s spoofing.

reviews.name: Mattie Lucas
reviews.message: Mylod has some fun with it, and Fiennes does some delicious work. But its eat the rich allegories are half-baked at best.

reviews.name: Sam Haysom
reviews.message: Splicing horror and comedy with skill and delight, the movie is a satire of class, privilege, and pretension that's also at its core a supremely entertaining story.

reviews.name: Sol Harris
reviews.message: ... A genuinely hilarious send-up of everything in the world of art, from those who create to those who consume. While this isn’t unique subject matter, the way that the plot unfolds is.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: Little by little, its plot loses its intriguing effect and ends up becoming a tasteless dish. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Konstantina Buhalis
reviews.message: This is a brilliant and intricate understanding of how art is the root of culture, and when there is no other purpose left for it, the artist resorts to self-immolation for the survival of creation.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: Pretty enjoyable on its own terms, and as long as you don't need it to be too precise in its satiric aims.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: A wickedly delicious satire of fine dining obsession.

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: Neither fun nor scathing, funny nor insightful, the film coasts on second-rate quips and third-rate violence.

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: This sinister, satirical dark comedy is undoubtedly one of the most bizarrely absurd thrillers of the year, skewering pretentious 'foodies' and the 'fine dining' they crave.

reviews.name: Kristen Maldonado
reviews.message: Led by Anya Taylor-Joy and Ralph Fiennes, the film explores classism and wealth through the performative lens of food and nostalgia.

reviews.name: Santanu Das
reviews.message: Anya Taylor-Joy anchors a wickedly entertaining satire.

reviews.name: Steph Cozza
reviews.message: The "eat the rich" movie of the year.

reviews.name: Brandon Judell
reviews.message: A tingling black comedy awash with thrills, wit, and well-earned heartburn. Reaching for the Tums has never been so much fun.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: A competently prepared dish that would like to be thought of, ultimately, as a well-made cheeseburger.

reviews.name: Kevin Sampson
reviews.message: The visually intimate and beautiful set, slowly turns into a claustrophobic and horrifying space. This is definitely worth the price of admission! Just remember to tip your waiter.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: The Menu is thematically untidy and slightly underdeveloped in spots, rendering it merely good instead of great. Otherwise, it’s a pointedly absurd, consistently funny and suspenseful chamber-piece thriller with strong performances and a sharp edge.

reviews.name: Sheraz Farooqi
reviews.message:
The Menu is an interesting look at class structure, a cultish devotion to art and a deconstruction of pretentiousness in today's society. 

Ralph Fiennes and Anya Taylor-Joy do an incredible job.

reviews.name: Samuel Leggett Jr.
reviews.message: The Menu is just out there, its violent, intentionally creepy, dark, and at times horrifically comedic and I truly loved every minute of it. With a great cast, very interesting concept for the script & devotion to the characters is always felt. A MUST SEE

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: It’s here we begin to see The Menu as a story about class and inequality, which swiftly translates into a reign of terror inflicted by the serfs on their social superiors.

reviews.name: Kiko Martinez
reviews.message: Director Mark Mylod lays on the dark comedy as thick as a creamy garlic aioli in this tasty thriller.

reviews.name: Kevin A. Ranson
reviews.message: The very definition of a slow-burn thriller... (like) the soft ticking of a kitchen timer teasing the cooking meal to come, waiting as the air fills with an aroma thick enough to already taste.

reviews.name: Dolores Quintana
reviews.message: THE MENU is a dark star of a satire with ornate dishes that are full of self-loathing and human frailty. It lovingly catalogs the artist’s attempt to share the contents of their soul with people who understand. THE MENU is refined, precise, and deadly.

reviews.name: Al Alexander
reviews.message: Mylod  believes satire is a dish best served cold. But not when it’s this icy. It requires a modicum of warmth. And without it, “The Menu” struggles to pass the taste test. Still, try it, you might like it. But don’t forget the Alka Seltzer.

reviews.name: Chad Byrnes
reviews.message: Even if the film’s social commentary and satirical edge feels like a badly-tossed salad of ideas, its controlled directing, quick pacing, and fantastic performances provide some flavorful textures and cinematic bites.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: The third act proves somewhat rushed and messy, the joke finding its limits with apparently nowhere to go. Thankfully, however, Mylod and company do stick the landing, pivoting back to cold, calculating finality.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2
description: Peter Quill and his fellow Guardians are hired by a powerful alien race, the Sovereign, to protect their precious batteries from invaders. When it is discovered that Rocket has stolen the items they were sent to guard, the Sovereign dispatch their armada to search for vengeance. As the Guardians try to escape, the mystery of Peter's parentage is revealed.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Language|Brief Suggestive Content|Sequences of Sci-Fi Action|Violence)
characteristics.Producer:: Kevin Feige

reviews.name: Joseph Garcia
reviews.message: The humor and character relationships compensated for what I perceived as a slightly weaker story compared to the first film.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: Attempts to make the characters more than incessant joke boxes pays off (for the most part), and despite the humor’s inconsistency, there are some truly funny moments.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: It entertains by finding an equilibrium between diversionary thrills and emotional substance.

reviews.name: Luis Bond
reviews.message: Like its predecessor, it stands on its own and might as well have 10 sequels without having to flirt with other Marvel movies. Paradoxically, despite being the funniest film in the MCU, it is, at the same time, the most emotional [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Hosea Rupprecht
reviews.message: Baby Groot steals the show...

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: The jokey demeanor that informed the first film remains, even if writer-director James Gunn forces too many gags. But the freshness of the characters remains intact, and the actors continue to interact in a manner that supports the narrative spine.

reviews.name: Nicolás Delgadillo
reviews.message: You just can't help but have a smile on your face right away.

reviews.name: Michael J. Casey
reviews.message: Not all the pieces fit ... but what doesn't work never sticks around long enough to ruin the whole shebang.

reviews.name: Nick Levine
reviews.message: A very watchable second slice of intergalactic fun.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: With vibrant colors of the multiple planets, creatures, and space opera-like battles, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is an eye-popping, visual rock concert.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: An overdependence on CG and its wirework equivalent is disappointing, as it makes the already unbelievable stunts appear just that much more phony.

reviews.name: Leigh Monson
reviews.message: If you want more Guardians of the Galaxy, this movie is sure not to disappoint, even if it deigns to fly a little too high on its own excess.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Pretty close to everything I've ever wanted from a superhero flick.

reviews.name: Kelechi Ehenulo
reviews.message: Some can argue that the surprise factor has gone...The first film was a feel good exercise involving infinity stones with a sing-a-long and toe-tapping soundtrack. But the sequel felt like an overcooked and bloated indulgence.

reviews.name: Stephen A. Russell
reviews.message: By the final-act showdown with a much larger threat, you may find yourself inadvertently tearing up. Family can be tough, but then, love usually is.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: How much mileage you get out of Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 will depend a great deal on how you feel about the first movie, because this is more of the same.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is James Gunn's version of a Marvel Universe Empire Strikes Back: A film that retains everything the audience loves about the preceding movie, yet going deeper to expand the characters and story for further exploration.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: A sequel that I enjoyed as if I were a kid swimming in a sea of candies. It is even more fun than the predecessor. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Avaryl Halley
reviews.message: A really fun time.

reviews.name: Andrew Galdi
reviews.message: I had a lot of fun in this movie.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: In the end, it isn't about whether it's a better movie than the first installment; like most of the characters within, it's more mature and substantial and doesn't rely on past accomplishments to make it great.

reviews.name: Tim Brennan
reviews.message: There are still familiar elements, like the early-80's pop tunes that add to the exuberance of the film; overall the film has a vibrant joy that's infectious. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is the antidote for grimdark foolishness...

reviews.name: Christie Cronan
reviews.message: There's a complete mix of fun, laughs and A LOT of emotions all thrown into one epic saga.

reviews.name: Sarah Knight Adamson
reviews.message: More of the same, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

reviews.name: Chris McCoy
reviews.message: Gunn and company just go for whatever feels good from moment to moment. They've got jetpacks, and they're not afraid to use them. And I'll have to say, it's pretty refreshing.

reviews.name: Ard Vijn
reviews.message: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 leans very, VERY heavily on the familial tropes (not to mention their redemptive myths), and you need to be able to cope with a lot of sentimentality to fully enjoy this film.

reviews.name: Phumlani S Langa
reviews.message: The fresh part about this is the soundtrack. Man, old-school bangers and nostalgia in the air. An interesting dynamic between Gamora (Zoe Saldana) and her long-lost sister Nebula (Karen Gillan) injects an entertaining sibling rivalry.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: It may very well be Marvel's most mature film, zeroing in on the emotional complexities of abuse carried forward into adulthood

reviews.name: David Harris
reviews.message: Like its scruffy crew, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is an affable and harmless way to spend a few hours.

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 is the comic book movie we had no idea could exist, until it lands in front of our eyes.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: Those seeking big budget, escapist entertainment should easily be won over by Gunn's sequel, which is insistently witty, even if its storyline doesn't hold up past the credits.

reviews.name: Rhys Tarling
reviews.message: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is worthy and it's a hoot and a half to boot.

reviews.name: Kate Rodger
reviews.message: Laugh out loud, reassuringly rewatchable and building nicely on the characters and their stories, fans new and old should leave the cinema just like I did, beaming from ear to ear.

reviews.name: Linda and Al Lerner
reviews.message: This sequel doesn't have as much snappy repartée as the original that made audiences howl and want more. But the [Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2] provide more than enough, in another wild ride.

reviews.name: Chris Sawin
reviews.message: The sequel has too much of a good thing with comedy being exaggerated for far longer than it has any right to be and a story that could have been edited to trim excessive bickering and a specific Taserface joke that loses its oomph due to overuse.

reviews.name: Josh Wilding
reviews.message: An out of this world experience packed full of strong performances, stellar story beats, and fresh ideas help ensure that Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is one of Marvel's best movies to date. It may, in fact, be their greatest of all-time.

reviews.name: Juan Luis Caviaro
reviews.message: Not only does it have the humor and the awesomeness of the original, it is more mature and exciting. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Allison Rose
reviews.message: Overall, Guardians Vol. 2 still had elements of the original and even though it started off slow, it picked up steam to a supercharged, somewhat hokey ending.

reviews.name: Tyler Smith
reviews.message: Gunn tries to keep an eye towards character development and relationships in the midst of the chaos.

reviews.name: Dominic Griffin
reviews.message: Guardians of The Galaxy (...) was a unique outlier compared to its homogenized brethren. While Vol. 2 is just as charming, if not more so, it still suffers from many of the same issues that have plagued every Marvel film.

title: Fast & Furious 6
description: Since Dom (Vin Diesel) and Brian's (Paul Walker) heist in Rio left them and their crew very rich people, they've scattered across the globe; however, they must still live as fugitives, unable to return home to their families. Meanwhile, Agent Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson) has been tracking a gang of lethally skilled mercenary drivers whose second-in-command is someone Dom knows. Unable to take them down himself, Hobbs asks Dom and his crew for help in exchange for full pardons for everyone.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Intense Sequences of Violence|Intense Sequences of Action|Language|Mayhem Throughout|Some Sexuality)
characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz, Vin Diesel, Clayton Townsend

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: These films are clearly designed first and foremost to be fun, and that has never been more true than with the sixth entry. That’s largely because the film is a globe-trotting adventure that features some of the best stunts of the franchise.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: Garnishing a candy bar with some candlelight and fine dinnerware and calling it a gourmet dessert isn’t going to fool anyone, nor will pretending Fast & Furious 6 is anything more than loud, mindless entertainment.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: Understand that this film and this series is all about the wild ride, and if you’re willing to get into the car, you’re going to have a good time.

reviews.name: Grant Watson
reviews.message: This push further and further away from realism was done in such an incremental fashion, and the films performed in such a likeable and engaging manner, that it is genuinely hard not to throw caution to the wind and enjoy the stupidity.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: While not quite reaching the frenetic highs of its direct predecessor, Fast and Furious 6 is a worthy follow-up, packed to the gills with riotous one-liners and superlative vehicular carnage.

reviews.name: Scott Nye
reviews.message: In an already strong summer, Furious 6 is the best of the bunch thus far, making in images what exists in the heart of every song about owning the road.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: The plot is so generic that it never even tries to reason with the audience.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Lin has really amped up the unbelievable factor here with some of the action sequences.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: Fast & Furious 6 is just as fun and exciting as the previous entries.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: Turn off the ignition in your head, then throttle up all other senses, and you will feel the rush of this guilty-pleasure joy ride to the max.

reviews.name: Katie Smith-Wong
reviews.message: Action-packed and ridiculously fun, it is hard not to cheer during Fast & Furious 6.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: The latest in what has essentially become the James Bond for gearheads franchise embraces its inner goofiness -- so over the top that you can't help but be entertained.

reviews.name: Amon Warmann
reviews.message: Offering more of the high-octane action that the series is famous for, Lin's Fast & Furious 6 is easily the most ridiculous blockbuster of 2013 thus far; and also one of the most watchable.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: Lin and Company generally know what they're doing, particularly exploiting the fun of having Diesel and Johnson appear together and play off each other, as Dom and Hobbs try to out-tough one another.

reviews.name: Zaki Hasan
reviews.message: Excels at deepening the characters while also tying together multiple threads from previous films in a way that feels fulfilling.

reviews.name: Sarah Gopaul
reviews.message: Fast & Furious 6 is the culmination of the last five films and it's jam-packed with non-stop excitement.

reviews.name: Aaron Peterson
reviews.message: This series is not about logistic possibilities. It's about taking it to 11, and Furious 6 does just that once again. If you enjoyed the direction of Fast Five, you are in good hands here.

reviews.name: Josh Terry
reviews.message: Even non-fans will get a thrill or two, followed by a quick laugh and a feeling like someone is trying to insult their intelligence.

reviews.name: Matthew Bond
reviews.message: Sleek and fine-tuned, these movies do exactly what they say on the bodywork.

reviews.name: Candice Frederick
reviews.message: And while director Justin Lin's eye for the flamboyant makes the film less credible, it's never not fun to watch even as you shake your head at the absolutely bogus action scenes.

reviews.name: Mike McCahill
reviews.message: Contain your excitement: this is a London populated by monodimensional toffee noses or thick necks and, while it's good to have the no-nonsense [Michelle] Rodriguez back, she's soon crowded out by dreary ex-models and wisecracking dipsticks.

reviews.name: Sonny Bunch
reviews.message: As long as 'let it go, bro' is your mantra, you'll have a fine time at Fast and Furious 6.

reviews.name: Kristian M. Lin
reviews.message: There's still some gas left in the tank here.

reviews.name: Jason Bailey
reviews.message: Nobody goes to these movies for dialogue. And maybe that's true - but that doesn't mean they have to be written like a bunch of third graders playing "movie" in the school yard.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: Diesel's mega-bass voice and the slo-mo charisma with which he delivers those bass lines have resulted in a series that got more popular in its fifth and sixth installments.

reviews.name: Francesca Rudkin
reviews.message: Unfortunately, in between bouts of high-speed action there's a dud story about nasty mercenaries driving around Europe stealing military equipment.

reviews.name: J. Olson
reviews.message: If action is your cinematic elixir of choice, "Fast & Furious 6" won't just sate your thirst - you'll be blackout drunk by the end credits.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: While [it] isn't a masterpiece, it's a really damn good follow up...

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: Over and over again, Vin Diesel spells it out: family this, family that, all that matters is family.

reviews.name: Sean Burns
reviews.message: Fast Five was the best John Woo movie John Woo never made. Fast & Furious 6 aims to top it.

reviews.name: Chris Stuckmann
reviews.message: These Fast and Furious movies are different, they've actually improved upon the mistakes of their predecessors.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...mostly this is another showcase for superior stunt work, including a highway chase involving a speeding tank.

reviews.name: Ray Pride
reviews.message: Vin Diesel makes gravel audible-there's one reason he didn't choose "Vin Cashmere" as his nom de zoom-with elongated, not quite drawled delivery of lines like "L'es go for a li'l ride."

reviews.name: Sam Fragoso
reviews.message: Jaggedly oscillates between action absurdity and familial drama.

reviews.name: Nilay Patel
reviews.message: A soap opera with a casual disregard for physics.

reviews.name: Mark Adams
reviews.message: Adrenaline packed petrol-head entertainment.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: A worthy, nitrous-blasting addition to a franchise that may not be so fresh any more but is as fast and furious as ever.

reviews.name: Jim Lane
reviews.message: The biggest laugh, though, comes at the end, with a prim, don't-try-this-at-home disclaimer.

reviews.name: Christopher Tookey
reviews.message: No one's going to pretend this is art, but it makes sense commercially. The fights and chases are superbly choreographed and genuinely spectacular.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: a movie that delivers exactly what it promises

title: Operation Fortune: Ruse de guerre
description: In the film, super spy Orson Fortune (Jason Statham) must track down and stop the sale of a deadly new weapons technology wielded by billionaire arms broker Greg Simmonds (Hugh Grant). Reluctantly teamed with some of the world’s best operatives (Aubrey Plaza, Cary Elwes, Bugzy Malone), Fortune and his crew recruit Hollywood's biggest movie star Danny Francesco (Josh Hartnett) to help them on their globe-trotting undercover mission to save the world.

characteristics.Producer:: Ivan Atkinson, Bill Block, Steve Chasman, Guy Ritchie, Jason Statham
characteristics.Writer:: Guy Ritchie, Ivan Atkinson, Marn Davies
characteristics.Production Co:: The Searchers NV, Tencent Pictures, AZ Celtic Films, STX Films, Miramax, Toff Guy Films

reviews.name: Liam Macleod
reviews.message: A frustraingly damp and discordant caper, with a capable cast done a disservice due to haphazard editing and an underdeveloped script. A mess, and a shame.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: It’s like someone doing Guy Ritchie doing Guy Ritchie.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: Flashy but hollow...

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a familiar yet mostly entertaining spy caper that’s elevated, on a remarkably consistent basis, by the agreeable, affable performances...

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre provides a nice, smooth, undemanding watch, elevated by another killer performance from Hugh Grant in peak form…

reviews.name: Tim Robey
reviews.message: With a shoes-clicking-on-marble start that’s pure Burn After Reading, and some saucy surveillance games that reminded me of Sneakers, Ritchie plans his menu with familiar ingredients.

reviews.name: Dulcie Pearce
reviews.message: ... The colourful script repeatedly rescues the lagging by poking fun and delivering on real humour.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: The film is mostly content to watch Statham perform some nifty beat-downs before introducing us to a scene-and-movie-stealing Hugh Grant... as a buffoonish arms dealer apparently slathered in Donald Trump’s fake tan.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: Guy Ritchie barely puts a foot wrong with his solid but largely forgettable spy caper.

reviews.name: Joe Muldoon
reviews.message: Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre works wonderfully as an entertaining popcorn flick.

reviews.name: Anne Brodie
reviews.message: The breakneck pace, and endless sequences of people typing and texting, overlong, deadening fight sequences seem regressive, but Plaza's energy and brightness raises Ritchie's retro effort

reviews.name: Catherine Bray
reviews.message: Riper than the ripest of ripe Brie, this crime caper provides a ridiculous vehicle for the talents of pretty much everyone involved, all of whom appear to be having a splendid time.

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: Director and co-writer Guy Ritchie’s buoyant spy caper and franchise non-starter Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre is a fine enough movie to watch on a weekend afternoon when one has nothing better to do.

reviews.name: Richard Crouse
reviews.message: Operation Fortune: Ruse de guerre feels like a Xerox copy of the movies that made Guy Ritchie and Jason Statham famous. The sum of its parts is a bland espionage story that is, at best, serviceable.

reviews.name: Brian Lloyd
reviews.message: 'Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre' is a series of bad decisions caught on camera. Avoid at all costs.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: ... Proceedings trundle chaotically along until the whole thing comes to a sputtering close, as if all involved just decided to call it quits and hit the nearest bar.

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: Were it not for the presence of Hugh Grant, Guy Ritchie’s awkwardly titled international crime thriller would be easily forgotten.

reviews.name: Michael Calleri
reviews.message: "Operation Fortune” hits the mark. The cast is very good, with extra points to Aubrey Plaza, who is especially appealing in a tongue-in-cheek role that could have been tedious, but happily, is breezy and entertaining.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre offers modest escapist pleasures – a bit of witty banter, a glitzy car chase and an oleaginous Hugh Grant performance – but little more than that.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: The title may be unwieldy, its plot inconsequential, and its behind-the-scenes backstory bizarre, this is an entertaining action romp.

reviews.name: Andy Klein
reviews.message: It's pretty well done... It does deliver on what it does, and it's got really good light touches.

reviews.name: Petr Navovy
reviews.message: Operation Fortune stalls after a relatively promising opening and never recovers. By the end, I was completely disengaged from what was happening on screen.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: A weightless and dizzying globetrotting caper that still delivers a refreshing dose of cheeky entertainment.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: Thoroughly superficial, Guy Ritchie's globetrotting action/adventure is nonetheless consistently swift and light, and the fun that the cast seems to be having on-screen is contagious.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: Audrey Plaza, being very Vanessa Kirby-ish, is a delight to watch.

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre is a consistently entertaining action spy thriller carried by Jason Statham’s combination of brute-force action and deadpan comic relief.

reviews.name: Steven Warner
reviews.message: Operation Fortune instead finds Ritchie in Man from U.N.C.L.E. mode, a breezy contraption that isn’t necessarily good, but never reaches the barrel bottom.

reviews.name: Lynn Venhaus
reviews.message: “Operation Fortune” is the kind of breezy spy game that’s fun to watch, despite plot shortcomings, because the cast appears to work well with each other. They could get the gang together again, and it wouldn’t be that far-fetched.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: Parts of the movie are unimaginative but somehow still fun, which is most likely a testament to the director (who has always had his finger firmly on the pulse of what action fans want) and the cast of actors who are obviously having a good time.

reviews.name: Marie Asner
reviews.message: What appealed to me were the scenes between Florence Pugh and Morgan Freeman. They seemed natural and at ease.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: Most of the characters, by the way, are very well dressed. [But] don’t get me wrong, I’m not recommending Operation Fortune...

reviews.name: Fiona Underhill
reviews.message: Guy Ritchie is back on the form we haven’t seen since his first two British gangster flicks, and channeling the glamour of his best movie – Man from UNCLE. A brilliant cast deliver one liners with aplomb, in this hugely enjoyable spy thriller caper.

reviews.name: Edwin Arnaudin
reviews.message: A breezily entertaining romp that makes many recent would-be peers look like…well, Statham’s films without Ritchie.

reviews.name: Murtada Elfadl
reviews.message: For the most part, this is a fun time at the movies. There’s laughter, action, and movie stars playing to their strengths. It’s exactly what audiences expect to see from Ritchie and that’s its main selling point.

reviews.name: Alan Ng
reviews.message: Bland is the best word I could use to describe Operation Fortune.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Ritchie uses his usual mix of jagged editing, offbeat musical choices and achingly cool actors to liven everything up considerably.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: So-so espionage tale.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: It serves no purpose other than unnecessarily extend the running time, which this film definitely doesn’t need. Ask me how I feel about Ritchie again in a month and a half, but I’m guessing it’ll be better than I do today.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: This smug and cliché-plagued action flick is proof that Guy Ritchie and Jason Statham have gotten lazy in their movie collaborations. The fights look too fake. The whole film is a failure of imagination, motivated by greed and paid trips to exotic places.

reviews.name: Katie Walsh
reviews.message: Classic recent Ritchie: star-studded, snarky, and ultimately grating, lousy with weird glasses and bad accents. This thing is so slight, a Xerox of a Xerox of a Xerox of a “Mission: Impossible” that it’s barely a movie.

title: The Whale
description: A reclusive English teacher suffering from severe obesity attempts to reconnect with his estranged teenage daughter for one last chance at redemption.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: It has a more or less decent preamble that is propelled by an organic performance from Brendan Fraser on his return, but its psychological marrow is locked into a basic routine of trivial conversations and a lack of substance. [Full reveiw in Spanish]

reviews.name: Nilton Arana
reviews.message: A strangely hopeful story that manages to stay on the surface even as it seems to sink into mediocrity. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: David Walsh
reviews.message: One of the most deplorable elements of The Whale is its near celebration of defeat and resignation. The decision by Charlie to eat himself to death is treated as a meaningful act of self-sacrifice. Why would this possibly be so?

reviews.name: Milana Vujkov
reviews.message: All the weight of the story (metaphorically and literally) is carried by its tragic protagonist — the ailing Charlie, whom Brendan Fraser portrays with such depth, nuance, and wit. Nothing in the film's text matches this commitment, and that's a problem.

reviews.name: Allison Rose
reviews.message: Two words - Brendan Fraser.  He was born to play Charlie and his Oscar award is extremely well deserved.

reviews.name: Amber Wilkinson
reviews.message: Chamber settings, by their nature, let the acting echo out and Fraser’s central performance speaks volumes about his character’s history.

reviews.name: Stacey Yvonne
reviews.message: Though The Whale has captured the interest of the public, I can’t say that it’s earned. I hated this movie, but not for the reasons you may think.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: Aronofsky’s film of this joyless play was a hit, so I guess it touched something in the moviegoing public. It had to use a bodega claw to do it because it couldn’t get off the couch, but it touched them.

reviews.name: Armond White
reviews.message: Aronofsky uses The Whale for easy, unsightly, virtue-signaling.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: At times, it feels like they had a list of difficult themes they wanted to include, which makes for an uneven experience. But we also can't deny the power of Fraser's performance, which some would argue is superior to the film. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Eric Webb
reviews.message: At every moment when subtlety might afford Charlie humanity or control of his own story, Aronofsky takes the lurid path.

reviews.name: Al Alexander
reviews.message: There’s much ado about Brendan Fraser’s king-sized portrayal of a doomed 600-pound Idahoan college professor, but the stagey, often ridiculous movie he’s wedged into, alas, is thin as a rail.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: Even his [Brendan Fraser] unblemished commitment to the role can't redeem this intimate behind-doors drama from excessive pathos and an inordinately staged posture that makes it less genuine than it was supposed to.

reviews.name: Alejandro Turdo
reviews.message: In lots of ways, The Whale is your standard Aronofsky movie. Only this time it doesn't rejoice in the main character's flaws, it uses them to tackle tough subject matters such as traumas, guilt, pain and redemption. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Beth McMillan
reviews.message: Aronofsky offers an honest and authentic portrait of a man struggling to come to terms with his past and move forward, but he does so seemingly without knowing what message Charlie’s story is supposed to impart...

reviews.name: Pablo De Vita
reviews.message: ... A film that never disguises its theatrical origin to the point of artificiality. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: It isn't a bad film, but it's not that good either, and it's worth discerning and separating, to appreciate what's fat and what's bloated. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo Villaça
reviews.message: The Whale is indefensible, turning out to be a silly melodrama that views its protagonist with a loathing it tries to present as empathy. [Full review in Portuguese]

reviews.name: Ezequiel Boetti
reviews.message: It's true that the metaphor of Moby Dick's redeeming character falls into the obvious... but The Whale is much more than that: it's the last station of a life that once was full but now only awaits its end. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Denise Pieniazek
reviews.message: The narrative oscillates constantly between exposing the clinical consequences of obesity and portraying the psychology of the protagonist. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: Ultimately we come away from "The Whale" warmed by the openness of heart and spirit Fraser brings to it.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: Aronofsky’s career-long obsession with the grotesque is alive and well here, and he skirts the edge of exploitation. But The Whale is very much a splayed-open tragedy, and a weirdly romantic one at that...

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: It should come as little surprise that Aronofsky's eighth film is at its finest when it lets Fraser, Chau and Sink verbally bounce off of each other.

reviews.name: Annie Banks
reviews.message: The Whale is set leveling the rawness of human sadness with practice sympathy and forgiveness.

reviews.name: Rosalynn Try-Hane
reviews.message: Incredibly moving.

reviews.name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
reviews.message: By far, his [Aronofsky] worst film. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jenny Nulf
reviews.message: There’s nothing consciously sinister about THE WHALE’s use of Charlie’s eating disorder (the original play was, in fact, written from experience), but Aronofsky’s adaptation is cruel, not just to Charlie’s character, but to all of them.

reviews.name: D. Patrick Rodgers
reviews.message: The Whale is a film characterized by wall-to-wall woe and the lonesomeness and obsession felt by one doomed man. It is devastating, dark and raw, relentless in its commitment to make the audience feel something.

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: He doesn’t have issues with his body image – he has given up on his body altogether. He’s not unhappy because he’s fat, but fat because he’s unhappy.

reviews.name: Mike Scott
reviews.message: Brendan Fraser stands out, but every member of Darren Aronofsky's tiny cast gets moments to shine, and they all prove up to the challenge. Together, they combine to tell a lovely heartbreaker of a story.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: Darren Aronofsky's The Whale is all of these things: a remarkable spectacle, a play adaptation, a lousy film, an Oscar-comeback vehicle for Fraser.

reviews.name: Carlos Bonfil
reviews.message: The pathetic story of a futile repentance. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alfonso Flores-Durón y Martínez
reviews.message: Aronofsky mistrusts the audience's capacity to understand and empathize, and feels the need to employ an irritating, tear-inducing score... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Gisela Savdie
reviews.message: The film leaves us questioning our own preventions regarding physical appearance, the effects of homophobia, and religion as a means of escaping reality. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Damien Straker
reviews.message: A clunky and imbalanced chamber piece that lacks the director’s reliable visual instincts.

reviews.name: Hugo Hernández Valdivia
reviews.message: Aronofsky builds a thorough melodrama. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rahul Desai
reviews.message: Fraser is singularly heartbreaking as a man whose body stars as a mammoth monument to grief...

reviews.name: Eric Eisenberg
reviews.message: [Brendan Fraser is] an enchanting performer, and that’s accentuated in Darren Aronofsky’s The Whale: a film that has the actor serving as a powerful, bright light in a dark pool of despair.

reviews.name: Kate Rodger
reviews.message: While the film itself isn't necessarily a sum of all its incredible acting parts, The Whale is an emotionally affirming story which -- once again it seems -- feels like just what we need right now.

reviews.name: Ben Turner
reviews.message: It might be the director’s most restrained film, but there’s beauty in its subtlety and horror in its nuance. Simply put; this is a feast of a film.

title: Asterix & Obelix: The Middle Kingdom
description: Gallic heroes and forever friends Asterix and Obelix journey to China to help Princess Sa See save the Empress and her land from a nefarious prince.

characteristics.Producer:: Yohan Baiada, Alain Attal
characteristics.Production Co:: Just Bridge Entertainment, Pathé, Trésor Films, Les Enfants Terribles

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Pretty danged dumb...but if your kids are into slapstick and you haven’t outgrown the Stooges, this nonsense could be just the ticket.

reviews.name: Dhaval Roy
reviews.message: The film is driven by rib-tickling moments, high production value and a fresh story, but it’s best viewed independent of the iconic comic book series. It’s a family entertainer for those who don’t mind a slightly slow-paced watch...

reviews.name: Whang Yee Ling
reviews.message: There are few bright spots in this Gaul-ling retelling of a beloved comic book.

reviews.name: Pablo Vázquez
reviews.message: ... Fine tunes the broad strokes of the rescuable past films without reneging on their merits. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Randy Meeks
reviews.message: After five movies, it's time to be realistic and hang up the sword: live-action doesn't work for a character that's so dependent on drawing such as Asterix.  [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Carlos Marañón
reviews.message: Lellouche's Obelix gobbles up the healthy version of Asterix. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Outpost
description: An abused woman gets a job as a fire lookout in the mountains of northern Idaho, hoping the peaceful solitude will heal her trauma. However, the PTSD and isolation have other plans, and it's suddenly a fight to save herself and the town.

characteristics.Producer:: Kara Baker, Joe Lo Truglio, Joe Mortimer

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: It’s a solid first effort from Lo Truglio, and I’m curious to see if he continues down this horror path or if he has other genre avenues to explore.

reviews.name: Dan Scully
reviews.message: By the time the story elements are forced to be reckoned with, it’s all so messy and illogical that there’s no angle through which they can be explored. It’s a frustrating experience because it’s clear that there’s something worth digging into here.

reviews.name: Josh Bell
reviews.message: There's still plenty of potential in Lo Truglio's first film as a writer-director, which starts out as a grounded drama before rather abruptly shifting into full-on horror.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: A horror thriller about isolation and trauma.

reviews.name: David Gelmini
reviews.message: With its strong performances and serious themes, Outpost is a film which horror fans cannot afford to miss.

reviews.name: Luke Gorham
reviews.message: There’s a whole lot of derivation of other works here... but very little to suggest a fully-formed vision from Truglio.

reviews.name: Crockett Houghton
reviews.message: The problem with Outpost is that it turned our survivor of something horrible into a murderer with no redeeming qualities. A swing and a miss.

reviews.name: Brian Tallerico
reviews.message: A film that’s too choppy and ridiculous for too long for its gut-punch of a final act to really connect.

reviews.name: Kimberley Elizabeth
reviews.message: [Outpost] ventures into the dark corners of the human psyche while delivering an unforgettable survival horror experience.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: It's difficult to imagine a less thoughtful and empathetic way to tell the underlying story of Outpost.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: While it’s of little surprise for me to once again see a comedic performer transfer their sense of tension and timing to the world of horror, I can say that I was ultimately won over thanks to having a cast full of character actors.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: While Outpost proves Joe Lo Truglio's ability within the horror genre and successfully overcomes many of the common faults in the genre, the film fails itself and its own characters with a beyond-questionable final act.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: 'Outpost' has lofty aims and takes big swings. Though not all of them land and it never quite reaches the possible highs, this is a hell of a debut.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: A little uneven, but Lo Truglio captures the mental quake of trauma reasonably well, getting the endeavor on its feet with some degree of success.

reviews.name: Melissa Hannon
reviews.message: While Outpost may tell a familiar tale of survival, this elevated indie is a solid entry in the psychological horror subgenre. Fans will always love (Joe Lo) Truglio for his comedic roles, but let's hope he has more horror up his sleeve.

reviews.name: Tim Brennan
reviews.message: The fact remains that Joe Lo Truglio is a new voice in horror, one that’s thoughtful when necessary and always committed to going for your guts.

reviews.name: Joel Harley
reviews.message: While the film never quite reaches the heights it aims for, this striking debut makes a solid platform for its director’s genre aspirations.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: ...an ordeal of endurance as much mental as physical, where victimhood is not just overcome but inverted. This is a glorious calling card – sensitive to sympathetic characterisation, yet unafraid, when the time is right, to call in the nasty exploitation

title: A Thousand and One
description: A THOUSAND AND ONE follows unapologetic and free-spirited Inez (Teyana Taylor), who kidnaps six-year-old Terry from the foster care system. Holding onto their secret and each other, mother and son set out to reclaim their sense of home, identity, and stability, in a rapidly changing New York City.

characteristics.Producer:: Eddie Vaisman, Julia Lebedev, Lena Waithe, Rishi Rajani, Brad Weston
characteristics.Production Co:: Sight Unseen Pictures, Makeready, Hillman Grad

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: A Thousand and One will be tough to swallow but it’s rooted in reality. That’s what makes it great.

reviews.name: Ryan Gilbey
reviews.message: The director maps the contours of a destabilised existence. It is one thing to put us in Terry and Inez’s shoes, quite another to make us feel, as Rockwell does, the ground shifting unpredictably beneath them.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: Even dwindling in intensity in the last quarter, the film will leave you prostrated with its thoroughly wired reality.

reviews.name: Amon Warmann
reviews.message: Come for Taylor’s breakout performance, stay for a tender, confidently told story of Black motherhood and sacrifice. Rockwell is one to watch.

reviews.name: Mark Hughes
reviews.message: A Thousand and One is the best film of 2023, a tragic and triumphant story of a family living and loving in a broken world they refuse to let break them, too.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: It's a strikingly original approach that cuts through the stereotypes to create complex characters and relationships while also taking a fresh look at New York's transition from the seedy and crime-ridden 1990s to the ruthlessly gentrified 2000s.

reviews.name: Joe Friar
reviews.message: A.V. Rockwell gives us one of this year’s best films driven by Teyana Taylor's superb performance. Gentrification and racial profiling simmer in the background as the film remains focused on a strong mother-son bond.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: The directorial debut from AV Rockwell is rather special.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: Making her screen debut, Taylor gives this abrasive momma her all: she almost dares you to judge her. It will only make her stronger.

reviews.name: Brian Lloyd
reviews.message: 'A Thousand and One' is a career-defining performance for Teyana Taylor and a strong debut for AV Rockwell's talents as writer and director.

reviews.name: Saskia Baron
reviews.message: A Thousand and One is reminiscent of the work of John Cassavetes, and also shows the influence of black American directors like Charles Burnett, Leslie Harris, and Barry Jenkins. It’s altogether a powerful debut and not to be missed in the cinema.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: [A] heartfelt melodrama that consistently sparks and sputters without ever fully igniting.

reviews.name: Leslie Felperin
reviews.message: The delicately pitched performances, luminous cinematography and quiet, jazzy score counteract [any] excess, creating a stately feel that’s rare in stories of contemporary urban suffering.

reviews.name: D. Watkins
reviews.message: Sacrifice is the critical ingredient in survival for those of us who grew up Black and poor, and this film knocks that fact out of the park, so well that the act of sacrifice becomes kind of a character.

reviews.name: Cheyenne Bunsie
reviews.message: Teyana Taylor shines in a tale of the past that feels no less relevant and affecting today.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Tells a story that is real, credible and painful.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: A powerful debut that offers us a sincere and moving story about motherhood and the devastating process of gentrification. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Shani Harris
reviews.message: Taylor is so passionate and palpable during her delivery making a speech about maternal instinct that we wholeheartedly believe every word.

reviews.name: Jason Fraley
reviews.message: The gritty drama follows a single mom who is released from prison and kidnaps her son from the foster care system. Together, they try to reclaim a sense of home amid the gentrification of New York. Who knew Teyana Taylor was THIS good at dramatic acting?

reviews.name: Bob Mondello
reviews.message: Character portraits just don't come sharper than "A Thousand And One."

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: The film gets by on the strength of Taylor’s performance and is not over-sensationalized when it comes to reckoning with some story turns.

reviews.name: Frank Swietek
reviews.message: Anchored by a fiercely committed performance by Teyana Taylor, “A Thousand and One” combines a searing domestic drama and the larger socio-political context against which it occurs with skill and insight.

reviews.name: Edwin Arnaudin
reviews.message: In those final moments, it achieves an authentic greatness rarely seen in modern filmmaking.

reviews.name: T.J. Callahan
reviews.message: Bring tissues as you watch Taylor’s career defining performance. Selected as AWFJ's Movie of the Week!

reviews.name: Liz Whittemore
reviews.message: The film's finale is mind-blowing. Emotionally wrought, undeniably shocking, and beautifully nuanced, A Thousand and One is a story of unconditional love through circumstances that are unimaginable to many. AWFJ's Movie of the Week!

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: A quietly devastating Black-centered film featuring exceptional performances. AV Rockwell's instincts as writer/director will make for her success going forward, assuming those who can open more doors for her watch the film.

reviews.name: Loren King
reviews.message: Motherhood and generational trauma are the complex, emotional layers grounding writer-director A.V. Rockwell’s gritty 1990s New York-set drama. The film is anchored by the unforgettable powerhouse performance from Teyana Taylor. AWFJ's Movie of the Week!

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: An intimate mother-and-son character study that’s most rewarding in sharing the details of barely scraping by in New York City.

reviews.name: Jennifer Merin
reviews.message: AWFJ's Movie of the Week! Brilliantly crafted by writer/director AV Rockwell. Teyana Taylor and three young actors who play her son give compelling, complex, convincing performances. It’s impossible not to become invested in their welfare.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: Ready to start your Oscar list for 2024?

reviews.name: Monique Jones
reviews.message: A gripping, heartfelt, mature story of motherhood and family.

reviews.name: Robert Denerstein
reviews.message: Rockwell’s bold direction matches Taylor’s vivid performance, ensuring that A Thousand and One packs a wallop.

reviews.name: Travis DeShong
reviews.message: These thematic concerns carry into this feature-length offering, a heart-rending, subtly epic drama that balances its raw vision of urban struggle with an empathetically poetic exploration of the bonds that sustain the folks working within that hardship.

reviews.name: Peter Howell
reviews.message: Taylor is terrific in a role that doesn't seek our sympathy and rarely commands it. The three kids who play her son over the years, especially Josiah Cross, truly seize the heart. An excellent '90s hip-hop soundtrack directs the flow.

reviews.name: Alison Willmore
reviews.message: A Thousand and One is rich and complex, the saga of someone battling to build a family and a stable home with no real experience of what that looks like.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: Rockwell has made a humanistic epic – really, it could be a filmed novel – and brings it to life through empathy, subtle shadings, and a central figure and performance that won’t be denied.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Exploring life on the socioeconomic margins with raw authenticity and hard-earned compassion, this evocative coming-of-age drama overcomes its mild contrivances with deeply felt performances and unflinching sincerity.

reviews.name: Richard Lawson
reviews.message: A Thousand and One is an auspicious debut for Rockwell. And it’s a thrilling evolution for Taylor, who puts her My Super Sweet 16 days very far in the rearview.

reviews.name: Joshua Mackey
reviews.message: In all, A Thousand and One is a fabulous debut for both Rockwell, as a filmmaker, and for Taylor as a leading lady.

reviews.name: Kyle Smith
reviews.message: It’s a reasonably compelling premise for a movie. A Thousand and One, however, does very little with it.

title: Thor: Love and Thunder
description: "Thor: Love and Thunder" finds Thor (Chris Hemsworth) on a journey unlike anything he's ever faced -- a quest for inner peace. But his retirement is interrupted by a galactic killer known as Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks the extinction of the gods. To combat the threat, Thor enlists the help of King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who -- to Thor's surprise -- inexplicably wields his magical hammer, Mjolnir, as the Mighty Thor. Together, they embark upon a harrowing cosmic adventure to uncover the mystery of the God Butcher's vengeance and stop him before it's too late.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Intense Sci-Fi Violence|Action|Language|Partial Nudity|Some Suggestive Material)
characteristics.Producer:: Kevin Feige
characteristics.Production Co:: Marvel Studios, Walt Disney Pictures, Fox Studios Australia

reviews.name: Annie Banks
reviews.message: There may be thunder, but lightning does not strike twice.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: Therein lies Thor: Love and Thunder‘s biggest issue, its inability to balance tone and spectacle.

reviews.name: William Jones
reviews.message: Thor: Love and Thunder's editing routinely works against Taika Waititi's film, often undoing the emotional work the film is attempting to deliver.

reviews.name: Joseph Garcia
reviews.message: Taika Waititi and Chris Hemsworth leaned heavily into the more goofy aspects of Thor: Ragnarok. Thor: Love and Thunder piles on the jokes, bathos and stupidity until the film feels more like a parody of the MCU rather an addition to it.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: I’m laying down the hammer a bit more harshly because somewhere hidden in this messy pastiche to 80s fantasy movies is an adventure worthy of the gods. Unfortunately, hilarity and humanity fail to harmonize in Thor: Love and Thunder.

reviews.name: David Hogan
reviews.message: Overall a fun time but not the big blockbuster some might be expecting and certainly not recommended if you didn’t find Ragnarok very funny…

reviews.name: Christina Newland
reviews.message: Hemsworth has always been likeable as the smug superhero-god with the Adonis-like physique to match, but the risky attempt to transfer that charisma or to spread it around to other characters is not a gamble that pays off.

reviews.name: Murjani Rawls
reviews.message: 'Love and Thunder' will remind you of fantastical adventure films like The Neverending Story, where the impossible can happen. At the same time, it may get in its own way trying to tackle as much as it does.

reviews.name: Marriska Fernandes
reviews.message: It's bonkers in the best possible way. It's silly, laugh-out-loud funny and never takes itself too seriously. For those who have been living on a steady diet of Marvel films, this one delivers hilarious one-liners, jabs and Easter eggs.

reviews.name: Brady Langmann
reviews.message: In Love and Thunder, Waititi pulls off a sneaky, deeply cool move—one that'll likely go unappreciated.

reviews.name: Matthew Pejkovic
reviews.message: Proves to be more spoof than smash.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Waititi seems driven to tell a story about Gorr and Jane Foster, allowing Christian Bale and Natalie Portman to outshine their peers. Bale simply outclasses the rest of the cast, appearing obscenely menacing and haunted by grief.

reviews.name: Andrew Kendall
reviews.message: Years after "Ragnarök", Waititi seems stuck in a facsimile of that same register to diminishing returns. What was previously fresh air has grown stale and “Love and Thunder" more dull and and unspectacular. Not quite godlike.

reviews.name: Hasitha Fernando
reviews.message: As a huge fan of Thor: Ragnarök, this film left me bitterly disappointed and to be honest, quite heartbroken since I had such high hopes for it.

reviews.name: Richard Trenholm
reviews.message: Why should we feel anything when clearly none of it matters?

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: What's missing is any freaking hint as to where all this is going. <i>Love and Thunder</i> is the sixth (sixth!) movie in Phase Four of the MCU and we still don't know what the endgame (no pun intended) is.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: I not only think that this is the worst Taika Waititi's movie, but also one that occupies a privileged place at the top of the Olympus of the most boring of the MCU. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rohan Naahar
reviews.message: Taika Waititi's Thor Love and Thunder was a disappointment of godlike proportions, featuring a villain that deserved a much better film.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: What makes the film durable and winning is the rare blend of comedy and serious drama weight, which is pushed through by a game cast.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: As visually memorable as the sequence can be, narratively, it’s wet spaghetti flung at the plaster and wacky-wallwalking its way to the floor.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: ... Not just the best Marvel movie yet made, but a bona fide camp comedy classic: fast, bright, gaudy, prickly, antic and fun.

reviews.name: William Bibbiani
reviews.message: It brings up a lot of interesting ideas and ultimately does almost nothing with them.

reviews.name: Maggie Lovitt
reviews.message: A refreshing venture back to what the MCU is best at delivering: summer popcorn films. You get exactly what you expect: two hours of laughs, colorful scenery, and thunderous joy.

reviews.name: Ron Seoul-Oh
reviews.message: Hilarious, irreverent and full of crowd pleasing moments. However, there are moments where the story development suffers in favor of the humor, and ultimately the fourth film is not quite as strong as Ragnarok

reviews.name: Jason Escamilla
reviews.message: Thor: Love and Thunder is merely a subpar love story meshed within a subpar superhero action movie.

reviews.name: Cody Leach
reviews.message: Oh how the mighty have fallen! Taika Waititi was clearly given significantly more freedom here and it is not a good result. The slapstick comedy is way too frequent and makes the film feel like a spoof of it's own characters. It's dumb fun...but not much.

reviews.name: Travis Johnson
reviews.message: Here’s the thing about Thor: Love and Thunder, the fourth solo outing for the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s God of Thunder: pretty much every individual element works on its own, and almost none of it works taken as a whole.

reviews.name: Ross Anthony
reviews.message: This is not an action film with humor, this is a comedy with action. Don't take it too seriously and you'll have a lovely time. Russell Crowe knocks it out of the park.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: They should have simply let James Gunn play with Thor in Guardians 3 and given Jane Foster her own Mighty Thor film so as not to relegate her into footnote status. Thank goodness for Bale. [His] grief’s authenticity proves how superficial the rest is.

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: Thor: Love and Thunder is lacking in both love and thunder, and could have used more dramatic tension and more palpable, affecting stakes.

reviews.name: Mark Kermode
reviews.message: The jokes, the catch-phrases, just incredibly tired...

reviews.name: Samuel Leggett Jr.
reviews.message: Thor: Love and Thunder had a great opportunity with Portman as the new Thor & Bale as the God Killer but they were under utilized. At times this was downright silly, visual effects were not well done, & this was one my least favorite Marvel films to date

reviews.name: Michael A. Smith
reviews.message: I love me some Taika Waititi!  The Oscar-winning filmmaker has a perfect touch when balancing drama and humor.  And that touch is on full display in “THOR: Love and Thunder.”

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A silly new Thor.

reviews.name: Jordan Ruimy
reviews.message: There’s dry wit throughout this movie, but also a sense of unearned familiarity.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Rogers
reviews.message: The resulting tone is so sloppily winking and unserious that it feels grotesque.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: I'll say this about Thor: Love and Thunder, it tries a little of everything. Unfortunately it results in a pretty disappointing mess.

reviews.name: Cris Kennedy
reviews.message: Hemsworth is a dream - he really understands his own strengths as a performer and as a thing to be objectified.

reviews.name: Matt Neal
reviews.message: The idea that Waititi has made the Thor films throwaway comedic fluff is nonsense.

reviews.name: Rob Hunter
reviews.message: Is Thor: Love and Thunder a bad film? I don’t know, but maybe it’s time to reevaluate 2013’s Thor: The Dark World as the franchise’s weakest entry…

title: Bullet Train
description: In Bullet Train, Brad Pitt stars as Ladybug, an unlucky assassin determined to do his job peacefully after one too many gigs gone off the rails. Fate, however, may have other plans, as Ladybug's latest mission puts him on a collision course with lethal adversaries from around the globe -- all with connected, yet conflicting, objectives -- on the world's fastest train. From the director of Deadpool 2, David Leitch, the end of the line is only the beginning in a wild, non-stop thrill ride through modern-day Japan.

characteristics.Rating:: R (Pervasive Language|Brief Sexuality|Strong and Bloody Violence)
characteristics.Producer:: Kelly McCormick, David Leitch, Antoine Fuqua
characteristics.Production Co:: Sony Pictures Entertainment (SPE), 87North, Hill District Media, CTB Inc.

reviews.name: Brian Rowe
reviews.message: Bullet Train is a mixed bag, worth seeing for action fans, but maybe at a matinee screening or when it hits VOD. There’s a tighter and better 100-minute movie in that 126-minute high-energy extravaganza...

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: With an A-list cast happily playing against type, a nonlinear storytelling approach, witty dialogue and a plethora of creative violence, Bullet Train plays out like an immensely satisfying upgrade of prime Tarantino.

reviews.name: tt stern-enzi
reviews.message: A blast... The film works because Brad Pitt is a really funny and engaging guy.

reviews.name: Jonathan Sim
reviews.message: Leitch helms his action with clarity and impact, creating a beautifully nonsensical thrill ride that could have been a trainwreck, but entertains to the end of the line.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: If Kill Bill: Vol. 1 is wagyu steak, this is a juicy dive burger.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: Strangely, this murder at 320kms per hour action comedy may be an embarrassment of riches in the talent department, but the execution leaves one exhausted by the trip, impatient to find their stop.

reviews.name: Joe Lipsett
reviews.message: Without ebbs or flows to modulate the viewing experience and a never-ending barrage of increasingly ridiculous action (fun at first; exhausting by the end), Bullet Train proves that sometimes “more” is actually too much.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: Like the titular mode of transportation, it does pick up speed as it barrels along.

reviews.name: Marriska Fernandes
reviews.message: Brad Pitt's comedic chops are what saves an otherwise exhausting Bullet Train. It is Pitt's incredible comedic deliveries and charisma that carry the film. He proves that, even with a poor script, he has the talent to keep the film on track.

reviews.name: Jeff Beck
reviews.message: With unpredictable intersecting storylines, innovative fight sequences, and a memorable cast of characters, Bullet Train is that rare action flick that doesn't skimp when it comes to delivering in the important areas that are often neglected in the genre.

reviews.name: Charles Taylor
reviews.message: If Brad Pitt's remaining performances are numbered, I would hate like hell to think of what we missed just so that we could have this.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: Not even its sensational cast can save this mildly entertaining train ride from derailment. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Scott Tobias
reviews.message: It’s not fatal that Leitch and company have no evident goal other than to amuse audiences with two hours of spiffy nonsense, but there’s a whiff of try-hard desperation behind the film’s bravado.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a relentlessly frenetic (and utterly exhausting) actioner that’s rarely, if ever, as exciting as one might’ve anticipated...

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: Is the movie trying to say something here? Something about the cruel, farcical hand of fate? Nah. But it is trying to say something: Shut up and enjoy this.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: It's supposed to Tarantino-esque, and cute, and Antoine Fuqua-riveting-action-y, and hilarious, but it's just none of the above. Miss this train.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: As an action comedy, it borrows a handful of Ritchie clichés and mixes them conventionally into a violent plot that stumbles unsurprisingly along the rails of chaos and boredom. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Latoya Austin
reviews.message: Bullet Train is an entertaining high-octane thriller ... is guaranteed to be memorable to audiences

reviews.name: Michael Wood
reviews.message: Fantasies of crime, especially unruly ones, often have ideas of order and control at their heart, a reach of power we rarely have in ordinary existence.

reviews.name: Andrew Kendall
reviews.message: It's a shortcoming when a film set on a highspeed train seems to take no strategic visual approach to presenting that velocity onscreen. "Bullet Train" is not lazy enough to be 'by the numbers', but it never feels aesthetically thought out or engaging.

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: Unlike the best action-comedies, there is nothing breezy or light about the film; rather, it runs hard and heavy, constantly trying to impress you with its bloody mayhem.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: The film needed more of that rebellious yet natural energy instead of the “he killed my wife, I’m mad about that” vengeance diet. What could have been pretty cool ended up being very dull and forgettable.

reviews.name: Rebecca Harrison
reviews.message: It’s a shame that the filmmakers didn’t trust the spatial and dramatic tensions provided by the train journey, and opted instead for seen-it-all-before spectacle.

reviews.name: Nestor Bentancor
reviews.message: Not as clever and funny as it thinks it is, but the stylish action comedy is always stimulating and amusing.

reviews.name: Jeff Ewing
reviews.message: A lot of fun to watch, while the talented cast fully leans into the colorful cast of characters they’re given to work with. It’s outlandish, a little hard to believe at times, and over-the-top in a way that never falls into full blown camp.

reviews.name: Sarah Marrs
reviews.message: It’s just funny enough, just star-powered enough, just well-choreographed enough to squeak by its own shortcomings.

reviews.name: Carey-Ann Pawsey
reviews.message: Bullet Train is a completely zany yet butt-kicking good time film with a fun story.

reviews.name: Tony Baker
reviews.message: It didn't blow me away, but I was entertained.

reviews.name: Maggie Lovitt
reviews.message: Bullet Train is an exceptionally fun trip to the cinemas. Pitt gives a downright hilarious performance, reaffirming that he is one of the greats, while Henry and Taylor-Johnson give him a run for his money as the best of the film’s cast.

reviews.name: Emma Simmonds
reviews.message: Bullet Train is too cartoonish for much to be at stake and piles on the effects-heavy carnage in its final throes. Luckily, Pitt's delivery just about keeps it on track.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: It delivers nothing we haven't seen before. Yet it succeeds on charisma and energy alone.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: I ended up asking myself what was more vexing in this film: the allusions to popular culture, the crass hypocrisy of an overworked plot, or the phony action sequences.

reviews.name: Thomas Stoneham-Judge
reviews.message: Bullet Train offers a lot to like and leaves something to be desired at the same time.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: It moves at a good pace, it is full of charismatic performances, and it is always ready to include more violence and blood and one-liners to distract the viewer. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: We're left with a movie that doesn't bother with logic and that believes piling on more stylized action, more shallow humor, and a few cheap cameos is enough to get by.

reviews.name: Eric Francisco
reviews.message: While Bullet Train’s basic premise is a recipe for fun and does succeed in entertaining with pleasing action choreography, it’s never as clever as it thinks it is nor as exhilarating as it ought to be.

reviews.name: Kent Garrison
reviews.message: Leaves a lot on the table with this concept, but no one can pull off a bucket hat like Brad Pitt.

reviews.name: Travis Johnson
reviews.message: The twisty, more-smug-than-clever plot doesn’t really matter, the fun and the guns and the odd celebrity cameo and gruesome death do.

reviews.name: Chris Joyce
