reviews.message: To say I was horrified isn’t quite the right word, but Nope gave me that queasy, funny feeling only Peele knows how to create.

reviews.name: Mitchell Beaupre
reviews.message: There are few experiences more thrilling in cinema these days than watching a Jordan Peele film, and Nope is without question his biggest effort so far in terms of scale and spectacle.

reviews.name: Grant Watson
reviews.message: Nope continues Peele’s winning streak of smart, surprising, and hugely effective thrillers.

reviews.name: Samuel Leggett Jr.
reviews.message: NOPE has ground breaking cinematography and sound design. If seen in theaters or under surround sound, you truly feel like something is out there. Palmer and Kaluuya have great performances, but it was Steve Yeun's character that was most engaging here

reviews.name: Kevin Sampson
reviews.message: Nope establishes Jordan Peele as an auteur, with a unique perspective in telling stories cinematically! Don’t worry folks, if you think you saw the movie in the final trailers, you don’t know what you’re in for.

reviews.name: Fletcher Peters
reviews.message: Brandon Perea quickly became one of our favorite new performances of the year thanks to his fantastic comedic timing in Nope...five stars, Angel, five stars.

reviews.name: Ella Feldman
reviews.message: It's a spectacle about spectacle, and about the gambles we'll take to create it and monetize it. That quest lies at the heart of American culture. Nope suggests it's a quest that might eat us all alive.

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: Beautiful and terrifying.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: This is a film full of symbolic exhortations, which is as much a part of the goals of science-fiction as it is essential to Peele’s cinematic oeuvre.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: If you’re expecting another Get Out or Us, you’ll be sorely disappointed. But if given the chance to enjoy it for what it is, then you’ll be saying Nope is dope! That’s a huge yep from me.

reviews.name: Candice Frederick
reviews.message: Closer to the slick visuals of “Get Out” but with a more probing narrative, akin to “Us,” “Nope” is as much an experience as all of Peele’s efforts, with a similarly intriguing premise.

reviews.name: Dan Schindel
reviews.message: “Nope” is another equally thrilling and smart ride from the rising director, subtly tackling intersecting ideas about “seeing” and “being seen” along the way.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: ... layering text and subtext so that audiences can choose to engage with either, deriving pleasure from the tale as either a cinematic spectacle or a profound exploration of humanity’s inability ...

reviews.name: Shawn Edwards
reviews.message: Jordan Peele's latest is ambitious and well made but exhausting and confusing.

reviews.name: Brandon Judell
reviews.message: The first hour of Nope is pretty negligible fare with the exception of a flashback to a killer chimpanzee and the wonderful-to-see-again Donna Mills almost getting kicked in the kisser by an upset steed.

reviews.name: Jonathan DeHaan
reviews.message: Nope is full of fun, freaky, thoughtful re-imaginings of the classic UFO movie loaded with creepy monsters, silly characters, and high-stakes action sequences.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: The odd pacing and ofttimes disjointed storytelling will be off-putting to some, but they're in the service of a variety of knotty themes.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: It's a comment on Hollywood and how people are wasted, swallowed up, disfigured in the name of entertainment. But it’s also foreboding and spooky as hell.

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …a good Saturday night entertainment, but perhaps more was expected from a writer director whose name has become an established brand…

reviews.name: Ro Moore
reviews.message: Peele puts the logic-defying risks people take to "capture the moment" and feed society’s obsession the mysterious front and center. It’s dark, twisted and tilts at windmills full throttle.

reviews.name: Kathryn Reklis
reviews.message: Peele has emerged as one of the great living filmmakers by marrying the genre conventions of science fiction and horror with deep, layered social commentary.

reviews.name: Michael Wood
reviews.message: [Nope] takes this word as its title and offers several other interesting usages. All of them suggest that what we’re thinking or saying is absurdly wrong: a proposition that doesn’t need to be made, or that can’t be responded to in any other way.

reviews.name: Gisela Savdie
reviews.message: Instead of trying to elucidate the plot, it is better to let ourselves be abstracted by the images with their allegories and symbolism alluding Hollywood, and racial and social differences. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Scott Tobias
reviews.message: Working with the fine cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema, Peele turns the Haywood ranch into a wide-format proscenium of supernatural mayhem.

reviews.name: Jaby Koay
reviews.message: I thought that this was like a well told story, it kept me hooked and engaged all the way to the end.

reviews.name: Ileana Meléndez
reviews.message: I got the same rush/thrill watching NOPE that I did watching "War of the Worlds"... I found NOPE to be pretty chilling.

reviews.name: Latoya Austin
reviews.message: Peele’s direction remains thought provoking whilst utilising jump scares, close framing and the audience’s fear of the unknown to amplify that sensation of unease.

reviews.name: Jorge Arturo Mora
reviews.message: Far from perfect, but with more interesting visuals and themes.  [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: My best guess is that Nope is an allegory about what happens when we try to profit from forces we barely understand.

reviews.name: Alex Billington
reviews.message: Acclaimed horror filmmaker Jordan Peele's latest film Nope is an attempt at addressing our obsession with spectacle and this insatiable desire to look, rather than look away.

reviews.name: Kristen Maldonado
reviews.message: The first act of Nope is strange, scary, and even a little weird [but] the intrigue doesn't last.

title: Source Code
description: Helicopter pilot Colter Stevens (Jake Gyllenhaal) is part of a top-secret military operation that enables him to experience the last few minutes in the life of Sean Fentress, a man who died in a commuter-train explosion. The purpose of Colter's mission is to learn the identity of the bomber and prevent a similar catastrophe. As Colter lives Sean's final moments, he becomes more certain that he can prevent the first tragedy from occurring -- as long as he doesn't run out of time.

characteristics.Producer:: Mark Gordon, Philippe Rousselet, Jordan Wynn

reviews.name: Sean Axmaker
reviews.message: ... a nifty mystery with snappy action and a real paranoid atmosphere for our (correctly) suspicious hero...

reviews.name: Michael Clark
reviews.message: It might and does take until the last scene to do so, but every plot thread is sewn-up, and there isn't a clue doled out along the way that doesn't make sense or fit into the final puzzle. Its as close to perfect as a screenplay can get.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: The cast is great, the plot is quite ingenious and the runtime is nothing too overbearing.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: What begins as a highly engaging science-fiction quandary steadily devolves into a less sincere and confusing predicament that opens itself up for a multitude of plot-holes.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Michelle Monaghan adds tremendous depth and humanity to a woman who could have easily just been a romanticized caricature or afterthought.

reviews.name: Ed Travis
reviews.message: Source Code is a really strong film. It is a significantly more "pop" film than Moon was and will probably reach a wider audience.

reviews.name: Debbie Lynn Elias
reviews.message: As he did with Moon, [Duncan] Jones, together with screenwriter [Ben] Ripley, tackle concepts few dare to imagine let alone address.

reviews.name: David Harris
reviews.message: One of the most exhilarating and satisfying films I've seen.

reviews.name: Nikki Baughan
reviews.message: [A] bold - and often brilliant - piece of action filmmaking, which artfully blends notions of identity and fate with blockbuster effects and some snappy editing.

reviews.name: Noah Berlatsky
reviews.message: It's just a dumb Hollywood film.

reviews.name: Kate Rodger
reviews.message: The cheesiness at times was a negative but I enjoyed the simple effective narrative, and the cast delivers nicely.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: This slickly crafted, time-shifting thriller from director Duncan Jones takes an intriguing premise and mixes it with some compelling twists and turns that make it a fun ride from start to finish.

reviews.name: Nathalia Aryani
reviews.message: Source Code is a streamlined, suspenseful sci-fi thriller served with heart.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: Mostly, though, Source Code satisfies as both science-fiction and crime thriller.

reviews.name: Kelly Jane Torrance
reviews.message: [Director] Duncan Jones isn't just creating his own career; he's helping to transform a genre.

reviews.name: Matthew Groizard
reviews.message: This is a film that feels 'smart' without desperately trying to be so. The characters are few and the settings limited, such that complex ideas can peacefully exist inside the film, without tying the narrative in knots.

reviews.name: Johnny Gayzmonic
reviews.message: If you can overlook the pseudoscientific explanations...you'll be treated to a trippy, head-spinning sci-fi drama with amazingly organic, human characters at its core.

reviews.name: Annalee Newitz
reviews.message: As science fiction, it's a little shaky. But it's definitely worth seeing-Duncan Jones has delivered an entertaining, fast-paced thriller with characters you actually care about.

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: ...one heck of a time-bending sci-fi thriller...

reviews.name: Sarah Marrs
reviews.message: ... Source Code is a well-made sci-fi thriller, continuing the evolution of an interesting filmmaker in Duncan Jones.

reviews.name: Lindy West
reviews.message: Source Code is Quantum Leap meets Groundhog Day meets a train. Silly but fun.

reviews.name: Sean Burns
reviews.message: I'd rather flirt with Michelle Monaghan than hunt down a mad bomber, too.

reviews.name: Una LaMarche
reviews.message: Ultimately, Source Code makes good on its Hitchcockian opening sequence -- it may pale in comparison to the master, but it's a fun, puzzle-filled ride, with excellent pacing and a mounting uneasiness that recalls the best episodes of The Twilight Zone.

reviews.name: Peter Howell
reviews.message: Source Code is a sci-fi thriller that simply shouldn't work as well as it does.

reviews.name: John Swansburg
reviews.message: It's this emotional arc underlying the ticking-time-bomb plot that keeps the movie from succumbing to its flaws.

reviews.name: Jay Stone
reviews.message: Source Code is a mind-bending minor classic of its type, a sort of Groundhog Day with terrorism and fewer weather reports. It's as if The Matrix hopped aboard a rapid-transit line and got derailed into the American military bureaucracy.

reviews.name: Tim Basham
reviews.message: Source Code takes off with some intense performances and an inventive story that pulls you in and makes you work for the payoff.

reviews.name: Frank Lovece
reviews.message: A thoroughly original, imaginative and fast-flying tale in which the Groundhog Day aspects are secondary to a story of service, honor and dedication.

reviews.name: Matthew Odam
reviews.message: Jones proves with Source Code that he understands how to pace a traditional thriller, and Gyllenhaal's display of comedic chops, confident bravado and tender sympathies prove that the 30-year-old actor has arrived at leading-man status.

reviews.name: Scott Foundas
reviews.message: Jones ... has a light touch of the sort that enlivens the material without trivializing it-think of it as tongue delicately navigating the perimeter of cheek

reviews.name: Amy Curtis
reviews.message: Fantastic pacing, an excellent performance by Gyllenhaal and smart storytelling make this a wonderful film.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Adorably preposterous

reviews.name: Ben Kendrick
reviews.message: In spite of an over-complicated premise, Source Code succeeds in offering an above-average thriller -- with interesting sci-fi ideas for genre buffs to debate.

reviews.name: Matt Looker
reviews.message: More like a thinking man's Speed as opposed to a what-were-you-thinking man's Déjà Vu.

reviews.name: Jeff Beck
reviews.message: "Source Code" is a fascinating sci-fi action film that works surprisingly well given the scant logic it gets away with.

reviews.name: Michael Dequina
reviews.message: Duncan Jones continues to build a rep for heady and ambitious sci-fi.

reviews.name: Claudia Puig
reviews.message: Holes in logic get swept aside by the brisk pace and stimulating tale.

reviews.name: Perry Seibert
reviews.message: Jones' conception of how the universe works pretty much eliminates the possibility of drama.

reviews.name: Ed Gibbs
reviews.message: Were it supremely confident of knowing when to show its trump card, the film could have gone even further.

reviews.name: Laurence Boyce
reviews.message: Source Code is genuinely compelling and - whilst not always successful - remains a fine example of an intelligent, modern sci-fi thriller.

title: Triangle of Sadness
description: In Ruben Östlund's wickedly funny Palme d'Or winner, social hierarchy is turned upside down, revealing the tawdry relationship between power and beauty. Celebrity model couple, Carl (Harris Dickinson) and Yaya (Charlbi Dean), are invited on a luxury cruise for the uber-rich, helmed by an unhinged boat captain (Woody Harrelson). What first appeared instagrammable ends catastrophically, leaving the survivors stranded on a desert island and fighting for survival.

characteristics.Producer:: Philippe Bober, Erik Hemmendorff
characteristics.Production Co:: Imperative Entertainment, TRT Sinema, Sveriges Television, 30West, BBC Film, Coproduction Office, ZDF Arte, Film i Väst, arte France Cinéma, Essential Films, Plattform Produktion

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: I found it to be far too obvious and much too long; it's nowhere near as searing and subtle as Östlund's 'Force Majeure,' which had an emotional sting.

reviews.name: David Bax
reviews.message: As was the case with Force Majeure (and not so much the case with The Square), Triangle of Sadness is funny, at times outrageously so.

reviews.name: Rudie Obias
reviews.message: It’s a wild satire of the mega-wealthy and the people who serve them.

reviews.name: Preston Barta
reviews.message: 'Triangle of Sadness' kicks up the wild meter and delivers a more narratively scattered work [compared to Östlund’s previous films]. Still, it hangs in the mind and is intelligent filmmaking.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: This year a good Scandinavian director shows many things I have observed in real life but never once seen depicted on screen and he gets castigated for it.

reviews.name: Antonio G. Spíndola
reviews.message: Despite the spiciness of its ingredients, this feature film becomes the equivalent of a frustrating three-course meal that gradually disenchants the palate. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Milana Vujkov
reviews.message: There is a point where all good intentions in a storyline turn to dust, and that is when the said narrative stops respecting its characters, however vile they are.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: Its satire sinks into a cocktail of stereotypical and unfunny characters that only work on the surface to build an basic social text about the human condition and the class divergence implanted by the verticality of capitalism. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Robert W. Butler
reviews.message: Malevolent pleasures [are] exhibited...

reviews.name: Namrata Joshi
reviews.message: A scathing stab at class divides.

reviews.name: Saibal Chatterjee
reviews.message: Triangle of Sadness is a thoroughly entertaining, delightfully wicked fable about structures of power that are only one shipwreck away from going belly up. A perfect parable for an age of excess.

reviews.name: Elissa Suh
reviews.message: Ostlund doesn’t want to eat the rich; he wants to eat with them.

reviews.name: Graeme Tuckett
reviews.message: If you have the stomach for it, Triangle of Sadness is the comedy of the year so far. No contest.

reviews.name: Margot Harrison
reviews.message: There's something bracingly right, even crowd-pleasing, about the plot's final twist. It may not be uplifting Oscar material, but this satire is seaworthy.

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: Östlund always employs an insolent outlook, laughing at his characters, judging them for their thoughts and actions, making fun of their reactions and contradictions, and showing off their baseness. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: Exhilarating at its best and worthy of reflection even at its most obvious and narrow.

reviews.name: Alejandro Lingenti
reviews.message: In this exercise in unbridled misanthropy, cinema seems to fade into the background. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: Perhaps too long, the uneven film starts out high and above but ends up somewhere beneath. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alfonso Flores-Durón y Martínez
reviews.message: Despite the sharp satirical tone, some biting observations, and the use of some clever visual metaphors, Östlund repeatedly lapses into the obvious... and is barely saved by his craft and, of course, his indisputable talent. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alejandro Alemán
reviews.message: It is a film full of demagogy and social resentment whose darts are overwhelmingly obvious. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Gavia Baker-Whitelaw
reviews.message: Set on a luxury cruise, this dark comedy feels like a psychological experiment crossed with the gross-out humor of 'Jackass.'

reviews.name: Randy Meeks
reviews.message: Between period dramas and meta-cinematic reflections, here's a hilarious and shameless parody. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Luis Martínez
reviews.message: The virtue of the Swede's gaze is in his ability to turn each daily act into the result of infinite meticulously ordered errors. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Desirée De Fez
reviews.message: Triangle of Sadness is the best manifestation of a current trend (although Öslund has always practiced it): the sharp satire saturated with black humor geared towards the rich. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Mariona Borrull
reviews.message: It's protagonist, a woke and dumb model, surely has a null sense of humor, right? He'll be the first to fall head-first on contradictions when driven out of his mind. Same as Östlund... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Nando Salvá
reviews.message: It's vulgar, childish and lacking in subtlety, but also a lot of fun. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Brian Susbielles
reviews.message: Not just on the cruise, but in the social hierarchy. Östlund drags them down to earth cruelly, and no champagne can clean this new stench.

reviews.name: Ruth Maramis
reviews.message: Watching this brazen satire is quite a singular experience. Hilarious and well-acted but also overlong and as indulgent as the filthy rich aboard the yacht.

reviews.name: Rahul Desai
reviews.message: ...wicked but weirdly unsubtle social satire...

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: Insofar as originality is concerned - the plot is directly lifted from the British film 'The Admirable Crichton' (1957), based on a J.M. Barrie play...I found this a smug, self-indulgent bore - but, obviously my negative opinion is in the minority.

reviews.name: Pablo Villaça
reviews.message: Ruben Östlund is proving himself to be a master at creating discomfort by exposing the hypocrisy of the characters he follows. [Full review in Portuguese]

reviews.name: Sonny Bunch
reviews.message: Might have been the picture of the year if it had ended nearly 80 minutes in.

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: Best projectile vomiting of 2022.

reviews.name: Morgan Rojas
reviews.message: 'Triangle of Sadness' satirizes high society's self-obsessed elites, making for a side-splitting, vomit-spewing, hilariously unhinged time.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: Money can't buy you a solution to basic bodily functions when food poisoning and seasickness strike, and doesn't this scathingly entertaining flick revel in that notion at its most gleefully gross.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: A painfully blunt satire of the super rich and Instagram celebrity that is rarely entertaining and often annoying.

reviews.name: Fernanda Solórzano
reviews.message: Östlund's new order... showcasing people appearing sophisticated (and failing). [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jason Fraley
reviews.message: A surprisingly accessible yet deeply profound social commentary. The first act explores evolving gender dynamics, the second act spews seasick political satire aboard a luxury yacht, and the third act becomes a “Lord of the Flies” survivalist allegory.

reviews.name: Wenlei Ma
reviews.message: The title doesn’t effectively sell how chaotically funny and eviscerating Ruben Ostlund’s social satire is.

reviews.name: Jane Freebury
reviews.message: Dark satiric take on the uber rich and ridiculously influential from a filmmaker with a wicked eye and ear for how we behave, and a gift for sending us up

title: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever
description: In Marvel Studios' "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever," Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett), Shuri (Letitia Wright), M'Baku (Winston Duke), Okoye (Danai Gurira) and the Dora Milaje (including Florence Kasumba) fight to protect their nation from intervening world powers in the wake of King T'Challa's death. As the Wakandans strive to embrace their next chapter, the heroes must band together with the help of War Dog Nakia (Lupita Nyong'o) and Everett Ross (Martin Freeman) and forge a new path for the kingdom of Wakanda.

characteristics.Producer:: Kevin Feige, Nate Moore

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: A disappointment, especially compared to its excellent predecessor.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: Wakanda Forever is very long and needed an intermission. You know it’s a Marvel movie because it’s steeped in boredom, with every scene threatening to not end.

reviews.name: David Hogan
reviews.message: lack Panther: Wakanda Forever has the usual MCU mix of humour and fun action scenes but it's severely lacking a charismatic lead performer, and some of the lazy writing during the final third was frankly embarrassing. One of the weaker MCU efforts.

reviews.name: Annie Banks
reviews.message: Its pacing may feel a bit undercalculated as some scenes consume too much screen time, though unsure footing can be forgiven by closed chapters and new beginnings.

reviews.name: Gavia Baker-Whitelaw
reviews.message: The sheer volume of subplots makes the finished product rather unwieldy, struggling to maintain the tight thematic focus of ‘Black Panther.’

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: If there’s one compelling callback to the lost T’Challa that really works, it’s the Queen who has seemingly lost a good chunk of her family and now is faced with its greatest threat. Bassett is the brightest light here.

reviews.name: Vera Wylde
reviews.message: There's already something kind of special about a movie that's largely about grief being made as an act of grieving.

reviews.name: Noah Berlatsky
reviews.message: Wakanda Forever tries to be a tribute and a recapitulation and a cog in the ever-grinding Marvel machine. The result is sometimes moving and intermittently watchable. But it’s a also a mess—not least in its politics.

reviews.name: Peter Martin
reviews.message: Feels like a very fitting memorial to a friend who died unexpectedly from a horrible disease, far too young.

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: Wakanda Forever doesn't show, it tells. This is, simply and plainly, an affront to cinematic language. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: The tribute here is heartfelt, but the spirit of the man and the character sometimes get lost in all the bric-a-brac of the Marvel machine... the film lands on a triumphant note of succession, as it must– the gods inside and above the narrative demand it.

reviews.name: Grant Watson
reviews.message: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a good film, that much is certain. At the same time it fails to quite match the extraordinary impact of the original Black Panther.

reviews.name: Matthew Pejkovic
reviews.message: An exercise in superhero mourning done right.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: A beautiful tribute, an attempt at every turn to honor and recognize Chadwick Boseman's importance... they meant so well, but as a film there are a lot of misses here.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: A compelling, beautiful story about family and carrying on a loved one’s legacy...

reviews.name: Kip Mooney
reviews.message: A superhero movie with soul.

reviews.name: Kevin Sampson
reviews.message: You can hear a pin drop in the first five minutes of Wakanda Forever. It’s intense and doesn’t let go of wrestling with loss, the cycle of violence and how we respond to it all throughout its running time. Even with that, this film is a vibe!

reviews.name: Joseph Garcia
reviews.message: In this meta way, there is this audience recognition that the actors on screen aren’t just going through the motions here and what you’re witnessing isn’t a performance of grief, but an actual show of grief.

reviews.name: Diane Carson
reviews.message: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever entertains but also disappoints, perhaps because we expect so much more.

reviews.name: Carla Renata
reviews.message: Angela Bassett is in control with a cinematic elegance that can't be taught or directed - it's in her DNA making this sequel another reason for audiences to cross arms proclaiming Wakanda Forever with pride and tribute to Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.full_review: Bassett brings her unique prowess to every role she inhabits, but there is something a little more powerful and special about her as Queen Ramonda.  She is in control with a cinematic elegance that can't be taught or directed - it's in her DNA

reviews.name: Fletcher Peters
reviews.message: Tenoch Huerta had his breakthrough role not only in Hollywood’s massive Marvel Cinematic Universe, but also in the MCU’s grand Black Panther story...

reviews.name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
reviews.message: This soulful sequel teams an emotional tribute to late star Chadwick Boseman with some spectacular visual action. A maturity milestone for the Marvel Cinematic Universe, starring Angela Bassett and Winston Duke.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: Where The Avengers: Endgame lacked in its depiction of post-traumatic psychological exploration, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever makes up for in its examination of grief as a motivator and the difficulty of moving on from a core part of one’s own identity.

reviews.name: Erin Maxwell
reviews.message: Though it will be remembered for the strong performances by Wright and Bassett, and the way it powerfully honors Boseman, the storytelling is standard and lacking the same strength.

reviews.name: Rob Hunter
reviews.message: As a tribute to Chadwick Boseman, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a beautiful remembrance of the man, the talent, and the character under his brief stewardship. As a movie, though, the results become a bit shakier.

reviews.name: Carolyn Hinds
reviews.message: For the most part, Coogler balances the film’s onscreen and offscreen needs extremely well. But three areas didn’t quite work for me.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: From veteran Angela Bassett’s emotional speeches to the introduction of young genius Riri Williams (Dominique Heart), there’s plenty to be optimistic about in this crowded but emotionally satisfying Black Panther return.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever pays homage to Boseman's legacy and succeeds in taking the saga into new and exciting directions. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Damon Smith
reviews.message: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever falls noticeably short of its predecessor in many respects except for an unnecessarily bloated 161-minute running time that could easily have trimmed with a few slashes of the title character’s vibranium-enriched claws.

reviews.name: Robin Holabird
reviews.message: It risks letting women handle all the heroics, not a favorite idea among many fanboys—but an approach that succeeds.

reviews.name: Sameen Amer
reviews.message: It may not be the most exciting superhero flick, but Wakanda Forever makes up for its shortcomings with touching drama and terrific acting.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Rogers
reviews.message: Director Ryan Coogler tries valiantly to make this all work and it does here and there. In the end his considerable gifts are arguably better suited to grounded human drama than superhero pictures.

reviews.name: Kathryn Reklis
reviews.message: Much like the Star Wars galaxy or Tolkien's Middle Earth, Wakanda is becoming the realest kind of fictional place, one that inspires collaboration by artists and writers and ordinary fans.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: It's a pretty compelling narrative with the perfect amount of fuel to really make us question how far off T'Challa's path grief has taken Shuri. Ultimately a narrative bridge for the MCU, it always strives to deliver upon its own drama first.

reviews.name: Bruce R. Miller
reviews.message: “Black Panther,” in fact, is on a higher plan than most. It creates a world, inhabits it and gives reasons for its people’s actions. It’s a bold mission statement that’s largely due to Coogler. He makes the 160 minutes worthwhile.

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: Like its predecessor, <i>Wakanda Forever</i> often feels more like it's occupying its own space than advancing the larger narrative.

reviews.name: Reginald Ponder
reviews.message: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever offers a lot of surprises, plenty of action, and a fitting tribute to Boseman as well as to Wakanda. Get your passport stamped and return to Wakanda because it is Well Worth Watching,

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …Wakanda Forever may well have fans, but it’s hard to imagine anyone who could prefer this bloated, confusing film to the far more effective original….

reviews.name: Stephen Kearse
reviews.message: After the death of Chadwick Boseman, the makers of the superhero movie had to reimagine the series. The result makes for a sobering and affecting sequel.

reviews.name: Matt Donato
reviews.message: Tries to do too much with too much movie — but when it stuns, it's stunning.

title: Frequency
description: What if you had the chance to travel back in time and change just one event in your life? What would it be? For John Sullivan (Jim Caviezel), there is no question. He would undo the events of October 12, 1969, when the out-of-control Bruxton fire took the life of his father (Dennis Quaid), a heroic firefighter. Now John may get exactly what he wished for -- and much more than he bargained for.

characteristics.Producer:: Bill Carraro, Toby Emmerich, Gregory Hoblit, Hawk Koch
characteristics.Distributor:: New Line Cinema, New Line Home Video [us]
characteristics.Sound Mix:: Dolby A, Dolby Stereo, DTS, SDDS, Surround, Dolby SR, Dolby Digital

reviews.name: Tony Black
reviews.message: Frequency attempts to ground its subject matter in a level of humanity. The message is simple: you *can* go home again.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: A film that works for virtually all of its running time on a scene-by-scene basis, but also completely fails to work as a holistic object.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: It's an appealingly out-there premise that's employed to perpetually captivating effect by filmmaker Gregory Hoblit...

reviews.name: Nell Minow
reviews.message: Scary, tense, grisly mystery-thriller.

reviews.name: Nick Rogers
reviews.message: Gregory Hoblit's best film generates Spielbergian fascination with temporal drama of twisting timelines, infused with personal conflict and situational tension. It blends "Back to the Future's" rush with "Backdraft's" firefighting and a dash of "Zodiac."

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: If you see the movie, ask yourself what would be the most upbeat ending possible; you'll see it all and more.

reviews.name: Lisa Alspector
reviews.message: Quaid's buoyant earnestness complements the stunning, low-key performance by Caviezel, whose close-ups give new meaning to the idea that still waters run deep.

reviews.name: Betsy Bozdech
reviews.message: As long as you're willing to suspend your disbelief, this is one heck of an entertaining way to kill a couple of hours.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: Like a kid who builds and details a lovely sand castle on the beach and then stomps all over it, the movie is completely destroyed in the last 15 minutes.

reviews.name: Nick Funnell
reviews.message: This ambitious but frustrating timeshift thriller never quite manages to jam together two distinct stories.

reviews.name: Scott Nash
reviews.message: Good action, lots of suspense, Dennis Quaid, and an intriguing Time Travel concept. What more could you ask?

reviews.name: Louis B. Parks
reviews.message: Why gripe about a few minor inconsistencies? Just relax and enjoy the show.

reviews.name: Robin Clifford
reviews.message: An intelligent science fiction thriller that also happens to be a solid father/son movie. It's entertainment aimed at the adult, not teen, audience and squarely hits the mark. Forgive the Hollywood ending.

reviews.name: Moira MacDonald
reviews.message: Features plenty of soft-focus, picture-perfect, father-and-son baseball scenes, an enormous amount of plot, and not quite enough of anything else.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Westhoff
reviews.message: Creates an ingenious twist for the time travel story.

reviews.name: Jeanne Aufmuth
reviews.message: Director Gregory Hoblit has managed to bypass the bulk of the schmaltz and inject real tension.

reviews.name: John R. McEwen
reviews.message: It's amazing what kind of cool stuff you can come up with if you first throw logic and physics out the window.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: “Frequency” is an interesting movie that will appeal to a wide audience, but reality is checked at the door for this solely escapist movie.

reviews.name: Tom Tunney
reviews.message: It's difficult not to notice certain dramatic flaws in Frequency's speculative narrative logic.

reviews.name: Jean Lowerison
reviews.message: There also are too many collage sequences indicating time shifts. The first two or three are interesting; after that they become dizzying, and finally downright annoying.

reviews.name: Margaret A. McGurk
reviews.message: The plot may be out-and-out absurd. But the action-packed script, Mr. Hoblit's fast-paced direction and the array of engaging performances made Frequency easy to embrace.

reviews.name: Philip Martin
reviews.message: ...better executed than conceived

reviews.name: James Sanford
reviews.message: a combination fantasy/tearjerker/thriller with several dizzying twists. It's the first screenplay of former film industry executive Noah Emmerich, and it all but overflows with imagination, suspense and big ideas.

reviews.name: Mick LaSalle
reviews.message: A fairly wonderful movie about fathers and sons and the mystery of time.

reviews.name: Steven D. Greydanus
reviews.message: Touches upon the profound human longing to escape the constraints of time, to see the wrongs and mistakes of the past somehow set right, redeemed.

reviews.name: Liam Lacey
reviews.message: Movies sometimes end up looking like a head-on collision between opposing impulses. Frequency is that kind of movie.

reviews.name: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat
reviews.message: A psychological thriller about the deepening of a father-son relationship.

reviews.name: Chuck Rudolph
reviews.message: The film succeeds because it chooses to focus on the human side of the story.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Fascinating enough to hold our interest, even as it drifts away from its early promise and tries just a bit too hard to bring all of the plot threads to a happy, tidy conclusion. But then, believability isn't an issue here.

reviews.name: Rob Vaux
reviews.message: None of its early heroics really matter: only the botched finale lingers in the mind.

reviews.name: Michael Thomson
reviews.message: For the most part, Frequency works, and works well.

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: A satisfying thriller because it is about something more than just the mechanics of its plot. It has a good story and characters to go along with the suspense, which makes it that much more interesting and involving.

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: The film is fast paced.

reviews.name: Susan Granger
reviews.message: If you're into edge-of-the-seat suspense pulling the cosmic strings of time travel, Frequency will light your fuse.

reviews.name: Eleanor Ringel Cater
reviews.message: Not only does the film benefit from that 'what if?' fascination of being able to change fate, but it allows Quaid and Caviezel to do some effective emotional button-pushing without pushing their luck.

reviews.name: Eugene Novikov
reviews.message: Frequency is at once a crowd pleaser, an intelligent thriller and a heartfelt drama.

reviews.name: Lou Lumenick
reviews.message: My head says Frequency has a 31/2-star first half and 21/2-star second half, averaging out to three stars. But my heart says: Don't miss this one.

title: Emily the Criminal
description: Emily (Aubrey Plaza) is saddled with student debt and locked out of the job market due to a minor criminal record. Desperate for income, she takes a shady gig as a "dummy shopper," buying goods with stolen credit cards supplied by a handsome and charismatic middleman named Youcef (Theo Rossi). Faced with a series of dead-end job interviews, Emily soon finds herself seduced by the quick cash and illicit thrills of black-market capitalism, and increasingly interested in her mentor Youcef. Together, they hatch a plan to bring their business to the next level in Los Angeles.

characteristics.Producer:: Tyler Davidson, Aubrey Plaza, Drew Sykes

reviews.name: Grant Watson
reviews.message: A small gem just waiting for viewers to discover it. You should make sure that you do.

reviews.name: Pedro Gallego
reviews.message: Emily the Criminal confirms Plaza as one of the most magnificent performers of our times, and she should be offered roles of every kind. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Craig Mathieson
reviews.message: As an arts graduate on the wrong side of inequality, Plaza is riveting as a young woman finding her foot in the Los Angeles underworld.

reviews.name: Shannon O'Connor
reviews.message: Emily the Criminal is just the latest in a decade’s worth of iconic, perfect, unforgettable dramatic roles for the queen of deadpan.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: The movie has a social commentary that’s not preachy, putting on display the cut-off predicament that ex-cons of all ages run into. Plaza just keeps getting better and better.

reviews.name: Steve Murray
reviews.message: Plaza’s tough but sympathetic performance keeps you hooked all the way.

reviews.name: Catherine Bray
reviews.message: As neatly set-up as the world of the film is, it wouldn’t work half as well without Aubrey Plaza’s brilliantly specific lead performance, portraying Emily as an emotionally shut-down woman on the edge.

reviews.name: James Wegg
reviews.message: Well, what would you do?

reviews.name: Neal Pollack
reviews.message: Emily the Criminal is great at portraying the side of L.A. that we all know and love from classic noir, but also contemporizing it.

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: Aubrey Plaza is just incredible in the lead performance. She's just a skinny little thing, but she really makes you believe that she can hold her ground with bigger, tougher guys. She also makes you believe that she has real steel inside her.

reviews.name: Mitchell Beaupre
reviews.message: Using crippling student loan debt as a motivation for someone breaking bad as opposed to any sort of revenge plot is a genius move, and Ford loads the film with down-to-earth details that make Emily’s story feel so intrinsically rooted in the real world.

reviews.name: Alex Billington
reviews.message: It's a late fest highlight, one of my faves. It remains hyper focused and never wanders, with a 96 minute runtime that is just right for this story...

reviews.name: Carla Renata
reviews.message: Aubrey Plaza, gives a nervy, committed performance, transforming Emily from an embittered temp worker into a stone-cold thief. She is a boss for the entire film ultimately creating her journey on her terms

reviews.name: Scott Phillips
reviews.message: It’s difficult to comprehend this is a debut feature from writer-director John Patton Ford. The filmmaking is so assured. The narrative is so tight. It feels like the work of a seasoned pro.

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: There's a style reminiscent of the Safdie brothers (Uncut Gems) in Ford's film, but this writer/protagonist duo delivers a tour de force with its own signature and merits. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Chad Byrnes
reviews.message: This is not your usual indie fare; it’s a guileless indictment of the broken American dream and one of the best films of the year.

reviews.name: Dustin Rowles
reviews.message: It’s a tight 96-minute runtime and it’s directed with quiet ferocity by John Patton Ford, who is making his feature directorial debut here. Based on this, he’s probably gonna get more jobs

reviews.name: Dylan Roth
reviews.message: Emily is Plaza’s Michael Corleone, a character who erodes your sympathies so slowly that you almost don’t notice what’s becoming of her — or perhaps, what she always was.

reviews.name: Katie Rife
reviews.message: As a crime thriller, Emily the Criminal is well-written and absorbingly paced, but it’s Plaza’s fearless work that makes it memorable.

reviews.name: Lori C.
reviews.message: Emily The Criminal is a brilliant piece of art that’s particularly relevant to today’s world. It’s almost terrifyingly realistic and shows how far a person is capable of going when society turns its back on them.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: Plaza absolutely crushes it!

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: A bit overt in its messaging, I liked the parallel dramatic arcs pitting the lead's personal and professional awakenings together for a tense climax.

reviews.name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
reviews.message: This is a down-to-earth, small-scale, tightly focused genre film. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: Emily The Criminal isn’t in any way bad, it’s just that Plaza is way too good and nothing reaches her level.

reviews.name: Heidy Morales
reviews.message: Written and directed by John Patton Ford, the film showcases Aubrey’s versatility and screen presence. Rossi is cast well as co-star and sidekick. Cinematography by Jeff Bierman works well in evoking the moodiness of the film with cool tones.

reviews.name: Dallas King
reviews.message: Emily the Criminal is a decent thriller driven by an interesting character, but from the faltering pace to the predictable plot, the story overall fails to match the intensity of Plaza’s lead performance.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: It's a bracing look at a society that makes it almost impossible for someone to escape their past. So even as it dips into several thriller cliches, it remains gripping.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: A hugely assured debut for writer-director John Patton Ford.

reviews.name: Tim Robey
reviews.message: Much of the film’s success comes down to Plaza, who has left that deadpan sphinxlike mode of hers some way back in the rear-view mirror.

reviews.name: Leslie Felperin
reviews.message: The glower of actor Aubrey Plaza is a thing of great beauty and precision, as subtle as a stiletto secretly sheathed in a kicky pair of boots.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: Debut writer/director John Patton Ford wrings plenty of queasy, claustrophobic tension out of this scenario and Plaza – clearly relishing the chance to play gritty after a career of kooks and weirdoes – is as good as she’s ever been.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a wholeheartedly enthralling endeavor...

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: A dark exploration of the American Dream and the dangers that it holds

reviews.name: Scott Tobias
reviews.message: Through the conventions of a tidy and efficient little thriller, Emily the Criminal paints a bleak picture of a generation that’s entering adulthood with few avenues to prosperity.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: "Emily" is apropos of the record numbers of low-wage employees currently voluntarily quitting jobs that can never pay the bills. Which is one of the planned steps towards a society's workers letting the state take care of them. An excellent example of it.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: It’s like Robin Hood robbing the rich and giving to the poor; it has the allure of punk rock.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: If you like your crime thrillers slightly smoked with fraught anxiety, then you should be able to commune with this film at a satisfactory level.

reviews.name: Joe Friar
reviews.message: Aubrey Plaza turns in a career-high as a low-grade gangster forced into the Los Angeles underworld to pay off her student loans. The tension is unyielding, the writing impeccable, and the cast first-rate especially Theo Rossi as Plaza’s mentor.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: It’s strangely exhilarating to see a film imbued with such 1970s-style worker rage.

reviews.name: Dana Han-Klein
reviews.message: Plaza is at her absolute best in this unapologetic look at repurposing talent for "unsavory" activities. The film highlights how broken the system is while not getting preachy.

title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift
description: Sean Boswell (Lucas Black) always feels like an outsider, but he defines himself through his victories as a street racer. His hobby makes him unpopular with the authorities, so he goes to live with his father in Japan. Once there and even more alienated, he learns about an exciting, but dangerous, new style of the sport. The stakes are high when Sean takes on the local champion and falls for the man's girlfriend.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Language|Involving Teens|Reckless and Illegal Behavior|Sexual Content|Violence)
characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz
characteristics.Writer:: Alfredo Botello, Chris Morgan, Kario Salem

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: This entry lacks due to Sean being the least interesting character in the film, but it also finds success by featuring some of the very best racing scenes of the entire franchise.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: In lesser hands, Tokyo Drift could've been the series' early death knell, but Justin Lin's confident, propulsive direction makes it a fun, and ultimately necessary, adjunct.

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: ...all Fast and Furious films deliver the goods to their spiralling core audience, Tokyo Drift is the best stand-alone film in the franchise...

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: The film is both hindered by and benefits from the stylized but disconnected directing style of Justin Lin.

reviews.name: Alberto Abuín
reviews.message: The script, if we can call it that, is full of stupidities. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Elliott Noble
reviews.message: With nary a cheap, under-powered motor in sight, this hairpinning if hare-brained sequel goes about its tyre-squealing business with reckless aplomb.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: Not only does the visual style evolve to be less cartoonish in its power zooms, but the sense of humor finds a happy medium between The Fast and the Furious' severity and 2 Fast 2 Furious' all-out comedy.

reviews.name: Mark O'Neill-Cummins
reviews.message: Following 'The Fast and the Furious' and its sequel, '2 Fast 2 Furious', speed fans are in for a treat with this third instalment of action and destruction.

reviews.name: Dennis King
reviews.message: As with the two previous "F&F" films, "Tokyo Drift" is mainly an adolescent fantasy about big, brassy, belching cars and bodacious babes.

reviews.name: People Staff
reviews.message: Many races ensue, but Drift remains strictly for motorheads.

reviews.name: Anthony Quinn
reviews.message: This third outing made me almost nostalgic for the original movie starring Vin Diesel and Paul Walker. Almost.

reviews.name: Christopher Borrelli
reviews.message: It made me want to book a trip to Japan then do doughnuts in a subdivision.

reviews.name: Tim Robey
reviews.message: Whizzily underwhelming...

reviews.name: David Aldridge
reviews.message: Closer in spirit to the stylish 2001 original than the more contrived sequel, Tokyo Drift does just what it says on the tin: the locale is exotic and the race scenes are fast and furious, as are the women.

reviews.name: Total Film Staff
reviews.message: The continent shift provides little more than window dressing.

reviews.name: James Christopher
reviews.message: The Fast and Furious: Tokyo Drift is another dismal chapter in a franchise that started promisingly enough with Rob Cohen's rebel-with-too-much-horse-power-but-lots-of-chicks.

reviews.name: Marcianne Miller
reviews.message: The movie var-rooms on, through its sequence of ear-splitting, knuckle-biting, artery-thumping yet eerily emotion-free races. Ho-hum.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: Considered the red headed stepchild of the 'Fast and Furious' franchise, but beyond the obvious missteps, it's a very fun outing that truly doesn't deserve its bad rap.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...by far the most formally intriguing installment in the franchise.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: A perfunctory and unintentionally goofy attempt to keep the series running without its stars Vin Diesel and Paul Walker.

reviews.name: Joshua Starnes
reviews.message: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift is an uninspired, unoriginal entry in what was already an unoriginal franchise. It's fun to look at, but its narcissistic message is unappealing in the extreme.

reviews.name: Fernando F. Croce
reviews.message: Tediously testosterone-filled

reviews.name: Felix Gonzalez Jr.
reviews.message: It reaches a level of mediocrity that leaves the previous entries in the dust ....

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...the movie's striking setting and compelling lead performance ensure that it remains a slight cut above its immediate predecessor.

reviews.name: Tom Meek
reviews.message: The car races/chases invigorate, but the plot, a hash of an American on foreign soil, the Yakuza underworld, and reconnecting with your father, just spins its wheels.

reviews.name: Donald Clarke
reviews.message: Sadly, as the film progresses, the foolish film-makers succumb to the fatal temptations of plot and dialogue.

reviews.name: Phillip Stephens
reviews.message: Watching events unfold amidst this setting almost makes the film worth the effort until 600 Nissan product-placements flash across the screen.

reviews.name: Jim Lane
reviews.message: The result: worthless idiot-bait for those in the "No Fear" T-shirt crowd who can't handle the mental challenge of playing Grand Theft Auto.

reviews.name: Garth Franklin
reviews.message: The result however remains the same as the last one - a couple of intense and well done race scenes inserted into a truly dull generic movie about a coming of age foreigner driving his way to the top.

reviews.name: Joe Lozito
reviews.message: While the films are still fast, the only thing furious might be the audience after paying $10 for this.

reviews.name: Kam Williams
reviews.message: Just remember that the hot rods burning rubber are the real stars of this spectacular, high-octane tribute to testosterone.

reviews.name: Mark Palermo
reviews.message: The third entry in the Fast and the Furious franchise burrows culture shock in dishonesty.

reviews.name: Peter Travers
reviews.message: Look out for a star cameo -- it's the only surprise you'll get from this heap.

reviews.name: Una Kennelly
reviews.message: Brash, superficial, sexist (the women are fluff - nothing more) and downright boring, it would be insulting to simply label The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift as 'one for the boys'. Not all boys are that stupid.

reviews.name: Mark Pfeiffer
reviews.message: The third time around for The Fast and the Furious finds the franchise spinning its tires.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: This piece of junk is so bad that even Paul Walker turned it down.

reviews.name: Kevin A. Ranson
reviews.message: A nod to the old "new kid in town" formula film... it's better than you might expect.

reviews.name: Steve Rhodes
reviews.message: In Stunt Drivers Gone Wild 3, the plot stays the same although the style of driving differs slightly.

reviews.name: Collin Souter
reviews.message: I found myself responding to its fenderheaded foolishness... and I suspect that those of you with a healthy taste for the absurd may find themselves reacting in the same way.

reviews.name: Neil Smith
reviews.message: Lin's enjoyably stupid action flick keeps the thrills coming thick and, er, fast.

title: Top Gun: Maverick
description:
After more than thirty years of service as one of the Navy’s top aviators, Pete “Maverick” Mitchell (Tom Cruise) is where he belongs, pushing the envelope as a courageous test pilot and dodging the advancement in rank that would ground him. When he finds himself training a detachment of Top Gun graduates for a specialized mission the likes of which no living pilot has ever seen, Maverick encounters Lt. Bradley Bradshaw (Miles Teller), call sign: “Rooster,” the son of Maverick’s late friend and Radar Intercept Officer Lt. Nick Bradshaw, aka “Goose”.

Facing an uncertain future and confronting the ghosts of his past, Maverick is drawn into a confrontation with his own deepest fears, culminating in a mission that demands the ultimate sacrifice from those who will be chosen to fly it.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Some Strong Language|Sequences of Intense Action)
characteristics.Producer:: Jerry Bruckheimer, Tom Cruise, David Ellison, Christopher McQuarrie
characteristics.Writer:: Ehren Kruger, Eric Warren Singer, Christopher McQuarrie
characteristics.Production Co:: Don Simpson/Jerry Bruckheimer Films, Paramount Pictures, Jerry Bruckheimer Films, Skydance Media

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: The film is pure ideology, pure militarism, generic, and like the first Top Gun in 1986, undemanding.

reviews.name: Li Lai
reviews.message: Women in Top Gun: Maverick don’t see much development, but written dialogue and camerawork treat them with respect.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: There’s no reason in the world it should have worked, but it does.

reviews.name: Alison Gillmor
reviews.message: A movie-movie with an old-school movie star, this actioner is best seen in theatres, where the dazzling fighter-jet sequences will make you dizzy.

reviews.name: Benjamin Wiebe
reviews.message: All of these elements come together to form one of the biggest third acts in recent cinema.

reviews.name: Victor Pineyro
reviews.message: While other actors disappear behind their roles, Tom Cruise wants you to know it's him. This movie uses all of its technical marvel to bring us back to an adrenaline-filled formula blockbuster full of emotion. Made for the movies. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: Top Gun: Maverick is a little bloated at times and could have used a bit of trimming, especially in its third act, but there’s no denying the magnetic energy the film brings to the viewer.

reviews.name: Cate Young
reviews.message: "It’s a valid critical interpretation that Top Gun: Maverick is merely propaganda wrapped in a very pretty bow. But boy, that bow is really something."

reviews.name: Santanu Das
reviews.message: Its a sure-footed performance from an actor that never fails to hold the attention of its audience.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: A big jingoistic cartoon. But it’s a fun jingoistic cartoon...

reviews.name: William Jones
reviews.message: After years of uncertainty with the pandemic, Tom Cruise's Top Gun: Maverick has saved movie theaters, revitalizing their business with a great film.

reviews.name: Kevin Sampson
reviews.message: We want the thrill of suspense, to root for characters, to be in awe of cinematography, and to share the collective experience of unity in watching a film with strangers.This movie gives you that and more!

reviews.name: Jason Fraley
reviews.message: Stunning aerial action sequences aren't just random dogfighting but serve as narrative test runs to prep viewers for the climax. Granted, the nostalgia wouldn’t exist without Tony Scott, so it’s hard to give Kosinski credit for copying the flight pattern.

reviews.name: Scott Phillips
reviews.message: As the movie star system gives way to the IP era, don’t ever forget one thing: Tom Cruise is still a major movie star.

reviews.name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
reviews.message: Burnished 1980s blockbuster nostalgia as Tom Cruise and producer Jerry Bruckheimer prove they can still make ’em like they used to. Strap in for the thrillingly real aerial dog fights.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: The zenith of modern “legacy sequels,” Top Gun: Maverick is in many ways traditional—from its “rah rah” militarism, to its 1980s individualism—but it’s also a metatextual lament for the dying light of movie stars.

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: Visually and emotionally satisfying in ways that you’d think would be the norm for big movies featuring families and explosions but very much aren’t.

reviews.name: Frank J. Avella
reviews.message: … an astonishing and glorious film that far surpassing its mediocre predecessor with a good story, amazing tech credits and some fab performances beginning with Cruise himself, who deserves to be in the Oscar conversation

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: Top Gun: Maverick will take your breath away!

reviews.name: Niall Browne
reviews.message: So, why did Top Gun: Maverick strike such a cord with audiences? It’s a film about feeling relevant. About a changing world. Parenthood. Friendship. It resonates.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: It contains just as many formulaic narrative sops and expected character beats as the original, but the streamlining of the simple storyline provides a breeziness that befits and benefits the picture.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: "Top Gun: Maverick" delivers on just about every level imaginable and then exceeds it: plus ultra.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a decent-enough sequel that ultimately falls right in line with its watchable yet far-from-flawless predecessor...

reviews.name: Chase Hutchinson
reviews.message: If a more cheesy sensibility is what you are looking for, then you'll likely enjoy the hell out of this film.

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: Like its predecessor, it thrives on military fetishism, a**hole energy, and the suspension of belief usually reserved for latter-day Liam Neeson fight scenes.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: One more piece of advice: See it in a theater. A big, loud, and crowded one. See it with the fans. That's the way these summer blockbuster blasts were designed to work.

reviews.name: Frantz Jerome
reviews.message: Cruise delivers a nuanced performance that gives Maverick multitudes. More than the character deserves. They find a way to make this guy likable and that is an achievement in itself...

reviews.name: Zoë Rose Bryant
reviews.message: Top Gun: Maverick represents the best of what blockbuster filmmaking can be, brilliantly blending spectacle with sentiment to exhilarating effect.

reviews.name: Laura Hiros
reviews.message: A good story made for young and no so young. It will bring to the beloved franchise a whole new herd of followers. A splurge of technology and action without equal. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: CJ Sheu
reviews.message: After Cruise and McQuarrie perfected the action thriller with Mission: Impossible—Fallout (2018), now they’re back (along with [director Joseph Kosinski and] some other screenwriters and story originators) to perfect the hero’s farewell.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: It flies higher than the original with a few aerial sequences that demonstrate Cruise's skill at piloting anything, but I don't find the sense of adrenaline in the flight routines and the predictable missions in the danger zone. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: ... A summer blockbuster of the old school, with rust-bucket F-14s duking it out with young pups in F-18s, all shot on celluloid rather than sketched in by computers, at the behest of a star who refuses to quit.

reviews.name: Maggie Lovitt
reviews.message: Maverick may make you cry at points, but it is a feel-good, crowd-pleaser through and through.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: The screenplay impeccably balances the new with the nostalgic, drafting on the previous movie’s conflicts and amplifying its emotions.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: It shines brightest in the final 30 minutes which features some of the best aerial fighter footage ever put on screen. See it in the theater. You won’t regret it.

reviews.name: Prahlad Srihari
reviews.message: Sights, sounds and speed act as a unifying force in an assault on our senses. When the engine roars, our knees tremble. When the jets dive, swoop and pirouette like they were in a musical number, the adrenaline rush trickles into the rest of the body.

reviews.name: Alissa Wilkinson
reviews.message: Brings Maverick’s story full circle in a satisfying manner that adds depth and dimension to its predecessor, but still tells a story that’s all its own.

reviews.name: Jordan Ruimy
reviews.message: Forced ode to the original doesn't fully embrace the cheese

reviews.name: Sean Chandler
reviews.message: A sequel that manages to soar higher than it's predecessor.

reviews.name: Taylor Baker
reviews.message: One of the rare films where every discussion leaving the theater is about how much fun you just had, instead of an analysis of its quotients.

title: Absolutely Anything
description: Eccentric aliens give a man (Simon Pegg) the power to do anything he wants to determine if Earth is worth saving.

characteristics.Producer:: Bill Jones, Ben Timlett
characteristics.Production Co:: Media Pro Two, Media Pro Four, Bill and Ben Productions, Premiere Picture, GFM films, Media Pro One

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: Absolutely Anything may be a bad movie, but I laughed a lot, and really, that's what Jones and company set out to accomplish.

reviews.name: Phil W. Bayles
reviews.message: Eric Idle always tells us to look on the bright side, but it's hard to see a bright side to this depressingly unfunny movie. See absolutely anything else.

reviews.name: Matthew Bond
reviews.message: Jones's cult status ensures a decent cast but the execution is messy, short of laughs and tiresome.

reviews.name: Joanne Soh
reviews.message: [Simon] Pegg's goofy charm is on overdrive, elevating this silly comedy where the best scenes are between Neil and his talking dog Dennis (voiced by the late Robin Williams).

reviews.name: Chris Ball
reviews.message: This 2015 film badly misses the mark.

reviews.name: Sandie Angulo Chen
reviews.message: Crass comedy's only redeeming feature is Robin Williams.

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: Treat-sized food-for-thought from a wonderfully silly director.

reviews.name: Chris Tilly
reviews.message: The result is a loosely knitted together series of vignettes, some of which raise titters, but the majority of which elicit groans.

reviews.name: Stephen Dalton
reviews.message: Absolutely Anything is a good idea but is executed poorly, with a lame take-home message about great power demanding great responsibility.

reviews.name: Jake Wilson
reviews.message: The redeeming factor is the sheer, unabashed silliness.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: [It] should have been a lot for fun, [but] sadly it's almost "absolutely anything" but.

reviews.name: Giles Hardie
reviews.message: There is only one thing worse than a bad film. That is a bad film that should have been a great film.

reviews.name: Kaori Shoji
reviews.message: Absolutely Anything is just content to laugh at itself and leave everyone else stranded without a hope in the world.

reviews.name: John Lui
reviews.message: There is good-natured British wackiness aplenty.

reviews.name: Chus Pérez Girón
reviews.message: Kate Bechinsale is totally wasted with a performance that not even she believes. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ignacio Navarro
reviews.message: The movie works in bits and pieces, but in general is just forgettable entertainent. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Sergio Benítez
reviews.message: An entertaining film that will make you laugh out loud. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Toni Vall
reviews.message: Using only four rooms and low budget special effects, the film is full of witt and sarcasm, giving us a smart tale that rises above it's limitations. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Norman Wilner
reviews.message: For a movie about limitless potential, Absolutely Anything carries no creative spark of its own.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: Jones doesn't quite know how to manage all the quirk and slapstick of the picture, which never comes together as completely as it could, disappointing on multiple levels.

reviews.name: Scott Nash
reviews.message: Rarely has so much comic talent been wasted in one movie.

reviews.name: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley
reviews.message: While forgiving Python diehards will probably enjoy Jones irksome outing, others are advised to keep away unless there's absolutely nothing else worth watching.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: Ubiquitous British funnyman Simon Pegg in a crazy sci-fi lark directed by Terry Jones of Monty Python fame? Sounds like a match made in Heaven, yeah? Unfortunately, once this tale gets going it feels more like a match made in purgatory.

reviews.name: CJ Johnson
reviews.message: The worst film thus far of 2015, and so staggeringly terrible I can't imagine it being beaten to the bottom ... Lord knows how and why anyone agreed to make this script into a projected image, but a projected image is all that it is.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: Sounds like fun? Let me assure you, it ain't.

reviews.name: Louise Keller
reviews.message: Mildly amusing, but grossly overdone. The same goes for everything. Absolutely everything

reviews.name: Alex Leadbeater
reviews.message: The absolute worst thing Monty Python has ever done.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Simon Pegg continues his rollercoaster career, alternating between superior blockbuster franchises (Mission: Impossible and Star Trek) and awkward British romantic-comedies (Hector and the Search for Happiness).

reviews.name: Jason Best
reviews.message: The jokes are mostly mirthless, sub sit-com stuff, but one brief gag does raise a chuckle when Pegg's wish for a penis that women find exciting is swiftly followed by the addendum, 'Can I have one in white?'

reviews.name: MaryAnn Johanson
reviews.message: Subjuvenile and offensive, sentimental and ridiculous. Every attempt at a joke falls flat. Every talent here is wasted. Save yourself.

reviews.name: Brigit Grant
reviews.message: It is a very silly, eccentric British film with comedy coy enough to suit the whole family and Python devotees who will see it out of duty.

reviews.name: Jonathan Romney
reviews.message: Watch absolutely anything else.

reviews.name: Simon Reynolds
reviews.message: Based off a script that's been knocking around for some years, Absolutely Anything feels like a half-baked Python sketch strung out and bludgeoned into anti-laugh oblivion.

reviews.name: John Nugent
reviews.message: Forgive the obvious wordplay... but truly, you'll wish you were watching absolutely anything else.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Animated segments should offer some nostalgic interest to Python fans, but it's scant reward for a wish-fulfilment comedy that doesn't fulfil anyone's wishes.

reviews.name: Robbie Collin
reviews.message: It's often been said that Simon Pegg would agree to star in absolutely anything: now at least it's official.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: Certainly one of the worst movies yet made.

reviews.name: Peter Bradshaw
reviews.message: The second word of the title should be "appalling".

reviews.name: Stefan Pape
reviews.message: What would you do if you could absolutely anything? Well, choosing to go back in time 90 minutes and see something else would be rather high up on the agenda.

reviews.name: James Mottram
reviews.message: Bar the occasional faint-smile-raising line, just about every gag, set-piece or quip meets with dead-eyed, stony silence.

title: Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw
description: Brixton Lorr is a cybernetically enhanced soldier who possesses superhuman strength, a brilliant mind and a lethal pathogen that could wipe out half of the world's population. It's now up to hulking lawman Luke Hobbs and lawless operative Deckard Shaw to put aside their past differences and work together to prevent the seemingly indestructible Lorr from destroying humanity.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Some Strong Language|Prolonged Sequences of Action|Suggestive Material|Violence)
characteristics.Producer:: Dwayne Johnson, Jason Statham, Chris Morgan, Hiram Garcia
characteristics.Production Co:: Chris Morgan Productions, Seven Bucks Productions

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: It’s not the most ridiculous film in the franchise from an action standpoint, but nearly the entire runtime is taken up by two grown men...

reviews.name: Kate Boyle
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw is exactly as advertised. It’s a fun action flick, with gratuitous violence, crazy stunts, and lots of entertaining bickering between Jason Statham and Dwayne Johnson.

reviews.name: Adrian Ruiz
reviews.message: Even without Dominic and the rest of the Family, Hobbs and Shaw provide an outlet for spin-offs that works while still paying homage to the messages that got us to this point.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Harris
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw is an overall fun action movie. It delivers on most of the high points, with some amusing banter and interplay between The Rock and Statham, and some crazy, over-the-top action sequences.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: ...funny, violent, predictable and utterly preposterous.

reviews.name: Lonita Cook
reviews.message: It's a fun ride.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: Hobbs and Shaw proves the series remains viable without the rest of the Family, taking an inspired detour into steroid-injected buddy cop territory while dishing up some slyly effective character development.

reviews.name: Alex Bentley
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw focuses on humor and one great central relationship, and winds up being one of the best films in the series because of it.

reviews.name: Fletcher Powell
reviews.message: If you're up for spending 10 bucks to see good movie stars make jokes and explosions, that's what you'll get, and some of it even kind of works.

reviews.name: Richard Crouse
reviews.message: Manages to both rev its engine and spin its wheels, providing some hare-brained action and charming actors but not much else.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: The overdramatic heroism of these cartoonish he-men becomes exhausting as they struggle to ooze cool.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: The spinoff has all the makings of a summer hit. Along with the larger than life talents of the bald-headed warriors in its lead and now the cunning ability of its chief bad guy in Elba.

reviews.name: James Hanton
reviews.message: David Leitch lets his action movie skills do the talking to deliver a summer blockbuster with old-fashioned thrills and spills.

reviews.name: Jason Fraley
reviews.message: You'll walk out smiling. Can you call it a great movie? Not with a straight face. But damned if it isn't one of the more enjoyable "Fast & Furious" flicks in years.

reviews.name: Allen Almachar
reviews.message: I'm all for the suspension of disbelief, but goodness gracious, the line has to be drawn somewhere, doesn't it?

reviews.name: Nabila Hatimy
reviews.message: The film has all the loveable qualities of the original franchise while introducing an inspired comical element from its two main stars.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: It's a fun and exciting action film, infused with plenty of heart, and driven by some great chemistry between its leads.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: Whether Hobbs & Shaw is the dumbest movie ever made is a topic for debate, but it's in the running. Sometimes that's dumb in a fun, goofy way, but more often, it's tedious, exhausting, and a test of patience.

reviews.name: Andrew F. Peirce
reviews.message: Much noise, little wow.

reviews.name: Dan Scully
reviews.message: Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw is a messy, overlong cash draw that despite having a general air of fun about it, pales in comparison to even the worst chapter in the proper saga of the Fast Fambly (The Fate of the Furious to be specific).

reviews.name: Atavia Reed
reviews.message: More times than not this film trips over its superhero tropes.

reviews.name: Charlotte Harrison
reviews.message: This kind of feels like a sorbet, a palate cleanser after action flicks that try so hard to be serious that end up being dull, or confuse dark with bland murkiness.

reviews.name: Julian Lytle
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw is one of the most fun action movies of the year and one of the best superhero movies as well.

reviews.name: Damian Levy
reviews.message: If you can go in for some high-level action with a low-brow script, you'll be entertained.

reviews.name: Angie Han
reviews.message: Maybe the family isn't all there. But it turns out the extended relatives throw a pretty good party, too.

reviews.name: Neil Morris
reviews.message: The bickering bromance between Johnson and Statham is the only reason to endure this illogical, temporally-challenged, cartoonish CGI fest.

reviews.name: Paul McGuire Grimes
reviews.message: Still retains the feel of Fast and the Furious while taking it in a new direction. Cross between that, Mission: Impossible and The Terminator.

reviews.name: Chase Whale
reviews.message: It doesn't matter that HOBBS & SHAW ignore physics and defies the laws of gravity, this movie is one hell of a good time.

reviews.name: Blai Morell
reviews.message: A movie driven above all by the personality and charisma of its two protagonists, who are undoubtedly the biggest action stars today. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Amanda Greever
reviews.message: It's ridiculous fun, which is exactly why you go see one of these films. It won't win any Oscars, but it's a diverting way to spend a couple of hours.

reviews.name: Joshua Starnes
reviews.message: Sure it's lighter than air, and will evaporate quickly, but if that's not the definition of the Hollywood action movie, what is?

reviews.name: Brian Gill
reviews.message: The movie threatens to run itself right off the rails over and over again but maintains its abject absurdity throughout by the slimmest of margins. Thus, it is unbelievably stupid and also unbelievably fun. Long live the Fast Cinematic Universe.

reviews.name: Linda Cook
reviews.message: 'Hobbs & Shaw' is enjoyable 'Fast & Furious' spinoff.

reviews.name: Vicky Roach
reviews.message: A pedal-to-the-metal action adventure - with very little under the hood.

reviews.name: Hoai-Tran Bui
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw is an action movie as a meme; the entire film is a self-effacing wink at the audience.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...an especially ineffective modern blockbuster that wears out its welcome by a good 45 minutes.

reviews.name: EJ Moreno
reviews.message: Who would've thought Hobbs & Shaw would make you appreciate the subtly of the Vin Diesel-led films? This is one of the weaker entries in the Fast and Furious franchise, and that's say something with Tokyo Drift.

reviews.name: Deirdre Molumby
reviews.message: Pumped with adrenaline, humour and action

reviews.name: Chris Sawin
reviews.message: There's chemistry amongst the cast that is undeniable and some of its outrageousness is entertaining, but it all begins to feel similar and falls apart far sooner than it should. The story is basically a dunce cap disguised as a pocket protector.

reviews.name: Kaely Monahan
reviews.message: Hobbs & Shaw" is the boost this franchise needs. I need more Rock and Statham "frienemy" movies, please.

title: She Said
description: Two-time Academy Award® nominee Carey Mulligan (Promising Young Woman, An Education) and Zoe Kazan (The Plot Against America limited series, The Big Sick) star as New York Times reporters Megan Twohey and Jodi Kantor, who together broke one of the most important stories in a generation--a story that helped propel the #Metoo movement, shattered decades of silence around the subject of sexual assault in Hollywood and altered American culture forever.

characteristics.Producer:: Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner

reviews.name: Kathryn Reklis
reviews.message: She Said is remarkably restrained, almost muted.

reviews.name: Gisela Savdie
reviews.message: Even though the subject could lead to sensationalist scenes, the film does not fall into this category, showing a fine discretion that brings the case to the level it deserves. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …She Said does an effective job of evoking the ghosts of the past to warn us that our precarious present is very much open to the very same kind of exploitation of the young….

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: Like all of the great films about journalism, She Said is a fascinating picture that explores the challenges of working in journalism...investigative reporters follow their leads until they can put together a firm and unimpeachable story.

reviews.name: Andrew Kendall
