reviews.message: She Said feels so nimble in craft, but also thoughtful in spite of its initially surprising approach. Schrader has directed a film that is generous and decisive with genuine awareness of the work of journalism that feels so sharp without being officious.

reviews.name: Rebecca Liu
reviews.message: The film is most resonant when it understands its own limits, while not losing sight of its hopes.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: A riveting docudrama, and one of the best films of 2022.

reviews.name: Juan Pablo Russo
reviews.message: Schrader doesn't frame women in a spiral of violence they can't escape, instead, she gives them perspective through collective reflection and, unlike Jay Roach [Bombshell], abstains from sensationalism. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Matt Pais
reviews.message: A crackling intellectual thriller that really understands the essential, difficult work of journalists, and the courage it takes from all sides to bring truth to power.

reviews.name: Catherine Springer
reviews.message: Carey Mulligan and Zoe Kazan are brilliant...each one navigating varying levels of doubt and tenacity, portraying real, three-dimensional people who are more than their job, but are tireless and dedicated representatives of their profession.

reviews.name: Allison Rose
reviews.message: The leads, Mulligan and Kazan, are terrific and help to move the plot along nicely as they scramble to build an article.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: In a world of quick judgments and self-crafted realities, serves as a reminder about the importance of people (and orgs that support them) who diligently, patiently, and thoroughly seek to expose truth regardless of the challenges they face to do so.

reviews.name: Leonardo Garcia Tsao
reviews.message: She Said captures effectively a historical moment when sexual abuse and its legal cover-up stopped being systemic; when victims dared to denounce their abusers no matter how powerful they were. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: M.V. Moorhead
reviews.message: An absorbing account, focusing on the extreme reluctance of the targets of Weinstein's savagery to be first to go on the record by name.

reviews.name: Antonio G. Spíndola
reviews.message: She Said complies with delving into journalism with great rhythm and absolute respect for those who exercise it to its ultimate consequence. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: What this movie shows is how difficult investigative journalism is, and how expensive it is to investigate a story like this. It takes vast resources and top notch talent and expertise in a variety of fields to accomplish what the New York Times did.

reviews.name: Freda Cooper
reviews.message: With all the thriller elements of its illustrious predecessors, it leaves us in no doubt about what the survivors had to lose in speaking up. Everything. The film's heart thumping passion has a power of its own. A triumph.

reviews.name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
reviews.message: Zoe Kazan … and Carey Mulligan … star as Kantor and Twohey, and though they each do a wonderful job, it is the many other actors appearing for but brief onscreen minutes as Weinstein’s victims who make the movie soar.

reviews.name: Samuel Leggett Jr.
reviews.message: She Said is a very good film. The script is tight and feel very organic, even with things still in flux now they allow for the story to experience the lives tragically impacted by this case and the individual involved. Great performances through!

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: The discussions between the journos and their editors are like therapy sessions rather than the kind of spiky, difficult confrontations that might be expected.

reviews.name: Kiko Martinez
reviews.message: A multilayered and intense feature that demands an audience.

reviews.name: Laura Pérez
reviews.message: The narrative weight falls on the women's declarations, some with memorable monologues such as Samantha Morton, and Ashely Judd who plays herself. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Andrea G. Bermejo
reviews.message: The director allows herself a certain distance from the bestseller in the moments that show the personal lives of the leading journalists marked by their status as women and, above all, by motherhood. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Al Alexander
reviews.message: Mulligan and Kazan triumph with remarkable, finely nuanced performances that perfectly capture the life - I use that term loosely - of reporters committed to seeking the truth at a time when my trade is unfairly being labeled “fake news.”

reviews.name: Edwin Arnaudin
reviews.message: All the triumphs and applause-worthy moments are there, but in this by-the-book presentation, they’re sadly muted.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: She Said declines to aim for anything other than the factual narrative, doing it with a mix of courage and relative panache.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: While tidily told by Schrader and her cast, future films about this period would do well to make it clear just what was – and still is – at stake.

reviews.name: Rene Sanchez
reviews.message: Zoe Kazan and Carey Mulligan deliver outstanding performances in this solid journalistic thriller about one of the stories that helped propel the MeToo social movement. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Prairie Miller
reviews.message: Sex, lies and victim porn. And an elephant in the newsroom, more self-congratulatory promo for the NY Times. While intimating a kind of fox in the hen house cover for damage control related to the paper's own numerous scandals, and as common in the media.

reviews.name: Jorge Loser
reviews.message: She Said is informative but fails in trying to be like a '70s political journalism thriller with its timid attempts to create the allusion of danger... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Kevin Carr
reviews.message: An excellent slow-burn story of how real journalism works, even if there are few surprises.

reviews.name: Bruce R. Miller
reviews.message: Interestingly, “She Said” begins with women alleging that Donald Trump assaulted them. That story didn’t seem like such a hand wringer, but the Weinstein one does.

reviews.name: tt stern-enzi
reviews.message: It's a great, strong film. Those two leads are incredible in it.

reviews.name: Dorothy Woodend
reviews.message: As the two journalists build their case, chasing down leads, knocking on doors, the full horror is revealed...

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: Any sense of justice we feel at knowing Weinstein will never breathe free air again is mitigated by the fact that the frameworks designed to protect him and others like him are still largely in place.

reviews.name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
reviews.message: The film tells us a lot about the abuse of power by privileged men towards women with fewer opportunities; about sexism, power roles in the workplace, and how certain men feel they deserve to treat women however they please. Full review in Spanish.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: It lacks the energy and precision vital to any journalistic investigation, and especially to one taking place under this kind of pressure.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: Once the film gets going, Maria Schrader's directing really starts to sharpen up and create some brilliant moments.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: It is so good but not quite so so good.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: It’s been years — maybe as far back as “All the President’s Men” in 1976 — that a movie has captured the craft and the passion of journalism as precisely and as smartly as director Maria Schrader’s “She Said.”

title: Interstellar
description: In Earth's future, a global crop blight and second Dust Bowl are slowly rendering the planet uninhabitable. Professor Brand (Michael Caine), a brilliant NASA physicist, is working on plans to save mankind by transporting Earth's population to a new home via a wormhole. But first, Brand must send former NASA pilot Cooper (Matthew McConaughey) and a team of researchers through the wormhole and across the galaxy to find out which of three planets could be mankind's new home.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Some Intense Perilous Action|Brief Strong Language)
characteristics.Producer:: Emma Thomas, Christopher Nolan, Lynda Obst

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: Staggeringly beautiful, bafflingly complex, this is proper event cinema.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: The film demands quite a bit of time from its viewers too, but its big ideas and wondrous sights are ample reward.

reviews.name: Vadim Rizov
reviews.message: When Mann appears to explain man, it collapses under the weight of a repeated thesis that doesn’t merit such explicit, redundant reiteration.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: It’s a contemplative adventure and an emotional exploration that captivated me from its opening moments.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: Rarely do epics of this scope and intelligence reach theaters anymore; such serious commercial filmmaking seems like a market almost exclusively maintained by Christopher Nolan.

reviews.name: Josh Parham
reviews.message: While not all-together perfect, the film represents a monumental cinematic achievement that deserves to be placed high within the caliber of Nolan’s filmography.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Nolans ambition and talent, coupled with arguably the best leading performance he's ever had in McConaughey's Cooper, brings about a wonderful work of science fiction, one that leaves the viewer breathless during and talking after.

reviews.name: Therese Lacson
reviews.message: The inherent message of the film brings hope, but it can definitely get waterlogged by intellectual speak and long-winded scenes.

reviews.name: Kip Mooney
reviews.message: The film is indeed a sight to behold -- and one that demands to be seen on the biggest possible screen.

reviews.name: Richard Crouse
reviews.message: Nolan reaches for the stars with beautifully composed shots and some mind-bending special effects, but the dime store philosophy of the story never achieves lift off.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: Audiences are sure to lose their suspensions of disbelief over the nearly impenetrable climax.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...an often insanely ambitious science fiction epic that that remains mesmerizing for most of its (admittedly overlong) running time...

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Scientists will debate, theologians will contemplate, philosophers will wonder, and cinema lovers will bask in the glory of another remarkable Christopher Nolan achievement.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: A big-budget reprise of ideas Nolan has been exploring since the beginning of his career. Not only is it a film about the passage of time, it's also a film about memory.

reviews.name: Stephen A. Russell
reviews.message: None of these characters feel fully-fledged... for a film so rife with schmaltzy musings on the meaning of life, it's alarming how lacking it is in this department.

reviews.name: Kelechi Ehenulo
reviews.message: Interstellar is not Christopher Nolan's best film but what I will say is that you can't deny his ambition.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: As spectacular as it is flawed.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: Interstellar is not only a grand space adventure worthy of the big screen, it's also a powerfully emotional story about the bond between a father and daughter, and how that love can drive one to attempt the impossible.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: One of the boldest science-fiction movies I've ever seen, both in narrative and visual terms. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Avaryl Halley
reviews.message: It was a blockbuster movie-going experience.

reviews.name: Andrew Galdi
reviews.message: I guess the take away is all you need is love... and morse code?

reviews.name: Kathi Maio
reviews.message: Interstellar is, all in all, a very fine science fiction film.

reviews.name: Chris McCoy
reviews.message: Interstellar is 120 minutes of good movie stuffed into 170 minutes.

reviews.name: David Harris
reviews.message: Interstellar is Nolan at his most humane. It's a good look for him.

reviews.name: Katie Smith-Wong
reviews.message: Overall, Interstellar looks nice but ultimately lacks substance. Nolan essentially loses his way by going to space.

reviews.name: Kirsten Acuna
reviews.message: The space voyage is easily one of Nolan's most thought-provoking films yet. It's definitely his most ambitious.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: As far as a masterful visualization of space and an exploration of profound theory, it belongs on a shortlist of must see films which it's comparably akin to... But Nolan's film falls short in other realms, namely the human component.

reviews.name: Karl Delossantos
reviews.message: It's as grand as it is introspective and as grounded as it is existential. By the end of the nearly three-hour running time - it goes by in a flash - you feel as if you've experienced something that is so rarely captured on film.

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: Christopher Nolan more than deserves however much money the studios are willing to keep giving him to make these brainy beautiful blockbusters.

reviews.name: Ryan Syrek
reviews.message: Preposterous, pseudointellectual, poorly constructed, clichéd, impenetrably masculine, goofy and possessed of an indecipherable ending, Interstellar is the mother of all misfires.

reviews.name: Dominic Griffin
reviews.message: Moreso than any of his previous projects, Interstellar left me largely confounded, wondering if Nolan had finally "lost it."

reviews.name: Mattie Lucas
reviews.message: The old saying "shoot for the moon - even if you miss you'll land among the stars" has never rung quite as true as it does here.

reviews.name: Christopher Preston
reviews.message: There is absolutely a breathlessness to Interstellar, although perhaps too much of that is huffing and puffing.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: I found it emotionally moving and... what I wanted in a good sci-fi movie.

reviews.name: Ben Nicholson
reviews.message: Interstellar may not be perfect, but tent-pole filmmaking with such ambition and grandeur is always worth celebrating.

reviews.name: Paula Fleri-Soler
reviews.message: With the likes of Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Michael Caine, Casey Affleck, Ellen Burstyn and John Lithgow as supporting players, it is redundant to say that the ensemble adds so much more to a film that boasts excellence in all departments.

reviews.name: Amanda Greever
reviews.message: A contrived science fiction film without authenticity, emotionally and narratively.

reviews.name: Nathalia Aryani
reviews.message: A celestial tapestry of space exploration, time bender and heartfelt human story, it earns its place among the stars.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: Literally reaches for the stars -- and comes up short. Despite the best efforts of a talented cast and writer/director Christopher Nolan, this film just can't overcome a script with black hole-size plot craters.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: Interstellar is impressive. It is superbly made, and combines compelling thought about everything from ecology to the nature of time to a child's belief in ghosts into something cohesive and mostly engrossing.

title: Creed III
description: After dominating the boxing world, Adonis Creed (Michael B. Jordan) has been thriving in both his career and family life. When a childhood friend and former boxing prodigy, Damian (Jonathan Majors), resurfaces after serving a long sentence in prison, he is eager to prove that he deserves his shot in the ring. The face off between former friends is more than just a fight. To settle the score, Adonis must put his future on the line to battle Damian -- a fighter who has nothing to lose.

characteristics.Producer:: Irwin Winkler, Charles Winkler, William Chartoff, David Winkler, Ryan Coogler, Michael B. Jordan, Elizabeth Raposo, Jonathan Glickman, Sylvester Stallone
characteristics.Production Co:: Proximity, Chartoff-Winkler Productions, Glickmania, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), Outlier Society

reviews.name: Erik Childress
reviews.message: When the film's antagonist plays his scheme close to his chest the film achieves an effective level of drama. When all is revealed the film seems desperate to overdrive itself so it can catch up to its inevitable confrontation in the ring.

reviews.name: Greg Carlson
reviews.message: The increasingly sophisticated fight choreography, as rendered via the bloody ballet between Majors and Jordan, is the bread and butter of the genre.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: In one amazing sequence, the crowd at a big fight goes missing, being replaced by a post-apocalyptic ghost land with only the two fighters’ grunts supplying the sound. The camera often whips around the fight as a big exchange is unfolding.

reviews.name: Agustín Acevedo Kanopa
reviews.message: Creed has to definitely become Apollo and survive this transformation in which his ex-friend is much more like Rocky. Thus, destroying the past and rebuilding from it seems to be something that closes not only Creed's arc, but also Rocky's.

reviews.name: Víctor López G.
reviews.message: A spectacle as vibrant as usual and drenched in the trademark Balboa spirit —with an extra dose of sugar, though—.

reviews.name: Sean P. Means
reviews.message: “Creed III” feels like a summation of sorts, but also a new beginning — because it shows a franchise, and a character, finally walking out of the long shadow of Rocky Balboa.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: Nothing really motivates us... Adonis, maybe it’s time to really hang up the gloves!

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: There’s a line late in Creed III that sums up this installment perfectly — “The Creed dynasty reigns supreme.” That’s appropriate for a franchise that keeps knocking out one sequel after another without taking a bad outing to the chin yet.

reviews.name: Marshall Shaffer
reviews.message: It checks all the boxes to keep people who want all their sports competition film needs met (hello training montages!) with enough to satisfy the dramatic storytelling needs of someone who can’t tell a Balboa from a Drago.

reviews.name: James Berardinelli
reviews.message: By delivering the expected and doing so with style and intensity, it lands in the top tier of the nine Rocky universe movies, although falling short by a few titles from the pinnacle.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: Better than the second <i>Creed</i>, worst than the first, and that's pretty much the best-case scenario it was worth hoping for.

reviews.name: Sean Chandler
reviews.message: After nearly 40 years, this franchise is still punching.  This time around they prove the series can work without Rocky or Stallone.  The real standout here is Jonathan Majors who plays one of the best antagonists in the series.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: Jordan makes a few unnecessary forays into expressionism to make this point, but he needn’t have. The climactic bout has more than enough impact without getting into the ring with Scorsese.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: It’s one of the best films of the year...

reviews.name: Justin Brown
reviews.message: It's so predictable that you knew what was going to happen within the first few minutes. But this movie did hit the feels, particularly with the storyline with Adonis' daughter and Damian.

reviews.name: Brandon Collins
reviews.message: It's a bit too predictable but very entertaining with strong direction by MBJ. Jonathan Majors is almost too good as he was on another level...wish there were more scenes between him and Tessa Thompson!

reviews.name: Ed Whitfield
reviews.message: You can replicate the character dynamics of the original series & its story beats – you can chuck in an exhilarating montage, and direct the climatic showdown with style. But without the heart that powered the original movies, it’s a mechanical pastiche.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: A first-rate outing, which shows great potential on Jordan’s part as a director

reviews.name: Paul Risker
reviews.message: Michael B. Jordan’s directorial debut Creed III escapes the shadow of Apollo, Rocky, and Drago and finds new ground for Donnie and the Creed spin-off series to build their own legacy.

reviews.name: Frantz Jerome
reviews.message: Creed III is a thoroughly surprising movie. There is an attention to detail and symbolism that quite frankly has no business being as well done as it was.

reviews.name: Robert Roten
reviews.message: Despite the well-worn path this story travels, it is very well acted and directed. As usual in this series, the fight scenes are expertly staged, but it isn't all about blood, violence, anger and hatred. It is also about love, friendship and respect.

reviews.name: Adam Kempenaar
reviews.message: Creed III is too sleek, too rushed, and too contrived to deliver [all] the emotional payoffs it promises.

reviews.name: Bruce R. Miller
reviews.message: While “Creed III” has that nagging feeling of unfinished business, it also doesn’t have the skills of Sylvester Stallone’s Rocky. Rocky, in fact, isn’t even a fond memory in this outing.

reviews.name: Valerie Complex
reviews.message: The visuals are full of action and energy.

reviews.name: Tim Cogshell
reviews.message: Solid installment!... Pretty pedestrian, but goes places I really like.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: Creed III is no knockout it's still a worthy bout.

reviews.name: Brian Gill
reviews.message: MBJ proves to be equally equipped to provide strength and brilliance both inside the ring and outside of it, stepping into Coogler's massive shoes with great competence. Jonathan Majors is a STAR.

reviews.name: Mikel Zorrilla
reviews.message: Every time a new franchise offering comes out, I'm doubtful we need it, yet, so far they've all been notable and proven that the blade is still sharp, and this new offering isn't an exception. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: It's a powerhouse film whose hardest blows take place outside the ring.

reviews.name: Max Covill
reviews.message: Creed III is a winner, with Jordan and Majors bringing their epic talent to the boxing ring.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: It packs a punch but it seems like you have been ringside at this fight in the past.

reviews.name: Matt Hudson
reviews.message: Proving that the Rocky saga doesn’t necessarily need Rocky himself, Creed III continues to build and improve on what came before, whilst also showing it can stand alone as a fine movie in its own right.

reviews.name: D. Watkins
reviews.message: Creed III is promoted as a boxing movie, but is really a tale of pain, regret and the power of brotherhood.

reviews.name: Stephen Romei
reviews.message: Worth the price of a ringside seat.

reviews.name: Alison Gillmor
reviews.message: An uneven but often powerful threequel...

reviews.name: Miles Surrey
reviews.message: Creed III has largely succeeded in stepping out of Rocky’s shadow, and Adonis looks more than ready to go a few more rounds before hanging up the gloves for good. Just like his predecessor, Adonis isn’t going down without a fight.

reviews.name: Adam Nayman
reviews.message: While Creed III features a well-drawn, menacing adversary in Jonathan Majors’s Dame Anderson, it doesn’t utilize him enough.

reviews.name: Kambole Campbell
reviews.message: Creed III is much more sure-footed in presenting a fascinating emotional struggle for its title character as well as a physical one, even if it ends up diminishing its most subversive plot threads.

reviews.name: tt stern-enzi
reviews.message: There are a couple of decisions that take place in the film in terms of story that get a little hokey... [but] by the time you get to the finally fight, Michael B. Jordan does something really interesting with the fight sequences.

reviews.name: Cris Kennedy
reviews.message: For a first-time director, Jordan does a very good job, notably in the film's handful of fight scenes, understanding the ballet of the match.

title: Heat
description: Master criminal Neil McCauley (Robert De Niro) is trying to control the rogue actions of one of his men, while also planning one last big heist before retiring. Meanwhile, Lieutenant Hanna (Al Pacino) attempts to track down McCauley as he deals with the chaos in his own life, including the infidelity of his wife (Diane Venora) and the mental health of his stepdaughter (Natalie Portman). McCauley and Hanna discover a mutual respect, even as they try to thwart each other's plans.

characteristics.Producer:: Art Linson, Michael Mann
characteristics.Production Co:: Warner Brothers, Regency Enterprises, Forward Pass

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: The gloriously excessive indulgence Michael Mann allowed himself after his brisk, bracing masterpiece, “The Last of the Mohicans.”

reviews.name: Kevin Carr
reviews.message: Hard hitting and full of spirit, Heat delivers on the action as well as the nuanced characters, raising it above the standard 90s cop drama.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: One of the best crime movies ever made...

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: Mann ups the ante on all of the formulaic elements by instilling them with a grandiloquence they may not even deserve.

reviews.name: Mal Vincent
reviews.message: The movie is lacking in both heart and soul, but it makes up for it with sheer voyeurism.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: In Heat, all the meticulous authenticity and coolly portrayed characters inherent to a Michael Mann picture fulfill a crime epic of incredible scale and ambition.

reviews.name: Graeme Tuckett
reviews.message: Twenty-six years after it was released, I'm not sure that Heat has ever been bettered as an action film, or as a crime drama.

reviews.name: Joe Nolan
reviews.message: Heat gives us one of crime cinema's great cat-and-mouse chases, and brilliantly pairs it with the little everyday dramas of family, romance, parenting and work-life balance in the life-and-death professions of both cops and robbers.

reviews.name: Toussaint Egan
reviews.message: A triumphant assemblage of carefully interlocking components; working in concert with the precision of a Swiss timepiece.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: The precious few exchanges between legendary actors Al Pacino and Robert De Niro make it all worthwhile.

reviews.name: Allen Almachar
reviews.message: 'For me, the action is the juice.' That is the defining theme of Michael Mann's work - to examine how people operate within their own moral system, and how it contrasts with the rest of society.

reviews.name: Leigh Paatsch
reviews.message: Unbelievably, this was the first film to bring together DeNiro and Pacino, and the scene where they finally come face-to-face... is the true highpoint of an intelligent and exciting actioner absolutely jam-packed with great moments.

reviews.name: Sean Burns
reviews.message: The most meticulously designed of Mann's features, with careful compositions positioning the characters against bustling cityscapes and empty expanses that externalize their interior lives.

reviews.name: Quentin Curtis
reviews.message: This movie confirms Mann as one of the most distinctive and skilled of current American directors.

reviews.name: Nick Rogers
reviews.message: Ominous, operatic, often emulated but never equaled. This is go-for-broke, GOAT-level filmmaking - not only upending expectations but exceeding them with unanticipated success in its elegant, exciting examination of existential and emotional entropy.

reviews.name: Barbara Shulgasser
reviews.message: Criminal and police face off in bloody '90s action-adventure

reviews.name: Michael Wilmington
reviews.message: When Pacino's loud, bruised cop and De Niro's canny crook stare at each other, you can read something spent and weary in their eyes and voices. The heat is hell. So are their jobs -- but somebody's got to do them.

reviews.name: Anthony Lane
reviews.message: The taciturn De Niro and the braying Pacino share a flawless scene over a cup of coffee, but the real honors go to Val Kilmer and Ashley Judd as a warring, loving couple.

reviews.name: Steven Rea
reviews.message: So why doesn't Heat, with its elaborately staged, tautly edited robberies, its killer cast, edgy score and elegant cinematography, offer more satisfaction? It's the script, stupid.

reviews.name: David Ansen
reviews.message: Just when it seemed that the only hope for crime movies lay in the postmodernist artifice of films like Pulp Fiction, Mann reinvests the genre with brooding, modernist conviction. This one sticks to your gut.

reviews.name: Jonathan Rosenbaum
reviews.message: There's nothing really new in this lengthy 1995 thriller by writer-director Michael Mann about cops and robbers in Los Angeles, but it has craft, pacing, and an overall sense of proportion, three pretty rare classic virtues nowadays.

reviews.name: Dave Kehr
reviews.message: An odd though often entertaining blend of The Asphalt Jungle and Oprah, a traditional cops-and-robbers story weirdly fitted out with long, earnest discussions of interpersonal relationships.

reviews.name: Jay Boyar
reviews.message: There isn't much going on at this party other than what the actors bring to it. But fortunately, Mann has invited some exceptional ones.

reviews.name: Gary Thompson
reviews.message: A movie with two powerhouse performances and enough bad dialogue (it runs two hours, 45 minutes) to clog a Pentium processor.

reviews.name: John Hartl
reviews.message: Heat becomes consistently more interesting as it forges on toward the 180-minute mark.

reviews.name: Adrian Turner
reviews.message: Though punctuated by bursts of virtuoso action, including a running battle in downtown LA that ranks as one of the best action scenes ever filmed, it is the unusual emphasis on character that impresses most.

reviews.name: Stephen Hunter
reviews.message: This is glandular, not intellectual, movie-making but it's at the highest end of technical expressiveness.

reviews.name: David Sterritt
reviews.message: The performances are persuasive but the plot rattles on much too long.

reviews.name: Rod Dreher
reviews.message: Though it's a tad too schematic, Heat, written and directed by Michael Mann, provides a venue for white-hot acting by De Niro and Pacino.

reviews.name: Simon Cote
reviews.message: With a stellar cast including Val Kilmer and Jon Voight, Heat has it all including a great soundtrack full of tone-setting, ambient, and symphonic arrangements.

reviews.name: Dan Webster
reviews.message: If, overall, Mann stretches a bit, the numerous successes are nevertheless worth watching.

reviews.name: Blake Howard
reviews.message: The conversation in Heat is one of the most perfectly executed and eloquently intertextual moments in the history of American Cinema.

reviews.name: Peter Canavese
reviews.message: A stealth epic, framing an urban jungle and making its own kind of contemporary history by pairing acting giants Robert DeNiro and Al Pacino in what has arguably become the preeminent cops-and-robbers movie. [4K Blu-ray]

reviews.name: John J. Puccio
reviews.message: I have always wondered if Pacino and De Niro flipped a coin before the movie began shooting to see which of them would play which part?

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: A slow-moving, overburdened, well-meant and at times quite entertaining slog.

reviews.name: Radheyan Simonpillai
reviews.message: The director's signature sleek and romantic aesthetic is reason enough to take a seat for this operatic three-hour marathon.

reviews.name: Todd McCarthy
reviews.message: Heat occupies an exalted position among the countless contemporary crime films.

reviews.name: Pablo Villaça
reviews.message: Fascinante por se concentrar em dois homens que, obcecados por suas profisses, acabam dependendo um do outro justamente por no saberem fazer outra coisa.

reviews.name: Bob Westal
reviews.message: I admire Mann's emotional commitment and his sense of style, but it also grates on me.

reviews.name: Peter Travers
reviews.message: Robert De Niro's last great role before he devoted himself to self-parody.

title: 2 Fast 2 Furious
description: This sequel focuses on ex-police officer Brian O'Conner (Paul Walker), who relocates from Los Angeles to Miami to start over. Becoming involved in the street-racing scene in his new city, Brian befriends car-savvy Tej (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges) and Suki (Devon Aoki), but his competitive streak ends when federal agents apprehend him and he must enter into a deal with the FBI. Working with new partner Roman Pearce (Tyrese), Brian begins a dangerous mission to take down a powerful drug dealer.

characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz
characteristics.Writer:: Michael Brandt, Derek Haas, Michael Brandt, Derek Haas, Gary Scott Thompson
characteristics.Sound Mix:: Dolby A, Dolby Stereo, DTS, SDDS, Surround, Dolby SR, Dolby Digital

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: 2 Fast 2 Furious features hundreds of practical effects that take your breath away. It makes 2 Fast one of the low-key best films in the franchise.

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: The 2003 film looks like it was shot on a fairly low budget. Aside from an electrifying introductory race, the film is a bore visually and narratively, and it includes one of the most forgettable villains of the franchise.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: 2 Fast 2 Furious' narcotising script conspires with excessively effects-driven racing sequences to sap much of the fun out of an otherwise promising buddy cop setup.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: Vin Diesel managed to distance himself from this mess; it's too bad Singleton didnt do the same.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...has half the racing scenes, twice the plot and none of the Vin Diesel.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: Loads up on colors, cars and characters to distract from what's missing under the creative hood, yet this spirited sequel is fun as it rarely takes itself too seriously.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: It's a pretty bold move to make a film for groups of young males about the latent sexual nature of the relationships in such groups - and this alone made 2 Fast, 2 Furious an unexpectedly hilarious treat.

reviews.name: Nell Minow
reviews.message: Death by sequel. Extremely violent sequel.

reviews.name: Felix Gonzalez Jr.
reviews.message: The philosophy here is when you can't make high art, make high trash.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...ultimately doesn't fare as well as its mediocre predecessor...

reviews.name: Oz
reviews.message: I'd go so far as to say that if you really liked this film, you have a career working in fast food to look forward to. Get it? Fast food?

reviews.name: Lori Hoffman
reviews.message: ... it provides enough sexy rides, blacktop fury, screeching hairpin turns and crashes to keep the celluloid humming ...

reviews.name: Daniel M. Kimmel
reviews.message: This is not a movie about people. It's about cars going very, very fast.

reviews.name: Josh Bell
reviews.message: It's all curiously rote, though: The cars go really fast, and then, for a change, they go really, really fast.

reviews.name: Shawn Bowers
reviews.message: Just because you give an old car a new paint job doesn't mean it runs better.

reviews.name: Harry Guerin
reviews.message: Whatever charms the first one had, the sequel badly misses the Diesel-injection.

reviews.name: Mike Sage
reviews.message: Surprisingly better minus the original director and star, this sequel to the 2001 sleeper hit should have no problem speeding its way to box office gold

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: 2 Fast 2 Furious features hundreds of practical effects that take your breath away. It makes 2 Fast one of the low-key best films in the franchise.

reviews.name: Brett Doze
reviews.message: The 2003 film looks like it was shot on a fairly low budget. Aside from an electrifying introductory race, the film is a bore visually and narratively, and it includes one of the most forgettable villains of the franchise.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: 2 Fast 2 Furious' narcotising script conspires with excessively effects-driven racing sequences to sap much of the fun out of an otherwise promising buddy cop setup.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: Vin Diesel managed to distance himself from this mess; it's too bad Singleton didnt do the same.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...has half the racing scenes, twice the plot and none of the Vin Diesel.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Lyles
reviews.message: Loads up on colors, cars and characters to distract from what's missing under the creative hood, yet this spirited sequel is fun as it rarely takes itself too seriously.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: It's a pretty bold move to make a film for groups of young males about the latent sexual nature of the relationships in such groups - and this alone made 2 Fast, 2 Furious an unexpectedly hilarious treat.

reviews.name: Nell Minow
reviews.message: Death by sequel. Extremely violent sequel.

reviews.name: Felix Gonzalez Jr.
reviews.message: The philosophy here is when you can't make high art, make high trash.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...ultimately doesn't fare as well as its mediocre predecessor...

reviews.name: Oz
reviews.message: I'd go so far as to say that if you really liked this film, you have a career working in fast food to look forward to. Get it? Fast food?

reviews.name: Lori Hoffman
reviews.message: ... it provides enough sexy rides, blacktop fury, screeching hairpin turns and crashes to keep the celluloid humming ...

reviews.name: Daniel M. Kimmel
reviews.message: This is not a movie about people. It's about cars going very, very fast.

reviews.name: Josh Bell
reviews.message: It's all curiously rote, though: The cars go really fast, and then, for a change, they go really, really fast.

reviews.name: Shawn Bowers
reviews.message: Just because you give an old car a new paint job doesn't mean it runs better.

reviews.name: Harry Guerin
reviews.message: Whatever charms the first one had, the sequel badly misses the Diesel-injection.

reviews.name: Mike Sage
reviews.message: Surprisingly better minus the original director and star, this sequel to the 2001 sleeper hit should have no problem speeding its way to box office gold

title: Marvel's the Avengers
description: When Thor's evil brother, Loki (Tom Hiddleston), gains access to the unlimited power of the energy cube called the Tesseract, Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), director of S.H.I.E.L.D., initiates a superhero recruitment effort to defeat the unprecedented threat to Earth. Joining Fury's "dream team" are Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Captain America (Chris Evans), the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), the Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner).

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Intense Sci-Fi Action/Violence|A Mild Drug Reference)
characteristics.Producer:: Kevin Feige

reviews.name: Sean Axmaker
reviews.message: You wouldn’t accuse 'The Avengers' of being good drama, but the sprawling, splashy spectacle and its much-much-much-larger-than-life heroes makes for a genuine comic book epic for the big screen.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: After four years’ worth of building piece by piece against mounting expectations, Marvel and Whedon have managed to satisfy the majority of fan expectations, and in some ways, even exceeded them.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: Everyone is invested in their character and not one single performer phones it in.

reviews.name: Don Shanahan
reviews.message: Go back a rewrite the definitions for "unprecedented," "groundbreaking," and those other buzz words.

reviews.name: Mat Brunet
reviews.message: The Avengers, as a movie, can be best described as one of the most prominent examples of a crowd pleaser.

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: The story works, the acting is superb, the humor is on key and the action sequences are breathtaking.

reviews.name: Nathan Mattise
reviews.message: The 2010s will undeniably go down as the decade of superheroes...

reviews.name: Nicolás Delgadillo
reviews.message: It is the textbook example of a comic book movie, the gold standard to strive for, and a validation of comic book storytelling as an art form.

reviews.name: Luke Holland
reviews.message: A mega-budget action extravaganza that succeeds on just about every level, and it's one you should certainly go and see as soon as possible.

reviews.name: David Hogan
reviews.message: A perfect example of an ensemble cast and great example of well shot spectacle that also manages to actually develop a lot of the titular heroes as well. Great stuff.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: The posing, evil grimacing to denote villainy, and arsenal of one-liners are at an all-time high.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: The Avengers will undoubtedly please nearly all fanboys and most other moviegoers hoping for the quintessential popcorn flick experience.

reviews.name: Yasser Medina
reviews.message: The Avengers is an amazing madness that guarantees entertainment, fun and awe with the most fantastic gathering of heroes that cinema has ever seen. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Matthew Rozsa
reviews.message: 'The Avengers' May Be the Best Comic Book Film Ever Made

reviews.name: Josh Wilding
reviews.message: Clever, funny, emotional, and downright amazing; The Avengers is a spectacle which demands repeat viewings. Joss Whedon has delivered what is quite simply an epic comic book movie masterpiece.

reviews.name: Jim Ross
reviews.message: ...not without its flaws, but Joss Whedon has put together an immensely enjoyable film, the best Marvel-based one to date, and one that is not in the least bit ashamed of its comic book roots.

reviews.name: Sarah Knight Adamson
reviews.message: This star-studded, action packed film lives up to all the hype.

reviews.name: Siddhant Adlakha
reviews.message: The Avengers is as close as you can get to a quintessential blockbuster experience. One of the rare MCU films where the action beats feel entirely like extensions of story and character.

reviews.name: Katie Smith-Wong
reviews.message: Overall, Marvel's Avengers Assemble is fun, funny and downright entertaining. Joss Whedon did good.

reviews.name: David Harris
reviews.message: I think the problem is inherent in the format.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: It is no longer enough for one superhero to fight a single villain while dealing with his own personal problems, apocalypse must now enter into it.

reviews.name: Noah Berlatsky
reviews.message: The movie is not utterly worthless in every way. I'll grant that. But does that mean it's good? Or even adequate? No.

reviews.name: Mattie Lucas
reviews.message: Tightly scripted and filled with enough moments of levity to balance the extended and spectacular battle sequences.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: Gets everything right. So entertaining when our characters gather to fight Loki who is the best.

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: Marvel's The Avengers is the team-up movie that we've been waiting for and it's absolutely everything we wanted it to be.

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: The film begins with a bang and builds from there, a thrill ride peppered with Whedon's trademark self-aware humor. It's fun to watch all these egos clash, especially Downey, who just owns the Tony Stark role.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: The Avengers will appeal to fans of comic books, fans of action and fans of characterization and dialogue. It's a pretty awesome assembly.

reviews.name: Nathalia Aryani
reviews.message: This all-star superhero extravaganza is fun entertainment at a grand scale.

reviews.name: Lee Cassanell
reviews.message: If you're in the market for one of the most wondrous and entertaining cinematic experience you could ever hope to have, book your tickets, buy your popcorn and prepare to be amazed.

reviews.name: Kelly Jane Torrance
reviews.message: The Avengers is an engaging-enough film. But with that kind of treasure, talent and time, you'd expect more -- a lot more than this completely conventional action flick delivers.

reviews.name: Colby Bryant
reviews.message: It will forever stand as Exhibit A in the case for why the Marvel Cinematic Universe exists and why it continues to thrive.

reviews.name: Debbie Baldwin
reviews.message: This is an incredible action movie. From special effects to fights to explosions, it hits every marker. But the movie is so much more. It's hysterically funny, charming and smart.

reviews.name: PJ Nabarro
reviews.message: Avengers Assemble does exactly what it says on the tin: the Avengers assemble and proceed to smash things up...a lot!

reviews.name: Zaki Hasan
reviews.message: The Avengers shatters the last barrier separating the printed page and the celluloid image, fully wresting the superhero genre away from the medium that birthed it.

reviews.name: Eileen Jones
reviews.message: Sounds kind of corny, you say? Oh, that's nothing. Massive corn-shucking in this film, corn piled everywhere, cornpone, corn fritters, corn syrup, corn as high as an elephant's eye, the Feast of Our Great God Corn!

reviews.name: Johnny Gayzmonic
reviews.message: This is what a comic book movie should be: thrilling, exciting and surprisingly, almost shockingly, human.

reviews.name: Pat Padua
reviews.message: Achieves something more than just a competent wrangling of diverse comic book stories: it manages to keep Hollywood egos in check

reviews.name: Leona Laurie
reviews.message: Black Widow has so much potential! We hope they seize on it within the next 6 years! *a tumbleweed blows by*

reviews.name: Joseph Walsh
reviews.message: The final action scene, which runs for over half-an-hour, is awe-inspiring.

reviews.name: Andre Meadows
reviews.message: For an action movie there are a lot of genuinely funny lines. There were parts of this movie that had my laughing out loud.

title: Babylon
description: A tale of outsized ambition and outrageous excess, Babylon traces the rise and fall of multiple characters during an era of unbridled decadence and depravity in early Hollywood.

characteristics.Rating:: R (Drug Use|Bloody Violence|Graphic Nudity|Pervasive Language|Strong & Crude Sexual Content)
characteristics.Producer:: Marc Platt, Matthew Plouffe, Olivia Hamilton
characteristics.Production Co:: Marc Platt Productions, Organism Pictures, Wild Chickens

reviews.name: James Kendrick
reviews.message: Chazelle seems to have abandoned the moving humanism that animated his early films, opting instead to wallow in grotesquerie, absurdity, and debauchery

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: A fascinating mess.

reviews.name: Joanne Laurier
reviews.message: Babylon is ambitious, and costly—and almost a complete shambles. It is badly constructed and unconvincingly done, providing little or no insight into the film industry, culture in general or American society.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: For all that is great and grand in its use of history, the film is long and you can feel it, a problem when making an epic.

reviews.name: Stacey Yvonne
reviews.message: As it stands, after two movies that started the “White People Freaking Out About Jazz” genre, I don’t have a lot of faith in Chazelle telling these stories and Babylon has shown me that my fears were founded.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: Babylon’s sound-recording scene replicates Singin’ in the Rain’s as something dire and unfunny and way too long.

reviews.name: Eric Webb
reviews.message: A filthy, funny, frenetic film that might be the weirdest holiday-season release in recent memory.

reviews.name: Gemma Creagh
reviews.message: The writing utilises pitch black humour to lambast a terrible system while still sincerely acknowledging the beauty of the artform.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: Chazelle appears to have mistaken his own dexterity for directing.

reviews.name: Ian Thomas Malone
reviews.message: Babylon is an easy film to hate. Chazelle’s work is sloppy, arrogant, and self-indulgent bordering on masturbatory, but also irritatingly beautiful and hard to get out of one’s head.

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: Outside of these production moments, the film feels like it’s toiling away at revealing plot threads that aren’t nearly as engaging as they could be.

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: Surely there came a point in this extravaganza when the director, the producers, the actors, and the people who did the catering, began to feel it had all gone wrong.

reviews.name: Mike Scott
reviews.message: Chazelle’s overstuffed homage to old Hollywood is often totally bonkers, but it’s also consistently mesmerizing. Running longer than 3 hours, it's an undeniably self-indulgent exercise, but one that showcases magnificent craftsmanship at every level.

reviews.name: Brian Susbielles
reviews.message: It may have been a box office failure, but all three hours are utilized perfectly and never goes flat.

reviews.name: Gisela Savdie
reviews.message: Babylon is as chaotic and messy as what it tries to describe, but it's wonderful, and manages to make us reflect on the implications of fame, with its moments of glory and decline. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Eric Eisenberg
reviews.message: The back half of the film, while it does have its highlights, demonstrates an inability for the movie to fully carry its own weight, and the multi-faceted narrative descends into tropes and some groan-worthy material before the end credits start to roll.

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: With Babylon, though, Chazelle gives us magic, but trumps it with sheer, unadulterated madness.

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: There’s nothing personal or profound in this messy imagination of the early movies; it’s just a spectacle reduced to tics and gimmicks.

reviews.name: Alex Flood
reviews.message: Damien Chazelle’s bonkers biopic about the excess of Old Hollywood will bowl you over in the best way, but it might leave you scratching your head in confusion too

reviews.name: Casey Chong
reviews.message: [Babylon] is a bumpy ride but rarely feels tedious.

reviews.name: Julia Swift
reviews.message: So bad it's shocking.  Such of waste of acting talent.  This is what happens when Hollywood calls someone a genuis and lets them create without ever having to think twice about any of their decisions.

reviews.name: Dave Lee
reviews.message: This is an absolutely repugnant masterpiece. It is a romantic nightmare. It is bat-shit crazy. And I loved every last second of it.

reviews.name: Andrew Kendall
reviews.message: Babylon lurches from moment to moment. It is full of half-ideas but lacking in the imagination to do much with it. Instead, it feigns jocularity while feeling unspontaneous and unnatural in its convulsions, too studied and tedious to excite.

reviews.name: David Stratton
reviews.message: Attempts to out-Fellini Fellini are regrettable and for much of its length Babylon is an unsubtle and indigestible mess so that despite all the talent involved and the fascinating subject matter, it must be seen as something of a disaster.

reviews.name: Ben Turner
reviews.message: A more ruthless editor could easily have stream-lined a stronger piece, but as it stands it’s a bedazzling screech of a film that threw restraint out the window, where it landed in a pile of Robbie’s vomit on a designer rug. It’s bonkers.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: A relentless and ravenous movie that's always a lot, not just in length, but is dazzling (and also very funny) when it clicks.

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Judged against Chazelle’s previous work, Babylon lacks the edge of Whiplash, the heart of La La Land, and the focus of First Man. Such a well-versed student of cinema should know better than to fall into self-indulgence.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: A prurient, celebratory, confused, scandalized, and sad celebration of the notion of Old Hollywood as a place of incomparable possibility and freedom.

reviews.name: Nick Hasted
reviews.message: At its best, Babylon is indecently good fun.

reviews.name: Hugo Lara
reviews.message: ... An intense tribute to cinema that delights hard-core cinephiles. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Brendan Cassidy
reviews.message: It's a different kind of Damien Chazelle film. It's more cynical, it's more mean-spirited, in fact it almost feels like a response to LA LA LAND and what happened after that film's notorious "win" at the Oscars.

reviews.name: Carlos Bonfil
reviews.message: An artistic melting pot. Babylon is an uneven and disorganized film in line with the Hollywood carousel of cheap impressions that spins in all directions yet never bets on any. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Mark Kermode
reviews.message: Subtle it is not. Nor is it good.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: Blah-blah land.

reviews.name: Ayelet Dekel
reviews.message: Watching the film is like riding a rollercoaster in a storm of images, lifted on the rhythms of Justin Hurwitz’s compelling score.

reviews.name: Ed Whitfield
reviews.message: If anything, Babylon is too good a recreation of late-silent era Hollywood – it’s self-indulgent, overwrought, underwritten, and following a full-frontal assault on the senses, peters out into irrelevance.

reviews.name: Donald Clarke
reviews.message: Chazelle’s film commemorates the era’s hubris as it indulges in a bit of its own.  This is how a world ends. Not with a whimper but a great deal of banging, baby. And vomiting. And snorting.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: I staggered out trying to shake off not just the onset of cramp, but also the vague, dispiriting sense that I'd just been hoodwinked by the ending into thinking that Babylon is a better film than it is.

reviews.name: Beatriz Martínez
reviews.message: An exercise of superlative narcissism that's as hollow as it's irritating and amorphous. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ricardo Rosado
reviews.message: As uneven as it is magnetic, Babylon is an essential chute in which Margot Robbie and Brad Pitt not only know they are the brightest stars in the sky but they make it clear that they have enjoyed it... [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Matrix
description: Neo (Keanu Reeves) believes that Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne), an elusive figure considered to be the most dangerous man alive, can answer his question -- What is the Matrix? Neo is contacted by Trinity (Carrie-Anne Moss), a beautiful stranger who leads him into an underworld where he meets Morpheus. They fight a brutal battle for their lives against a cadre of viciously intelligent secret agents. It is a truth that could cost Neo something more precious than his life.

characteristics.Producer:: Joel Silver
characteristics.Sound Mix:: Dolby Digital, SDDS, DTS, Surround, Dolby Stereo, Dolby SR

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: The Matrix became an achievement in blockbuster filmmaking as soon as it was released. It remains one of the most quotable, memorable, and enjoyable films to throw on for a few hours.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: By remaining so accessible yet thoughtful, The Matrix transcends its narrative downfalls through its influence and insight—characteristics that continue to define the Wachowskis' unique brand of ambitious entertainment.

reviews.name: Bill Stamets
reviews.message: The Matrix does a good job of repackaging Baudrillard’s critique of hyperreality, as well as riffing on Christ, Marx, Lewis Carroll, and L. Frank Baum.

reviews.name: Danilo Castro
reviews.message: A cinematic landscape without The Matrix would be as barren as the scorched earth above Zion.

reviews.name: Brian Phillips
reviews.message: The Wachowski sisters tackle the most gigantic questions known to humanity-reality, identity, knowledge, causality, memory-with a spirit of play.

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...generally as intellectually rewarding as it is viscerally captivating.

reviews.name: David Hogan
reviews.message: While certain aspects have now lost their shine, either due to outdated CG or just being parodied so damn much, they can't take away from the original's pull, even in 2021.

reviews.name: George Fenwick
reviews.message: Keanu Reeves and Carrie-Anne Moss are brilliant in their iconic roles.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: Overall, for a complicated scenario, things are pretty tight story wise and the film noir feel adds to the aesthetics.

reviews.name: Mike Massie
reviews.message: To say that it must be seen for yourself is no understatement.

reviews.name: Debbie Holloway
reviews.message: Good news, my dudes. The Matrix might be better now than it was in 1999!

reviews.name: Fico Cangiano
reviews.message: Whoa! A film that without a doubt left its mark on cinema and pop culture. One of the best sci-fi films of all time. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Sezín Koehler
reviews.message: The Matrix isn't just a movie, it's an entire philosophy that also examines metamorphosis and personal transformation to mirror The Wachowskis' own personal journeys as trans women.

reviews.name: Kathi Maio
reviews.message: The [Wachowskis] have "borrowed" bits from here, there, and everywhere, and they have ended up creating a two hour and fifteen minute jumble of cultural and philosophical references with violence to spare, but precious little clarity or logic.

reviews.name: Peter Bradshaw
reviews.message: The Matrix still stands up as a fiercely exciting and discombobulating futurist drama, which pioneered breathtaking "bullet-time" action sequences inspired by Asian martial arts.

reviews.name: Ben Lindbergh
reviews.message: The Matrix is an inner-circle sci-fi Hall of Famer, a visual trendsetter, and a cultural touchstone that remains culturally prominent today.

reviews.name: Adam Kempenaar
reviews.message: Neo offers Reeves the perfect combination of Ted Theodore Logan's curiosity and wonder, Johnny Utah's earnestness and the badassedness of Jack Traven.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...hallucinatory cinema.

reviews.name: Zaki Hasan
reviews.message: Full to the brim with eye-popping effects and "How'd they do that?" stuntwork, it yearns to have audiences be utterly enraptured in its created reality.

reviews.name: Rob Vaux
reviews.message: The Matrix embedded itself in pop culture so thoroughly that it's easy to forget how different it was when it first arrived.

reviews.name: Sean Axmaker
reviews.message: The Matrix has become such a touchstone of American pop culture-referenced, copied, parodied, and parroted)-that it's hard to remember just how new and different and distinctive it was when it debuted in 1999.

reviews.name: David Hunter
reviews.message: A technologically stunning movie that furthers the genre and features crowd-pleasing performances to go with the frequent scenes of gunplay and violence.

reviews.name: Keith Simanton
reviews.message: Extremely violent, extremely preposterous, extremely entertaining, The Matrix succeeds at two extremely difficult tasks: as a vast, exciting virtual-reality movie and as a defibrillator for Keanu Reeves' big screen career.

reviews.name: Tom Sander
reviews.message: Hang on tight for a real mind-blower, with astonishing visual effects, frightening monsters and exciting stunt fights.

reviews.name: Chris Kridler
reviews.message: The Matrix is a movie experience like no other, and experience is what it's all about. It explodes with dazzling visuals and a transcendent sense of excitement.

reviews.name: Alan Jones
reviews.message: Thematically complex, yet intelligently integrating eastern philosophy, Lewis Carroll and ancient mysticism.

reviews.name: Leah Rozen
reviews.message: The Matrix is tough to explain, but then how much explaining does an amusement park ride require?

reviews.name: David Denby
reviews.message: The movie is nonsense, but it does achieve a brazenly chic high style -- black-on-black, airborne, spasmodic.

reviews.name: Mark Caro
reviews.message: The Wachowskis and cinematographer Bill Pope take advantage of currently available technical trickery to create visually distinct levels of reality while setting high-speed cameras in motion to make the action sequences particularly dynamic and fluid.

reviews.name: Keith Phipps
reviews.message: Where other films are done in by the freedom offered by computer effects, The Matrix integrates them beautifully.

reviews.name: Emanuel Levy
reviews.message: Inspired by different sources (including Japanese anime), The Matrix is a new kind of movie, a visionary mixture of technology, philosophy and thrilling action.

reviews.name: Leo Goldsmith
reviews.message: It's that balance between blockbuster-style action sequences and in-depth philosophical undertones that I've always admired about The Matrix.

reviews.name: Nell Minow
reviews.message: Intense, but many teens will be able to handle it.

reviews.name: Tim Brayton
reviews.message: Exemplifies the idea that a sufficiently cool outcome justifies all of the tortured narrative it takes to get there.

reviews.name: Tim Dirks
reviews.message: The Matrix (1999) is a kinetic, action-oriented, dystopian science-fiction virtual reality film that came from the directorial-writing team of the Wachowski Brothers. Their ambitious and inventive virtual-reality flick was their second feature film...

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: Other than some caveats, this is an innovative and original science fiction entry...

reviews.name: John J. Puccio
reviews.message: The original Matrix stands perfectly well on its own, despite the fact that the filmmakers went on with second and third episodes.

reviews.name: Mark Halverson
reviews.message: Dimension-hopping has never been so exhilarating and breathlessly lyrical as brilliant visuals and bracing Hong Kong action stunts punch through lengthy streams of technobabble.

reviews.name: Steve Biodrowski
reviews.message: Time and imitators have chipped away at The Matrix's aura of originality and innovation, but the movie remains rousing entertainment two decades later, and it looks better than ever in Dolby Cinema.

reviews.name: Rob Gonsalves
reviews.message: The paranoid details of the premise are thoroughly worked out; the characters and motives, much less so.

title: Pearl
description: Filmmaker Ti West returns with another chapter from the twisted world of X, in this astonishing follow-up to the year's most acclaimed horror film. Trapped on her family's isolated farm, Pearl must tend to her ailing father under the bitter and overbearing watch of her devout mother. Lusting for a glamorous life like she's seen in the movies, Pearl finds her ambitions, temptations, and repressions all colliding in this stunning, technicolor-inspired origin story of X's iconic villain.

characteristics.Producer:: Jacob Jaffke, Harrison Kreiss, Kevin Turen, Ti West
characteristics.Production Co:: BRON Creative, Universal Studios Inc., Little Lamb, A24

reviews.name: John Serba
reviews.message: Instead of lining up the victims and letting Pearl get her Lizzy Borden on, Goth and West ruminate in the age-old debate of nature vs. nurture.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: While Ti West’s X was a smart, sassy homage to The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and other rural horrors from the 1970s, it pales in comparison to the vivid Technicolor 1918 nightmare he and his star Mia Goth have unleashed here.

reviews.name: Roe McDermott
reviews.message: For a film with such darkness, violence and pitch-black humour, the visuals of Pearl are a technicolour delight.

reviews.name: Tom Shone
reviews.message: The film is more sumptuously upholstered than most exercises in kitsch, closer to David Lynch than John Waters, with one of those wraparound musical scores that feels like a mink coat.

reviews.name: Ryan Gilbey
reviews.message: Pearl wants so badly to be a star. Part of the film’s pleasure lies in realising that Goth already is.

reviews.name: Stephen A. Russell
reviews.message: I'm quite sure no animals were harmed in the making of this film, but many of those farmyard critters don't make it out alive...

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: A savvy deepening and recontextualising of a must-see scary-movie franchise that's as much about desire, dreams and determination as notching up deaths.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: Goth is riotously entertaining throughout, but two specific scenes, in both of which the camera rests solely on her face for an extended shot, capture the full force of her unnerving talent.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: She slashes, stabs and decapitates aplenty, and proves a dab hand with a pitchfork. That’s essentially the film. It’s Judy Garland goes rogue on a farm.

reviews.name: Paul Whitington
reviews.message: Goth’s energy, focus and commitment here is extraordinary.

reviews.name: Harry Guerin
reviews.message: This prequel to the much-admired 2022 slasher X is turbocharged by a gloriously bonkers performance by Mia Goth. Seriously, it's one of the best acting jobs you'll see this year -- a top hat-wearing, liquid morphine-guzzling, monologue-unleashing triumph.

reviews.name: Clarisse Loughrey
reviews.message: Pearl’s torment is believable largely because Goth single-handedly wills it to be. Her commitment to every choked cry for attention, to every glassy-eyed departure from reality, is unimpeachable.

reviews.name: Tom Beasley
reviews.message: Pearl exists primarily as a savage and silly showcase for the utterly luminous Goth, who sinks her acting teeth into the myriad tones and vibes of the character.

reviews.name: Leslie Felperin
reviews.message: From the opening credits with their cursive retro font to the end crawl that plays over Goth making a deranged face, the film harks back to vintage B-movies about crazed young ladies...

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: Fresh, subversive and drenched in delicious irony and dark humour. Goth continues to impress.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Genre cinema performed at the top of its game, Pearl is a masterclass in just about everything. If you’re one of the few that hasn’t yet sought out Pearl by other means, your patience is about to be very richly rewarded.

reviews.name: Dulcie Pearce
reviews.message: It’s mad, bad and sad and will leave you wondering how it’s possible to root for this demonic diamond — or Pearl — in the rough.

reviews.name: Jake Wilson
reviews.message: This tenderly perverse Cinderella story functions just as well all on its own, and in some respects hovers outside of time, as a parable about cinema in general

reviews.name: Christopher Machell
reviews.message: Pearl is notable as a pandemic film... though much like its engagement with sex, violence and entertainment, and its treatment of women, the film sets the table for a discussion but doesn’t quite make a full meal of it.

reviews.name: Kim Newman
reviews.message: ... An American gothic shocker with a lot to say — and an awards-worthy lead performance from Mia Goth.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: Pearl is brutal, emotionally satisfying and horrifying, in all the best ways.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: A new-wave horror chiller that clocks in as an absolute knockout exercise in top-tier terror; a cliche-averse, outside-the-box prequel to X, the trip skillfully blends old-school movie trappings with a laser-sharp edge

reviews.name: Andiee Paviour
reviews.message: As nubile worry Pearl, Mia Goth is a textbook definition of torment.

reviews.name: Katherine McLaughlin
reviews.message: Goth’s powerhouse performance is shot through with both a mischievous and desperately sad giddiness that never lets up.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: Ti West’s brilliantly bonkers new film Pearl, for instance, would be unthinkable without Mia Goth.

reviews.name: David Jenkins
reviews.message: One to chalk up to that small but delightful sub-genre of retro slasher weepies.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: Separately, X and Pearl might not have made my 10 Best of 2022 list; together, how could they not?

reviews.name: Matt Glasby
reviews.message: The result doesn't quite stand up on its own, but as an eye-catching origins story that casts new light on the original film, it's a malevolent marvel.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Ti West’s horror prequel sours the conventions of Golden Age melodrama, while unhinging the American dream with harsh reality

reviews.name: Simon Miraudo
reviews.message: An amazing technicolour nightmare.

reviews.name: Ezequiel Boetti
reviews.message: The film is very similar to its titular protagonist: pure unprejudiced extreme. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Adrián Monserrat
reviews.message: Its daring trademark will win both lovers and haters, but this is coherent with the franchise's morals and story. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Nadine Whitney
reviews.message: … beautifully shot, but deeply ugly… Mia Goth is definitely a star.

reviews.name: Hernán Ferreirós
reviews.message: Pearl feels like an acting exercise: some performers need to know a character's backstory before incarnating it. Pearl turns this exploration into a somewhat redundant story that seems to only exist to showcase Goth's talents. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Pablo O. Scholz
reviews.message: Pearl has everything it takes to become a horror classic. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Benjamin Wiebe
reviews.message: Pearl is a masterclass of horror filmmaking with a powerful ending, but it relies on a familiarity with the franchise that holds it back.

reviews.name: Dan Buffa
reviews.message: It isn’t your standard horror film, and the movie is better for it. While some filmmakers could ease their foot off the pedal for their second round, West keeps his engaged to the floor here.

reviews.name: Santanu Das
reviews.message: It's a hypnotic, shattering performance that rings of emotional truth.

reviews.name: Josh Larsen
reviews.message: ...as if Dorothy got sucked up by a tornado and dropped down in The Texas Chain Saw Massacre — holding the chainsaw.

reviews.name: Steph Cozza
reviews.message: Pearl provides a surprisingly tender origin story for its titular character.

title: Dune
description: Paul Atreides, a brilliant and gifted young man born into a great destiny beyond his understanding, must travel to the most dangerous planet in the universe to ensure the future of his family and his people. As malevolent forces explode into conflict over the planet's exclusive supply of the most precious resource in existence, only those who can conquer their own fear will survive.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Some Disturbing Images|Sequences of Strong Violence|Suggestive Material)
characteristics.Producer:: Denis Villeneuve, Mary Parent, Cale Boyter, Joseph Caracciolo Jr.
characteristics.Writer:: Jon Spaihts, Denis Villeneuve, Eric Roth
characteristics.Production Co:: Legendary Pictures, Warner Bros., Villeneuve Films

reviews.name: Russell Holly
reviews.message: Trust me, on the big screen, the blue is blue enough to bring the intensity when needed...

reviews.name: Benjamin Wiebe
reviews.message: Dune is a true masterpiece. I can’t wait to see how this duology ends, and if Denis Villeneuve sticks the landing, this may be the best science fiction movie of all time.

reviews.name: Vadim Rizov
reviews.message: Five years later, the most cogent thought I emerged from Dune with was, "Hans Zimmer must be stopped."

reviews.name: Wesley Lovell
reviews.message: A film is, at its core, a piece of entertainment. While cinema is also a fascinating and diverse macrocosm of art, films like Dune make the case that intermingling approaches to the medium aren’t always possible.

reviews.name: Dallas King
reviews.message: So people of the world, spice up your life and see Dune. So Villeneuve can conduct the final part of this truly epic space opera.

reviews.name: M.N. Miller
reviews.message: A sophisticated sci-fi blockbuster, Villeneuve’s Dune has an epic scope, jaw-dropping action sequences, and stunning visuals.

reviews.name: Cris Kennedy
reviews.message: Visually epic, but also part of his [Villeneuve's] approach to the screenplay's slow deliberate pace to pull out the novel's more important scenes and storylines.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: From its opening shot to the final fade, I found myself enraptured and transported.

reviews.name: Matthew Haynes
reviews.message: The world building and story telling in this film was completely brilliant! Everything had a purpose, and everything was well planned out meticulously. Besides the beautiful cinematography, Hans Zimmer's score shined throughout!

reviews.name: Nicki Dusse
reviews.message: There was a lot of things to like about this film but when it ended I couldn't help but say to myself "Damn that's it?" - Kennith B. Inge

reviews.name: Cody Dericks
reviews.message: Villeneuve adds his usual brains and soul to yet another epic blockbuster property and, once again, he’s secured victory. But it is us, the audience, who gets to reap the rewards of his hard work.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: What gleams brightest in this take on the tale is its breathtaking visuals, meticulous plotting, a pace that gives the narrative space to breathe and an alluring sense of mystery, as well as the ability to prove simultaneously vast and intimate.

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: [Villeneuve] delivered superbly produced entertainment cinema, of visual fortitude, aggrandized form, and banal contemplation. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Cory Woodroof
reviews.message: Generational spectacle.

reviews.name: Carlos Boyero
reviews.message: No emotion... just a remarkable tedium. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jessie Gender
reviews.message: While clearly just the first half of a longer narrative, what a thrilling first half this is.

reviews.name: Alachia Queen
reviews.message: While Dune 2021 is a very well presented and styled gourmet sci-fi dish, for a platter stuffed with "spice", it unfortunately lacks a ton of Dune flavor.

reviews.name: Milana Vujkov
reviews.message: Feels more like an obscure, scattered conversation overheard on a long train ride, peaking early with Rampling’s natural mystique, and then hitting a downward spiral – all dense plot and mild tedium, a bounty of sensual imagery wasted on zero substance.

reviews.name: Pete Vonder Haar
reviews.message: Paul's family is evidently descended from a long line of matadors.

reviews.name: Steve Crum
reviews.message: The paramount attractions, the visuals, connect immediately. The landscapes, costuming, sets, makeup, creatures and wild special effects are stunning.

reviews.name: Agustín Acevedo Kanopa
reviews.message: Duna works sometimes like a strange abstract opera in which we perceive more the intensities than the representation of the events, and sometimes not only do we not know what part of the story we are in, but what is concretely happening.

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: To promise a whole series of films might be dressed up as a gift for fans, but theres a lingering cynicism about this project  a feeling that its essentially a way of maximising returns at the box office.

reviews.name: A.S. Hamrah
reviews.message: This Dune toys with the idea of genocide, but it’s mostly a movie for people who like to memorize things. All these stupid names, one after another.

reviews.name: Scott Campbell
reviews.message: Dune might not be for everyone; but if you strap in, immerse yourself in the world and go along for the ride, Denis Villenueve delivers a blockbuster sci-fi epic that's regularly jaw-dropping.

reviews.name: Cole Smithey
reviews.message:
A dishwater war narrative masquerading as sci-fi.
Pshaw.

reviews.name: Miles Surrey
reviews.message: A blockbuster celebrating the awe-inspiring power of the big screen that everyone can get behind.

reviews.name: David Reddish
reviews.message: If nothing else, Dune wins its place as a masterpiece of adaptation, truncating roughly half the novel into its runtime to expand the books monomaniacal focus on Paul into a more ensemble narrative.

reviews.name: Rubén Rosario
reviews.message: Mature yet juvenile, otherworldly yet pleasingly familiar, “Dune” demands to be experienced on the biggest screen you can find (sandworms!).

reviews.name: Emma Stefansky
reviews.message: Dune: Part One will leave fans not only wanting, but hoping for more. The spice, in other words, must flow.

reviews.name: Ian Bunting
reviews.message: Dune is another triumph for Villeneuve and I can’t wait to see him finish his epic.

reviews.name: Christina Newland
reviews.message: Denis Villeneuve’s windswept epic is engrossing enough to maintain an audience with an intermission and a running time twice its length.

reviews.name: Grant Watson
reviews.message: From the costumes to the enormous machinery and craft of mining spice the film presents a beautifully realised and consistent universe.

reviews.name: Josie Melendez
reviews.message: Dune falls under a high-brow take on science fiction. It is an entertaining cinematic feat to say the least. The franchise has a bright future.

reviews.name: David Lynch
reviews.message: "Perhaps the best, or at least the most revealing, thing that can be said about Denis Villeneuves grandly mounted adaptation of Frank Herberts 'Dune' is that he makes it look easy."

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Many people will encourage you to see new releases on as big a screen as possible. With a masterful spectacle like Dune, its practically a commandment.

reviews.name: Matt Brunson
reviews.message: Its stateliness is both an asset and a detriment.

reviews.name: David Gonzalez
reviews.message: Every few years, a film arrives that changes the landscape of cinema.

reviews.name: Jeffrey Harris
reviews.message: Dune is an exceptional, big-budget sci-fi spectacle, with amazing production values, high-level acting performances, and grand visuals by director Denis Villeneuve.

reviews.name: Brian Eggert
reviews.message: I recognize this film's individual excellence, but its lasting effect may depend on what follows.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: Sure it is long and dense, but the drama of Dune is engaging and it does make the audience care about its characters and stories.

title: After
description: Tessa Young is a dedicated student, dutiful daughter and loyal girlfriend to her high school sweetheart.
