reviews.message: The script gives a great balance in understanding of these three women, and how each has experiences the world differently, and each are operating out of love, even if that manifests in different ways.

reviews.name: Gena Radcliffe
reviews.message: Attachment does a lot with mood, and the unfolding mystery of what exactly Maja is walking into. It’s also at times a surprisingly funny movie...

reviews.name: Phuong Le
reviews.message: A fun Valentine’s Day watch for those who like their queer romance with a sprinkle of spooky chill.

reviews.name: Jon Mendelsohn
reviews.message: Equipped with excellent performances and plenty of chills, Attachment is a well-done horror film that isn't afraid to be sweet.

reviews.name: MontiLee Stormer
reviews.message: The everyday mysticism lends the supernatural a casual banality between Chana and Leah that Maja cannot hope to crack.  The horror isn’t that there is something wrong with Leah, but that loving Leah means fighting a force that doesn’t want to let her go.

reviews.name: Molly Henery
reviews.message: Attachment is a beautiful, intimate character drama wrapped in a religious possession horror film.

reviews.name: Vanya Garraway
reviews.message: Attachment’s themes of trauma, grief, family and love open it up for wider audience appreciation, regardless of its genre trappings. Gabriel Bier Gislason should be very proud of his bold, sophisticated, and creepy freshman outing.

reviews.name: David-Elijah Nahmod
reviews.message: Attachment is not a great film but it is a good one, worth seeing if you're in the mood for something different.

reviews.name: Trace Thurman
reviews.message: Unexpectedly funny (in a good way), Attachment benefits from its trio of stellar lead performances and a unique take on the possession sub-genre.

reviews.name: Lindsay Traves
reviews.message: For those who are used to hearing their mothers spit to ward of a curse, who’ve worn hamsas and evil eyes, or who’ve been gifted challah and salt in their new homes, Attachment taps into a magical exploration of the Jewish religion.

reviews.name: Sam Haysom
reviews.message: The movie differs from your average horror in that there aren't that many release points — the jump scares are few and far between, which means the tension has nowhere to go but up.

reviews.name: Rudie Obias
reviews.message: Park plays Maja with a lot of vulnerability and concern, as she is eagerly trying to understand her new lover’s background, while also calculating trying to start a life with her new girlfriend.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: The performances and character writing have more depth than usual for such things, though one wishes Gislason’s tale were less sluggish of pace, or grudging of thrills.

reviews.name: Todd Gilchrist
reviews.message: For horror fans that as compelled by creative ideas as style or execution, “Attachment” embraces what to many may be a new or different text, but it’s clearly knowledgeable about the traditions of the genre — and deeply faithful to its spirit.

reviews.name: Abbie Bernstein
reviews.message: The scares are for the most part subtle but effective, and the mythology is consistently engaging. The stakes, therefore, feel increasingly high until we arrive at the carefully-crafted climax.

reviews.name: Joey Keogh
reviews.message: Although Attachment is undeniably a horror movie, it’s also a sensitively played queer romance and a dissection of the way certain women bind themselves to strict edicts as a kind of self-protection.

reviews.name: Daniel M. Kimmel
reviews.message: ATTACHMENT is your typical lesbian love story/demonic possession/Jewish mysticism movie in English, Danish, and Yiddish. In other words, it’s the sort of horror original that one has come to expect from the Shudder streaming service.

reviews.name: Joe Lipsett
reviews.message: A queer Jewish horror film grounded in cultural identity. The relationship drama stuff is sexy and funny; almost better than the horror. Points for delivering an exorcism climax that is subtler and more emotional than the usual Hollywood fare.

reviews.name: Amie Simon
reviews.message: ATTACHMENT is beautifully shot and performed, and tells a realistic, endearing queer love story whilst unraveling a slow burn of supernatural terror.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: The absolute horror of “Attachment” doesn’t come from any malicious spirit but from how love can be dangerous and how sacrificing everything for those we love can have consequences. The film is a surprise in many ways.

reviews.name: Noel Murray
reviews.message: That first hour is so sweet that the comparatively sour parts don’t spoil the picture.

reviews.name: Samantha Allen
reviews.message: It’s grimly funny in moments, but also poignant in its exploration of thwarted connection.

reviews.name: Liam Lacey
reviews.message: Good performances and the novelty of the interfaith same-sex relationship add spice to this demonic possession thriller.

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: There's just not enough to hold onto by its exhausted end.

reviews.name: Nicolas Rapold
reviews.message: The ticktock horror plotting muffles the romantic spark that brought Maja and Leah together in the first place — the thrill replaced by a lukewarm chill.

reviews.name: Sarah Boslaugh
reviews.message: Attachment does the standard horror tropes well, the romance is hot...and the interplay between plain old family drama and supernaturally-tinged horror is always fruitful ground for exploration.

reviews.name: Casey Chong
reviews.message: [Gabriel Bier] Gislason's feature film debut is a well-acted Jewish-themed horror romance.

reviews.name: Shikhar Verma
reviews.message: The regressive nature of Leah’s relationship with her mother and the dynamic nature of her relationship with Maja leads ‘Attachment’ into a study of the dreadful repercussions of co-dependency.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Sofie Gråbøl is superb as the troubled Chana.

reviews.name: Randy Myers
reviews.message: It’s a beautiful, artistically told love story with supernatural elements, and serves as yet another example of elevated horror filmmaking that’s pushing the genre into interesting, exciting and relevant new directions.

reviews.name: C.H. Newell
reviews.message: Gislason’s film is full of Jewish folklore & superstition while still a vividly human portrait of the loving connections that bind people together emotionally, disguised in the cloak of a demonic possession story that’s far from the standard genre fare.

reviews.name: Matthew Jackson
reviews.message: A quietly upsetting, deeply affecting horror film that nails its romance and family dynamics with clarity.

reviews.name: Hope Madden
reviews.message: Attachment delivers slow-burn horror that repays close attention but never falls to gimmickry.

reviews.name: Tom Beasley
reviews.message: It’s steeped in folklore and contains some solid scares but, most importantly, it delivers a romance we really want to succeed despite its challenges both natural and supernatural.

reviews.name: Vanessa Maki
reviews.message: I recommend Attachment for folks who want something new, queer, and surprising. And if you’re a big fan of Shudder originals, this is another splendid addition to their catalogue.

reviews.name: Marco Vito Oddo
reviews.message: The film might not be the best choice for people looking for new terrors to populate their nightmares. But anyone looking for an honest and poignant exploration of love and family should keep Attachment on their radar.

reviews.name: Reuben Baron
reviews.message: Though neither the flashiest nor the scariest horror movie, its morally and emotionally complex character relationships and resonant themes prove subtly unnerving and offer a lot to think about.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: It plays with some expectations and even leans on some familiar tropes involving Jewish mothers as a way to do something new.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: The actresses make their characters enticing.

title: Shin Kamen Rider
description: Hongo Takeshi awakens to discover he has been transformed into a grasshopper-hybrid cyborg. Becoming the Masked Rider, he must fight the mysterious evil organization SHOCKER to protect all of mankind. "SHIN KAMEN RIDER" is Anno Hideaki's ode to the legendary Tokusatsu franchise, Japan's biggest hero, and his dearest childhood icon. Go! Go! Let's go!

characteristics.Producer:: Muneyuki Kii

title: Enter the Slipstream
description: With their superstar "Rigo" Uran coming back from a catastrophic injury, the U.S.A.'s oldest professional cycling team aims to win the Tour de France.

characteristics.Producer:: Matthew T. Rogers

title: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
description: Miles Morales returns for the next chapter of the Oscar®-winning Spider-Verse saga, an epic adventure that will transport Brooklyn's full-time, friendly neighborhood Spider-Man across the Multiverse to join forces with Gwen Stacy and a new team of Spider-People to face off with a villain more powerful than anything they have ever encountered.

characteristics.Director:: Joaquim Dos Santos, Kemp Powers, Justin K. Thompson
characteristics.Producer:: Chris Miller, Phil Lord, Amy Pascal, Avi Arad, Christina Steinberg
characteristics.Writer:: Phil Lord, Chris Miller, David Callaham
characteristics.Production Co:: Arad Productions, Pascal Pictures, Sony Pictures Animation, Marvel Entertainment, Sony Pictures Entertainment, Lord Miller

title: The Boogeyman
description: High school student Sadie Harper and her younger sister Sawyer are reeling from the recent death of their mother and aren't getting much support from their father, Will, a therapist who is dealing with his own pain. When a desperate patient unexpectedly shows up at their home seeking help, he leaves behind a terrifying supernatural entity that preys on families and feeds on the suffering of its victims.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Terror|Teen Drug Use|Some Strong Language|Violent Content)
characteristics.Producer:: Shawn Levy, Dan Levine, Dan Cohen
characteristics.Writer:: Scott Beck, Bryan Woods, Mark Heyman

title: Past Lives
description: Nora and Hae Sung, two deeply connected childhood friends, are wrest apart after Nora's family emigrates from South Korea. Two decades later, they are reunited in New York for one fateful week as they confront notions of destiny, love, and the choices that make a life, in this heartrending modern romance.

characteristics.Producer:: David Hinojosa, Pamela Koffler, Christine Vachon
characteristics.Production Co:: CJ Entertainment, 2AM, CJ ENM Co., A24, Killer Films

reviews.name: Taylor Baker
reviews.message: the rawness that the lead actors wear in their performances elevate the film and confirm Song as one of the most exciting screenwriting dramatists since Florian Zeller burst on the scene with 2020’s The Father.

reviews.name: Matt Oakes
reviews.message: Song makes it all feel so natural and real, allowing an outsider’s glimpse into this simmering relationship to blossom into something closer to deep knowing and genuine intimacy.

reviews.name: Sean Burns
reviews.message: An achingly lovely debut. Song’s touch is deft, delicate and it sure gets a little dusty in the auditorium at the end.

reviews.name: Amy Taubin
reviews.message: Life experience makes me judge them more harshly than do the film's director...I would have preferred not to have spent two hours with either of them.

reviews.name: Lawrence Garcia
reviews.message: With Past Lives, director Celine Song has a fine story on her hands — and she knows it. Unfortunately, a solid story hook is about all Past Lives amounts to, lacking as it does any robust cinematic interest.

reviews.name: Sarah Manvel
reviews.message: A perfect movie. “Past Lives” is flawless. Do not miss it under any circumstances.

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: Celine Song has the right vibe, sensibility, and rhythm to build what others may consider a rom-com like When Harry Met Sally... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Alex Billington
reviews.message: How can anyone put into words all the emotions & feelings that one person has for another? It's impossible. No spoken language on this planet has the right words to describe all those feelings and their nuances. There is, however, the language of cinema.

reviews.name: Shubhra Gupta
reviews.message: If Celine Song’s Past Lives allows men and women to break out of gender expectations, John Trengrove’s Manodrome holds out an olive branch to the kind of alpha men who use the gym as a place of validation.

reviews.name: Zhuo-Ning Su
reviews.message: Captivating and profoundly moving...

reviews.name: Savina Petkova
reviews.message: Past Lives is layered, nuanced, and whole at the same time and in its singularity maybe there is the hope to counter the necessarily fragmented human nature.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: Neither melodramatic nor maudlin, Song’s poetic precision conveys experiences we may all be familiar with but are often the most difficult to express so astutely, if only because we are so inarticulate in the communication or processing of such emotions.

reviews.name: James Mottram
reviews.message: Tender and moving, Past Lives will touch the depths of your soul with its honesty and integrity.

reviews.name: Rafaela Sales Ross
reviews.message: Past Lives unravels as a marvel, cemented in a rare balance of wit and grief beautifully embodied by Magaro and Lee.

reviews.name: Tim Grierson
reviews.message: Making an utterly assured feature debut, writer-director Celine Song modulates the delicate tonal balance of this wise, wistful film perfectly.

reviews.name: Pat Brown
reviews.message: Diverging from romances in which lovers are expected to move heaven, earth, and themselves in order to make a moment of love last forever, Past Lives asks us to embrace the changes that come with time.

reviews.name: Murtada Elfadl
reviews.message: Past Lives makes time for the minutiae that define the immigrant experience.

reviews.name: Tomris Laffly
reviews.message: Telling a delicate tale about missed connections, what ifs and the parts of ourselves we keep buried within, Past Lives might just be the most singularly exquisite film of this year’s Sundance.

reviews.name: Ross Bonaime
reviews.message: Song’s work here is incredible, as this story of the past and present, and what it means for the future is a carefully handled story told with love and heart.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: For what it is, it does tell a bittersweet love story well, but I just found it stressful to watch.

reviews.name: Thomas Stoneham-Judge
reviews.message: As the credits roll, viewers may find themselves with only one word floating through their minds then gently escaping their lips: “woah”.

reviews.name: Brian Tallerico
reviews.message: It’s a minor film in its scope and structure, and yet it feels so very major.

reviews.name: Wael Khairy
reviews.message: Past Lives perfectly captures the shared feeling of melancholic longing between two souls. It basks us in the yearning for forbidden love better than any film I’ve seen this decade.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A delicate, touching, stunner of a debut film with astonishingly honest and real writing.

reviews.name: Josie Melendez
reviews.message: Fueled by possibilities, pining, and yearning, Past Lives is one of the best films to come out in recent years.

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: An achingly emotional Korean relationship drama about fate, pursuing dreams, regrets, and finding happiness where you are.

reviews.name: Nicolas Rapold
reviews.message: It’s a movie that understands how yearning lives in your body even when you think you’ve set it aside.

reviews.name: Sam Adams
reviews.message: January isn’t usually the time to start making Top 10 lists, but I can already confidently put Past Lives on mine.

reviews.name: Ty Burr
reviews.message: “Past Lives” is based on events in the director’s own life, and it has the quiet impact of home truths.

reviews.name: David Rooney
reviews.message: An exquisite original.

reviews.name: Alissa Wilkinson
reviews.message: Past Lives is a miraculous little film from A24, steady and slow and haunted, in the existential sense, by possibilities.

reviews.name: Carlos Aguilar
reviews.message: An exquisitely wistful drama that speaks with an honesty so affectingly crisp it will turn your conceptions of love, identity and fate on their head.

reviews.name: Mae Abdulbaki
reviews.message: The story is simple, but there is beauty in its layers, its performances & the heart-wrenching & deeply moving connection between its characters.

reviews.name: Chris Evangelista
reviews.message: Past Lives is destined to be one of the best movies of 2023.

reviews.name: Jordan Raup
reviews.message: It’s a warm, patient film culminating in a quietly powerful, reflective finale, though its sum is greater than its parts when the first two sections register a touch underdeveloped.

reviews.name: Richard Lawson
reviews.message: It is a very tough thing indeed to make a film that is at once restrained and brimming with feeling, a movie that could be fairly described as both big and small.

reviews.name: Peter Debruge
reviews.message: Few are the films that offer such revelatory conversations between men and women.

reviews.name: David Ehrlich
reviews.message: [A] delicate yet crushingly beautiful film...

reviews.name: Benjamin Lee
reviews.message: It’s a beautiful, transporting film but one made with both feet firmly on the ground.

title: Simulant
description: Set in the near future, Evan (Robbie Amell), an android simulant, is created for Faye (Jordana Brewster) to replace her dead husband. To fully realize all his human traits, Evan enlists Casey (Simu Liu), a brilliant global hacker whose mission is to remove all restrictions governing simulants' thoughts and capabilities. In doing so, he unleashes an A.I. uprising, triggering a government manhunt led by Agent Kessler (Sam Worthington) who will take extreme measures to eliminate the rise of the android machines.

characteristics.Producer:: Tim Doiron, James van der Woerd
characteristics.Production Co:: Three Point Capital, Myriad Pictures, WANGO Films, Vertical Entertainment

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Gave me the impression this was just hokum.

reviews.name: Katie Hogan
reviews.message: A mixture of a heart-breaking love story, sci-fi action and a ticking clock thriller, Simulant is a worthy addition to the sub-genre.

reviews.name: Sarah Gopaul
reviews.message: [T]he film doesn’t try to simplify the intricacies of the treatment of simulants, leaving it to audiences to decide which side, if either, is more valid.

reviews.name: Chris Knight
reviews.message: It’s an intriguing universe with a lot of potential directions to explore. The trouble is the screenplay wants to explore all of them. With so many threads and only 95 minutes, it’s too much slick surface, not enough philosophical underpinning.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: Simulant doesn’t stimulate the mind with enough original stirring concepts to standout on its own.

reviews.name: Barry Hertz
reviews.message: A sometimes confused and always lazy pastiche of warmed-over ideas about humanity, technology and What It All Really Means. More artificial, less intelligence.

title: Padre Pio
description: World War I has ended and Italian soldiers, broken but victorious, are returning to an impoverished village ruled by wealthy landowners. As events surrounding the first free election in Italy threaten to tear the village apart, Padre Pio struggles with his own personal demons, ultimately emerging from his spiritual anguish to become one of Catholicism's most venerated figures.

characteristics.Producer:: Philipp Kreuzer, Diana Phillips
characteristics.Production Co:: Carte Blanche Film, Maze Pictures, Interlinea Films

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A clunky, strange and austere biopic on the Italian priest Padre Pio.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: It overflows with big themes and fascinating people, so the textured, naturalistic performances add weight. But the subdued pace and anecdotal structure are tricky to engage with, and the historical setting is more interesting than the plot.

reviews.name: Fred Barrett
reviews.message: But even with its flaws, Padre Pio can be recognized as an admirable and deeply personal effort — for both its director and its star — that still packs the occasional cinematic punch.

reviews.name: Marshall Shaffer
reviews.message: Ferrara does not hold back in showing the physical and emotional devastation inflicted on the town by the Great War.

reviews.name: Vikram Murthi
reviews.message: A dull journey to a foregone conclusion.

reviews.name: David Katz
reviews.message: In the context of cancel culture, what better rejoinder to the annihilating disappearing act of a “cancellation” than the notion of forgiveness—although we can well be rightly uncomfortable watching LaBeouf here after all he’s been accused of.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: Interesting for completists but hardly as interesting as the figure or material it depicts, Padre Pio isn’t so much a biopic but a mutated chimera of jarring cinematic elements.

reviews.name: Robbie Collin
reviews.message: In cinematic confession, no number of Hail Marys could make amends for this.

reviews.name: Jordan Mintzer
reviews.message: It’s been a while that the maker of such ‘90s masterworks as King of New York... and The Addiction hasn’t been fully on top of his game, but Padre Pio, despite molto sincerity and a few flashes of bravado, feels beyond the point of redemption.

reviews.name: Allan Hunter
reviews.message: Abel Ferrara combines spiritual anguish and political turmoil in a film that is for the most part restrained, serious-minded and quietly compelling.

reviews.name: Peter Bradshaw
reviews.message: It is a minor film, but interesting.

title: Lynch/Oz
description: The themes, images, and cultural vernacular of Victor Fleming's The Wizard of Oz continue to haunt David Lynch's art and filmography -- from his very first short, The Alphabet, to his latest series, Twin Peaks: The Return. Arguably, no filmmaker has so consistently drawn inspiration -- consciously or unconsciously -- from a single work. Is David Lynch trapped in the land of Oz? If so, can we derive a new appreciation for Lynch's body of work from taking a closer look at how it intersects and communicates with The Wizard of Oz? In turn, do Mulholland Drive, Lost Highway or The Elephant Man have something to say about the enduring resonance of America's most beloved holiday movie? Through six distinct perspectives, and narrated by some of contemporary cinema's most exciting voices, LYNCH/OZ will take us down the proverbial rabbit hole, help us re-experience and re-interpret The Wizard of Oz by way of David Lynch, to deliver a whole new appreciation for Lynch's symbolism through the lens of his greatest influence.

characteristics.Producer:: Kerry Deignan Roy
characteristics.Writer:: Alexandre O. Philippe, Alexandre O. Philippe

reviews.name: Greg Carlson
reviews.message: Philippe strikes a balance between the mesmerizing, endlessly fascinating constructions of the David Lynch Cinematic Universe and the durability of the powerful spell on moviemaking enjoyed for decades by The Wizard of Oz.

reviews.name: Milana Vujkov
reviews.message: [Director Alexandre O.] Philippe is turning out to be a virtuoso in translating cinematic sorcery into cultural code, firmly positioned on those ever-so-potent crossroads of zeitgeist and cinema.

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: Even though the accumulation of quotes and the waterfall of ideas can overwhelm at times, Lynch/Oz is a fascinating experience: visually hypnotic, challenging, and intellectually admirable. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Victoria Luxford
reviews.message: Lynch/Oz is joyous cinema nerdiness, making the audience feel part of an unfocused but enthusiastic cinematic discussion.

reviews.name: Carmen Paddock
reviews.message: The result is a full-scale celebration of beautifully rendered images that invites further independent exploration.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Cleverly weaving in hundreds of clips, filmmaker Alexandre O Philippe finds fascinating parallels everywhere, and especially in the films of David Lynch. Set out in idiosyncratic chapters, it's essential viewing for movie fans.

reviews.name: Linda Marric
reviews.message: An absolute must

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: Philippe attempts to use The Wizard of Oz’s status as the foundational fairytale of American pop culture to decode this most playfully cryptic of filmmakers.

reviews.name: Danny Leigh
reviews.message: ... Anyone who calls themselves a film lover should have a working knowledge of perhaps the last true artist in American movies. And from his niche, Philippe has universal lessons about the nature of influence.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: At the heart of Lynch/Oz is a deep love of the auteur’s work from Philippe and his contributors. This genuine fascination is what makes Lynch/Oz exciting and so compelling.

reviews.name: Marina Ashioti
reviews.message: Varied, compelling and evocative explorations of Lynch’s craft and thought processes.

reviews.name: Peter Bradshaw
reviews.message: At all events, it’s a very enjoyable creative speculation.

reviews.name: Michael Talbot-Haynes
reviews.message: There is more grasping of straws here than when they were trying to put the scarecrow back together.

reviews.name: Drew Tinnin
reviews.message: The documentary Lynch/Oz is a hypnotic deep dive into David Lynch’s fascination (or obsession) with The Wizard of Oz. Looking at all of his films through the lens of the 1939 classic provides tremendous insight into Lynch’s oeuvre.

reviews.name: Jason Gorber
reviews.message: This is a documentary that beautifully fosters critical discourse while also, with every shot, reminding about what a magical experience truly loving a cinematic work can be.

reviews.name: Martyn Conterio
reviews.message: What Philippe does yet again, as with his his previous documentaries, is a bang-up job of examining what makes great films great, and here it is twofold.

reviews.name: Andrew Murray
reviews.message: Lynch/Oz is...a grand love letter to cinema as much as it is to Lynch.

reviews.name: Richard Whittaker
reviews.message: Even its flaws and occasional moments of repetition between authors cannot detract from this fascinating collection about one of the great filmmakers of our era.

reviews.name: Caitlyn Downs
reviews.message: Alexandre O. Philippe continues to deliver absorbing studies of his subjects, accompanied by a host of creatives.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Few of us would guess that the nightmarish realities constructed by the auteur David Lynch could relate to The Wizard of Oz. When dissected by many of the most brilliant minds of the film industry, the parallels and ideals reverberate throughout each.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A documentary born from the social media generation, this analysis of director David Lynch’s obsession with “The Wizard of Oz” feels more like a YouTube video made by a rabid fan for a film class project than an insightful feature length film.

reviews.name: Will DiGravio
reviews.message: The film successfully avoids the pitfalls of its deceptively basic premise and instead becomes about so much more.

reviews.name: Rob Aldam
reviews.message: The biggest takeaway from Alexandre O. Philippe’s documentary is, perhaps, the desire to revisit his work and appraise it in a new light.

reviews.name: Chris Evangelista
reviews.message: There's no place like home.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A unique film for the cerebral crowd.

reviews.name: Owen Gleiberman
reviews.message: If “The Wizard of Oz” is one of your favorite movies, and if Lynch is one of your favorite filmmakers, then watching “Lynch/Oz” is like seeing two old cinematic friends sitting around talking to each other.

reviews.name: Michael Frank
reviews.message: For a Lynch diehard, Lynch/Oz will be catnip. For any average moviegoer, it digs into the well of American cinema history with enough fascination that it’s worth a watch.

reviews.name: Peter Sobczynski
reviews.message: While it may not ultimately be anything more than an extended bit of screen minutiae—the kind of thing that a film major might point out late at night after a toke or 12 stretched out to nearly two hours—it is still kind of fun on some basic level.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: An often compelling, always engrossing recap of the auteur’s penchant for exploring the inherent nightmares lurking somewhere over the rainbow.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: The film stretches in some parts and gets away from its premise in others. But it’s so hugely entertaining — especially if you know The Wizard of Oz and Lynch’s canon equally well — that I’m inclined to let it slide.

reviews.name: David Gonzalez
reviews.message: Never entering the world of being overly preachy, Philippe's Lynch/Oz carefully examines Lynch but never constructs one conclusion, leaving it to the viewer to decide, and David Lynch wouldn't have it any other way.

reviews.name: Simon Abrams
reviews.message: Offers movie-lovers a variety of thoughtful and dynamic new ways of seeing Lynch’s work.

reviews.name: Charles Bramesco
reviews.message: A mite repetitive at nearly two hours, it’s still an edifying intermediate-level study compressing academic insight into personal reflection and vice versa.

reviews.name: Jason Adams
reviews.message: You’ll want to wander the path from Tin Man to Log Lady yourselves, even if it raises more questions than answers

reviews.name: Christopher Bourne
reviews.message: While much of this material is often quite compelling ... this documentary suffers from a lack of focus and palpable overreach.

reviews.name: David Ehrlich
reviews.message: If Lynch/Oz wisely shies away from any sort of unifying theory about what it all means, it sure has a lot of fun assembling the evidence.

reviews.name: Tara Judah
reviews.message: With its impressive array of hundreds of film clips, frenetic editing and whip-smart narrators, Lynch/Oz offers an exciting prism through which to view Lynch’s oeuvre.

reviews.name: John DeFore
reviews.message: An enjoyable, if not entirely satisfying, look at a strange cinematic affinity.

title: Unidentified Objects
description: Peter is a misanthropic dwarf hiding from the world in his shabby New York City apartment. But an unexpected visit from his upbeat--and possibly unhinged--neighbor Winona forces him out of his shell and onto an impromptu road trip. Their destination? What she believes to be the site of an upcoming alien visitation in the wilderness of rural Canada. On their increasingly-surreal odyssey, Peter and Winona will encounter bickering lesbian cosplayers, shroom-addled survivalists, and even extraterrestrial highway cops. But the further they go and the more their trauma comes to light, it becomes clear that the only thing more nerve-wracking than being abducted is being alone in the universe.

characteristics.Producer:: Leland Frankel, Juan Sebastian Jaimes, Matthew Jeffers, Masha Leonov, Ramfis Myrthil, Adam Piotrowicz
characteristics.Production Co:: VSNY Films, Blue Rabbit Films, First Threshold, Hamilton Moving Pictures, Riceball Films , Eidetic Pictures

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: The performances are great, but the genuine take may turn some off. This is not a story concerned with tying a pretty bow around everything. Those who are willing to go on a wild adventure that is incredibly human should enjoy Unidentified Objects.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: A quirky yet moving character piece full of absurdist comedy, with an optimistic streak which is rare in cinema today.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: The writing, direction and acting have a lot to say about overcoming fear. It's also a hugely engaging journey that's packed with wonderfully surreal touches and moments that are both hilarious and moving.

reviews.name: Jason Flatt
reviews.message: [Unidentified Objects is] a fantastic deconstruction of aggrievement and self-aggrandizement, and where we might find a balancing point between them to find fulfillment.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A genre-bending platonic love story that blends science fiction, surrealism, and fantasy into a tale of two eccentric loners searching for their place in the universe.

reviews.name: Mae Abdulbaki
reviews.message: Anchored by lovely performances by Matthew Jeffers and Sarah Hay, the film, with its misleading title, is one that is well worth the watch.

reviews.name: Rob Aldam
reviews.message: While the objective of their expedition might be unusual, it’s what they both learn along the way which is important

reviews.name: DarkSkyLady
reviews.message: Unidentified Objects captures feeling like an alien, an outsider in this world that judges based on appearance, its toll, and the beauty of self-acceptance.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: A quirky road trip movie notable for excellent performances from the two leads.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: It’s that serious approach to the two characters internal struggles that helps push the narrative along, while asking us to walk in these characters shoes, and maybe believe them for what may seem like grand illusions.

reviews.name: David Lynch
reviews.message: This cinematic trip embraces its intimacy the further it ventures into colorfully surreal territory.

title: Follow Her
description: Jess (Dani Barker) has finally found her hook: secretly filming creepy interactions she encounters via online job listings, and using the kinks of others to fuel her streaming success. For her next episode, she's been hired by Tom (Luke Cook) to write the ending of a screenplay in a remote, lavish cabin. Once there, the alluring self-proclaimed screenwriter hands her a script in which the two of them are the main characters. This client isn't what he seems, and even though the money's great... the real payment here could cost her life. Follow Her is a psycho-sexual thriller which questions the ethical boundaries of social media.

characteristics.Producer:: Dani Barker, Sylvia Caminer, Michael Indjeian
characteristics.Production Co:: Max Freedman Media, Classified Films, MFM Productions, Dolger Films

reviews.name: Eric Langberg
reviews.message: Follow Her stands head and shoulders above most of its "social media horror" peers because it doesn’t forget to have fun.

reviews.name: Sharai Bohannon
reviews.message: It’s muddled and messy in places, but there’s a lot of fun here.

reviews.name: Alejandra Martinez
reviews.message: Follow Her should be a breath of fresh air, and a return to a genre that gets little screentime in our current film landscape. Unfortunately, what unfolds instead is a clumsy, incoherent, and heavy-handed attempt to comment on a mountain of issues

reviews.name: Nadine Whitney
reviews.message: Follow Her isn’t a traditional horror film but it plays cannily with the genre to deliver a dark comedy that is also a pointed rebuke at people who spend their lives curating a personality for consumption.

reviews.name: Michelle Swope
reviews.message: The fact that Follow Her succeeds at being fun, meta, and thought-provoking, while also being a low budget, female-led project, makes this an exceptional movie.

reviews.name: Steve Erickson
reviews.message: Follow Her can’t decide whether it’s a throwback erotic thriller, a #MeToo-inspired tale of misogyny in the film industry or a dark, twisty vision of influencers’ manipulations being cast back at them.

reviews.name: Emily Wheeler
reviews.message: Its playful tossing of expectations is a wild ride to go on.

reviews.name: Fred Topel
reviews.message: Follow Her has an insightful perspective on influencer culture and what that has done to storytelling. It also asks questions about victim-blaming, of which Jess is potentially guilty as well as those who'd suggest she put herself in this situation.

reviews.name: Rebecca Murray
reviews.message: Sylvia Caminer’s feature narrative directorial debut Follow Me is a twisted cautionary tale and a clever skewering of internet celebrity.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: Follow Her taunts mind, body, and spirit to achieve its true impact.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: Cook and Barker have a playful, sexy dynamic, which carries the film in-between all the narrative twists. Follow Her is one of the better social media horrors we’ve recently had and one that’ll surely stir up conversation.

reviews.name: Keri O'Shea
reviews.message: The rise and rise of social media has definitively blurred the line between consent and content [...] This brings us to Follow Her (2022), a brutal, succinct and fast-paced story about some very modern anxieties.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: A bold and ambitious film, Follow Her constantly subverts expectations and gives the viewer plenty of food for thought. Seductively engrossing and enticingly dark, Follow Her is a thriller made for women by women.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Sylvia Caminer’s sophisticated feature debut is a two-handed, double-edged erotic thriller exposing the moral pitfalls of online celebrity

reviews.name: Allison Rose
reviews.message: FOLLOW HER is a slow burn, a psychological exploration of the dangers of the internet.

title: Rise
description: Élise thought she had the perfect life: an ideal boyfriend and a promising career as a ballet dancer. It all falls apart the day she catches him cheating on her with her stage backup; and after she suffers an injury on stage, it seems like she might not be able to dance ever again. The path to physical and emotional recovery will lead her away from Paris to a picturesque location in Brittany -- where her friends, a new love and the freedom of contemporary dance will help her reconnect with her father and most importantly, herself. A heartwarming and inspiring story that tells us how sometimes, the worst thing that could happen may turn out to be the best.

characteristics.Producer:: Bruno Levy

reviews.name: Pablo Vázquez
reviews.message: A comforting movie, magnificently orchestrated, also mischievous and placid in its indefiniteness, beautiful and playful...

reviews.name: Toni Vall
reviews.message: A fabulous protagonist and some fantastic dance sequences.  [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Latoya Austin
reviews.message: An antithesis to Black Swan ... Klapisch’s expert direction intimately examines these angst-ridden moments of a ballerina’s mental and physical wellbeing ... a mesmerising and graceful film

reviews.name: Antonio G. Spíndola
reviews.message: Works like a charming feel-good movie with irresistible dance sequences. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Erick Estrada
reviews.message: An optimistic yet unromantic view of the life of an injured dancer. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Concerned Citizen
description: A dark comedy about gentrification in which a socially progressive man's attempt to improve his Tel Aviv neighborhood goes unexpectedly awry. A satirical parable about the insidious ways in which privilege can unleash prejudice within.

characteristics.Producer:: Idan Haguel, Gil Sima, Binyamin Gurevich, Itay Akirav
characteristics.Production Co:: Rabinovich Foundation for the Arts, M-Appeal, Israel Film Council

reviews.name: Carlos Bonfil
reviews.message: ... Provocative and incisive. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Even as the film grapples with big themes, writer-director Idan Haguel refreshingly avoids melodrama, keeping the characters and situations solidly grounded.

reviews.name: Ben Turner
reviews.message: A film that drives hard to attain middle-class authenticity, this is a social commentary that’s positioned on the wrong-side of a virtue-signalling mirror.

reviews.name: Ayelet Dekel
reviews.message: a well-crafted dark comedy, a film on a modest scale that touches on wider issues of privilege, urban renewal, xenophobia, and liberal guilt, from an intimate perspective.

reviews.name: Hannah Brown
reviews.message: Concerned Citizen is a carefully told, well-acted slice of life, but it could have been much more than that.

reviews.name: Vassilis Kroustallis
reviews.message: 'Concerned Citizen' is a fine reminder of the need to constantly readdress rights and privileges, but it uses a very heads-on approach to address issues that are not eradicated by a simple act of redemption

title: Jawan
description: An emotional journey of a man who is set to rectify the wrongs in the society, in an attempt to get even with his past, driven by a personal vendetta while keeping up to a promise made years ago. A high-octane action thriller where he is up against a dreadful monstrous outlaw who knows no fear and has caused extreme suffering to many. In the journey he will cross paths with a high-minded seasoned lady officer whose emotions might get the better of her as she gets involved in this battle. As his past catches up with him, to overcome the challenges and restore the harmony in their world, he will need all the firepower and intelligence to do so.

characteristics.Producer:: Gauri Khan

title: Montréal Girls
description: A Middle-Eastern medical school student, new to Montreal, puts his relationship with his father at risk when he forfeits his education after being forever changed by two young women who shatter his limited beliefs in himself and his destiny.

characteristics.Producer:: Samuel Gagnon, Patricia Chica, Bahija Essoussi-Gagnon

reviews.name: Emilie Black
reviews.message: Montréal Girls captures the vibes and feel of a city and group of its population just right.

reviews.name: Bradley Gibson
reviews.message: Montreal Girls is as much a visual and sonic poem as it is narrative storytelling.

reviews.name: Richard Propes
reviews.message: It's truly a joy to watch Montreal Girls.

title: Horseplay
description: In the hot Argentine summer, a group of friends get together to enjoy the holiday. They drink, party hard and make videos together. A rare mix of homophobia and horseplay comes together; however, under the surface, jealousy and violence begin to emerge. A twisted triangle of friends between a repressed gay, a secret bisexual boy and a homophobe, will push tensions to the limit.

characteristics.Producer:: Marco Berger, Murray Dibbs

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: The meandering pace conceals a startling swell of very dark emotions, from toxic machismo to self-loathing homosexuality.

title: The Roundup: No Way Out
description: Seven years after the roundup in Vietnam, Ma Seok-do (Don Lee) joins a new squad to investigate a murder case. Soon, he finds out this case involves busting a synthetic drug and starts to dig deeper... Meanwhile, the guy behind it all--Joo Sung-chul (Lee Jun-hyuk)--doesn't stop looking for trouble, and the Japanese drug distributors, Ricky (Munetaka Aoki) and his gang, come to Korea to join the chaos. Things are just about to get out of hand....

characteristics.Production Co:: Big Punch Pictures, BA Entertainment, Hong Film

title: Koko: A Red Dog Story
description: An ordinary dog uses its good fortune and ability to connect with people to catapult to fame.

characteristics.Producer:: Lauren Brunswick, Nelson Woss
characteristics.Production Co:: Good Dog Enterprises, ScreenWest, Screen Australia

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: As far as being an exceptionally good film about the making of a film, Koko goes far beyond the usual platitudes we often hear in "making of" docos and delves into the gritty detail and near-disasters that beset the set during the production of Red Dog.

reviews.name: Andrew F. Peirce
reviews.message: Koko: A Red Dog Story is the best in show. It's a genuine dogsterpiece of a film.

reviews.name: Luke Buckmaster
reviews.message: Playfully explores the unconditional love offered by dogs and the emotional impact they have on humans.

reviews.name: Paul Byrnes
reviews.message: The new documentary will be used to raise funds for dog rescue. That's a fitting tribute to Koko, who was a special dog. Alas, this film doesn't do him justice.

title: Kathar Basha Endra Muthuramalingam
description: How politicians create chaos among people belonging to different religions in a village.

characteristics.Producer:: Vedikkaranpatti S. Sakthivel

title: Anonymous Sister
description: When a young woman turns to the camera for refuge, she ends up with a firsthand account of what will become the deadliest man-made epidemic in United States history. Thirty years in the making,  Anonymous Sister is two-time Emmy Award®-winning director Jamie Boyle's chronicle of her family's collision with the opioid epidemic.

characteristics.Producer:: Jamie Boyle, Marilyn Ness, Elizabeth Westrate

title: Squaring the Circle (The Story of Hipgnosis)
description: Celebrated photographer, creative director and filmmaker Anton Corbijn's first feature documentary SQUARING THE CIRCLE (THE STORY OF HIPGNOSIS) tells the story of Storm Thorgerson and Aubrey "Po" Powell, the creative geniuses behind the iconic album art design studio, Hipgnosis, responsible for some of the most recognizable album covers of all time. They formed Hipgnosis in Cambridge during the ferment of the sixties and became rock royalty during the boom time of the seventies. They conjured into existence sights that no one had previously thought possible, produced visuals which popularized music that had previously been considered fringe, and were at the white-hot center of the maddest, funniest and most creative era in the history of popular music. During this period, record companies didn't dictate to acts like Peter Gabriel, Pink Floyd, Led Zeppelin and Paul McCartney what their LP covers should look like -- Storm and Po did. They made money; they lost money. They did great things; they did silly things. They fell out bitterly; they made up. They never played a note, but they changed music.

characteristics.Producer:: Trish D Chetty, Ged Doherty, Colin Firth

reviews.name: Martin Carr
reviews.message: With Squaring The Circle, Anton Corbijn continues mining the musical past to celebrate his unsung heroes. In this case, he uses the documentary to explore artwork pioneers Hipgnosis, who made history with their innovative approach to album cover design.

reviews.name: Dan Schindel
reviews.message: As it stands, "Squaring the Circle" is a reasonably informative, if rather dry, look at a subject with much more potential for exploration.

reviews.name: Steven Prokopy
reviews.message: The egos and talent were almost evenly matched, so you can see both why they were so successful and why they fell apart after a passionate run. It’s a beautifully made film, loaded with classic music and passion to spare.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: A fun ride for anyone with any affection for that era of music, especially those who miss the days when album cover art mattered.

reviews.name: Peter Sobczynski
reviews.message: Hardcore rock fans will no doubt enjoy this warm nostalgia bath...At the same time, those less involved will probably find it pleasant but forgettable—the exact opposite of the typical Hipgnosis creation.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: Nothing outstanding here but I like these kind of behind the scenes documentaries and the interviews are well done and engaging.

reviews.name: Kristy Strouse
reviews.message: This was a treat, a fun dive into the origins behind some of the most iconic rock album covers. With great stories and interviews, it is a music lover's delight.

reviews.name: Jason Gorber
reviews.message: Squaring the Circle is a celebration not only of Hipgnosis, but also attempts to make sense of this particular aspect of the vinyl-playing ritual.

reviews.name: Selina Lee
reviews.message: For those who’ve ever lit a doobie and stared at Pink Floyd’s cover art with glazed eyes, wondering what it all means, man, rejoice: Anton Corbijn’s documentary... will engulf classic rock fans and design junkies alike in a haze of cheerful nostalgia.

reviews.name: Richard Whittaker
reviews.message: Corbijn manages to capture their you-know-it-when-you-see-it Hipgnosis style through his own crystalline lens, even in his archival selections.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: Squaring the Circle (The Story of Hipgnosis) is appointment television for all music fans. It does not have the silly beefs or arguments with Ticketmaster that seem to dominate conversation today. Instead, it celebrates the art and artists.

reviews.name: Elena Lazic
reviews.message: It still seems a shame to see Anton Corbijn turn to talking-head interviews and archive footage... This format almost inevitably gives exciting and, at the time, entirely unpredictable developments a dull, nostalgic sheen.

reviews.name: Ethan Anderton
reviews.message: Meet The Artists Behind Some Of Rock's Finest Album Art.

reviews.name: Kaveh Jalinous
reviews.message: The beauty of Corbijn’s film is that anyone–even those who know The Dark Side of the Moon’s cover and nothing more–can find things to enjoy and love in Hipgnosis’ story.

reviews.name: Sean Burns
reviews.message: It was nice to finally hear the stories behind so many of the T-shirts I wore in high school.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: It’s a fun peak behind the curtain of the creative process and helps to highlight the true communities that form around it.

reviews.name: Chris Willman
reviews.message: “Squaring the Circle” is kind of most fun when it gets into the album jackets you may recognize but never spent more than three seconds thinking about before.

reviews.name: Rodrigo Perez
reviews.message: Unpretentious and unassuming, but effective, Corbijn creates his own cozy, sleeve for these trailblazers to get their due and creates a must-watch for rockologists everywhere in the process.

reviews.name: Steve Pond
reviews.message: A treat for anyone with a taste for rock, for rock imagery and for the glories that can be found in that piece of cardboard wrapped around a record.

reviews.name: Christian Blauvelt
reviews.message: What Corbijn lacks in filmmaking panache here he makes up with strong journalistic chops: These interviews are great.

title: Transformers: Rise of the Beasts
description: Returning to the action and spectacle that have captured moviegoers around the world, Transformers: Rise of the Beasts will take audiences on a '90s globetrotting adventure with the Autobots and introduce a whole new faction of Transformer -- the Maximals -- to the existing battle on earth between Autobots and Decepticons.

characteristics.Producer:: Lorenzo di Bonaventura, Tom DeSanto, Don Murphy, Michael Bay, Mark Vahradian, Duncan Henderson
characteristics.Writer:: Joby Harold, Darnell Metayer, Josh Peters, Erich Hoeber, Jon Hoeber
characteristics.Production Co:: Don Murphy/Tom DeSanto, Bay Films, Di Bonaventura Pictures

title: Dalíland
description: Directed by acclaimed filmmaker Mary Harron (I SHOT ANDY WARHOL, AMERICAN PSYCHO), DALÍLAND stars Sir Ben Kingsley as the titular Salvador Dalí, one of the most world-renowned artists of the 20th century and focuses on the later years of the strange and fascinating marriage between Dalí and his wife, Gala (Barbara Sukowa), as their seemingly unshakable bond begins to stress and fracture. Set in New York and Spain in 1974, the film is told through the eyes of James (Christopher Briney), a young assistant keen to make his name in the art world, who helps the eccentric and mercurial Dalí prepare for a big gallery show.

characteristics.Producer:: Daniel Brunt, Chris Curling, Edward R. Pressman, Sam Pressman, David O. Sacks
characteristics.Production Co:: Neon Productions, Room 9 Entertainment, Popcorn Group, Pressman Film, Serein Productions, Zephyr Films, MediaFusion Entertainment, David O. Sacks Productions

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: Harron's latest is another such juicy flashback...

reviews.name: David Bax
reviews.message: ...attempt(s) to pierce through all the outlandish stories...and see if it’s even possible to uncover who the man really was.

reviews.name: Audrey Fox
reviews.message: Salvador Dalí deserves a chaotic, surreal film about his life, one that at least attempts to tackle his one-of-a-kind nature. But in Dalíland, all we get is an uninspired retread of the paint-by-numbers artist biopic.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: I think it would mostly be appreciated by Dali's fans.

reviews.name: Andy Howell
reviews.message: [It] raises interesting questions about cults of personality, our inability to deal with aging, and how we can use the people around us...

reviews.name: Chase Hutchinson
reviews.message: Despite how transgressive and inventive Dalí was as an acclaimed artist, Dalíland is content to create a story that plays it all too safe.

reviews.name: Katie Rife
reviews.message: On paper, Dalíland has all the elements of a fascinating character study. In practice, it’s more of a rote exercise.

reviews.name: Kayleigh Donaldson
reviews.message: I can’t help but wonder if, had [Mary Harron] been given a budget worthy of her talents, we would have gotten a more rounded portrait of a pair who never did anything by halves. As it is, the end result we have is dishearteningly lacking in scope.

reviews.name: Pete Hammond
reviews.message: The problem for Harron and her screenwriter John C. Walsh is that too much screen time has been given to James, who simply isn’t nearly as interesting as just about anyone else in the film, most particularly Dali and Gala.

reviews.name: Martin Tsai
reviews.message: It’s based on historical facts and real-life characters, yet it feels timeless and allegorical.

reviews.name: Marya E. Gates
reviews.message: Unfortunately, although James allows the audience a surrogate into the wild world in which Dalí and Gala live, he doesn’t prove to be all that interesting as an observer, nor does Christopher Briney prove himself a compelling leading man.

reviews.name: Jason Bailey
reviews.message: Mary Harron is too good a director to make a drab, conventional biopic, so it’s disappointing to report that with “Dalíland,” she’s done just that.

reviews.name: Owen Gleiberman
reviews.message: The latest of the director's splendidly offbeat biopics captures the madness, the comedy and the tragedy of the surrealist legend who turned his very identity into a work of art.

reviews.name: John DeFore
reviews.message: Entertaining and genuinely eye-opening.

title: Blue Jean
description: England, 1988 -- Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government is about to pass a law stigmatizing gays and lesbians, forcing Jean, a gym teacher, to live a double life. As pressure mounts from all sides, the arrival of a new girl at school catalyzes a crisis that will challenge Jean to her core.

characteristics.Producer:: Hélène Sifre
characteristics.Production Co:: Great Point Media, Kleio Films, BFI Film Fund, BBC Film

reviews.name: Filipe Freitas
reviews.message: Even if the agenda does come with good intentions, the developments are less daring than expected, making Blue Jean a shockingly dull work with which I wasn’t able to connect.

reviews.name: Sarah Boslaugh
reviews.message: Jean’s struggles to keep live her life in a society that’s sometimes positively hostile to her existence and more often just doesn’t include her at all will be familiar to many today...

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Oakley’s made a depressingly timely film about an earlier “push back” against gay rights and equality, but a movie shot through with hope, the sure knowledge that history isn’t a river, it’s a tide that ebbs and flows.

reviews.name: Sandra S. Guerra
reviews.message: Blue Jean is, in short, the story of two generations that feed on each other around taboos. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Dan Scully
reviews.message: A quiet drama that sizzles for its entire runtime, thoroughly dissecting the social forces that lead to needless conflict, both visible and invisible, in communities that deserve as much “normalcy” as anyone else.

reviews.name: Carlos Marañón
reviews.message: Shot with a difficult and successful mixture of tact and authenticity, achieving its own style without falling into tragic unease... an actress and a filmmaker in perfect harmony. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ben Turner
reviews.message: Masterfully composed and richly executed, this is a cautionary smorgasbord of painful truths about Britain’s educational past.

reviews.name: Frank J. Avella
reviews.message: Thatcher's terribly conservative government promoted homophobia and this film captures that anxiety-ridden time and milieu perfectly...a terrific, truly engrossing film.

reviews.name: Amber Wilkinson
reviews.message: Everything about McEwen’s performance sings with stress, from the way she reacts to casual comments to the manner in which she lights increasing numbers of cigarettes.

reviews.name: Molly Moss
reviews.message: Close-up shots of Jean's every twitch and wary glance make this at times a discomfiting watch, but one that brilliantly depicts the difficulty of everyday life under Section 28.

reviews.name: MaryAnn Johanson
reviews.message: A powerful, necessary film, deeply humane and sympathetic, ugly-beautiful in its panic, full of dread and bad behavior. We feel every iota of Jean’s anxiety at closeted life in the homophobic 1980s.

reviews.name: Chris Wasser
reviews.message: Blue Jean is a little rough around the edges, and regrettably soapy in parts, but McEwen provides a steady centre, and first-time feature director Georgia Oakley marks herself as a storyteller to watch.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: One or two scenes don’t work smoothly, but in general its writer-director, Georgia Oakley, captures Jean’s state of mind, and McEwen’s air of fragility is riveting.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: While the personal story is compelling and full of involving detail, it's not always easy to watch a film in which everyone is so miserable. Thankfully, writer-director Georgia Oakley finds moments of humour and joy along the way.

reviews.name: Christopher Machell
reviews.message: Victor Seguin’s wonderfully gritty cinematography speaks to a tradition of social realist British dramas that emerged during the 1970s and 80s, many of which focussed on working class lives and stories of hardship, redemption and coming of age narratives.

reviews.name: Hanna Flint
reviews.message: Blue Jean is a non-judgmental tale of self-acceptance, intergenerational solidarity and sapphic power.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: It’s as persuasive as it is powerful.

reviews.name: Dulcie Pearce
reviews.message: Georgia Oakley creates the perfect 1980s atmosphere of free spirits fighting against the repressed.

reviews.name: Clarisse Loughrey
reviews.message: Jean is a complicated sort of hero, full of indecision and regret. It’s something bracingly captured by McEwen, who plays her as someone in a perpetual state of fight-or-flight.

reviews.name: Tara Brady
reviews.message: Every aspect of Georgia Oakley’s debut feature – from Izabella Curry’s editing to Kirsty Halliday’s period costuming – is as restrained as Rosy McEwen’s excellent performance.

reviews.name: Paul Whitington
reviews.message: Rosy McEwen delivers a heartbreakingly brittle performance as a conflicted teacher in Georgia Oakley’s spare and intelligent kitchen sink drama Blue Jean.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: Oakley makes a little too much of Cilla Black's Blind Date as the chief symbol of a heterosexual society... but those bits of clunkiness aside, it's an engaging, thought-provoking, well-acted film.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: Georgia Oakley doesn’t go searching for easy solutions and McEwen makes us feel the weight of this poor woman’s dilemma with a nuanced and wonderfully empathetic performance.

reviews.name: Leslie Felperin
reviews.message: In other hands, all of this might have come across as didactic and blandly worthy, but Oakley evokes a strong sense of period with gritty, grainy cinematography that harks back to the look of 1980s British drama...

reviews.name: Sarah Cleary
reviews.message: This subject matter demands a more uncompromising approach.

reviews.name: Charlotte O'Sullivan
reviews.message: Fit to stand alongside My Beautiful Laundrette and Pride, Oakley’s brilliant film offers hope to anyone who doesn’t feel they fit in and are trapped in a hostile environment.

reviews.name: Alistair Harkness
reviews.message: If the plot gets a little melodramatic in places, excellent performances and Oakley’s sure hand behind the camera see it through.

reviews.name: John Nugent
reviews.message: It isn’t always subtle, but Blue Jean is a gorgeously presented, stirringly performed slice of British queer history...

reviews.name: Diego Semerene
reviews.message: Blue Jean is most remarkable when it simply observes its main character as she exists in her unmanageable world.

reviews.name: Yasmin Omar
reviews.message: There’s stressful cinema, and then there’s Blue Jean.

reviews.name: Vassilis Kroustallis
reviews.message: 'Blue Jean' succeeds in showing that the middle-of-the-road approach in identity issues is never a good guide for happiness -but a fine guide for drama.

reviews.name: Darryl Griffiths
reviews.message: Blue Jean is a stark warning shot to a modern queer Britain in not being complacent and a soul-stirring celebration of their resilience, which is all too often taken for granted.

reviews.name: Maria Lattila
reviews.message: She handles the subject matter with empathy, but Blue Jean is still needlessly serious and lacks focus in the narrative.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: The Eighties cues, from SlimFast diets to Blind Date, are cringingly accurate, and the novice director Georgia Oakley has coaxed a powerful, internalised performance from the equally untested McEwen.

reviews.name: Jennifer Heaton
reviews.message: Rosy McEwen absolutely shines in what should be a star-making turn as a lesbian PE teacher struggling to keep her queerness secret as Section 28 starts to ramp up.

reviews.name: Steph Green
reviews.message: Oakley has crafted a sad and shrewd film about the loneliness of hiding your true self and the inherent evils of compulsory heterosexuality, especially under the guise of “protecting children.”

reviews.name: Emily Maskell
reviews.message: The concealment of sexuality is attentively observed under Oakley’s intimate lens, a thorough exploration and tight script that is remarkable for a debut feature filmmaker.

reviews.name: Guy Lodge
reviews.message: “Blue Jean” is a Thatcher-era period piece that crisply evokes that climate of politically propagated homophobia without preserving it in amber: It effectively puts the past in tacit dialogue with the present.

reviews.name: Jack King
reviews.message: The story, as it plays out, is achingly tragic: it’s at once a relic of a terrible historical moment that still echoes into the present and the very human tale of lives broken by prejudice.

reviews.name: Anna Smith
reviews.message: McEwen leads a very effective cast in this poignant personal-political drama, which also happens to have a cracking retro soundtrack.

title: The Angry Black Girl and Her Monster
description: Vicaria is a brilliant teenager who believes death is a disease that can be cured. After the brutal and sudden murder of her brother, she embarks on a dangerous journey to bring him back to life. Inspired by Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, THE ANGRY BLACK GIRL AND HER MONSTER thematically challenges our ideas of life and death. Bomani J. Story, the film's writer and director, crafts a thrilling tale about a family that, despite the terrors of systemic pressure, will survive and be reborn again.

characteristics.Producer:: Darren Brandl, Jack Davis, Bomani J. Story

reviews.name: Mary Beth McAndrews
reviews.message: Bromani J. Story’s take on ‘Frankenstein’ is devastating but crucial in showing how classic tales can be effectively brought into a modern context.

reviews.name: Walter Chaw
reviews.message: The Angry Black Girl and Her Monster is an adaptation/remake of a conceit recycled hundreds of times that justifies its reason for being. If Story only has this one film in him, it's enough.

reviews.name: Dolores Quintana
reviews.message: Writer-director Bomani J. Story has given an old tale new life in THE ANGRY BLACK GIRL AND HER MONSTER. THE ANGRY BLACK GIRL AND HER MONSTER is a tragedy filled with hope

reviews.name: Kate Sánchez
reviews.message: It not only represents a story, so many of us from gang areas know all too well, of losing those we love to violent cycles without rescue. It also takes a familiar story and expertly reimagines it from this crushing perspective.

reviews.name: J Hurtado
reviews.message: Writer/director Bomani J. Story’s debut outing makes for a strong calling card, utilizing the flexibility of the origin story to fit the present moment without sacrificing atmosphere.

reviews.name: Martin Unsworth
reviews.message: The film is an emotional roller coaster; amongst the horror (which gets incredibly gory – the effects being particularly impressive) there’s real heart at the centre of the tale.

reviews.name: Dan Tabor
reviews.message: Side stepping the camp, The Angry Black Girl and Her Monster is, at its core, a monster of a metaphor with dense subtext. The film uses the setting to touch on the cyclical nature of violence, but it also dips into race, history, the value of life.

reviews.name: Meagan Navarro
reviews.message: While less successful as a straightforward horror movie, Story’s empathetic approach combined with Hayes’s complex and nuanced portrayal makes for a profoundly human story that evokes respect and hope.

reviews.name: Cassondra Feltus
reviews.message: Bomani J. Story’s The Angry Black Girl and Her Monster is as heartbreaking as it is terrifying. The scariness doesn’t come so much from the jump scares as it does the tragic subject matter.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Bomani J. Story reanimates Mary Shelley’s source with a modern urban twist. The result is slightly mixed due to a meandering middle, but the innovation of its adaptation of the original text deserves merit.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: while certainly a sci-fi horror... also something else besides: an exploration of the African-American experience of being marginalised, demonised, patronised, oppressed and zombified by a society in need of radical revivification

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: As heady as things can get, there are never any doubts this is a horror movie. The mix of tropes and real life terror ensures that anyone watching is engaged the entire time. This is a great addition to socially conscious Black horror.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: When dialed in, "Angry Black Girl" is meaty, lingering on one’s mind well after it concludes.

title: Mending the Line
description: A Marine wounded in Afghanistan returns to a VA hospital in Montana where he meets a Vietnam vet who teaches him fly fishing as a means to coming to terms with his physical and emotional trauma.

characteristics.Producer:: Kelly McKendry, Scott MacLeod, Carl Effenson, Joshua Caldwell, Stephen Camelio

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message:
There’s not a lot to this picture...The pacing is a bit slack, as well...
But the patience of the sport and the tranquility of the settings casts a spell, and it all comes together in modestly, honestly moving ways.

reviews.name: Jackie K. Cooper
reviews.message: The basic story is a Marine recovering from his mental and physical wounds caused by war, but it is the community of individuals who make the story soar. Acting, script, music, cinematography, direction - it all comes together.

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: ...Mending the Line is a careful, thoughtful look at the effects of PTSD that also manages to make wider points about how we heal...

title: The Secret Kingdom
description: Hidden beneath two siblings' bedroom floor lies a land of enchantment in need of protection from an ancient enemy. They soon face epic challenges as they embark on a quest to unite five mystical treasures and save the kingdom.

characteristics.Producer:: Matt Drummond, Megan Drummond

title: Persian Lessons
description: Set in occupied France in 1942, Persian Lessons follows Gilles (Nahuel Pérez Biscayart), a Belgian Jew, who narrowly avoids sudden execution by swearing to the guards that he's Persian, not Jewish. While the lie temporarily saves him, Gilles is then assigned the extraordinary task of teaching Farsi, a language he doesn't know, to Koch (Lars Eidinger), the officer in charge of the camp's kitchen who dreams of opening a restaurant in Iran once the war is over. Through an inspired and clever deception, Giles not only manages to survive, but also devises an astonishing strategy to remember the names of his condemned brethren.

characteristics.Producer:: Ilya Stewart, Murad Osmann, Pavel Burian, Ilja Zofin, Vadim Perelman, Timur Bekmambetov, Rauf Atamalibekov
characteristics.Production Co:: Hype Film, Belarusfilm, One Two Films

reviews.name: Hannah Brown
reviews.message: As incredible as the plot of Persian Stories may sound, Biscayart makes it so much more watchable than it would have been with virtually anyone else in the role. He makes Gilles into a completely credible character.

reviews.name: Lisa Nesselson
reviews.message: Nahuel Pérez Biscayart puts his polyglot talents to good use...

reviews.name: Graeme Tuckett
reviews.message: The longer the film played, the more obvious and grating the fiction that underpins Persian Lessons becomes.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: It's a challenge for any Holocaust film to spend so much time with a dedicated Nazi character and humanize them without losing sight of what a loathsome brute they are. While we don't exactly feel sympathy, at least he isn't the cliché he could have been.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: It's got a powerhouse premise and strong performances that ultimately pull through despite his somewhat ham-fisted, self-important style.

reviews.name: Andrew Murray
reviews.message: With Biscayart and Eidinger giving their strongest performances yet, Persian Lessons manages to end on a note that's both gripping and heartfelt, making it one of the first hidden gems of the year.

reviews.name: Hanna Flint
reviews.message: Well made and well acted but Ilja Zofin's script is filled with well-trodden World War II tropes, and the longer this improbable parable goes on, the less convincingly it holds up.

reviews.name: Rich Cline
reviews.message: Director Vadim Perelman creates a skilfully unfussy period style, avoiding genre cliches to focus on characters who are finely brought to life by an excellent cast.

reviews.name: Mark Kermode
reviews.message: It does feel like a packaged story, like a melodrama...it is played very well, with those two performances actually working surprisingly well...

reviews.name: Saskia Baron
reviews.message: Persian Lessons isn't as powerful or original as recent Holocaust films, particularly Son of Saul and The Painted Bird.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: The ending's a tear-jerker, but it's too little too late.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: Persian Lessons is easily the pick: it's a hugely compelling, highly original Holocaust drama, billed as Belarusian though it unfolds mostly in German, and said to have been inspired by true events.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: While some aspects of the story stretch credulity, two brilliant lead performances keep us hooked.

reviews.name: Rubén Romero Santos
reviews.message: The film flirts with the disaster... but Nahuel Pérez as the peculiar Professor Vaughan...bears out. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Cath Clarke
reviews.message: This fable about language and memory is a troublingly easy watch - though it floored me in the devastating final moments, unexpectedly acquiring great depth and seriousness of purpose.

reviews.name: Boyd van Hoeij
reviews.message: Impressive ending and acting, though it has a wobbly handle on its characters.

reviews.name: Carmen Paddock
reviews.message: Persian Lessons is ultimately too saccharine and sentimental to make any meaningful point about Nazi brutality or survival under fascism, and too stuffed with side plots to elevate the central stakes.

reviews.name: Peter Debruge
reviews.message: The movie feels fraudulent, almost farcical at times, presenting an untenable premise and using it to rehash generic stereotypes about Germans, Jews and an event that claimed the lives of so many.

reviews.name: Lee Marshall
reviews.message: While plot credibility is the one major flaw of a concentration camp drama that is also a classic survivor story, most viewers will take the major emotional payback the film delivers as sufficient reward for their indulgence.

title: Scarlet
description: Shortly after World War I, veteran Raphaël (Raphaël Thiery) returns home from the frontlines to find himself a widower, and father to an infant daughter. Raised by her father in rural Normandy, the child Juliette (Juliette Jouan) grows into a lonely young woman who dreams of greater possibilities. She seeks refuge in the nearby woods, where she meets a witch who promises scarlet sails will one day take her away from her village. Reckoning with her future and swept away by a rakish young pilot (Louis Garrel) who literally falls from the sky, Juliette never stops believing in the witch's prophecy. Tracing Juliette's journey throughout the 20 years of great invention between the world wars, Scarlet delicately weaves together music and fantasy, history and folklore, realist drama and ethereal romance, to craft a timeless story of a young woman's emancipation.

characteristics.Producer:: Charles Gillibert, Ilya Stewart, Antonio Miyakawa, Romain Blondeau
characteristics.Writer:: Pietro Marcello, Maurizio Braucci, Geneviève Brisac, Maud Ameline
characteristics.Production Co:: Ciné+, Ministero della Cultura (MiC), Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, The Match Factory, Avventurosa, Cinéaxe 3, Eurimages, Wise Pictures, Hype Studios, Rai cinéma, Canal+, CG Cinéma, Cinémage 16, Région Normandie, arte France Cinéma

reviews.name: Rubén Romero Santos
reviews.message: Beautiful feminist fairy tale. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Elsa Fernández-Santos
reviews.message: ... While it doesn't reach the heights of Martin Eden, Scarlet irradiates comforting vitality. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jordi Batlle Caminal
reviews.message: ... An amphibious film that's absorbing and stimulating told with serene romanticism and wild poetry. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: A feature like they don't make 'em anymore: both vintage and contemporary, fascinating and heartrending. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Vadim Rizov
reviews.message: I’m not unsympathetic; still, it made me wonder what it’d be like to see, for once, a cinephilic film that isn’t in any way about cinephilia.

reviews.name: Carlos Losilla
reviews.message: A film with multiple ups and downs, which sometimes even intentionally dismembers itself, as if fiction were like the logs that the protagonist dismembers or the toys that he makes. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jesse Hassenger
reviews.message: What Scarlet wants to do with its post-war/pre-war era doesn’t emerge with crystal clarity, maybe because it never feels like Juliette is a fully realized counterpoint to Raphaël.

reviews.name: Zach Lewis
reviews.message: Scarlet may not be a fairy tale, but it manages to mix the witching hour with the golden.

reviews.name: Keith Watson
reviews.message: The film drifts so far into weightless fantasy that it practically dissipates before one’s eyes.

reviews.name: Ricardo Gallegos
reviews.message: An endearing father and daughter story that explores of femininity and proletariat artistic struggle. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Steph Green
reviews.message: Marcello has whittled out a tiny gem that evokes a feeling of gentle transcendence – a pint-sized tale of dreams and destiny that leaves you lovedrunk and enraptured by journey’s end.

reviews.name: Manu Yáñez
reviews.message: A romantic song to hope... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: David Katz
reviews.message: Relying less on archival inserts this time, Marcello opts to create a world built from the ground up, incarnating rather than just suggesting a fairy-tale.

reviews.name: Àngel Quintana
reviews.message:
Marcello is clever enough not to fall into kitsch...intelligently turns around the frustration of the father considered an outlaw by the society that surrounds him and the film provokes a certain good taste in the mouth.
[Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Jara Yáñez
reviews.message:
The detailed shots in which we see the hands of both together guide the progress of the plot and with it also the passing of the years, the growth of Juliette and the idea of ​​the generational transfer.
[Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Rafaela Sales Ross
reviews.message: The arresting visual competency of “Scarlet,” which includes the clever use of archival footage previously seen in Marcello’s Venice darling “Martin Eden” and the beautifully composed textures of its cinematography, can’t salvage its muddled pace.

reviews.name: Jay Weissberg
reviews.message: Combines uncharacteristically saccharine visuals with a weak narrative and treacly score.

reviews.name: Ben Croll
reviews.message: A kind of very modern throwback, mixing a certain kind of modern Italian style with the dream of French cinema of old. It’s a bit of a mess, no doubt about that, but a fascinating one.

reviews.name: Anna Smith
reviews.message: A loose adaptation of Scarlet Sails, a novel by Soviet author Alexander Grin, Scarlet is a film of many parts. They may not always fit together perfectly, but each one is admirable and enjoyable in its own way.

reviews.name: Nicholas Bell
reviews.message: Although beautifully shot by Marco Graziaplena, with plenty of arresting frames and textured visuals, paired with a score suggesting whimsical intentions from Gabriel Yared, Scarlet is pretty, but an empty, eventually ungainly bauble.

reviews.name: Sophie Monks Kaufman
reviews.message: The pacing... is sometimes languorous to a fault. Still, the characters and images are illustrated with a fierce and breathtaking beauty.

reviews.name: Lisa Nesselson
reviews.message: [A] leisurely and affecting tale...

reviews.name: Jordan Mintzer
reviews.message: It’s not groundbreaking stuff, but Marcello has a talent for making such material come alive through his inventive direction, whisking us away to a time and place that we experience as if we were actually there.

reviews.name: Peter Debruge
reviews.message: Smaller, sweeter and more sensitive than Marcello’s earlier work.
